column2: Two insurgent members of the board of the Paramount Pictures Corporation filed a cross-complaint yesterday in Federal Court charging the management with "misusing corporate assets." The cross-complaint was also in answer to the company's antitrust suit charging them with "a conflict of interest" and "harassment."
The national tennis championship matches at Forest Hills are over, but the roar of the record crowds and the jingle of the record receipts linger on.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 13 -- Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall took a 60-mile cruise today along the Connecticut River in a canopied river boat. He saw at first hand what some have called "the world's most beautifully landscaped cesspool."
NEW DELHI, Sept. 13 -The fighting between India and Pakistan appeared tonight to be developing into a war of attrition.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 13 -- Provisional President Hector Garcia Godoy wants the Organization of American States to redefine the role of the Inter-American Peace Force here, emphasizing Dominican sovereignty.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 13 -- The names of Amintore Fanfani, Foreign Mister of Italy and Koca Popovic, former Foreign Minister of Yugoslavia, emerged today from the politicking surrounding the contest for the presidency of the General Assembly.

THE Open Team Championship, concluding event of the New York-New Jersey Regionals at Asbury Park, ended Sunday night in a victory for Murray Schnee of Jamaica, Queens, Dr. Kalman Apfel, Victor Shen, Alan Rich and Fred Weinberg, all of New York.

The Jewish Theological Seminary, the only academic institution preparing rabbis to serve the country's more than 800 Conservative synagogues, announced yesterday a $35 million expansion program that would double its present student capacity.
The Amalgamated Bank of New York, which charges the least for automobile and personal loans in the city, will soon have that distinction for special checking accounts.
OSLO, Norway, Tuesday, Sept. 14 -- Norway's Labor party, dominant for the last 30 years, was swept out of office early today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -About 250 Mississippi Negroes marched silently through the Capitol corridors today in support of a move to unseat the five Representatives from their state.
BUON EAYANG, South Vietnam, Sept. 13 -- Y-Jak is one of about 700,000 mountain tribesmen who inhabit the rain forests and mountains of South Vietnam's Central Highlands.

A re-evaluation of the work of Benjamin Franklin, John Adams, John Jay and Henry Laurens in bringing an end to the conflict in the colonies is presented by Richard B. Morris in "The Peacemakers." The author, Gouverneur Morris, Professor of History at Columbia University, has based his book on material on which he did research in England, Spain, the Netherlands, Italy, Austria and elsewhere.

Gen. James M. Gavin, chairman and chief executive officer of Arthur D. Little, Inc., was elected yesterday a director of the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company, Byron I. Elliott, chairman, announced.

Reggie Harding, the 7-foot center of the Detroit Pistons, was suspended indefinitely yesterday by Walter Kennedy, the Commissioner of the National Basketball Association, for conduct detrimental to professional basketball.
Black Nationalists and black Muslims have been hired by Haryou-Act, the antipoverty and antidelinquency project in Harlem.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 13 -- Charles Habib Malik asked the industrial Western nations today to preach the gospel of freedom and accomplishment to the developing nations.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13 (UPI) -- Clay Dalrymple's seventh-inning home run off Bill Niekro tonight gave the Philadelphia Phillies a 4-3 victory over the Milwaukee Braves.

THE aroma of freshly picked apples is one of the joys of the autumn harvest, which is running 6 per cent above average this year and should result in 130.6 million bushels, according to the United States Department of Agriculture.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -Vice President Humphrey cast a tie-breaking vote in the Senate today to give the Administration a victory on a key amendment to its farm bill.

The new Metropolitan Opera National Company will benefit Nov. 3 at its first performance here, which is being sponsored by the Metropolitan Opera Guild. The company will offer Rossini's "Cinderella" at the New York State Theater in Lincoln Center, beginning a three-week run.
LIMA, Peru, Sept. 13 -- The Cabinet resigned today to avert a deepening of the power struggle between President Fernando Belaunde Terry and the Opposition-dominated Congress.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- The Labor Department said today that nonagricultural payroll employment had risen to a record of 61 million in August.

TORONTO, Sept. 13 -- Toronto a city with a reputation for dour Scots and gloomy Sundays, opened a new City Hall today and began a week of outdoor celebrations featuring the Toronto Symphony, a Nation-builders folk festival and a Saturday night dance called Toronto-a-go-go.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -Chief Justice Earl Warren said today that prospects for an international rule of law were improving.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- In the current drive for the actual "equality" of all citizens in the legal and economic structure of the United States, "home rule" for this capital city is a proposition whose claim seems undeniable on any worthy ground.
The city's new school bus service was marred at its start yesterday by scattered breakdowns and delays.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Josephine died today, probably a victim of Hurricane Betsy.
Plans of Gulf Western Industries, Inc., to buy control of the New Jersey Zinc Company, rumored last week, were confirmed yesterday.

BERGDORF GOODMAN has added another designer to its roster of ready-to-wear talent -- Mrs. Marguery Burke Bolhagen of Washington. Her fall clothes were shown yesterday along with those of Bernard Newman and Gigliola Curiel, the store's other designers.
James Meredith became a Columbia law school student yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -This country has quietly passed one of those historic moments so uneventful in the happening that they never make a headline but so profound in their implications that they leave society shaken to its roots.

Potato futures prices were deflated yesterday by the Government's crop report of a larger-than-expected production for all of 1965. The potato report was issued after Friday's close, which meant that yesterday was the first chance for futures traders to react.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -Secretary of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler reported to President Johnson today that the 10 leading financial nations were agreed that the first stage of negotiations on improving the world monetary system should be started this month.

In television vernacular, it was a bad day yesterday at Black Rock and 30 Rock, industry designations for headquarters of two industry giants -- the Columbia Broadcasting System and the National Broadcasting Company.

KINGS POINT, L.I., Sept. 13 -- George Paterno, the new head coach at the United States Merchant Marine Academy, is certainly giving varsity football on this Long Island Sound installation a new look this season.
LONDON, Sept. 13 -- Everyone seemed to want sterling today -- in London, Frankfurt, Paris, Brussels and other centers where money is traded.

The Metropolitan Opera National Company will officially open its first season here at 8 P.M. Wednesday, Nov. 3, with a performance of Rossini's "Cinderella" in the New York State Theater at Lincoln Center.
TRENTON, Sept. 13 -- Chief Justice Joseph Weintraub of the State Supreme Court indicated today that defense lawyers ought to be able to obtain the minutes of grand jury proceedings.
A Standing Room Only sign could well have been posted yesterday at the new Louis D. Brandeis High School on the West Side as 2,400 pupils moved in for the first day of the fall term.
Another Wall Street institution is dipping a tentative toe into advertising waters.

WASHINGTON, Tuesday, Sept. 14 -- An exhausted House adjourned at 12:31 A.M. today after setting a record for roll-call votes and beating back Republican efforts to block action on bringing a civil-rights bill and other measures to the floor.
Strength in investment-grade issues and a variety of special-situation stocks dominated trading in a rising stock market yesterday.

Department store sales rose 7.8 per cent and specialty store sales gained 7.5 per cent in the 12 months to Jan. 31, compared with the same period a year earlier, according to "The Departmental Merchandising and Operating Results for Department and Specialty Stores," an annual study released yesterday by the Controllers' Congress of the National Retail Merchants Association.
Cardinal Spellman's office announced today the outline of a 13-hour schedule for Pope Paul VI when he visits New York City Oct. 4.

ATHENS, Sept. 13 -- The leader of Greece's second-largest party said tonight that it was "almost certain" that the party would not take part in the government that King Constantine is expected to designate later this week.

The Government bond market made a small gain yesterday -a rare event in the decline that is now seven weeks old -- but Wall Street's dealers were paying more attention to new corporate issues to be sold this week.
RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Sept. 13 -- Intensive fighting continued for the third day between Pakistani and Indian armored, air and artillery units near the west Pakistan city of Sialkot.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- President Johnson announced today that the Government would send its first commercial trade mission to Poland and Rumania this week. The seven-man mission will leave Wednesday and will arrive in Bucharest, Rumania, on Saturday.
SOMEONE once asked Robert E. Sherwood why he wrote "The Road to Rome." He thought a moment and gave three reasons: "A house -- and two mortgages."

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 13 -Police Chief William H. Parker said today that he thought the widespread rioting in Los Angeles last month had been exploited and aggravated, after its spontaneous outbreak, by an "organization."
The $60 million issue of Tennessee Gas Transmission Company debentures scheduled to be offered today will carry a 5 1/4 per cent interest coupon and will be priced at 100.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Senator Stennis, Democrat of Mississippi, announced today that he had directed the staff of the Senate Preparedness subcommittee to start an inquiry into United States airlift and sealift capabilities.

A contract has been signed for the sale of a 363-acre portion of Lyndhurst, the former Gould estate in Tarrytown, N.Y., to Tarrytown Hills, Inc., a land development concern and subsidiary of the Mid-Atlantic Corporation of Philadelphia, whose principal stockholder is William J. Levitt Jr.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- President Johnson was told today that all but a handful of the nation's 26,000 school districts had taken steps to comply with the nondiscrimination provisions of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.
OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 13 -- The sailing for the national 5.5-meter championship conducted by the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club began today in wet, cold and nasty weather.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 13 -- Lars P. Jensen, Minister of Trade and Shipping, opened a week-long seminar today on "Labor Problems Following Automation on Board Ships."
Two big railroads have new presidents today.
MOSCOW, Sept. 13 -- Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin was reported today to have asked a Japanese Government delegation for coopertion in the economic development of Siberia.
The Master Virtuosi of New York, conducted by Gene Forreli, will open their Vivaldi series at Carnegie Hall with three concertos and "The Four Seasons" tonight at 8:30.
ROCHESTER, Minn., Sept. 13 (AP) -- The Rev. Dr. Billy Graham was taken back to surgery today because of hemorrhaging, the Rev. Grady Wilson, associate evangelist, said.
Prices moved higher in moderately active trading on the London Stock Exchange yesterday after a strong opening.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach told the Cabinet today of "significant new directions and continuing accomplishments" in the Government's drive on organized crime.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Mrs. Phyllis Edwards was recognized a minister in the Episcopal church today in services conducted by the Right Rev. James A. Pike at Grace Cathedral.

VENICE, Calif., Sept. 13 (UPI) -- Tom Conway, who estimated he had made nearly $1 million during his acting career, was found today living destitute in a $2-a-day hotel. He is the brother of George Sanders, the actor.
Readers of Saturday Review have contributed $10,739.15 thus far to the magazine's campaign to rebuild a South Vietnamese village destroyed by United States marines.
The New York Giants cut their squad to the maximum number of 40 yesterday by dropping Allan Webb, an experienced defensive back, and Dave Powless and Frank McClendon, two rookie linemen.
The Chemical Bank New York Trust Company announced yesterday what it called "an important breakthrough" in stock-transfer operations.
Andrew Marshall, a biochemist, got tried of commuting three hours a day between North Babylon L.I., and Manhattan.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Sept. 13 -- The Special Branch, South Africa's security police force, was censured today by a justice of the Transvaal Supreme Court for its handling of the case of a man detained for 180 days as a possible state's witness.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 13 (UPI) -- Former San Francisco National Bank president Don. C. Silverthorne and his business associate, William S. Bennett, were sued today by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation for $32 million.

BONN, Sept. 13 -- In the first chapter of his long-awaited memoirs, Dr. Konrad Adenauer relates how in November, 1944, he walked out of a Gestapo jail without suspenders or shoe laces and started on the road to political power.
Robert D. Henderson has been elected assistant vice president in charge of block business of Harris, Upham Co., Inc.

In significantly weakening President Johnson's highway beautification bill, a Senate Public Works subcommittee has yielded to the arrogance of the highway builders and the industries allied with them.
AMRITSAR, India, Sept. 12 -- As Indian soldiers die under Pakistani guns only 15 miles away, Iqbal Singh seeks death more slowly here.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 13 -The president of the American Chemical Society has urged making the synthetic creation of life a national goal.

HOUSTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -Willie Mays hit the 500th homer of his career and Juan Marichal won his 22d game tonight as the National League-leading San Francisco Giants posted their 11th straight victory, a 5-1 decision over the Houston Astros.
The Radio Corporation of America has been awarded a contract for $7.7 million by the Army Missile Command for design, fabrication and testing of multisystem test equipment for missile systems.

John V. Lindsay, the Republican-Liberal candidate for Mayor, sought to assure liberals yesterday that he would tolerate no red hunt against Mobilization for Youth such as harassed the Lower East Side antidelinquency project last year.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 -- Tom Rolfe added $83,100 to his bankroll, shaved one-fifth of a second off the track record and made a powerful bid for horse-of-the-year honors today by winning the 55th running of the $128,100 American Derby at Arlington Park, which closed its 103-day season.
BOSTON, Sept. 13 -- A group of white parents today called on the Boston School Committee for equal treatment of their children if Negro youngsters were furnished transportation.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 13 -Argentina devalued the peso today by just over 4 per cent. The move raises the exchange rate to 178 to the dollar from the former official rate of 171 to the dollar. That rate was introduced on April 20 of this year when the peso was devalued by 14.5 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -Sargent Shriver announced today grants of $6.3 million for Atlanta's attack on poverty. He called that city's effort a "shining example" and defended the absence of the poor from its governing board.

William C. (Bill) Winfrey, who has guided Ogden Phipps's Buckpasser to the top of the 2-year-old group this season, submitted his resignation yesterday to the Phipps family for whom he has been training thoroughbreds since June, 1963.

An "annual amortization" method of paying for shipbuilding subsidies to replace the present method of lump-sum payments was advocated yesterday by the Shipbuilders Council of America as a means of expanding the American merchant marine.
PARIS, Sept. 13 -- The Benjamin Franklin Library, a popular center since World War II for thousands of Paris students, will not reopen this fall.
The Legislature's majority leaders called on Governor Rockefeller yesterday to double the number of attendants in state institutions for the mentally retarded.
TRENTON, Sept. 13 -- Gov. Richard J. Hughes ordered a full investigation today into the treatment of sex offenders at Greystone Park, the state's largest mental hospital.
United States steel production, reflecting a decline in orders after the labor settlement, fell 1 per cent last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 13 -The death toll from Hurricane Betsy continued to rise in south Louisiana today.
It won't take "no" for an answer.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 13 -- Dan Jesse, beginning his 34th season as coach at Trinity College, and Don Russell, starting his second at Wesleyan University, face wholly different problems on the gridiron this fall.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 13 -- Three pro-amateur and two all-amateur teams tied for low honors today in the preliminary to the Ballantine team matches at the Wykagyl Country Club.

Daniel W. Blumenthal, president of the National Realty Club, has announced that beginning Oct. 1 the club's headquarters will be the Baroque Room of the Park 100 Restaurant in 100 Park Avenue, at 40th Street, instead of the Roosevelt Hotel, the club's headquarters since 1952.
At 12:52 P.M. yesterday, Su Mac Lad, named as one of the eight starters in Thursday night's $100,000 1 1/2-mile United Nations Trot at Yonkers Raceway, was in the race.

The new two-year contract giving New York City teachers a raise in wages and benefits and improved working conditions will lead to the expenditure of nearly $93 million a year, a spokesman for the Board of Education said yesterday.
The Democratic voter who wants to record his choices in today's primary will have to pull down the lever to the right of the name of each candidate he favors.

An $850,000 negligence suit was filed yesterday in Federal court against the city by the widow of a pyrotechnician who was blown-off a barge during the 1964 fireworks display sponsored by R.H. Macy Co. The fireworks expert drowned.
Mayor Wagner's refusal to order universal water metering was attacked yesterday in the Westchester County Board of Supervisors.

MOSCOW, Sept. 13 -- The Soviet Union kept up its barrage of appeals today for an Indian Pakistani cease-fire and made one of the most direct denunciations thus far of Communist China's role in the conflict.

ROME, Sept. 13 -- More than 2,000 prelates of the Roman Catholic Church will assemble tomorrow in St. Peter's Basilica to hear a keynote speech by Pope Paul VI that is expected to set the tone for the final session of the Ecumenical Council.

The formation of a cooperative venture that would consolidate the operations of six American operators of luxury liner was advocated last night by John M. Will, chairman of the board of American Export Isbrandtsen Lines, Inc.

HAYNEVILLE, Ala., Sept. 13 (UPI) -- A Lowndes County grand jury of 17 white men and one Negro was empaneled today to consider evidence against a prominent Hayneville man charged with killing a white seminarian and seriously wounding another civil rights worker,

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 13 -- The Right Rev. Constantin Buketoff, pastor of the Russian Orthodox Church of the Transfiguration, 228 North 12th Street, Brooklyn, from 1931 to 1964, died yesterday in Princeton Hospital.
The lowly hog came into his own yesterday at the Americana Hotel.
PARIS, Sept. 13 -- The new French Ambassador to the United States is a big, solidly built man with hardly a hair on his head. But one thing Charles Ernest Lucet does have in profusion is friends.

Avnet, Inc., had the best results in its 20-year history with earnings up 42 per cent on a 32 per cent sales gain in the fiscal year ended June 30, the annual report to stockholders disclosed yesterday.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 13 -U Thant, the Secretary General of the United Nations, conferred with the Soviet charge d'affaires here late today after his second day of discussions with Indian leaders in his efforts to halt the fighting between India and Pakistan.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 13 -Two land developers named in an investigation into irregularities in the acquisition of Nassau County lands today filed a multi-million-dollar libel suit against Milton Lipson, Commissioner of Accounts.
There is a wealth of material appearing in print in this country protesting our involvement in Vietnam. I should like to defend our position.
One hundred and fifty engineers, most of them in active company management posts, took part yesterday in a freeflowing discussion of the "international impact on engineering managers."

DANANG, South Vietnam, Sept. 13 -- The tall, handsome gray-haired American knelt before a bashful boy in a Vietnamese refugee camp today and over his shoulder told an interpreter: "Ask him if he knows who I am."

BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 13 (UPI) -- Louisiana's capital today calmly let the Army and Navy worry about 600 tons of deadly chlorine gas sunk by Hurricane Betsy in the Mississippi River and went about the business of cleaning up after the big storm.

Sgt. William J. Dolan, art director of Army in Europe, a magazine published by the United States Army in Heidelberg, Germany, was the winner of the National Cartoonists Society's war cartoonist contest, it was announced yesterday.
PARIS, Sept. 13 -- If the French begin to sing about the housing shortage, the long grip of de Gaulle and crowded school-rooms, it will be because of Peter, Paul and Mary.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 13 (AP) -- The American Chemical Society announced tonight the award of its Priestley Medal to Dr. William O. Baker, vice president for research of Bell Telephone Laboratories.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13--Secretary of State Dean Rusk commended the Soviet Union today for its "helpful" attitude on the Indian-Pakistani fighting but said that Communist China was seeking to make political capital out of it.

IF nature had really been kind to mankind, she would have provided us with an optical system somewhat along the lines of the pronghorn antelope. That amazingly sighted animal has what amounts to a pair of medium-power binoculars embeded in its forehead.
The Newspaper Guild of New York announced yesterday that it would strike at The New York Times at 8 A.M. Thursday if agreement on a new contract had not been reached by then.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Sept. 13 -- A new round began today in the Government's effort to discredit The Rand Daily Mail's allegations of brutality in South African jails.

SEA ISLAND, Ga., Sept. 13 -- The Governors of Alabama, Mississippi and South Carolina said today that the new Federal voting law was having no major impact on politics in their states. Gov. George C. Wallace of Ala bama said his state was registering more than enough new white voters to offset any gains in Negro registrations under the new law.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 13 (AP) -- A 16-year-old boy died today of a bullet wound, which the police said was inflicted while the boy was playing a game of Russian roulette with a stolen revolver.

Concerts by the New York Philharmonic in Lincoln Center will be broadcast live by WOR and other radio stations throughout the country beginning Saturday, Oct. 2, at 8:30 P.M. Leonard Bernstein will conduct the orchestra on the first program.
The New York Mets, a going concern with offices at 680 Fifth Avenue and Shea Stadium in Queens, held their first organizational meeting yesterday and concluded that there was still room at the top.

Juan T. Trippe, the founder and chairman of the board of Pan American World Airways, was named the ninth winner of the National Football Foundation's annual Gold Medal Award yesterday. The 66-year-old executive was a guard on the 1919 Yale football team.

SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 13 -- The National Assembly voted today to reject the resignations of 53 opposition legislators that were tendered Aug. 12 in protest against the treaty of amity between South Korea and Japan.
The British pound continued to gain sharply in foreign exchange markets here yesterday under stimulus of the 10-nation sterling-support arrangement announced last Friday.
A $210,000 literary prize is going begging for want of a suitable manuscript.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP)] -- The Senate Appropriations Committee approved today a $3.193 billion bill to finance the foreign aid program. The total is $92 million below the amount voted by the House and $167 million below the amount President Johnson had requested.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 13 -- The state scrapped plans today for construction of the controversial Hudson River Expressway between the Tappan Zee Bridge here and the Major Deegan Expressway in the north Bronx.

Jo Mielziner, who collaborated with Eero Saarinen Associates, architects, in designing the Vivian Beaumont Theater, yesterday outlined their credo for the new $9.6 million home of the Lincoln Center Repertory Company.

CASABLANCA, Morocco, Sept. 13 -- Twelve Arab League leaders began a week-long conference tonight focused on the "liberation of Palestine" but already marked by discord and a renewed public quarrel between the United Arab Republic and Tunisia, which is not attending the conference.

Eighty-two Democratic contests for public office, ranging from the mayoralty down to State Assembly seats, and seven Republican races, all for the Assembly or City Council, are at stake in today's primary.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -The John Birch Society announced today that it would formally open its new Washington branch office on Friday with a "punch and cookies" reception for newsmen.

Britain's disarmament minister, Lord Chalfont, has thrown one small ray of light into the gloom at the Geneva conference by encouraging the nonaligned countries to continue working for a "threshold treaty" banning large underground nuclear tests.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 13 -- Pacific Air Lines announced today plans to acquire six Boeing jets. Two will be leased, the rest are on order for delivery in early 1968.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -Negro leaders charged today that the public schools in the District of Columbia practiced economic and racial discrimination. They urged that the schools be denied Federal funds.
HOUSTON, Sept. 13 (UPI) -- Owners of the American Football League voted today to expand to 10 teams, but decided to wait until next year to pick the city.
The new television season opened last night, and following is a rating of the evening's premieres:
WARREN SPAHN simply refuses to let the books close on his spectacular pitching career, and the chapter he is writing now may yet turn out to be one of the most remarkable in the whole long volume.

MOSCOW, Sept. 13 (Reuters) -- Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party chief, made an unannounced trip to Poland over the weekend for talks with Polish leaders. The trip caused speculation here that some important new policy decision was being worked out in the Soviet bloc.

The Port Authority said yesterday that it would start condemning land for the twin 110-story Towers of the World Trade Center by the end of this month. At the same time it raised its estimate of the total cost of the 16-acre complex to $525million.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- A House subcommittee's inquiry has revealed major loan shark operations in large cities across the country, Representative Charles L. Weltner, Democrat of Georgia, said today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -A secret underwater detection system to protect the Atlantic Coast against submarine attack has quietly been placed into operation by the Navy.

First reports indicated yesterday that new-car sales were continuing at a high level even as the introduction of the 1966 models neared. These will be in dealers' showrooms within the next few weeks, but, meanwhile the 1965 models are still finding strong public favor.
NEW DELHI, Sept., 12 -- Three Moslem housepainters whitewashing a wall here the other day stopped work and climbed down their ladders to say their evening prayers.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Sept. 13 -- Premier Amir Abbas Hoveida of Iran and Foreign Minister Hasan Isik of Turkey will arrive here tomorrow for urgent talks with Pakistani leaders about the fighting between Pakistan and India. There was a possibility that they might be joined later by Mr. Thant.

Recently in an article on your editorial page [Sept. 6] by William V. Shannon of your editorial board and in an editorial on the same page The Times analyzed the bill filed in Congress for development of Manhattan's East River waterfront from 17th to 30th Street for education and residential purposes, a project involving many difficult problems of piers, arterial relocation, reconstruction of parks and the like.
IT was a blast in more ways than one in Brooklyn Saturday morning as Martin's made the "moon scene" with more than 1,000 teen-agers.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Postmaster General John A. Gronouski authorized postmasters throughout the country today to make public, on request, the names of young people hired by them this summer.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- A former automobile dealer testified today that he had signed blank bid forms as a courtesy to a finance company repossessing automobiles that had been sold to service men.
NEWARK, Sept. 13 (UPI) -A personal receiver for bankrupt salad oil king Anthony (Tino) DeAngelis today sold 310,000 shares of stock once owned by DeAngelis for $248,775.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Vernon Law, backed by the hitting of Willie Stargell and Gene Alley, survived a four-run Cincinnati first inning and gained his ninth straight victory today as the Pittsburgh Pirates defeated the Reds, 8-4.
VANCOUVER, B.C. -- Arthur Erickson came home to the garages he has turned into a home the other evening and found that his reflecting pool had disappeared.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -The career of John Singleton Copley, often called this country's greatest pre-Revolutionary artist, will be reviewed through his paintings in an exhibition opening Sunday at the National Gallery of Art.

The new school year got off to a generally good start in the city yesterday. But in a few sections, parent demonstrations, overcrowded classes, a shortage of teachers and breakdowns in school bus service marred the opening day.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -The Treasury bill rate showed small opposite changes for three-month and six-month bills at today's auction, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
Bobby Fischer of the United States drew with Ludek Pachman of Czechoslovakia yesterday in their 13th-round game of the Capablanca Memorial Chess Tournament.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -United States companies with operations abroad plan a 20 per cent increase to $7.4 billion in their plant and equipment spending in foreign countries this year, the Commerce Department reported today.
The city's Democratic voters, their party facing the most dangerous opposition since the days of Fiorello H. La Guardia, will pick their candidate for Mayor today from among four contenders.

Whitin Machine Works, producer of textile machinery and graphic arts equipment, has agreed not to circulate any more material to stockholders on its proposal to merge with White Consolidated Industries, Inc., until a decision is rendered on a stockholder suit seeking Whitin's list of shareholders.
TUNIS, Sept. 13 -- President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia angrily accused President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic today of trying to dictate to Arab nations.

MADRID, Sept. 13 -- Antonio Tovar, chairman of the Latin department at the University of Madrid, announced today that he had requested an indefinite leave of absence to demonstrate his support of five professors punished last month by the Government for alleged political activity.
Several price changes were announced yesterday in various aspects of industry.

THERE is that passage in Samuel Beckett's "Happy Days," when Madeleine Renaud, playing Winnie, has been ruminating on the days that follow days in her life, no different from the days that have gone before and no different from the days that will come.

ELMSFORD, N.Y., Sept. 14 -- The Garden State Women's Golf Association team of 20 players defeated the Women's Tri-County Golf Association squad today, 20-10, in a best-ball match over the 6,083-yard par 75 Fairview Country Club.

FEW works of intellectual history can surpass Maurice Nadeau's "History of Surrealism" in solemnity, completeness and rigid adherence to authenticated doctrine. One would rather say "in seriousness, broadness and fidelity to the relevant facts," but no.
The British pound managed a modest gain in foreign exchange markets here yesterday despite announcement of a widening of the British trade gap in August.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Gov. John J. McKeithen said today that Hurricane Betsy had caused a billion dollars in damages to Louisiana and ordered all red tape cut to speed relief work.

The unexpected victory of Abraham D. Beame brought joy last night to a small crowd of Beame supporters at the Summit Hotel and stunned dismay to a much larger gathering of followers of City Council President Paul R. Screvane at the Americana.
" The stampede is on." That was the way one advertising agency executive put it yesterday in discussing the rush into color by producers of television shows and commercials.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The Senate passed today one of the most comprehensive farm bills in recent years, setting the pattern for the nation's complex agricultural subsidy system until 1970.
California, making its fifth bond offering of 1965, sold yesterday $105 million of bonds to an underwriting syndicate headed by the Bankers Trust Company.

City Council candidates supported by Controller Abraham D. Beame, winner of the Democratic mayoral primary, edged out candidatees backed by Paul R. Scrivane, winning 8 of the 14 posts at issue in the confontation.
A 39-year-old Bronx woman told the police she was obeying an "inner voice" yesterday when she pushed a neighbor to her death in front of a subway train.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 14 -- Richie Davis, sophomore at Upsala College, is starting the season as the star of the football team. A year ago, as a freshman, Davis averaged 5 yards a carry from the left-halfback spot to lead the Middle Atlantic Conference's college division in ground-gaining.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Norm Cash knocked in three runs with a homer and a double as Detroit combined power and walks to defeat Baltimore. 7-1, in the second game of a double-header tonight.
A labor dispute between shipping companies and the ship purser union, the Staff Officers Association, may pose a new strike threat for East Coast ship lines unless an agreement is reached by tonight.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 14 -- One thousand fashionably dressed women and a few men who arrived in chauffeur-driven limousines paid $10 each today to spend the afternoon inspecting the art collection in a 24-room Tudor mansion and in the gardens of the 24-acre estate of Joseph H. Hirshhorn, the son of poor immigrants who was, he says, "brought up in the gutters of Brooklyn."
BONN, Sept. 14 -- Former Chancellor Konrad Adenauer said today that the British had deposed him as Lord Mayor of Cologne in 1945 because of his friendly relations with the Americans.

The New York Giants acquired another newcomer yesterday for the team's worrisome defensive tackle positions when Mike Bundra joined the team from the Cleveland Browns in exchange for a future draft choice.

SAIGON, Sept. 14 -- An American military spokesman officially announced today that the Army's First Cavalry Division (Airmobile) would be based in the Ankhe valley in the Central Highlands, about 225 miles northeast of Saigon.

LAHORE, Pakistan, Sept 13 -- Two former comrades in the old British Indian Army embraced briefly in a jail courtyard here today in a quick, warm gesture that underlined the poignancy and some of the tragedy of the warfare between India and Pakistan.
There was plenty of poor pitching on both sides last night as the Cincinnati Reds defeated the New York Mets, 13-6, before 11,325 at Shea Stadium.

MOSCOW, Sept. 14 -- Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party chief, disclosed today that the Communist nations of Eastern Europe were planning to strengthen their military alliance under the Warsaw Pact. He gave no details.
A cessation of interscholastic sports in the city school system loomed yesterday as the result of a dispute between the Board of Education and the Public School Coaches Association.

Marian Anderson will suspend her retirement from concert singing to give a program of American Negro spirituals in Saints Chapelle, the renowned Gothic church in Paris, on the night of Sept. 28. It will be a gala occasion sponsored by Premier Georges Pompidou on behalf of the first World Festival of Negro Arts, which will be held in Dakar, Senegal, next April.
Most issues on the American Stock Exchange retreated yesterday for the second day in a row in very heavy trading.

A voter on the Lower East Side challenged yesterday the constitutionality of a provision of the state election law that permits church-owned property to be used as a polling place.
Reform Democrats in the Bronx claimed a major victory over the forces of Charles A. Buckley in yesterday's primary elections for nominations to the State Legislature.

KUCHING, Sarawak, Sept. 13 -- Sarawak's political groups were showing new signs of discontent this week as the recent separation of Singapore from Malaysia continued to aggravate the already sensitive relations between the state and federal Governments.
LA JOLLA, Calif., Sept. 14 (UPI) -- Nine weary aquanauts stepped from a decompression chamber today after more than two weeks 205 feet underwater in Sealab 2.

ATHENS, Sept. 14 -- Dr. Wernher von Braun told the 16th International Astronautical Congress here today that the Apollo program to land a man on the moon before 1970 was more than 50 per cent complete and moving forward with "full momentum."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The nation honored the Gemini 5 astronauts today for blazing a path to the stars that Vice President Humphrey said he hoped would be a pathway to peace.

A record $22.4 million capital-expenditure program for fiscal 1966, ending next May 31, is planned by the Pillsbury Company, Minneapolis, it was announced yesterday by Paul S. Gerot, president, at the company's annual meeting in Chicago.
CASABLANCA, Morocco, Sept. 14 -- Twelve Arab League leaders were reported today to have agreed to end radio attacks on one another to ease the way to unity on the Palestine problem.

Mario A. Procaccino, a protege of Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia, is a short, stocky, energetic man whose vigor is reminiscent of the Little Flower.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The Organization of American States was urged today to maintain its presence in the Dominican Republic and to provide technical and economic support for the Provisional Government or President Garcia-Godoy.

SAIGON, South Vietnam Wednesday, Sept. 15 -- About 1,100 South Vietnamese paratroopers dropped in a tropical rainstorm on a plain about 30 miles north of Saigon yesterday in a major effort to clear the area of guerrillas.

RICHMOND, Sept. 14 -- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower stumped here today for the Virginia Republican party and the biggest slate of candidates it has fielded here in a century of Democratic-controlled state government.

The stock market's upward drive halted yesterday in the heaviest trading since late last June. Leading averages showed modest declines as price drops outnumbered gains by almost two to one.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- President Johnson signed today a little-noticed bill that he said would some day be known as the "sleeper" of the 89th Congress.
PEORIA, Ill., Sept. 14 (UPI) -- Tornadoes struck central Illinois late today, demolishing homes, a Coca Cola plant and a Hiram Walker whiksy barrel factory before pushing into Indiana and Michigan.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- After months of wavering, Senator Thomas H. Kuchel has definitely decided not to seek the Republican nomination for Governor of California in 1966.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 14 (UPI) -- The California Angels topped the five runs in the eight inning tonight to gain a 7-1 victory over the Chicago White Sox.

LONDON, Sept. 14 -- Britain reported today that her trade deficit, based on seasonally adjusted figures, deepened in August to 52 million ($145.6 million), the highest level in four months. It compared with a revised deficit for July of 5 million ($14 million).

Eleven floors with more than 100,000 square feet of space have been leased by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc., at 1350 Avenue of the Americas. The 33-story building rising at the Southeast corner of 55th Street will be known as the M-G-M Building.

The Reserve Mining Company, Silver Bay, Minn., a producer of iron-ore pellets from taconite ore, announced yesterday its second major expansion and improvement program since it began production in 1955. George J. Beldock, Presiding Justice of the Appellate Division, Second Department, was reported yesterday to be under consideration for the Republican nomination for the Court of Appeals.

For sugar traders, yesterday was the busiest day of the year. Trading soared to 1,604 contracts, more than double the 702 that changed hands Monday, and somewhat higher than the 1,575 contracts traded Feb. 10.

The Xerox Corporation announced yesterday details of a new price plan for its 2400 copier that would be lower for volume users than any previous machines. The new rates, effective Oct. 25, will be based on meter readings that are tabulations of usage.

RABBITS and chipmunks are right in there among the minks and broadtails at Tailored Woman this year. The 46-year-old store at Fifth Avenue and 57th Street, long considered a bastion of almost-too-well-bred conservatism, let its fur down at a fall showing yesterday of young and daring styles in so-called fun furs. It's all part of a plan to attract a younger clientele.

HONG KONG, Sept. 14 -- Communist China charged today that U Thant, the United Nations Secretary General, was taking a biased stand in favor of India in the conflict with Pakistan. It was the first time that Peking had made a personal attack on the Burmese diplomat.

YONKERS, Sept. 14 -- Maurice Riaud, a 48-year-old native of Brittany, France, who went nowhere with France's Petit Amoy F. in the $50,000 Transoceanic Trot last Thursday, brought home a big winner tonight at Yonkers Raceway.

DARIEN, Conn., Sept. 14 -- After months of preparation, the "Colonial Break-Through Party" will be presented Friday evening at the Darien Shopping Center. If it rains, the carnival and sports attractions, historical displays and antiques sale will be held in the Darien High School auditorium.

OSLO, Norway, Sept. 14 -- Dr. Halvard Lange, the Norwegian Foreign Minister for 19 years and an instrumental figure in the founding of the North Atlantic defense alliance, is among the major casualties of the election defeat of the Labor party.
NEW DELHI, Sept. 14 -- The apparent lull in the fighting between India and Pakistan continued today, although the Indian Government said tonight that the aircraft of both sides had conducted raids.

Foster, the chief United States negotiator at the 17-nation disarmament conference, said today that the conference had "come a long way" toward a treaty to ban the spread of nuclear weapons. He declared discussions on such a treaty during the current meeting were ending "on a note of hope."

Mayor Wagner is to be congratulated upon his reappointment of Judge Justine Wise Polier to the Family Court. The troubled children of the city and their families thereby retain a valuable friend and wise counselor.

WHEN it comes to Paris fashions, the woman of ample proportions usually looks the other way because she has found that no one copies a couturier's handiwork in size 40.
A 72-year-old man, shot three times at close range, pursued two holdup men through busy 14th Street during the noon hour yesterday before losing them in the crowd.

Controller Abraham D. Beame mapped a campaign yesterday to portray Representative John V. Lindsay as a man trying to buy back political power for the Republicans and operating on the theory that charm could run the city.

Bernard Gittelson, who had pleaded guilty to 10 counts of perjury in the Duncan parking-meter scandal, was sentenced yesterday to serve a year in jail and to pay what was said to be a record $50,000 fine. He was given the alternative of five more years in prison in lieu of the fine.
ALBANY, Sept. 15 -- Republican officials here, analyzing the primary election results, believe the sales tax has been downgraded as an issue in the November legislative election.

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Judge James Rosen of the Hudson County Superior Court set aside today the June 15 election of Louis De Pascale as Mayor of Hoboken.

As Willie Mays piles up more and more impressive statistics, and brings the San Francisco Giants closer to a pennant, public appreciation of baseball's outstanding player is reaching new heights.
The British pound continued its steady climb yesterday on foreign-exchange markets here with a 10-point gain that pushed the closing spot rate to $2.7982.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Mel Stottlemyre, one of the New York Yankees' few bright spots in a bleak year, scored his 18th victory tonight, a 5-3 triumph over the Washington Senators. Stottlemyre allowed five hits.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 15 -- India published today what was called a captured secret Pakistani document purportedly signed by a general, giving details of military infiltration into Kashmiri territory under Indian control.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Those school officials who are now ordering boys to cut their hair short or stay out of class are on the wrong track. So are the worried traditionalists who would like to have every campus beard in the country shaved by fiat.

WHEN Mrs. Fred Curnow of Sussex, England, pointed to Ch. Ru Mar's Tsushima, C.D., as the best Doberman pinscher at the Westchester Kennel Club show last Sunday, there were tears streaming down her cheeks.
WASHINGTON Sept. 15 -- The Senate Judiciary Committee approved today a bill to allow poor defendants awaiting Federal trials to go free even if they could not afford bail.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- The number of union members in the United States climbed last year to the highest level since 1960, but the proportion of union members among nonagricultural workers continued its recent decline.

MANY New York players will journey to the Catskills this weekend to take part in the first Rip Van Winkle Sectional tournament. It begins tonight at Grossinger's with the following schedule: today, 8 P.M. Men's Pairs and Women's Pairs; Friday, 2 P.M. Mixed Pairs; 9 P.M. Master Pairs (over 20 master points) and Amateur Pairs; Saturday, 2 P.M. and 9 P.M. Open Pairs; Sunday, 10 A.M. Team-of-four.

A vacancy on the New York State Court of Appeals will be the only statewide office to be filled at the election Nov. 2. An increase of 1,105,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend, total supplies were 188,208,000 barrels, compared with 187,103,000 a week earlier and 187,131,000 a year ago.

ROME, Sept. 15 -- Pope Paul VI does not intend to extend his New York visit beyond the single day of Oct. 4 or to let it be transformed from a peace visit to the United Nations to a political or ecumenical mission to the United States, according to Vatican sources.

Tulsa, Okla. Sept. 17 . . . . . .Charlie Coe of Oklahoma City finished ahead of a swirling 40 mile an hour wind, rain and thunderstorms today to take the lead in the United States Amateur Golf-Championship. Coe's third round of 72 gave the 41-year-old former champion a 54-hole aggregate of 217 and a one-stroke margin at the Southern Hills Country Club.

As a teen-ager in the Army, he is relentleesly taunted by his fellow soldiers; in what appears to be a gesture of friendship, they offer him a bottle of beer; he accepts it, hopefully -- it is a bottle of urine.

THE poet Christian Morgenstern began amusing his companions with his Gallows Songs in his native Germany some sixty years ago. They have been tickling funnybones ever since. Nor are they less engaging because their humor is sometimes tinged with melancholy.

New York, Sept. 18 -- The Television Networks had the heaviest opening of their Premiere Week last night. Nine shows, perhaps the largest number to open on a single night in recent years, made their debuts.

IN this age when the universities are being inundated by textbooks, there are very few of any genuine distinction in sociological theory. One therefore picks up the first volume of Raymond Aron's history of sociological thought with hopeful anticipation.

Rats prowl the deserted shack in which they find shelter, and their picnic fare of bananas and cookies fast disappears.
ROME, Sept. 17 (AP) -- The Vatican has announced a ban on any further shipment abroad of its great art works, such as Michelangelo's "Pieta," which was sent to the New York World's Fair.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 17 -- The Secretary General of the United Nations, U Thant, proposed today that the Security Council stiffen its demand for a cease-fire between India and Pakistan with an implied threat of future economic sanctions.
ATHENS, Sept. 17 (Reuters) -- Former Deputy Premier Stephanos Stephanopoulos was given a mandate to form a new Greek government tonight in another bid to end Greece's nine-week political crisis.

ORRINGTON, Me., Sept. 17 (UPI) -- Mrs. Lynn Pierce McGinn, mother of two and the wife of a prominent Maine surgeon, was abducted today from the family's riverfront home by a fugitive from a mental asylum. She was held for nearly 24 hours and then was found safe.

HAVING SPENT 40 years on The New York Times, the author of "The Careful Writer" would be unlikely to describe himself as anything less than a newspaperman. Not as an author, though this is his fourth book.

New York, Sept. 18 -- The one thing most clearly demonstrated by the third New York Film Festival, which came to a close this evening, was the strong and increasing appetite of a large number of people in New York for nourishment through the culture of films -- for a chance to see unusual pictures and breathe in the atmosphere of them.

WARSAW, Sept. 17 (Reuters) -- A Polish writer, Jan Nepomucen Miller, was given a suspected sentence of three years today for slandering Poland. Under last year's amnesty, the sentence is reduced to 18 monts.
NEW YORK, N.Y., Sept. 17 -- Negotiations between The New York Times and the Newspaper Guild of New York resumed today amid conflicting reports about the progress being made.
Leopoldville, Congo, Sept. 17. -- Congo Premier Moise Tshombe faces a political crisis following a boycott of his party's Congress today by at least 40 of his erstwhile supporters.

Washington, Sept. 18 -- The Cancer deaths of 350,000 New Yorkers since 1940 will be studied by the Federal Government and the State for a possible link to the increased use of pesticides.

Washington, Sept. 17 -- The Senate opened debate on an immigration reform bill today amid indications that the administration had virtually dropped its opposition to place western hemisphere countries under an annual ceiling of 120,000.

NEW YORK, Sept. 19 -- For collectors of Australian stamps, next Feb. 14 will be the day of the decimal. Lima, Peru, Sept. 19 -- The new Cabinet of Prime Minister Daniel Becerra De La Flor is taking steps aimed at restoring confidence in the political and economic stability of Peru.

New York, Sept. 19 -- In an intensive search for Negro teachers, displaced by Southern school desegregation, New York City's Board of Education has announced the mobilization of 40 community and professional organizations, 75 Southern Negro colleges, nine metropolitan area universities and the New York State Employment Service.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- President Johnson and Pope Paul VI have arranged to meet Oct. 4 in New York, the White House announced yesterday. The meeting will take place "some time" that day, probably at the Waldorf Towers apartment of Arthur J. Goldberg, United States representative at the United Nations, according to Bill D. Moyers, the President's press secretary.

KASSEL, Germany, Sept. 19 (Reuters) -- The Soviet Union completed a European Cup athletics double today when their women won the final here to add to the cup won by the men last week at Stuttgart, Germany.

HONG KONG, Sept. 19 -- Communist China postponed today the deadline in its ultimatum to India by three days. The Indian Government was given until Wednesday mid night 1600 Greenwhich Mean Time) to dismantle military works on the Sikkim border and on the Chinese-claimed Tibetan side.

Santiago, Chile, Sept. 19 -- Every day the residents of this city, Chile's busy capital with its population of two-million, get an opportunity to choose the "truth" as pontificated by one of the city's major dailies.
New York, Sept. 19 -- Television's hectic week of premieres came to a close tonight with two openings.
Bonn, Sept. 19 -- A computer was supposed to be the guest of honor at the biggest election party in Bonn tonight. It wound up as an almost unnoticed wallflower.
CHICAGO, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Marshall Field Jr., the editor and publisher of The Chicago Sun-Times and The Chicago Daily News, died yesterday of an apparent heart attack. He was 49 years old.

LIMA, Peru, Sept. 19 -- Peruvian Air Force planes were reported today to have gone into action against a suspected Communist guerrilla concentration in the rocky mesa Pelada highlands near the Inca ruins of Machu Pichu in the Department of Cuzco.

New York, Sept. 19 -- Although Colonel John Hammond was the first front-office boss of the New York Rangers, he knew nothing about hockey. Pittsburgh, Sept. 19 -- Steel mills are moving into what seems to be an orderly market adjustment.

Toronto, Sept. 19 -- Last winter, while economists still marvelled at a 9 per cent increase in the 1964 output of goods and services, the common forecast was that the Canadian economy would grow at a slower rate this year, say 6 per cent.

PASADENA, Calif., Sept. 19 -- Scientists assembled here to examine recent discoveries regarding the solar system debated last week possible explanations for what is probably the most perplexing of all.

LONDON, Sept. 19 (UPI) -- Queen Elizabeth unveiled today the nation's permanent tribute to Sir Winston Churchill -- a simply engraved memorial stone in Westminster Abbey -- during services marking the 25th anniversary of the Battle of Britain.

MOSCOW, Sept. 19 (Reuters) -- The Soviet Union has invited the leaders of Pakistan and India to meet personally on Soviet soil and negotiate a settlement, Tass, the Soviet press agency, said tonight.

Los Angeles, Sept. 19 -- Governor Edmond G. Brown announced today he would ask the Federal Government for funds to advance the development of an integrated waste-disposal system that would be applicable anywhere in the country.

BONN, Sept. 19 -- Chancellor Ludwig Erhard's Christian Democratic Union and its Bavarian sister party, the Christian Social Union, took a definite lead over Willy Brandt's Social Democrats in early returns tonight.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- A medical bill that some view as far more revolutionary than medicare will move toward its final test in a House floor debate this week.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Sept. 19 -- The Cook Islands in the South Pacific, which this month have been celebrating the attainment of self-government, may become the model for further island groups scattered over the oceans of the globe.

New York, Sept. 19 -- The case for economic planning in a democracy has a new advocate in Britain's Labor Government. Its own comprehensive plan for a 25 per cent expansion by 1970, however, makes clear that it is easier to draw up a blueprint than to carry it out.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Sept. 19 (UPI) -- The American astronauts, Lieut. Col. L. Gordon Cooper Jr. and Lieut. Comdr. Charles Conrad Jr., arrived here today and received a reception that one member of the party called "a disgrace."

PARIS, Sept. 19 -- Interior Minister Roger Frey won a by-election tonight for the seat in the National Assembly left vacant by the death of Raphael Touret, his alternate in the 1962 general election. Mr. Frey belongs to the Gaullist party, the Union for the New Republic.

President Eduardo Frei Montalva scored a big legislative victory when the Chilean Senate gave its approval to his proposed plan for the so-called "Chileanization" of copper. SIALKOT, Pakistan, Sept. 18 -- The small scale of warfare between Pakistan and India was underscored here today.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 19 -- Provisional President, Dr. Hector Garcia-Godoy, confirmed yesterday that he had appointed a controversial military leader as a member of his Government without a public announcement.
SAIGON Sept. 19 -- Infantrymen of the 101st Airborne Division were believed today to have suffered heavy casualties in a battle near Ankhe in the central highlands.

ATHENS, Sept. 19 -- Premier Stefanos Stefanopoulos, whose Government of "National emergency" took office Friday night, warned yesterday there would be no elections until political agitation had ended.

MOSCOW, Sept. 19 (Reuters) -- The United States Embassy called on the Soviet Government today to arrange the early release of an American tourist arrested after he crossed the Norwegian-Soviet border two weeks ago.

NEW YORK, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Zoilo Versalles hit a two-run home run and four Minnesota pitchers scattered nine hits as the Minnesota Twins beat the Wahsington Senators, 4-2, yesterday.

PARIS, Sept. 20 -- Simone Berrlau, the usually astute and reliable theater director, and Robert Laffont, the French publisher of Graham Greene and Jean Le Carre, are presenting the English musical, "The Boy Friend," in an expensive production at the Antoine.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 20 -- India charged today that Communist China had begun firing on Indian border posts in Sikkim and Ladakh.
HONG KONG -- In perusing the voluminous declarations from Peking, an attentive reader gets the impression that Communist China is feuding with most of the world.

London -- The Great Dance Gala which played to a packed audience of thousands in London's vast Royal Albert Hall Sunday night is the biggest, and so far the most successful, event in Britain's Commonwealth Arts Festival. BIRMINGHAM, England, Sept. 20 (AP) - A house that was shut tight for 30 years gave up its secrets today under the hammer blows of demolition workers.

NEW YORK -- Despite the loss of 29 hoteels since World War II by demolition or cenversion to other uses, New York City has more hotel rooms than it had in 1945. This is one of the principal findings of a study of the hotel business here over the last 20 years made by Stephen W. Brener, a real estate man and hotel consultant.

PARIS, Sept. 20 -- At the age of 78, Marc Chagall is genial, passionate, whimsical and as sharp as a razor.

SAIGON, Sept. 20 -- The story of how American paratroopers fought at point-blank range for a full day and night against well-led, well-armed Vietcong guerrillas in an abandoned mountain rice paddy was told today by their commander.

ROME, Sept. 20 -- Pope Paul VI was reported today to have exerted his influence to bring a draft declaration on religious liberty to a preliminary vote in the Ecumenical Council despite conservative efforts to block it.

New York, Sept. 10 -- The madness of ratings in the television business was amusingly illustrated today. Two sets of figures purporting to suggest the popularity of last week's new shows were issued. They could have been prepared by statisticians who were not on speaking terms.

NEW YORK -- As good a way as any to begin the new season here is to visit Knoedler's on East 57th Street, if you have forgotten over the summer, and check up on things with an exhibition sponsored by the Mead Corporation and called "Art Across America."

NEW YORK, Sept. 20 -- The stock market was irregularly higher at the close today after a busy trading session.
LONDON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Larry Simpson -- whose team of nondrinking soccer players was crushed by a team of revelers -- drowned his sorrows in milk today.

NEW YORK, Sept. 22 -- Some of the dreams dreamed by ulcer patients make them produce more than the normal amount of acid in their stomachs during sleep, a study suggests.

New York, Sept. 22 -- David Lowe is almost the last of the vigorous documentarians with a fine zest for speaking out. He displayed his stature once again on Tuesday evening in an incisive television examination of the "Ku Klux Klan," part of the series known as "C.B.S. Reports."

Saigon, Sept. 22 -- The United States has agreed to supply South Vietnam with 100,000 metric tons of rice to meet food shortages caused in the Central Highlands and Central Coastal Region by Communist disruption and sabotage of rail and highway transportation lines.
NEW DELHI, Sept. 22 -- Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri announced in Parliament this afternoon that India had ordered her troops to stop firing at 2200 Greenwich mean time.
LONDON, Sept. 22 (UPI) -- Stanford Smith, general manager of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, urged today the use of the latest technological advances to improve the role of the press.
LONDON, Sept. 22 -- The Labor Government announced today its plans to curb soaring land prices by a new land development tax and the creation of a powerful Land Commission.

London (Times of London Dispatch) -- Karen is a mother's help over here from Denmark. This pretty redhead was zingy clothes, madly expensive perfume and lots of fun. She spends her afternoons touring fashion shops, strolling in the park or stretched out on a luxurious divan pondering which invitations to accept.
LONDON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The India-Pakistan cease-fire announcement spurred buying on the London stock market today and there were gains all around.
WASHINGTON -- The Johnson Administration is taking a very restrained and canny attitude toward the mounting problems of Europe and Asia.

New York, Sept. 22 -- Stockholders of the Chase Manhattan Bank, the Nation's largest State-Chartered and third largest commercial bank, approved today the conversion of the institution to a national bank operating under a Federal charter.

Kingston, Jamaica, Sept. 22 -- Regret was expressed at the absence of India and Pakistan as The Commonwealth Finance Ministers Conference opened here today, but there was a note of optimism from Jamaica's acting Prime Minister and Finance Minister, Donald Sangster, at the news of a cease-fire between the two countries.
ROME, Sept. 22 -- A plea for speedy clarification of the Roman Catholic stand on birth control was voiced by an Italian prelate today in the Ecumenical Council.
NEW YORK, Sept. 22 -- The stock market was sharply higher in heavy trading today.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 22 (UPI) -- Two bombs exploded on the floor of the Rio de Janeiro Stock Exchange at the height of trading today.

London, Sept. 22 -- There was been quiet, steady improvement of the pound in recent weeks in the Foreign Exchange Market. Today it sold at $2.79 15/16, only 1/16 cent below parity, the highest level since early May.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (Reuters) -- President Johnson said today that the acceptance of a cease-fire by India and Pakistan "takes us a long step away from the terrible dangers which have threatened the subcontinent of Asia."
Dearborn, Mich., Sept. 22 -- The Lincoln-Mercury Division of the Ford Motor Company unveiled here today a bigger, somewhat more affluent line of 1966 cars.

NEW YORK, Sept. 22 -- Negotiators seeking to end the week-old strike against The New York Times set aside today one of the major issues -- pensions -- to concentrate on the problems of automation and union jurisdiction.

Rio De Janeiro, Sept. 22 -- Brazilian political opinion bristled today at the resolution on unilateral intervention against Communist bids for power in Latin America adopted by the U.S. House of Representatives.

LONDON, Thursday, Sept. 23 (AP) -- David Ben-Gurion, former Premier of Israel, declared today that "bitterly hostile action against Palestinian Jewry" by the late British Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin had speeded Israel's emergence as a state.

New York, Sept. 21 -- Historians will dutifully note the date marking the clinching of their first pennant by the Minnesota twins. In the record books it will have the proper late September designation. But if these historians were to search a little deeper, they would discover that the key date in the drive for the championship was April 5, one week before the actual start of the season.
Los Angeles, Sept. 22 -- California' s Republican moderates on Thursday night will open an eight-month campaign against right-wing forces described by Senator Thomas Kuchel as "Neo-Fascist."

NEW YORK -- When John Huarte first arrived at the training camp of the New York Jets after his costly delay as a college all-star, he encountered a wanderer who had watched the Giants in an intrasquad game a few days earlier.
ATHENS, Sept. 22 (Reuters) -- Premier Stephanos Stephanopoulos told Parliament tonight that the first duty of his new Government would be to "restore calm, law and order" throughout Greece.
NEW YORK, Sept. 23 -- Mayor Robert F. Wagner re-entered the city's newspaper dispute today, but said he had no proposals to offer "at this stage."

The United States and 12 other participants in the Kennedy round of trade negotiations have listed the concessions they are prepared to make on agricultural products. But in doing so, they have been merely going through the motions, because the internal dispute that has deadlocked the Common Market has prevented the representatives of its member countries from even coming to the bargaining table.
As part of the so-called "uninformed public" I take issue with Sherrill H. Covian's letter entitled "Armed Space" which appeared in the Sept. 9, 1965 edition of your paper.

SAIGON, Sept. 23 -- United States paratroopers of the 173d Airborne Brigade uncovered yesterday a large arms cache hidden by Vietcong guerrillas in a village near Bencat about 35 miles north of Saigon.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 23 -- The United States called on the United Nations today to bar Communist China's entry on the ground that it is an aggressor that seeks to change the world order by force and violence.

United Nations, N.Y., Sept. 23 -- The Special Committee on Colonialism unanimously approved today reports to the United Nations General Assembly demanding immediate independence for British dependencies in Africa in the drive to eradicate colonialism.
LONDON, Sept. 23 -- The Rolls-Royce gets a new, sleeker look this year in the first radical style change for the British luxury car in 10 years.

NEW YORK -- One of the most consistently successful tournament performers in the New York area is Murray Schnee of Jamaica, Queens. Last week he followed a win in the Open Teams at the Asbury Park Regionals by two victories in the Rip Van Winkle sectional tournament at Grossinger's, N.Y.

Rome, Sept. 23 -- Even ten years ago, Pope Paul VI would not have been invited to address the United Nations, and if he had been, he probably would not have accepted. For these reasons, according to John Carmel Cardinal Heenan, Archbishop of Westminster, the Papal visit to New York will be an historically significant occasion.
LONDON, Sept. 23 (Reuters) -- Two top motor racing companies, Cooper of Britain and Maserati of Italy, are to produce jointly a new grand-prix car for the 1966 season.
RYE, N.Y., Sept. 23 (Reuters) -- Othmar H. Ammann, a Swiss-born engineer who built some of America's most famous bridges, died at his home here yesterday. He was 86 years old.

New York, Sept. 23 -- "This is the first week since mid-July," said Allie Sherman, "when we didn't have someone in camp pack his suitcase and depart. At last we're settling down. Although a lot of things went wrong for us in Dallas, I still can see hope for the future even though I can't begin to guess how far away that future is."

SAIGON, Sept. 23 -- A public execution of three accused Communist agents in Danang, 375 miles north of Saigon, was postponed yesterday afternoon because foreign news photographers refused to agree not to take photographs.
NEW YORK, Sept. 23 -- When Pope Paul VI comes here Oct. 4, he will see some of the wealthiest and some of poorest sections of the largest city.

NEW YORK, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds whipped the San Francisco Giants for the second straight time last night and both the third-place Reds and the second-place Los Angeles Dodgers gained a full game on the National-League leaders as a result.
