Organized labor was prominent on the New York political scene today. The New York City Central Labor Council, with a membership of 1 million, voted to support Controller Abraham Beame, the Democratic candidate for mayor. Before announcing its endorsement, the council's executive board met separately with Beame and with Representative John Lindsay, the Republican-Liberal nominee, to learn their views on labor and their other issues.
RAWALPINDI, Sept. 23 -- Pakistan reported today a complete cease-fire in her undeclared war with India.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The Senate passed a $3.14 billion foreign aid money bill today after cutting $50 million from the economic assistance total recommended by its Appropriations Committee.

PARIS, Sept. 23 -- Continental stock markets were relatively quiet today and price changes were mainly fractional. Paris again showed a firm tone as did Brussels and Zurich. Amsterdam, Frankfurt and Milan averages were on the downside.

The India-Pakistan cease-fire agreement is a triumph for the United Nations and world peace. At least for the moment, it averts the dangers of communal rioting on the subcontinent and a generalized conflict in Asia. Furthermore, the world now has seen the kind of joint action for peace by the great powers -- the United States, the United Kingdom, France, Soviet Russia -- for which the founders of the United Nations had always hoped.
On the cease-fire line in West Pakistan, Sept. 23 -- Indian and Pakistani soldiers stared at each other this morning across the 50-foot-wide Ichogil Canal in the quiet of the six-hour-old ceasefire.

SANTO DOMINGO, Sept. 23 -- Ellsworth D. Bunker left here today, his mission as chief peacemaker in the Dominican civil war all but concluded. He remarked that the new provisional Government appeared to be "getting along" reasonably well on the road to reconciliation.

Perhaps those members of the academic community to which Associate Professor Guenter Lewy refers in his letter [Sept. 14] should just give up their "ungrateful task of defending the Administration's basic policy in Vietnam," and ultize their time in presenting a solution to the situation.

SCARBOROUGH, England, Sept. 23 -- A former British representative at the United Nations today urged Britain to pull her forces out of the Persian Gulf and drastically cut her military commitments east of Suez.

ATLANTA -- Confronted with hostility and hatred at virtually every turn, Warren C. Fortson and his family have left Americus, Ga., where the 39-year-old white lawyer had tried to bring about racial harmony.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The International Brotherhood of Teamsters is planning testimonial dinners to raise a legal defense fund for its beleaguered president, James R. Hoffa.

Nairobi, Sept. 23 -- American Astronauts Gordon Cooper and Charles Conrad, now in Africa as part of their tour after their 8-day space flight in Gemini V, lost themselves today while flying a tiny Aztec aircraft over Kenya's Great Rift Valley.

Tokyo, Sept. 23 -- The Japanese motor industry has reacted in a lukewarm manner to advice from the Government that it should be reorganized to meet the challenge posed by the liberalization of imports of foreign cars scheduled for next month.

NEW YORK, Sept. 23 -- It was a close call Little by little, it has become clear that the longest peacetime expansion in the nation's history was in danger of giving out until the escalation of the war in Vietnam gave it a new lease on life.
MADRID, Sept. 23 -- An orange war between Spain and Italy was in prospect today, threatening to squeeze Western European consumers.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (UPI) -- The House approved today and sent to the White House a bill allowing all United
New York, Sept. 23 -- These are exciting, busy, profitable days on Wall Street.
For the first time in 40 years, both houses of Congress have now approved a major revision of the basic immigration law.
VATICAN CITY, Sept. 23 (Reuters) -- The Vatican Ecumenical Council's massive draft decree on the Church in the Modern World passed its first test today.

PARIS, Sept. 23 -- Terence Young, the director of the James Bond films, was an acquaintance of Sir Winston Churchill during the great man's last years. Sir Winston had an ardent interest in the cinema and wrote a screenplay about Sir Francis Drake for Alexander Korda.
You are filling an urgent need by publishing the brilliant articles of Joseph Lelyveld describing the various aspects of the unspeakable racial tyranny in South Africa.
BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Sept. 23 (AP) -- Michael C. Boyer, son of the actor, Charles Boyer, shot and killed himself early today in his home here, the police reported. He was 21 years old.

Amritsar, India, Sept. 23 -- The cease-fire this morning left Pakistan in control of 18 square miles of Indian territory on the Punjab front and India in control of about ten times that much Pakistani territory on the same front, Lieutenant General J.S. Dhillon, Corps Commander here, indicated tonight.
HONG KONG, Sept. 23 -- Communist China greeted the opening of the 20th session of United Nations General Assembly today by threatening to create a rival "revolutionary" organization.
LOS ANGELES, Calif., Sept. 23 (UPI) -- The police said Michael Boyer "had a record of doing funny things with guns." They were unable to say immediately whether the shooting was accidental.

NEW YORK, Sept. 23 -- Secretary of Commerce John T. Connor called upon American business today to increase exports substantially to avoid damage to the nation's improving international payments position.

WASHINGTON -- If Congress next week restores "home rule" to the citizens of the District of Columbia, with essential protection of the paramount: principle on which the Federal enclave was created in Article I, of the Constitution, the House Republican Policy Committee will deserve a share of the credit.
BERLIN, Sept. 23 (Reuters) -- The one-way traffic of West Berliners to East Berlin on family business may be halted next weekends even for marriages and funerals.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- Congressional leaders have abandoned hopes for adjournment before mid-October.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 23 -- Discovery of a plot to kill Premier Moise Tshombe was announced today by the Premier's press spokesman Pascal Hamici. But Minister of Interior Victor Nendaka and senior police and security officials denied there was any plot against the Premier.

MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 23 (UPI) -- Twenty-one Cuban refugees who escaped from their Communist-controlled homeland by boat were processed by immigration authorities today on the heels of 65 others who fled in two boats.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Fred Stolle, Frank Froehling 3d and Rafael Osuna were upset victims yesterday in the third round of the Pacific Southwest tennis championships.

NEW YORK, Sept. 23 -- The high-speed ticker tape lagged as much as 12 minutes behind the trading today as the stock market attracted corrective profit-taking and other selling in volume and moved lower.
HONG KONG, Sept. 23 -- Peking said today that India had retreated before the Chinese ultimatum to demolish or vacate military installations on the Sikkim-Tibet border.

Richard Nixon has in recent weeks issued several statements on the war in South Vietnam. Mr. Nixon has urged that the Vietnamese crisis should not be turned over to the U.N. and that no concessions should be made to our adversaries through negotiations!

I agree with Dr. Martin Luther King that Communist should be admitted to the United Nations if we are ever going to achieve peace in the world. According to Richard Nixon, it is heresy to talk peace. He seems to prefer the rule of thejungle of kill and be killed.
PARIS, Sept. 23 -- The French Communist party announced today its support of Francois Mitterrand in the Presidential election of Dec. 5.

BUDAPEST, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Hungary announced today she would remove the mine-fields from her Western frontier with Austria. The announcement did not say, however, what would be done about the rows of barbed wire and the watchtowers along the border.

In taking himself out of next year's governorship race in California, Senator Thomas H. Kuchel drew sharply the central issue now confronting the Republican party. That issue is whether the party is going to represent a fairly broad spectrum of opinion or is to be an organization committed to the reactionary radicalism of its extreme right wing.

THE HAGUE, Sept. 23 (Reuters) -- A group of 16 Dutchmen, including university professors and churchmen, urged Parliament today to reject a bill for approval of the wedding of Crown Princess Beatrix and her West German fiance, Claus Von Amsberg.

JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 23 -- The United States State Department, in a statement published in Pretoria today, announced that four senior American diplomats would be kept at their posts "despite differences in policies and outlook between the United States Government and the South African Government."

NEW DELHI, Sept. 23 -- India charged tonight that Pakistani troops in Kashmir had violated the cease-fire less than nine hours after it went into effect. A Government spokesman said Pakistani forces in the Jhangar area of the Kashmir cease-fire line had crossed the line this morning and started digging trenches. Neither side opened fire, he said.

TOKYO, Sept. 23 -- Britain, the United States and 10 other countries asked the International Atomic Energy Agency today to stick to its own proper functions and to leave to the other appropriate organizations a Communist appeal for a complete prohibition of nuclear weapons.
MOSCOW, Sept. 23 -- Pravda, the Communist Party newspaper, expressed concern today over Chinese Communist troop concentration on the Indian border.

PARIS, Sept. 23 -- An extensive program to make France's financial system work better -- to develop savings and channel them into productive investment -- was announced today by Finance Minister Valery Giscard d'Estaing.

SAN QUENTIN, Calif., Sept: 23 (UPI) -- A huge oil tanker and a Norwegian freighter collided in San Francisco bay yesterday. The collision touched off fires in both ships and injured two crew members, including a woman radio operator.

Colombo, Sept. 22 -- The Colombo Powers' Conference held in Colombo in December 1962 to effect a negotiated settlement between India and Communist China of their dispute over Himalayan border territories was a "complete failure." So said Cambodia's Prince Norodom Sihanouk, who passed through Colombo today en route to Red China, the Soviet Union, North Korea and Eastern Europe.

New York, Sept. 23 -- When a professional football player is traded, his family is traded too. Take the case of Mrs. Earl Morrall, wife of the New York Giants' new quarterback. She now finds herself living in someone else's apartment in Norwalk, Conn., her three children coping with strange schools, her housewifely day spent dealing with unfamiliar people and places.
BERLIN, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The United States Ambassador to West Germany, George C. McGhee, visited a museum in Communist East Berlin yesterday, the official East German press agency, A.D.N. said today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 24 -- The Soviet Union today asked the United Nations to approve a declaration, aimed primarily at the United States, that would ban interference in the internal affairs of other states.

Bogota, Colombia, Sept. 25 -- The first Colombian court-martial of a general ended last night in the acquittal of Brig. Gen. Hernan Medina Mendoza of the Air Force and his former Aide, Lieut. Col Ricardo Nanclares Restrepo.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- President Johnson announced today that general agreement had been reached with Panama on a new treaty the would "effectively recognize" Panamanian sovereignty over the Canal Zone.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Sept. 24 -- Pakistan intends to keep her troops in their present battle positions along the West Pakistan-Indian border until there is progress toward a final settlement of the Kashmir dispute, a Government spokesman said today.

Rawalpindi, Sept. 23 -- The government of Pakistan appeared to be moving with caution today to begin the delicate task of de-fusing the passions built up in this country during 22 days of warfare with India.

BUDAPEST, Sept. 24 -- An official of the Vietcong's political directorate has disclosed that the Communist forces have encountered "certain difficulties" in Vietnam as a result of the "massive" United States military effort.

New York, Sept. 25 -- "I'll grant you that my eyes may have been biased," said Birdie Tebbetts, "but I didn't see my man, Pedro Gonzales, swing his bat at Larry Sherry during their altercation the other day. After Gonzales had been twice decked by Sherry's beanballs, he rushed to the mound with his bat in his hands but he lowered it when he got there. I didn't see him swing the bat."
Moscow, Sept. 25 -- For the second time within a month the Soviet Union launched five instrumental satellites of its Cosmos series into similar orbits by means of a single rocket.

Formal pleas for increased aid will be made once again by the developing nations at the annual meeting of the World Bank which begins Monday in Washington. The grim prospect is that once again these pleas will fall on deaf ears.
NEW YORK, Sept. 24 (UPI) -- Mrs. John F. Kennedy flew from New York today for her first public appearance in Boston since her husband was assassinated.

Sudbury, Ont., Sept. 24 -- The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., already in the midst of a record 100-million-dollar expansion program this year, is planning another $79-million project here to enlarge capacity further.

QUINHON, South Vietnam, Sept. 24 -- A regiment of Vietcong guerrillas engulfed a Vietnamese outpost north of here early yesterday morning, then ambushed relief columns moving to the scene from the north and south.

NEW YORK -- The hardest thing to combat in the relations between competing groups of men is fear, particularly fear of an unknown future, and this is what is at the root of the newspaper strike and lockout in New York City.

Moscow, Sept. 24 -- Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist Party leader, has been officially identified for the first time as head of the Communist Party organization in the Russian Republic, the largest of the Soviet Union's 15 states.

Bonn, Sept. 25 -- The Christian Democratic Victory in the West German election was a personal triumph for Chancellor Ludwig Erhard, who surprised and confused his enemies by proving himself a more effective campaigner than his younger opponent, Mayor Willy Brandt of West Berlin.
NEW YORK, Sept. 24 -- The stock market staged a mild recovery today, with most price changes fractional.

West Berlin, Sept. 25 -- Chances for a compromise settlement of the wall-crossing agreement for West Berliners improved slightly here today following a two-hour meeting between representatives from East and West.

OYSTER BAY, N.Y., Sept. 24 (AP) -- Crown Prince Harald of Norway lost his bid to bring the Scandinavian Gold Cup home when he was beaten in the fourth and deciding race of the international yachting event on Long Island Sound yesterday.
NEW YORK, Sept. 24 -- The 1965 European Championships end tomorrow in Ostend, Belgium, and the experienced French team seems to be a likely winner in a relatively weak field.

The House of Representatives has passed a resolution in favor of unilateral intervention in Latin America that can only harm this nation's diplomatic efforts and provide helpful propaganda for its enemies. It was the worst day's work the House has done in a long time.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) -President Johnson ordered today a sweeping reorganization of Federal civil rights programs.

Karachi, Sept. 25 -- Cracks appeared to be spreading today along the tense cease-fire line established less than three days ago to end the undeclared war between India and Pakistan.
San Francisco, Sept. 24 -- It shapes up now to be Ronald Reagan against the field as California's Republicans gather here this weekend for a series of meetings.

The Ampex Corporation, one of the biggest in the tape-recording industry in the United States, has been fined a total of $1.2 million by a Federal Court jury in an antitrust suit. A jury of six men and six women in San Francisco found Ampex guilty of restraining trade in television tape recorders and ordered the company to pay $200,000 damages to the Mach-Tronics Corporation and $200,000 to the Precision Instruments Corporation.

Rawalpindi, Sept. 25 -- Pakistan's sullen acceptance of the United Nations cease-fire this week left little doubt that the cessation of hostilities along the West Pakistan-Indian border was a most fragile kind of peace.
Geneva, Sept. 24 -- The Soviet Union has joined the newly created International Agency for Research on Cancer, the World Health Organization announced today.
With the Indian Army in the Khem Karan Sector, Sept. 24 -- What was probably the crucial engagement of the battle of the Punjab was fought here two weeks ago, but the story was not told.
Rio De Janeiro -- With Tarzan and Claudia Cardinale in feature roles, an unprecedented flock of foreign producers today are shooting films in Brazil.

Saigon, Sept. 25 -- General William C. Westmoreland, United States Military Commander in Vietnam, announced today that no disciplinary action would be taken against a marine officer who used tear gas during an operation against the Vietcong. The announcement contained no additional details and Gen. Westmoreland refused to answer questions on the subject.

TOKYO, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Twelve United States Navy personnel were killed today in a fire that destroyed a two-story communications building at the Naval Communications post at Kamiseya, about 20 southwest of Tokyo.

ROME, Sept. 24 -- A Yugoslav Cardinal asserted today that stubborn "Christian" support for established political and social orders, "wrongly appealing to God's authority," had helped create modern atheism.

London, Sept. 24 -- A trademark action involving the use of similar Bayer Cross designs on pharmaceuticals produced by competing British and German companies wound up as a "stand off" recently in the British Patent Office Court.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- People interested in popular contemporary phenomena have begun to suspect that Miss America, as selected year after year in the pageant at Atlantic City, is no longer a real creature formed, like the rest of us, but has become only a girl-like product synthesized from fleshlike plastic and marketed with slight annual changes in packaging.

Karachi, Sept. 25 -- In a strong bid for Moscow's support, President Mohammad Ayub Khan of Pakistan has urged the Soviet Union to lend a powerful helping hand in the United Nations efforts to solve the dispute between Pakistan and India over Kashmir.

New York, Sept. 24 -- The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, which has played an important role in French Government financing in the United States, said today that the challenge to national sovereignty rather than farm policy was the cause of the present crisis in the Common Market.
Saigon, Sept. 25 -- A U.S. Air Force F-4C Phantom Jet Fighter Bomber was shot down yesterday during a raid on the Vinh Linh army barracks in North Vietnam, about five miles north of the border.

Moscow, Sept. 24 -- The Soviet Government has barred distribution of the current issue of Amerika, the United States Illustrated Russian-language magazine, on the ground that its cover shows the flag of Nationalist China among the founding members of the United Nations.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -The Administration is hopeful that restoration of the once close relations between Pakistan and the United States may come out of the Indian Pakistan conflict.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24 (UPI) -Jim Bunning broke a club strike-out record that had stood since 1915 and Chris Short registered the most victories by a Philadelphia Phillies' left-hander since 1916 yesterday in a double-header sweep over the Chicago Cubs, 11-5 and 7-4.
NEW YORK, Sept 24 -- It fell to the New York City Opera Company to launch the 1965-66 music season, and on Wednesday night the company led off with what it does best -- contemporary opera.
NEW DELHI, Sept. 24 -Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri ruled out today a re-opening of the Kashmir issue.
MOSCOW -- For the second time within a month the Soviet Union has launched five instrumented satellites of its Cosmos series into similar orbits by means of a single rocket.
TOKYO, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Communist charges that West German nuclear installations were also serving military purposes were rejected as "completely groundless" by Bonn's delegate at the conference.

Rome, Sept. 25 -- Unless there is some last-minute Papal intervention, the Vatican Council's declaration on religious liberty appears to be assured of passage. And no Papal intervention is expected, since Pope Paul VI made it clear last week that he favors the document and is eager to proclaim it.
Athens, Sept. 24 -- Greek travel agencies, hotels and souvenir shops were warned today of heavy sanctions if they failed to turn in to Greek banks all foreign currencies cashed by tourists.

MOSCOW, Sept. 24 -- Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader, renewed the call today for a non-aggression pact between the North Atlantic Treaty Organiza tion and its East European counterpart, the Warsaw Treaty Organization.

Washington, Sept. 24 -- A Japanese inventor was granted a patent this week for what he believes to be a practical commercial method of making diamonds. He uses the high instantaneous pressure and temperature of an electric spark.
NEW YORK, Sept. 24 -- The first arrival of the Broadway season is modest, awkward and fundamentally decent.
NEW YORK, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Cleveland and Baltimore, the two division winners in 1964, face serious challenges from St. Louis and Green Bay Sunday in key games of the National Football League.
SAIGON, Sept. 24 -- An American military spokesman reported today stepped-up ground fighting in widely scattered areas north of Saigon.

Srinagar, Kashmir, Sept. 25 --- The Kashmir Action Committee expressed concern today that the Security Council had not tried to face squarely the issue of Kashmir.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The Administration is planning to intensify recruiting for the Army National Guard under the "six months" active duty training program.
It now appears that under stern pressure from President Johnson, Congress is going to produce a road beautification bill this year.

PARIS, Sept. 24 -- The Paris stock market was resistant in trading today, although profit-taking did erase some of yesterday's gains. The Paris and Zurich averages showed slight advances, while indicators in Amsterdam, Brussels, Frankfurt and Milan fell slightly.
Jerusalem, Israel, Sept. 24 -- Israeli election officials are puzzling over a demand by Pro-Nasser Arabs for a place on the ballot for the November general election.

HOLLYWOOD, Sept. 24 (UPI) -- Dorothy Malone, Academy winning actress, battled for her life today after a six-hour lung operation in which her beart stopped but was kept beating by a mechanical heart-lung device.
PARIS, Sept. 24 -- Neapolitan folk comedy is, as they say, "definitely in" these days.

Washington, Sept. 25 -- Pierre-Paul Schweitzer, the Managing Director of the International Monetary Fund, warned today against "undue haste" in the drive, led by the United States, to enlarge the International Monetary System.
DETROIT, Sept. 24 -- A General Motors car will cost more in 1966 -- despite the big auto maker's announcement of a "price reduction."

United Nations, N.Y., Sept. 25 -- India, Pakistan and the United Nations Chief Military Observer in Kashmir all reported today that there were continuing violations of the three-day-old ceasefire in Kashmir as late as this morning.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -The Senate completed action today on a bill authorizing $1.8 billion for continuing the war on poverty and sent it to the White House for the President's signature.

NEW YORK, Sept. 24 -- As negotiations between The New York Times and the New York Newspaper Guild in the guild's nine-day-old strike resumed today, Theodore W. Kheel, Mayor Robert Wagner's chief labor mediator, said he hoped for a breakthrough over the weekend.
Eight soloists and six new works have been added to this season's International Festival of Visiting Orchestras sponsored by Carnegie Hall.
New York, Sept. 25 -- Did the planet Mars once have flowing waters and a far denser atmosphere than it does at present?

Saigon, Sept. 25 -- The six-month rainy season in South Vietnam's Mekong Delta and Central Highlands will be over in about thirty-five days and the much-feared monsoon offensive by the Vietcong guerrillas has failed to materialize.
Geneva, Sept. 25 -- Chile won confirmation today for her winter sports center of Portillo as the site of the 1966 World Alpine Ski Championships.
PARIS, Sept. 24 -- In an extraordinary gesture of cultural solidarity, French authorities and the University of Grenoble have volunteered to rescue the American Library branch in that city.

LONDON, Sept. 24 -- Over the objections of a European minority that wanted a continuing association with Britain, the British Government today started Mauritius, an island in the Indian Ocean, on the road to independence.
Moscow, Sept. 24 -- Failure of the 1965 Soviet grain crop was acknowledged today by Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist Party leader.
MOSPORT, Canada, Sept. 24 (UPI) -- The 1964 world racing car champion, John Surtees, was injured today when the Ferrari he was driving crashed through a guard rail.

New York, Sept. 25 -- A drama, not unlike The Perils of Pauline, is slowly unfolding on Capitol Hill.

Washington, Sept. 24 -- The Administration, responding to Congressional opposition, is preparing to reject renewed overtures by the Netherlands for American assistance in building an atomic submarine.

NEW YORK, Sept. 24 -- Max Adenauer, son of the former chancellor of West Germany, said here today that the new Government of Chancellor Ludwig Erhard "should and will" maintain close relations with France as well as the United States.

PARIS, Sept. 24 -- A Left Bank landmark, the Montparnasse railroad station, will close tomorrow night. The 113-year old building is to be demolished to make way for a newer, bigger station, and a group of modern, 18-story buildings.

PARIS, Sept. 24 -- The first faint sign of a break in the European Common Market's three-month deadlock as appeared in the form of a plan for a special meeting of all six member countries to discuss the fundamental issues that divide them.
NEW YORK, Sept. 24 -- The National Education Association announced today the end of its state of war with the education authorities of Oklahoma.
LONDON, Sept. 24 (UPI) -- Six men robbed a payroll delivery car today in North London a mile from the location of a similar robbery yesterday in which 32,000 ($89,000) was stolen.
NEW YORK, Sept. 24 -- There is evidence that the concerted market action being taken by nine Western nations to bolster the British pound is having its intended effect.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 24 (Reuters) -- Charles Pasarell of Puerto Rico, playing probably the best tennis of his career, defeated top-seeded Roy Emerson of Australia, today, 6-0, 6-4, in a quarter-final match in the Pacific Southwest tennis tournament.

NEW YORK, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Notre Dame, ranked first in the top ten among college football teams after its 48-6 victory over California last week, takes on Purdue in tomorrow's top college football game.
Auckland, New Zealand, Sept. 25 -- As a contribution to the worldwide problem of bird interference at airports, Auckland, New Zealand, is building one of the most sumptuous bird roosts ever devised.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Sky-diving has become a threat to all air commerce and even to the safety of the President the airlines contend.

E. William Henry roundly chided the television industry for the quality of its summer programing. In a zesty polemic delivered in New York, the Chairman of the Federal Communications Commission contended that many viewers have "tired television blood" after looking at reruns, rejects and repeats from May to September. He did not discuss October through April.

The half-truth of the letter published Sept. 15 from Donald Carmichael of Birmingham, Ala. -- civil disobelience leads to chaos -- should be balanced with the other half -- civil obedience leads to murder -- as was demonstrated by the Nazi regime six million times over.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 24 (UPI) -- Shouting Indian demonstrators marched to the Communist Chinese Embassy today and left 800 sheep -painted with bright colors -on the doorstep to mark the confrontation that brought the two nations to the verge of war this week.

Seoul, South Korea, Sept. 25 -- An Army combat division stationed in the Seoul area to suppress student demonstrations was ordered today to return to its original post near the truce line in the north as the situation remained quiet here. Troops were guarding against student protests against the Treaty of Amity between South Korea and Japan.

United Nations, N.Y., Sept. 25 -- The mutual interest of the United States and the Soviet Union in containing Communist China in Asia has developed into a key element in United Nations diplomacy, European and Asian diplomats said today.

LISBON, Sept. 24 -- Portugal has substantially increased economic assistance to her overseas possessions in the past year, despite heavy military expenditures there, the Minister of Finance announced yesterday.

Washington, Sept. 5 -- The Labor Department announced tonight that a new contract has been worked out between the Santa Fe Railroad and trainmen on its lines. A strike by switchmen and brakemen had halted freight service in several of the railroad's lines on September 11 but within hours President Johnson had invoked a provision of the Railway Labor Act to end the walkout.

New Delhi, Sept. 25 -- Indian President Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan said in a radio broadcast today that a plebiscite in Kashmir would be "neither practical nor necessary." He said elections in Kashmir had already decided the question.
VATICAN CITY, Sept. 24 (Reuter) -- Gypsy violins sounded today for the first time in the basilica of Saint Peter, as 3,000 Gypsies from all parts of Europe converged here in a day of penitence.

SALONIKA, Greece, Sept. 24 (Reuters) -- Thousands of United States Marines and Greek troops stormed ashore near here today in exercise Deep Furrow -- to repel an imaginary invader on the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's southeast flank.

TOKYO, Sept. 24 -- The chief of the Soviet atomic energy organization said here today that his country would agree to international inspection of its nuclear power installations only when "the principle of complete disarmament has been accepted."
COPENHAGEN, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Funeral Services were held yesterday for four Danish policemen who were killed by an ex-convict a week ago.

The United Nations has now gone from one of its finest hours to two of its dullest. Following the United Nations triumph in arranging the India-Pakistan truce, the opening statements to the 20th General Assembly by Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko and Ambassador Arthur J. Goldberg both sounded like broken records, largely replaying tired old policies.

OSTEND, Belgium -- Italy triumphed in the European bridge championships that ended here Friday night. The Italian team included only one one member, Giorgio Belladonna, of the famous blue team that has won eight world championships.

The Johnson Administration has shown statesmanship in its agreement with Panama over the future control and operation of the Panama Canal. In announcing the settlement of this festering dispute before all the details have been agreed on, President Johnson is obviously hoping to repair the damage done by hasty and thoughtless American gestures in Latin America.

New York, Sept. 26 -- In his youth Robert Randall Bragan could play the piano better than he could play shortstop. He left no enduring monuments as a shortstop or even as a catcher or to whatever other position his willingness carried him. But he did leave a monument of dubious permanence as a piano player.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Eleven House Republicans called today for development of the Organization of American States into "an institution of true collective security" as a means of encouraging Canadian membership.

HONG KONG, Sept. 26 -- General Li Tsung-jen, former acting President of Nationalist China, who recently went to Communist China after having lived for 16 years in the United States, asserted today that in 1955 a "Republican bigwig" asked him to arrange a coup in Taiwan aimed at the overthrow of Nationalist President Chiang Kai-shek.
Pittsburgh, Sept. 27 -- Steel demand is holding up much better than had been expected, and whatever the amount of reduction in output it will not match previous post-strike periods.

The new farm bill continues the modest progress away from high price supports and toward direct cash subsidies which has been the prevailing direction of farm policy under the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations. It echoes the much-reviled Brannan plan of years ago, which had much more common sense to it than was generally admitted.
Roeszke, Hungary, Sept. 26 -- The Hungarians, who are well known for their cosmetics industry, are doing a face-lifting job on their hitherto grim border crossings.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 26 -- Richard M. Nixon predicted yesterday that the Republican party would regain 40 seats in the House of Representatives next year. He also said the party must regain at least 30 seats to remain a vital force in American politics.

Jerusalem, Sept. 23 -- What opinion polls do for some countries, the Histadrut election did this year for Israel. Last week the labor union election produced some disquieting news for key government parties that will be fighting to retain control in the November general election.

WASHINGTON -- It suited the foreign policy of the Soviet Union to join its pressure in the Security Council of the United Nations with that of the United States for a ceasefire in the military conflict between India and Pakistan.

I was amazed to see you publish a letter [Sept. 16] which blames the religious partition of British India on "the conceited work of Gandhi and Nehru." Many interpretations are possible, but even the most sympathetic imagination could not make this generalization acceptable to educated observers.
LONDON, Sept. 26 -- Britain suspended Aden's Legislative Council and Council of Minister yesterday and took over direct rule of the state as a British Crown Colony.
Roeszke, Hungary, Sept. 26 -- The Hungarians, who are well known for their cosmetics industry, are doing a face-lifting job on their hitherto grim border crossings.

ROME, Sept. 26 -- Roman Catholic prelates elected and appointed to the future representative synod of the church will be responsible directly to the pope and not to the conservative Roman Curia, the central administration.

Athens, Sept. 26 -- Tension has been building up on the Greek-Turkish border in Thrace over the weekend following a dispute over an islet in the River Evros, which marks the frontier between the two countries.

United Nations, New York, Sept. 26 -- Pakistan alleged today that India has misused a flag of truce during repeated violations over the last few days of the cease-fire demanded by the Security Council.

New York, Sept. 26 -- The current television season is made up of two parts: poor shows and good color. The boom in TV in natural hues is exceeding all expectations and the three networks are continuing to hasten their conversion to complete schedules in color.
SAIGON, Sept. 26 -- An American Air Force pilot who parachuted into Vietcong territory when his plane was shot down Thursday described yesterday how a young Vietnamese boy had led him to safety.
SAIGON, Sept. 26 -- American paratroopers trudging through the jungles north of Saigon have uncovered several large caches of Vietcong weapons, military officials announced today.

NEW YORK, Sept. 26 -- When Pope Paul VI comes to New York Oct. 4 to speak before the United Nations, the Vatican will issue four stamps commemorating the occasion. Each will be inscribed "Pope Paul VI, Speaker for Peace."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UPI) -- Representatives of more than 100 countries meet here tomorrow to talk about money.
Washington, Sept. 26 -- The Administration faces its most bruising fight of the year as House debate opens tomorrow on a bill to give home rule to the District of Columbia.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 26 -- "If my friend Johnson really wanted to settle the Kashmir dispute," a Pakistani said today, "He could have easily done that a long time ago."

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Sept. 26 -- Tension on the bristling 1,500 mile cease-fire line between West Pakistan and India appeals to have eased slightly today. Pakistan announced that Indian forces who reportedly had violated the cease-fire yesterday in the Fazilka and Khem Karan sectors of the Punjab frontier had been pushed back.

Harry Schwartz is profoundly right, in his column on "M.O.L.: The New Arms Race in Space" (Sept. 14), when he contrasts the limited public reaction to President Johnson's move with what a military "manned orbital laboratory" actually means.
Washington, Sept. 26 -- A fight that erupted last week over legislation to allocate domestic and foreign supplies of sugar will be resumed in the House Rules Committee on Tuesday.

OTTAWA -- Not long ago, 15 French Canadian parents in Saskatoon, in the prairie province of Saskatchewan, withdrew their 45 children from the city schools because there was no provision for instruction in French.

HOMESTEAD, Fla., Sept. 26 (AP) -- The world's largest known solid-fuel rocket motor scored a success on its first test firing yesterday. The success was a major milestone in a program to determine whether large solid-propellant rockets can be effectively used as boosters for giant space payloads.

NEW YORK, Sept. 25 -- The new television season is being written off as the biggest yawn in the modern annals of broadcasting. Thirty-three new shows made their bow in a hectic period of seven days but even the apparent hits have generated little excitement.
DUBLIN, Texas, Sept. 26 (AP) -- a phantom Santa Claus slipped $100 bills into the mail boxes of at least nine unsuspecting rural residents last week.

Beirut, Sept. 26 -- Prince Khalid Ben Mussaed, 22, a cousin of King Faisal, was killed when a coup he was to have led with the Moslem Brotherhood in Saudi Arabia was foiled earlier this month, the newspaper Al Anwar said today.
NEW DELHI, Sept. 26 -- Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri warned the "big powers" today to stop bringing pressure on India to abandon Kashmir.
NEW YORK, Sept. 26 -- The threat or renewed inflation is dominating interest and discussion in the business and economic realm these days.
MOSCOW, Sept. 26 -- Two high-level Kremlin meetings due this week are widely regarded as marking a major turning point in the complex history of the vast Government-run economy.
Hong Kong, Sept. 26 -- Communist China announced today that it had decided to "sever all relations" with the standing commission of the International Red Cross.
ATHENS -- The Greek Government crisis is over for the time being, but the political crisis remains.

NEW YORK, Sept. 26 -- The Secretary of Commerce, John T. Connor last week admitted getting "a slight chill" from current estimates of American corporate capital spending abroad, but recent news in the international capital markets should keep him from shivering too much.
LONDON -- As he approaches the first anniversary of his Labor Government. Prime Minister Harold Wilson continues to amaze the political wise men with his equivalent of a circus high-wire act.
PARIS, Sept. 26 -- Elections for a third of the seats in the French Senate today brought about only slight changes in the make-up of the chamber.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Protests have prompted some second thoughts in Congress on the appropriateness of a resolution passed last Monday that approved the use of force to thwart Communist takeovers in Latin America.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 26 (AP) -- Ambassador Arthur J. Goldberg bid today for Soviet cooperation in getting a treaty to stop the spread of nuclear weapons. The chief United States representative also asked the Soviet Union and France for voluntary financial contributions to the United Nations.
SANTO DOMINGO, Sept. 26 -- Former President Juan D. Bosch returned by air yesterday from exile in San Juan, Puerto Rico. His homecoming day was marred by an outbreak of violence.

WASHINGTON -- American farm policy and American foreign aid policy have been criticized more than any other Government programs of the postwar period, yet these were undoubtedly the policies that led to the settlement of the Indian-Pakistani war.

Hong Kong, Sept. 26 -- Communist China announced today that it had decided to "sever all relations" with the standing commission of the International Red Cross.

SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 26 (AP) -- South Korea's Central Intelligence Agency has arrested a group of 10 college students and one other civilian on charges of attempting to overthrow the Government, it was reported today.

NEW YORK, Sept. 26 -- The united front of seven newspaper managements against the Newspapers Guild of New York, described by the newspapers as necessary for protection against union "whipsaw tactics," broke yesterday.

NEW YORK -- The Jewish Museum, that curious institution whose exhibitions so seldom have anything to do with Jewish art, opened its 1965-66 season last week with a three-floor exhibition of the American painter (and sometimes sculptor) Larry Rivers.

POMEZIA, Italy Sept. 26 -Pope Paul VI spent his 68th birthday today among 3,000 gypsies from a dozen countries at their rain-soaked international pilgrimage encampment here today. A torrential downpour and high winds this morning had turned the camp into a quagmire, wiping out many hours of work by the gypsies in preparation for the first recorded visit by a Roman pontiff to one of their camps.
SAIGON -- When I first arrived in Vietnam, I thought the war could not be won but it was worth trying. Now I sometimes think it can be won but that it is not worth the price.

NEW YORK, Sept. 26 (AP) -- The Minnesota Twins clinched a tie for the American League pennant, Sandy Koufax broke Bob Feller's major-league season strike-out mark and Willie Mays tied a National-League home-run record.
PARIS, Sept. 27 -- The Deller Consort of London, performers of baroque music, will return to Paris this season with a new member, it has been announced by Doda Conrad, American impresario here.
HAVANA, Sept. 27 (UPI) -- Vassily Smyslov of the Soviet Union won the Capablanca chess tournament today when Austria's Karl Robatsch beat Borislav Ivkov of Yugoslavia in 158 moves.

Washington, Sept. 27 -- Sargent Shriver said today that after 11 months of operation the VISTA Project-the Domestic Peace Corps-is proving to be one of the most successful and economical weapons in the war against poverty.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UPI) -- The measure to grant self-government to the District of Columbia survived two initial tests in the House today.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, Sept. 28 -- Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin has announced sweeping reforms in the planning and administration of the nation's Government-run industry.

Rio de Janeiro, Sept. 27 -- Petrobras, Brazil's state oil company, has signed an engineering contract for $360,000 with the Cameron Jones Company of Denver, Colo. to design an industrial plant to extract oil from bituminous shale.
SAIGON, Sept. 27 -- Premier Nguyen Cao Ky suggested today that there might be a number of changes in his three-month-old Government in the coming weeks.
NEW YORK, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Last year's National Football League champions displayed leaky pass defenses yesterday and lost to two strong contenders in this year's race.
NEW YORK, Sept. 27 -- Stock prices advanced sharply to new high ground today then paused at the close below their best levels.

Manhattan's diamond brigade, led by such elegant stalwarts as Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney, joined with celebrities, diplomats, politicans and other New Yorkers tonight for the 81st opening of the Metropolitan Opera.
LONDON, -- For a party with just 10 of the 630 seats in the House of Commons, the Liberal party is getting remarkable attention these days.

NEW YORK, Sept. 27 -- Negotiating committees of the mailers' union and of six newspaper managements, in separate meetings, worked out language today for a possible agreement on the job security issue This is the main block to a contract settlement between them.
NEW YORK, Sept. 27 -- More than any other woman entertainer her time, Clara Bow perhaps best personified the giddier aspects of an unreal era, the "Roaring Twenties."

MOSCOW, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Philip Stevenson, an author who writes under the name of Lauris Lawrence, is seriously ill in a hospital in Alma Ata, Kazakhstan, in Soviet Southeast Asia, the American Embassy reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UPI) -- The Johnson Administration was reported ready today to announce a $2-billion order this week for the world's largest jet transport.
Salisbury, Sept. 27 -- In a deepening crisis over Rhodesian independence, Britain's High Commissioner in the colony, J.B. Johnston, has been summoned to London for urgent consultations.
LONDON, Sept. 27 (UPI) -- Stocks advanced today in more active trading. Most sections, except oils, shared the gains.
STRASBOURG, France, Sept. 27 (UPI) -- Drugs have taken the lives of more than 1,000 sportsmen, a leading medical expert told an international conference on sport here this weekend.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Corks popped, champagne sprayed over the dressing room, and the celebrating Minnesota Twins chanted: Bring on the Giants."
PARIS, Sept. 27 -- The Baltimore Colts will beat the Minnesota Vikings in Paris Wednesday -- on film.

PARIS, Sept. 27 -- For Cezanne and Sisley and Renoir, the road from Paris to Leningrad and back to the Louvre has been long and arduous. Which is why the Louvre's current exhibition of French painting from the Russian national collections is so particularly touching.
PARIS, Sept. 27 -- Baron Frary von Blomberg, an Irish Yankee who divides his year equally among Asia, Europe and the United States, thinks the pace of life in Paris is too fast.

New York Stock Exchange members are enjoying a record year but President Keith Funston continues to complain that they are not doing well enough. He still wants to see a rise in commission rates charged on purchases and sales of listed stocks, claiming that some firms are unable to make a profit even with the present booming volume of business.

Washington, Sept. 27 -- The National Labor Relations Board today turned thumbs down on the common management tactic of banding together in labor negotiations to prevent unions from playing one company against another ("whipsawing") in contract negotiations. The Board ruled for the first time that any union may require employers to bargain with it individually even though the employers have a long history of bargaining as a group.

ROME, Sept. 27 -- The head of the powerful worldwide Jesuit order charged today that atheism constituted a conspiracy that had infiltrated even the Roman Catholic Church and virtually controlled international organizations, finance and mass communications.

KARACHI, Sept. 27 -- About 100 United States military officers and enlisted men are waiting restlessly in Pakistan for a final decision on a suspended arms aid program that many persons here believe to be doomed.

Surely, it would seem, much remains in the field of civil rights to which Dr. King could devote his energies, and his credentials in this area are subject far less to dispute.
The Army Corps of Engineers, one of the great feudal domains within the Federal Government, is about to receive its regular dues from the Treasury of the United States. The sum: $1,900,000,000.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 27 (Reuters) -- Arthur Miller, the playwright, has rejected an invitation to the White House because of his disagreement with President Johnson's Vietnam policy.

PARIS, Sept. 27 (AP) -- The Seine Prosecutor's Office has ordered a new investigation into the cause of the death of Baroness Sylvaine Thibon de Courtry, found dead three weeks ago with a Japanese sword in her back.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 27 (Reuters) -- The United Nations Security Council demanded tonight that India and Pakistan honor their commitments to the Council to observe a cease-fire.
NEW DELHI, Sept. 27 -- India reported today that 11 of her soldiers had been killed and 65 were missing following a "treacherous" Pakistani attack in the Fazilka area.

There were ghosts last night all over the Metropolitan Opera. There had to be. It was the last opening night the great old house ever will see; and it is safe to say that not one person in the audience, from Vice President Humphrey and Governor Rockefeller down to the youngest standee in the family circle, failed to be moved by the occasion.

WASHINGTON -- The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission has ruled that help-wanted advertisements published under male or female headings must state that the job is open to either sex -- unless the hiring of a man or a woman is "reasonably necessary" to the normal operation of the business.
SEATTLE, Sept. 27 (UPI) -- Gay Brewer Jr. withstood a challenge from Doug Sanders yesterday and won the $45,000 Seattle open golf tournament on the first hole of their sudden-death playoff.
NEW YORK, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Ten Cardinals, five of them Americans, will accompany Pope Paul VI on his peace pilgrimage to New York on Oct. 4.

The Johnson Administration has set out on an economic course that clearly puts the Government in the center of events. Tax cuts and unbalanced budgets are agreed-upon tools to stimulate economic activity -- and wage-price guidelines are employed to keep inflationary tendencies in check.

YOKOHAMA, Japan, Sept. 27 -- The world's largest tanker, a 150,000-deadweight ton vessel that will ply between the Persian Gulf and Japan, was launched here today in a gala ceremony. The keel of the huge Tokyo Maru was laid at the new Wegishi dockyard of Ishikawajima-Harima Heavy Industries Company here on May 6, only 140 days ago.

PARIS, Sept. 27 -- Stock prices on the Continent drifted lower today. Business came to a near standstill in second-hour trading in the Frankfurt market, which closed up to 5 1/2 points weaker. Business was also quiet elsewhere, resulting in price declines in Amsterdam, Milan, Paris, Zurich and Brussels.

From the outset of Project Head Start experts have warned that a one-shot effort to deal with the deprivations of slums children could turn the venture into Project False Start. With his recent announcement that the summer program is to evolve into all-year preschooling for needy 3- and 4-year-old children, the President envisages long-range action to keep the program moving forward.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Sept. 27 -- Five Israelis were injured today, one seriously, during a brief gun battle outside a border kibbutz near the Dead Sea.

BERLIN, Sept. 27 -- The representatives of East and West Germany continued their efforts today to hammer out a new wall-crossing arrangement for West Berliners, but again failed to reach an agreement. However, the negotiations were not broken off.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Approximately 216,000, or 7.5 per cent, of the Negro public schoolchildren in 11 Southern states are attending classes with whites.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (Reuters) -- The finance ministers of 10 major industrial countries reached agreement tonight on a plan to guide further negotiations on international monetary reform.
SAIGON, Sept. 27 -- A United States spokesman denounced today as "acts of wanton murder" the execution yesterday by Vietcong guerrillas of two American prisoners.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 27 -- New violence erupted today amid a deepening political-military crisis.

AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 27 -- President Johnson spoke by telephone yesterday with Comdr. Scott Carpenter. This would hardly have been remarkable were it not for the fact Commander Carpenter was imprisoned inside a decompression chamber on the deck of a ship off the coast of California.
CUZCO, Peru -- Peruvian Government troops are waging a protracted campaign against a small but elusive Communist guerrilla force entrenched in the formidable mountains of the central Andes.

ADEN, Sept. 27 (UPI) -- All secondary schools were ordered closed indefinitely today by authorities seeking to prevent further anti-British demonstrations.

Dar-es-Salaam, Sept. 27 -- The United States, Britain, Communist China, France and West Germany have been approached by the Tanzania-Zambia Rail Link Ministerial Committee and asked if they will help finance the project.
LONDON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- American witnesses against two British bridge champions accused of cheating testified at a closed inquiry that resumed in London today.
Leopoldville, Sept. 27 -- Congolese Government forces launched an intensive drive today against rebels north of Albertville on the shores of Lake Tanganyika.

NEW YORK, Sept. 27 -- Surgeons throughout the world have done more than 700 human kidney transplantations to date, according to the latest tabulation. The total has more than doubled within the last two years.
SAIGON, Sept. 27 -- The Vietnamese Communists are telling their followers to steel themselves for a "protracted war." This is their response to the United States military build-up in South Vietnam.
ROME, Sept. 27 -- A group of 37 American Roman Catholic scholars has given qualified endorsement to contraception and suggested a change in the church's traditional position on birth control.

LOS ANGELES, Sep. 27 (UPI) -- Dennis Ralston, the United States No. 1 ranked tennis player, defeated Arthur Ashe, 6-4, 6-3, yesterday in the men's singles final to win the annual Pacific Southwest championships for the first time.

STRASBOURG, France, Sept. 27 (Reuters) -- The 18-nation European Consultative Assembly opened here today with a warning from a British parliamentarian that a prolongation and deepening of the Common Market crisis could expose Europe to potential dangers from the East.

Philadelphia, Pa., Sept. 27 -- Even if Pope Paul VI's visit to the United Nations next Monday is construed as "mixing religion and politics," there is nothing wrong in it, Methodist Bishop Fred Pierce Corson of Philadelphia declared today.

Lima, Peru, Sept. 26 -- The Peruvian Government was reported today to have asked the United States to give "urgent attention" to an intensification of its aid program here and set aside, at least temporarily, differences created by the cancellation of an American oil company's concession.

HAYNEVILLE, Ala., Sept. 27 (UPI) -- A circuit judge today heard prosecution attorneys say their lives were in danger, but he denied their request for a postponement of two trials connected with civil rights killings.

Karachi, Sept. 27 -- The Pakistani Government has expressed its "sincerest apologies" to foreign correspondents for the many "inconviences" that impeded their coverage of the undeclared war between Pakistan and India.

Washington, Sept. 28 -- An agreement to proceed with reform of the existing monetary system has been reached at this week's annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund. But because each of the ten leading industrial nations taking part in the reform negotiations has its own ideas about the kind of reforms that are needed, there will be no quick and easy overhaul.

PRAGUE, Sept. 28 -- The secret to equal rights for women is equal duties for men around the house, according to one Czechoslovak housewife who holds a fulltime job, a husband and two boisterous children well under control.
LA JOLLA, Calif., Sept. 28 (UPI) -- Comdr. M. Scott Carpenter said today his 30 days beneath the ocean's surface in Sealab 2 convinced him "man can stay under water indefinitely."

MADRID, Sept. 28 (UPI) -- Tony Lema, the elegant golfer from Oakland, Calif., chipped and putted happily around the club de Campo course today while the rest of the world's top professional golfers complained about the length and sogginess of the layout prepared for the 13th Canada Cup tournament that starts Thursday.

HAYNEVILLE, Ala., Sept. 28 (UPI) Mr. Coleman, a popular "citizen deputy", is on trial for first degree manslaughter and assault, which carries a maximum sentence of 11 years on conviction. He is charged with the slaying of the Episcopal seminarian, who was blown apart by a shotgun blast in front of a Hayneville store shortly after he was released from jail following civil rights demonstrations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The United States has offered India 500,000 tons of surplus wheat as a stopgap measure to meet Indian food needs through this fall. Washington, Sept. 27 -- A little-publicized but unusually bitter dispute within the practice of medicine burst into public view here today in the closing days of this session of Congress, with prospects of a major professional and legislative debate next year.

BLACKPOOL, England, Sept. 28 -- Prime Minister Wilson rejected today the idea of collaboration with the Liberal party to keep the Labor Government in office.

Vienna, Sept. 28 -- Vietnam was put today on the agenda of the International Red Cross conference opening here on Saturday for a five-day discussion of current problems facing this worldwide organization. Member societies from 104 nations are expected to take part.

Has President Johnson at this late date applied for membership in the Kennedy clan? The question arises because Mr. Johnson has decided to appoint Francis X. Morrissey to the Federal bench.

SAIGON, Sept. 28 -- Vietcong guerrillas smashed five Government positions in the Mekong Delta yesterday and today, driving off South Vietnamese defenders in resumption of heavy fighting in the populous region to the south and west of Saigon.

New York, Sept. 28 -- The merger plan of the Norfolk Western Railroad and the Chesapeake Ohio Railway moved a step further today, but their effort to have five other Eastern carriers join in a consolidated system received a rebuff from two of the roads.
NEW YORK, Sept. 28 (UPI) -- Two former steel company executives received heavy fines today in connection with a price-fixing conspiracy in steel castings.

BARCELONA, Sept. 28 -- The last notes in the concluding "Agnus Dei" of Mozart's "Requiem" hovered over the ornate hall early today. Then one of Europe's most sophisticated audiences was on its feet shouting its applause with the enthusiasm Spaniards normally reserve for the bullring.

PARIS, Sept. 28 -- In the most sumptuous setting that royal pomp of the Middle Ages and the fashionable few of today's Paris could provide, a woman sang the prayerful songs of America's slaves tonight.

NEW YORK -- A contract of five in a major suit is usually unsatisfactory, because the declaring side will have regrets unless exactly 11 tricks are made. The regrets are somewhat diminished if they have been pushed to the five level by opposing bidding, as happened on today's deal from the semi-final of this year's Spingold Championship.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- The United States drew $60 million today from the International Monetary Fund, the Treasury announced.
Salisbury, Sept. 28 -- Tension over the issue of Rhodesian independence mounted just a bit more tonight with announcement that two senior Cabinet ministers were departing on short notice for London.

BRUSSELS, Sept. 28 -- Discussion about a proposed meeting of the six Foreign Ministers of the European Economic Community without the E.E.C.'s Executive Commission is centering not on the question of whether but on when.

NEW YORK, Sept. 28 (AP) -- The New York Police Commissioner, Vincent L. Broderick, urged New Yorkers today to stay off the streets during the visit of Pope Paul VI next week and to watch the event on television.

TOKYO, Sept. 28 -- The Soviet Union, backing away from a political showdown vote in the final session of the International Atomic Energy Agency's annual conference here today, withdrew its resolution calling for a prohibition of nuclear weapons.
Belgrade, Sept. 28 -- President Tito is confined to bed today with a 100-degree temperature and a case of flu, it was announced today by three of his physicians.
NEW YORK, Sept. 28 -- The stock market lost a tug of war to pull prices onto new high ground today.
Washington, Sept. 28 -- The House Rules Committee cleared for floor action today a controversial bill amending and extending the Sugar Act of 1948.
PARIS Sept. 29 -- Felicien Marceau appears in his plays to be continually preoccupied with cheats and cheating.

New York, Sept. 28 -- Five newly minted pro football players, who represent a commitment of almost one million dollars to their teams, are already paying dividends on the huge investments they represent.
The French Presidential race may yet confirm the old Gaullist prediction voiced by Andre Malraux: "Tomorrow, in France, there will remain only the Communists, ourselves and nothing."

ROME, Sept. 28 (AP) -- A progressive bishop from Mexico told the Ecumenical Council in the Vatican today that the Roman Catholic Church should make more use of psychoanalysis and the discoveries of Freud.

Washington, Sept. 28 -- A Republican accused the Johnson Administration today of trying to do what the British in one war and the Confederate Army in another failed to do: sack the City of Washington.

NEW YORK, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Los Angeles's streaking Dodgers and San Francisco's scrambling Giants posted victories yesterday that kept them tied for the National League lead.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (Reuters) -- The Council of the Organization of American States unanimously voted today to call a hemisphere foreign minister's meeting in Rio de Janeiro on Nov. 17 to consider means of strengthening the inter-American system.

WASHINGTON, -- Sept. 28 (UPI) -- There are no present plans for President Johnson's youngest daughter Luci, who became a Roman Catholic convert, to meet the Pope with her parents in New York, the White House said today.

No issue is more readily adaptable to the exercise of demagoguery in politics than taxation. The state sales tax enacted by the New York Legislature last winter has become a prime issue in the campaign for election of senators and assemblymen. Combined with the increase to 5 per cent in the New York City sales tax it is now entering prominently into the debate over who will occupy City Hall here after Jan. 1.

NEW YORK -- Phyllis Diller, a comedienne with martini-colored hair that looks like a well-used broom, and hazel eyes that change color as fast as you can say "contacts," sums it all up with: "I'm not nuts about looking like this."
PORT MORESBY, Australian New Guinea -- For Australia the West Irian frontier northwest of here has become a major security preoccupation.
MANILA, Sept. 28 (UPI) -- A dormant volcano that had been a tourist attraction exploded today with sudden violence. Thousands of villagers fled, and a death toll in the hundreds was feared.
Detroit, Sept. 28 -- Moderate style changes marked some of the 1966 models introduced here today by the Buick Division of the General Motors Corporation.

Peking, Sept. 28 (Times of London Dispatch) -- Peking staged a spectacular welcome today for Prince Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia, who is taking part in the celebrations of Communist China's 16th National Day.
Back in 1910 Tchaikovsky's "Queen of Spades" arrived at the Metropolitan Opera. It lasted four performances and never came back. Nor has it had many local performances outside the Met since then.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The finance ministers of the 10 major industrial nations agreed today to move ahead, on a limited basis with planning for expansion of the international monetary system.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UPI) -- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower said yesterday that a charge that a "United States Republican bigwig" sought in 1955 to overthrow the Government of President Chiang Kai-shek was "an absolute lie."
New York, Sept. 28 -- A $10,000 sable coat is still adequate protection against the cold, but it doesn't figure very prominently in fashionable circles these days.

LISBON, Sept. 28 -- Elections for Portugal's National Assembly will be held on Nov. 7. Announcing this today,-the Government of Premier Anton/o de Oliveim Salamr decreed that they applied to "all territories of tile Rpublic."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (Reuters) -- James Callaghan, Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, said today his nation had won the battle to eliminate its large balance of payments deficit and to prove to the world that the pound would not be devalued.

When the King [of Greece] steps down into the political arena and plays a political role, he no longer has the special privileges that a constitutional monarch has, but must suffer also the victory or defeat of any political battle.
ATHENS, Sept. 28 (UPI) -- The Greek security police are investigating a system of cheating on examinations through radio broadcasts.

MOSCOW, Sept. 28 (UPI) -- The Soviet Union and East Germany warned today that if West Germany was given access to nuclear weapons they and other Warsaw Pact nations would be compelled "to implement the necessary defense measures."
FRANKFURT, Sept. 28 (AP) -- An airline advertisement featuring Marlene Dietrich in a passenger seat has been permanently grounded here.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 28 -- Communist China's posture during the conflict between India and Pakistan over Kashmir is reported to have caused some countries favoring Peking's admission to the United Nations to take a second look.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- America's Central Intelligence Agency is circulating among a group of Congressmen a report describing a Soviet propaganda campaign aimed at the C.I.A.

NEW YORK, Sept. 28 -- The Mailers Union resumed negotiations today with six newspapers in the 13th day of their shutdown after both management and labor negotiators had held all-day conferences over a proposed solution to the job security issue.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 28 -- Pakistan proposed today that a United Nations force, drawn from African, Asian and Latin-America countries, police Kashmir until the state's political future is settled.

WASHINGTON -- The Administration and Congress are absorbed at this point in pressing and resisting a drive for two measures which do not merit the time and energy spent on them. Meanwhile small interest is being displayed by the executive or Congress in the acutely vital matter of safeguarding the solvency of the Federal Government.
NEW YORK, Sept. 28 (AP) -Texas is the new No. 1 team in the weekly college football poll but it was a close fight with Purdue and Nebraska.
LONDON, Sept. 28 (UPI) Industrials continued to work irregulary higher on the stock market today. Modest buying produced small gains, while sellers held off.

MOSCOW, Sept. 28 -- A new industrial "bill of rights" announced here today was expected to transform the Soviet factory manager from a virtual ward of the state to a more responsible, thinking executive of the Western type.

New York, Sept. 28 -- Wall Street speculation over the price the United States Steel Corporation would put on 3,602,811 shares of 7 per cent cumulative preferred stock it is proposing to exchange for debt ended today when the company announced a price of $175 a share.

NEW YORK -- Few ripples of excitement were stirred throughout the country when a comparative stranger from Florida, Bob Murphy, recently won the United States Amateur golf championship. But the entire nation was swept up in the high drama of this same title show 35 years ago this month when Bobby Jones was storming what George Trevor described as "the impregnable quadrilateral of golf."

Washington, Sept. 29 -- The conflict between France and the United States over international monetary reform came into the open again today in separate statements by French Finance Minister Valery Giscard D'Estaing and Secretary of the Treasurey Henry H. Fowler before the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund.
BRUSSELS, Sept. 29 -- The Banque de la Societe Generale de Belgique, Belgium's largest bank, announced today that it was expanding by merger and would have a new name.

Within 18 months individually powered electric carz, traveling alone or in tandem, will be in service on the Pennsylvania Railroad between Washington and New York. Designed to operate at sustained speeds of 120 miles an hour, they will cut the present four-hour running time between the two cities to three hours.
NEW DELHI, Sept. 29 -- India charged today that Pakistan had violated the cease-fire at least 42 times since it went into effect last Thursday.

Tunis, Sept. 29 -- Stuart Baron, Head of the U.S. aid mission here, and Ismail Khelil, a high official of the Tunisian Foreign Ministry, signed an agreement this morning under which the United States is granting Tunisia a $6,750,000 loan for the maintenance and modernization of her 11,000-mile road network.

MADRID, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Jack Nicklaus arrived in Madrid from the United States today and immediately set the Canada Cup golf championship alight by carding a birdie three on the opening hole in a practice round with his American teammate, Tony Lema.

NEW YORK, Sept. 29 -- Contract talks between The New York Times and the Newspaper Guild of New York went into a night session today as the newspaper's management reported to the union on a re-examination of the guild's pension demands.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI) -- President Johnson signed today a multi-million-dollar cultural development program "to make fresher the winds of art in our land." As a first step, he announced plans to create a national repertory theater.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 29 (Reuters) -- Pakistan said today she would withdraw from disputed territory in Kashmir if "self-executing" machinery was set up for a Kashmir plebiscite.
ROME, Sept. 29 -- The Roman Catholic world hierarchy heard today pleas for re-examination and clarification of the church's positions on marriage, divorce and, implicity on birth control.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (Reuters) -- A warning from the United States and a "revolt" by 93 countries against the 10 major financial powers highlighted debates at the International Monetary Fund and World Bank annual conference here today.

Moscow, Sept. 29 -- The Soviet leadership appears to have postponed the nation-wide introduction of a much debated system of direct buying and selling relationships between the Government's industrial enterprises.

In the weeks that have elapsed since Abraham D. Beame won the Democratic nomination for the mayoralty, Mayor Robert F. Wagner has kept his own counsel. To a reporter's inquiry as to whether he would support the Beame-O'Connor-Procaccino ticket, he replied that it won an impressive victory in the primary, but that there was plenty of time for him to make his decision.

The Times's lead editorial Sept. 14 begins by suggesting that the final session of the Vatican Council will open "amid a general sense of pessimism for the aggiornamento, or bringing up to date, that Pope John XXIII envisaged when he first conceived the Ecumenical Council in 1959."

BEIRUT -- After oil, tourism is the most booming industry in the Middle East and has become one of the main sources of foreign exchange. Several Arab countries have embarked this year on a number of ambitious projects to attract foreign tourists from both East and West.
London, Sept. 29 -- Is color television a misdirection of British resources or a technological innovation that will help advance the nation's trading position?

TAAL ISLAND, the Philippines, Sept. 29 (Reuters) -- The Phillipine President, Diosdado Macapagal, ordered the police today to stop villagers from returning to this devastated volcanic island. Experts warned that the Taal volcano might erupt again at any moment.

UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 29 (Reuters) -- Maurice Couve de Murville, the French Foreign Minister, called today for United Nations recognition of Communist China. He told the General Assembly that the problems of Asia could not be settled without its direct participation.
NEW YORK, Sept. 29 -- The usefulness of a low-fat diet for heart-attack patients has been disputed by the authors of a study made in Great Britain.

Washington, Sept. 29 -- Senator Albert Gore charged in a Senate speech today that the proposed trade agreement with Canada on automobile parts was "a nascent cartel" designed for the exclusive benefit of the "Big Four" auto manufacturers in this country and their Canadian subsidiaries.

PARIS, Sept. 29 -- Stock prices on the Continent were generally mixed today. Brussels and Frankfurt stocks showed a small over-all gain, while minor declines predominated in Zurich and Paris. Amsterdam and Milan were unchanged over-all.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Sept. 30 -- Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader, told the party's Central Committee yesterday that Soviet-American relations "have become greatly complicated and show a clearly evident tendency towards freezing."
About 4000 people are happy today. They are the ones who were fortunate enough to be at last night's performance of "La Boheme" at the Metropolitan Opera.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- India's Minister for External Affairs rejected today as "completely unacceptable" Pakistan's proposal that a United Nations force replace Indian and Pakistani forces in Kashmir until the state's political future was settled.

Mexico City, Sept. 29 -- Hostility has built up quickly in Government and political circles here to the resolution adopted last week by the United States House of Representatives favoring armed intervention to prevent a Communist takeover in Latin America.
Jerusalem (Israeli Sector), Sept. 29 -- Israeli authorities are becoming concerned over an apparent intensification of border incidents launched from Jordanian territory.
West Berlin, Sept. 29 -- Positions hardened today in East-West negotiations on wall-crossing permits for West Berliners, and city officials said there was little hope of an early settlement.

NEW YORK -- There can be several right ways to play a suit combination. One is the right way if all the players can see all the cards. A second is if declarer can peek and the defenders cannot. A third arises if only the defenders are playing double-dummy. And the fourth is the practical situation when all players are in the dark.

Leopoldville, Sept. 29 -- Congolese Premier Moise Tshombe's Conaco Party outvoted the Opposition 85 to 71 today on the election of a speaker for Parliament. Conaco Deputy Kimpiombi was approved as the speaker.
NEW YORK, Sept. 29 -- A late selling wave swiftly erased gains and drove prices lower on the stock market today.

Detroit, Sept. 29 -- Basic prices for most of the Ford Motor Company's 1966 models will be somewhat above the 1965 levels, it was announced today. But the extra cost often does not cover safety items added to the cars as standard equipment.

Bonn., Sept. 29 -- A new trial of former SS guards accused of participation in murder at the Auschwitz Concentration Camp has been scheduled to start on December 14 in Frankfurt, the Frankfurt Public Prosecutor announced today.

ESTORIL, Portugal, Sept. 29 -- A windmill in full sail has for centuries symbolized man's aspiration for release into space. Today, reality has outdistanced dreams and the windmill is in danger of extinction.

SAIGON, Sept. 29 -- The war in Vietnam continued at a moderate pace yesterday and today, with no large battles reported. An American pilot shot down on a mission over North Vietnam became the 100th pilot lost over the Communist nation and the 75th to be killed.

GENEVA, Sept. 29 -- The United States has asked the International Red Cross to make an on-the-spot investigation of North Vietnamese charges that its aircraft and naval vessels deliberately attack hospitals and other nonmilitary installations.
LONDON, Sept. 29 -- The pound broke through the $2.80 barrier today. It has not previously traded above this parity level with the dollar since May, 1964.

Salisbury, Rhodesia Sept. 29 -- A rail network shared as a unitary system by Rhodesia and Zambia may be broken on the racial and political ridge hardening between black Africa and the white-governed countries to the South.
LONDON, Sept. 29 (UPI) -Industrials continued their steady advance in the stock market today.

BONN, Sept. 29 -- The United States Information Service announced "regretfully" today that it would close its German-American Institutes in five West German cities at the end of December as a result of a cut in its appropriation for the year that began July 1.

WASHINGTON -- The character of the war in Vietnam seems to be changing again. The monsoon offensive of the Vietcong has failed, and the intelligence reports indicate that the enemy is beginning to break up disperse his units for a long war of harassment and sabotage.
BONN, Sept. 29 -- Cologne's mammoth fair grounds was filled as far as the eye could see last week with munching and bibbling people.
ATHENS, Sept. 29 -- The Athens security police announced today they had broken up a gang that used radio to cheat in school examinations that ended throughout Greece on Monday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The House handed President Johnson his only major defeat of the year today by shelving his home rule bill for the District of Columbia in favor of a weak substitute.

PARIS, Sept. 29 -- Leaders of the American community here organized today to combat the exclusion of citizens abroad from the new United States program of medical care for the aged.

Vienna, Sept. 29 -- Marshal Rodion Malinovsky, Soviet Defense Minister, arrived in Vienna today by special plane for a one-week visit at the invitation of his Austrian counterpart, Georg Prader. PARIS, Sept. 30 (AP) -- An estimated total of 105 million tourists spent more than $10 billion outside their home countries last year, Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said today.

Cairo, Sept. 30 -- Zakaria Mohieddin, the 47-year-old Premier-Designate, is expected to start his term of office with a clean-up of what are described as "reactionary extremist elements" in the United Arab Republic.

MADRID, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Gary Player, reigning United States Open champion, and his South African teammate, Harold Henning, took it a one-stroke lead today at the end of the first round of the Canada Cup golf team championship.
