A tense stock-market situation in which several issues have been unusually volatile has led the New York Stock Exchange to introduce a tranquilizer of sorts -- a selective ban on stop orders. The advance orders to buy or sell a stock when it reaches a predetermined price sometimes widen the gyrations of particular issues by automatically establishing new price levels. One stop order may tick off another, resulting in a snowballing effect.
NEW YORK, Sept. 30 -- The Mailers Union and the Publishers Association of New York City reached tentative agreement today on the key issue of job security under automation.

Dar-es-Salaam, Tanzania, Sept. 30 -- A major Cabinet reshuffle was announced by President Julius K. Nyerere today, within minutes after the result of the Presidential election became known. NEW YORK, Sept. 30 -- The stock market failed again today to break through a resistance level to new highs.
SAIGON, Sept. 30 -- The United States air war against North Vietnam increased noticeably in intensity in September.

Several things were unveiled last night in Philharmonic Hall. One was Leonard Bernstein, returning to the podium of the New York Philharmonic after a year's sabbatical and conducting the opening concert of the season. The other was the new acoustic setup in the Hall -- wooden free forms attached to the side walls, a new color scheme, and more seats. Philharmonic Hall, which started with 2680 seats, now has 2,840.

LONDON, Sept. 30 -- Prime Minister Ian Smith of Rhodesia will arrive here next week to seek a settlement on independence for the white-ruled British colony in which the Africans are in the vast majority.

NEW YORK -- The tournament player seldom, for technical reasons, has occasion to play Board 32. This was a matter for regret in the recent Knickerbocker Championships, because Board 32 in the Novice Game, pre-dealt by a computer and pre-analyzed, was of particular interest.
CHICAGO, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Leading business economists predicted yesterday that the current economic advance, in the United States would continue briskly through 1966.
NEW DELHI, Sept. 30 -- Students burned copies of Time and Newsweek here today as a pretest against what they called the "anti-Indian attiudes" of these magazines.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UPI) -- The Government awarded a $2 billion contract to the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, to build a fleet of giant jet transport planes, each capable of carrying 600 armed soldiers.

New York, Sept. 30 -- The visit of Pope Paul VI to New York City on Monday will receive probably the most intensive coverage ever accorded a single day's event on television.

LONDON, Sept. 30 (UPI) -- A new gain for the pound on foreign-exchange markets and a better economic outlook spurred another broad-based advance on the stock market today. Some gains for industrials were sharp.

In a letter published in The Times of Sept. 10, Staughton Lynd -- whom you identify as assistant professor of history at Yale -- advocates direct negotiations with the National Liberation Front as a means of seeking to achieve a negotiated settlement in Vietnam.

PARIS, Sept. 30 -- At 3 o'clock this afternoon, Jean Le Golf, a 63-year-old master gardener, reached into a row of vines replanted from the Bordeaux region and cut loose a bunch of grapes. Thus began the 1965 vendange in the only vineyard in Paris.

LAGOS, Nigeria, -- "Did you see God in the heavens?" "How did you attend to your toilet habits while in orbit?" "Why do Americans spend millions to go to the moon when they could invest the same money to help the underdeveloped countries here on earth?"

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara designated today 982 units, chiefly in the Army National Guard, for a 145,000-man select force that will be brought to the "highest possible state of readiness."

NEW YORK, Sept. 30 -- Economic pressure and the destructive power of television have brought down another of baseball's minor-league citadels, the Chattanooga Lookouts. The demise to any franchise is sad, but this one has an extra note of regret.

Tokyo, Sept. 30 -- Is Pacifist Japan going to rearm? The answer appears to lie in the eventual extent of a gradual shift in public opinion that is now taking place in favor of developing the national defenses in an insecure world.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) President Johnson told Congress today there was much evidence that the world was on the threshold of an exciting new era of nuclear power.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 30 (Reuters) -- India has told Pakistan she will attack Pakistani troops in the Chhamb sector of Kashmir within 24 hours if they do not withdraw from areas they occupy, Pakistan's permanent representative said today.

ROME, Sept. 30 -- The revised draft of the controversial Roman Catholic declaration on the Jews, designed to check anti-Semitic interpretation of the New Testament, contains at least three major alterations of the text given preliminary approval by the Ecumenical Council last year.

Three men and two women from New England were arrested yesterday at Aqueduct race track trying to cash daily double tickets that were forged. Police said the group picked up discarded tickets that had only one winner in the daffy double, and tampered with the printed numbers. Then they persuaded elderly women to collect at the cashier's window on the pretense that, as track employes, they could not cash tickets.

New York, Sept. 30 -- A spokesman for Reform Judaism today warned that the revised draft of the Roman Catholic declaration on the Jews may contribute to the very anti-Semitism that the statement wants to eliminate.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- There is growing doubt here that President Johnson will be able to deliver this year on his promise to labor to win repeal of the section of the Taft-Hartley act covering "right-to-work" laws.
MIAMI, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The former husband had the red lawn mower, which he wanted to keep.

The Museum of Modern Art opened an exhibition of paintings by Robert Motherwell yesterday. In either case, the exhibition is an embarrassing display of paintings made absurd by inflation.

Arthur Krock's article about the "overexposure" of your President [Sept. 17] is not only justified but touches a very sensitive spot of the present Administration's general policy.

SINGAPORE, Oct. 9 -- A new element was added to the Indonesian crisis tonight with the report that another general was killed in last week's abortive coup against President Sukarno. Six other generals were killed in the uprising.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Oct. 8 -- It was a grim, gray day in Minnesota yesterday, but only for Californians. The Twins' supporters thought it was bright, glorious and delightful, because their amazing heroes continued to achieve what everyone considered to be impossible.

Washington, Oct. 8 -- Bell Telephone Laboratories, Inc., received a patent this week for the first solid-state, continuous-wave laser. The company regards the discovery as of great potential importance in communications.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- At 7 o'clock this morning all 10 operating rooms in Bethesda Naval Hospital were occupied.
CHICAGO, Oct. 8 (UPI) -- The police evacuated Austin High School on the West Side today when bottle-throwing fights spread through the building.

ISTANBUL, Oct. 8 -- Turkish voters will go to the polls in Sunday's national elections after a campaign that provides them with a clear choice in foreign and domestic policies. For the first time in Turkish history, the campaign has been dominated by issues rather than personalities.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Louisiana's first interracial boxing bout in this century has been approved by the Louisiana athletic commission. Lou Messina, a promoter, will match the former junior welterweight champion, Eddie Perkins, a Negro, against Kenny Lane on Oct. 25 in New Orleans.

MOSCOW, Oct. 9 -- The Soviet leadership announced today that newly adopted reforms in industrial planning and freer factory operation would be introduced in some industries next yeas and in the entire industrial economy by 1968.
United Nations, N.Y., Oct. 8 -- British officials said today that Britain's policy of non-recognition of East Germany remains unchanged.

OSLO, Norway, Oct. 8 -- The American icebreaker Northwind returned yesterday from an expedition into the Soviet Arctic after completing the first major United States oceanographic survey of the polar seas between the Siberian mainland and the archipelago of Severnaya Zemlya.

United Nations, N.Y., Oct. 8 -- 19 African nations have sent women representatives to the current General Assembly session. They have helped to swell participation of women to a record 66, from 46 countries.
Jabulani, Rhodesia, Oct. 8 -- Jabulani is the Matabele word for rejoice but it isn't a particularly happy place.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 9 -- Claude Osteen, a refugee from the American League, pitched the Los Angeles Dodgers back into business in baseball's 62d World Series today by shutting out the Minnesota Twins, 4-0, on five hits.
Jerusalem, Israeli Sector, Oct. 8 -- Premier Levi Eshkol today commended King Hussein of Jordan for his recent pledge to crack down on Arab terrorists operating against Israeli border settlements.

Miami, Oct. 9 -- An entire flotilla of small boats is heading from here toward Cuba to pick up the hundreds of Cubans who, according to Premier Fidel Castro's recent announcement, will be permitted to emigrate to the United States. Premier Castro's offer specified October 10 as the starting date, but the exodus has already begun, with several dozen refugees sailing across the Florida Straits.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- President Johnson seemed well on the road to recovery today. He took a few more steps, shaved himself, and signed a host of minor bills.

Washington, Oct. 8 -- Kingman Brewster, Jr., the president of Yale University, asked college educators today to prevent the "impatient anti-intellectualism" of student activists from "seducing many of our best brains away from true usefulness."
NEW YORK, Oct. 8 -- President Johnson's successful surgery helped the stock market move ahead today.

With the New York city election less than four weeks away, John. V. Lindsay, the Republican-Liberal nominee for Mayor, continues the go-it-alone policy he adopted at the outset of his campaign. He invites no help from nationally prestigious Republicans. He remains, aloof from Governor Rockefeller. He has not hesitated to criticize Republican administration policy at Albany, and the question being asked there is whether he might be going too far in his go-it-alone policy.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 9 -- The situation in Southern Rhodesia has become so explosive that the Secretary General, U Thant, said today he thought it might be brought into the Security Council.
MADRID, Oct. 8 (AP) -- The International Olympic Committee split the German Olympic team today and gave full recognition to the East German National Olympic Committee.

LONDON, Oct. 9 -- Prime Minister Ian D. Smith of Rhodesia, whose talks with the British Government on independence broke down yesterday, said today that his people were prepared to fight for independence.

NEW YORK -- A Brooklyn expert, George Kennedy, has been a prominent figure in New York tournaments for more than years. His many interesting contributions to the theory of bidding have now been set out in a book "The Kennedy System of Bridge" (Arco Publishing Co. Inc., 219 Park Avenue South, New York; $3.95).
NEW YORK, Oct. 8 (UPI) -- The main roadblocks to which Mr. Kheel found acceptable solutions were:
NEW YORK, Oct. 8 -- A tentative agreement between The New York Times and the Newspaper Guild of New York was reached today.

TORONTO, Oct. 9 -- A United States expert on Latin America defended to a teach-in audience today United States intervention in the Dominican Republic. His position was assailed by two Latin-American leaders.
MOSCOW, Oct. 8 -- The Soviet Union acknowledged today that it had failed to soft-land an instrument package on the moon with its latest spacecraft, Luna VII.

BONN, Oct. 8 -- Chancellor Ludwig Erhard's attempt to form a new coalition Cabinet suffered a setback today when a foe of Gerhard Schroder, the present Foreign Minister, attacked policies championed by Dr. Schroder.

COCHABAMBA, Bolivia -- Popular disenchantment and the perennial social and economic misfortunes of this rugged Andean nation have seriously eroded the political backing of Bolivia's ruling military junta.

BERLIN, Oct. 8 (AP) -- The United States Army confirmed today that Soviet soldiers blocked with their weapons or grabbed by the arm four United States train commanders yesterday as they tried to carry out inspections of their trains inside Communist East Germany.
BRUSSELS, Oct. 8 (AP) -- France's five Common Market partners will start discussing next Monday a draft agreement on farm financing, which sparked off the trade bloc's crisis July 1.

PARIS, Oct. 8 -- The $300-a-year salary increase to be paid to teachers at United States military dependant schools "very shortly" will be retroactive to Jan. 1, Dr. Joseph A. Mason, director of the schools for the European area, said today.

NEW YORK, Oct. 9 -- Following the announcement of President Johnson's impending gall bladder surgery, the communications media of the country have reported such detailed information on the anatomy, physiology and function of the biliary tract that the average reader has become a temporary pseudo-specialist in gall bladder disease.
JAKARTA, Oct. 8 (UPI) -- Thousands of Moslem youths shouting "Long live America" stormed the headquarters of Indonesia's powerful Communist party (P.K.I.) today and burned it to the ground.

LONDON, Oct. 8 -- Queen Elizabeth II has reached halfway around the world to name Sir Robert Menzies, Prime Minister of Australia, to the ancient and honorific post of Lord Warden of England's Cinque Ports.
BUDAPEST -- It is now evident that the Governments of Communist Europe that tried to manage almost all aspects of human society have failed in family planning.

ROME, Oct. 8 -- A French bishop from Verdun challened today the validity of distinctions between nuclear arms and the so-called "conventional" weapons that killed 1,300,000 people in his diocese in World War I.
NEW YORK, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Texas-Oklahoma and Notre Dame-Army head tomorrow's college football schedule.

PARIS, Oct. 8 -- Stock prices on the Continent were generally mixed within a narrow range today. Small gains predominated in Milan and Brussels, while fractional declines held the edge in Amsterdam, Brussels and Frankfurt.

United Nations, N.Y., Oct. 8 -- The United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine reported today that the problem of supporting Arab refugees from areas now in Israel was steadily getting more critical.

Although he makes his living writing science fiction, Ray Bradbury is a humanist. The object of the three short plays that make up "The World of Ray Bradbury," which opened last night at the Orpheum Theater, is to show that man is in grave peril of being dehumanized by his mechanical and electronic marvels.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- President Johnson underwent today a successful operation during which surgeons removed his gall bladder and a ureteral stone. He was recovering as expected this afternoon.

SOUTHPORT, England, Oct. 8 (AP) -- The United States Ryder Cup team won four matches, lost two and halved two today to seize 8 1/2-6 1/2 lead over Great Britain and move well on the way to capturing the 38-year-old trophy for the 13th time in 16 attempts.
LONDON, Oct. 8 -- Britain's tallest building, a 620-foot Post Office tower that looks like a candlestick and has the fastest elevator in Europe, was formally opened today by Prime Minister Wilson.

Lima, Peru, Oct. 9 (Reuters) -- A Reuters dispatch from Lima reports that Major Ernesto Che Guevara, former Cuban Minister of Industries and close associate of Cuban Premier Fidel Castro, has been captured in Peru.
PARIS, Oct. 8 -- The Ford Motor Company and France are flirting with each other over whether Ford might build its next European plant in this country.

LONDON -- When the partisan fog clears away, the Conservative party's new manifesto is likely to have a lasting impact in at least one field: labor-management relations. Edward Heath and his men call for what amounts to a revolution in the labor of Britain.

VIENNA, Oct. 9 -- The International Red Cross conference, attended by more than 600 delegates from 93 countries, ended here tonight in a climate of relative harmony that few participants had hoped for after the opening clashes on Vietnam and China during the one-week session.
NEW YORK, Oct. 8 (UPI) -- A 900-year-old Koran stolen from the New York World's Fair was recovered abandoned in a mailbox last night.

United Nations, N.Y., Oct. 8 -- North Vietnam now realizes that the withdrawal of American forces from South Vietnam cannot be a precondition for a peace conference, United States officials said today.

Rome, Oct. 8 -- Pope Paul VI today held his first general audience in the Vatican since he returned from his historic journey to New York. In a brief but impassioned address to some 10,000 pilgrims and tourists, he declared that peace is not the concern of nations and government only. Calling for individual efforts, the Pontiff said that peace is "everybody's duty."

PARIS, Oct. 8 -- It now seems certain that President de Gaulle will be a candidate for re-election next December.

MADRID, Oct. 8 -- The filming of "Doctor Zhivago," the screen version of Boris Pasternak's novel, was completed here this week after nine months and nine days of shooting in which Spain was called upon to provide Russian scenery and people of Slavic appearance.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 10 -- The Minnesota Twins tried to beat Don Drysdale today for the second time in the World Series, but they did not succeed. Drysdale, whom the Twins routed inside of three innings in the opening game on Wednesday, pitched the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 7-2 victory to even the series at two games apiece.
New York will pay its usual noisy respects today to the last new major trans-Atlantic liner to enter service this year -- this 24,000-ton Norwegian liner Sagafjord.
Ivan Davis showed again yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall that he is one of the country's most musical and dependable young pianists.
Controller Abraham D. Beame won unqualified support in his race for Mayor yesterday from Herman Badillo, Reform Democratic candidate for Bronx Borough President.

TORONTO, Oct. 10 -- Patrick Gordon Walker, former British Foreign Secretary, told a teach-in audience today that white powers, including the Soviet Union, should have no permanent place in Asian affairs.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 10 (AP) -- North American Aviation, Inc., and the United Aerospace Workers Union announced today that a new contract had been approved covering 35,000 workers in four states.

DENVER, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Pete Beathard, a quarterback, ran for two touchdowns after passing Kansas City within scoring range today to pace the Chiefs to a 31-23 victory over Denver in an American Football League game.
Activity in the business and investment world is continuing to build toward a booming crescendo in the closing quarter of 1965, a year for the record books.
Some months ago, a public relations vice president for one of the largest agencies wrote and amusing article entitled, "The Day the Press Releases Stopped."

New York's newspapers have come out of their third major labor-management battle in three years with their most basic problems still unresolved, and another shattering power struggle probable when the present contracts expire in less than 18 months.

The scholarship and building funds of the Art Patrons Association of America and the National Art Museum of Sport will share today in the proceeds of a two-part benefit called "A Renaissance Evening." There will be a champagne supper at the Gallery of Modern Art following a performance of the film "The Agony and the Ecstasy" at the Loew's State Theater.

The American Broadcasting Company has won the rights to televise college football for two years, starting next fall. The games are currently an attraction on the National Broadcasting Company network.
The Budapest Children's Choir gave a concert at Carnegie Hall last night that should make many an adult choir green with envy.
ADEN, Oct. 10 (AP) -- British troops today captured four men suspected of being important figures in the Aden terrorist movement, a spokesman for British headquarters said.

BALTIMORE Oct. 10 (AP) -- Johnny Unitas of the Baltimore Colts threw three touchdown passes in the first half today as the Colts handed the Detroit Lions their first National Football League defeat, 31-7.

Additional Federal funds for Haryou-Act were held up last night until the Harlem antipoverty agency accepted new management and fiscal controls. An exception was made for aid in continuing the agency's summer work program to Nov. 30 and for financing its planning staff.
Retail business was the most severely affected aspect of the city's economic life during the newspaper strike and shutdown.

LIMA, PERU, Oct. 7 -- In the forbidding central Andes, one of the most strategic spots of Latin America, Peru's democratic Government is slowly winning a decisive battle against two closely related enemies: Communist guerrillas and woeful poverty.
Newspaper, union and labor experts urged yesterday that ways be found to solve disputes in the newspaper industry without strikes such as the one just ended.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- President Johnson shows signs of being reconciled to losing his top labor bill in Congress this year.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Gale Sayers scored on an 80-yard pass play in the third quarter today and pitched a 26-yard touchdown pass to Dick Gordon in the fourth to propel the Chicago Bears to a 31-6 victory over the Los Angeles Rams.

The New York Times was shut down on Sept. 16 when members of the Newspaper Guild walked out in a dispute over pensions, automation, jurisdiction and a union shop for news department workers. Other major dailies shut down later that day in sympathy.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 10 (AP) -- The army pressed its campaign against rebels and their Communist supporters today and unofficial estimates were that 1,000 Communists had been arrested.
How handsome the "new" Philharmonic Hall looks -- and handsomer still its new sound!
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- President Johnson demonstrated today that confinement to a hospital bed had neither dulled his wit nor damaged his political antennae.
COREYS, N.Y., Oct. 10 -Governor Rockefeller acted as trail boss today in nasty weather through rugged upstate mountain country.

HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 11 -- A motorcycle carrying a teen-age girl and boy roared up to a curb on the Sunset Strip Saturday night. The boy wore a Confederate Army cap, a long black cloak and boots. His girl wore an English fox hunt cap, striped bell-bottom slacks, a bright red blouse and yellow boots.
HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Less than four months before she died, Dorothy Dandridge wrote a 44-word note in which she outlined her will and handed it to her manager, saying:

Gerard W. Brooks has resigned as marketing vice president of American Airlines, Inc., following differences over organizational matters. He will be succeeded by F.J. Mullins, who was formerly vice president for sales and services.
A COLLEGE football team has the right to form a human pyramid in an attempt to block a field goal but it cannot use radio messages between coach and quarterback during the game.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- The Supreme Court declined today to review a decision requiring the Civil Aeronautics Board to hold a hearing before permitting Hughes Tool Company to re-acquire control of Trans World Airlines.
SAIGON, South Vietnam -- An electrically detonated land mine exploded last night, killing or wounding all of the handful of American paratroopers riding in a jeep.

Two floors full of goodies that most Americans would like to receive for nothing -- and that many will -- were put on display yesterday at the New York Coliseum. The occasion was the annual four-day New York Premium Show, where premium buyers from a wide variety of companies were exposed to the latest premium and incentive merchandise on the market.

ONE of the functions of National Educational Television is to do those things that would not appeal to advertisers, but last night it carried noncommercialism rather far. Its presentation of a portion of the first produced play by Robert Lowell, the poet, was a wearing workshop that would have benefited from metered interruptions.
SINGAPORE, Tuesday, Oct. 12 (Reuters) -- The Indonesian Army has captured Lieut. Col. Untung, leader of the Sept. 30 Movement, which staged the abortive coup early Oct. 1.
The Martin Foundation yesterday dedicated its headquarters building at 26 West 56th Street to the memory of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt.

Martha Graham will return to Broadway next month for a three-week engagement, the longest American season she has ever given. The dancer and her company will appear at the 51th Street Theater from Nov. 2 to Nov. 20.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- The Federal Crop Reporting Board is holding to its forecast that crop production this year will surpass the 1963 record by 4 per cent and last year's volume by 7 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The Supreme Court continued its high interest in antitrust questions today by agreeing to review several antitrust appeals.

ROBERT GRAVES, a Stoic bon vivant, went to Majorca 30-some years ago because it was cheap. He stayed on because it was rich. The riches he found there are spread before us in a wonderfully engaging book, ably illustrated by Paul Hogarth.

The official United Nations English translation of Pope Paul's comments on birth control differs from the translation released earlier by the Papal Visit News Center and used in news reports, it was learned yesterday. The Pontiff spoke in French.
R.H. Macy Co. opened its 51st establishment yesterday, a vast, circular combination of bazaar and parking lot on Queens Boulevard in Elmhurst, Queens.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11 -- The Education Act of 1965, rather than the Civil Rights Act of 1964, will be invoked in a new attempt to block the more than $30 million in Federal funds earmarked for Chicago school programs, civil rights leaders said today.

The Magnavox Company, reporting a 200 per cent increase in its shipments of color-television sets, announced yesterday the highest sales and earnings for the third quarter and nine-month period in its 54-year history.
BELGRADE, Oct. 11 -- The United States has become Yugoslavia's foremost trade partner, replacing Italy, it was reported today.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Billy Martin, the outspoken third-base coach of the Minnesota Twins, said today the Los Angeles Dodgers were parlaying a rock-like infield and a 1,200-pound roller into a home field advantage in the World Series.

RYE, N.Y. Oct. 11 -- Bunting Crocker of the Canadian team won a free-for-all race on Long Island Sound today in a special event that concluded the annual three-day regatta between skippers of the Royal Canadian Yacht Club of Toronto and American Yacht Club of Rye.
RIGA, Latvia, Oct. 11 -- Six men went on trial in Riga, the Latvian capital, today on the death of 15,000 people during World War II.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Oct. 11 -- Former President Juan D. Bosch said today he considered the Dominican Republic a member of a "Latin-American democratic front" and hoped like-minded nations in the hemisphere would back his demand for a huge idemnity from the United States.

Frank Wille, New York State's youthful Superintendent of Banks, laid down some guidelines yesterday in the thorny question of when -- indeed whether -- the holder of an ac count in a savings and loan association in the state should have the right to challenge its management.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Former Vice President Henry Wallace entered the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md., about 10 days ago, but is not critically ill, a spokesman for the clinical center said today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The State Department said today that the United States had no thought of trying to conclude a tariff-cutting deal in the Kennedy round of trade negotiations without the European Common Market.

Controller Abraham D. Beame said yesterday that a careful study should be made of the feasibility of putting the controversial $110 million Lower Manhattan Expressway underground before any families or businesses were dislocated.

The Transit Authority said yesterday that the two-way radio system on the IRT's Lexington Avenue line could have alerted the police and prevented the fatal knifing of Arthur F. Collins, 28 years old, on a train in Harlem Saturday night.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 11 -- The General Assembly's Trusteeship Committee demanded in a resolution today that Britain "take all steps necessary to put an end to the rebellion" implied in Rhodesia's threat to declare its independence unilaterally.

NORMALLY, the trip from Vernal down the length of the 450,000-acre Uintah and Ouray Indian Reservation is routine when the Nu Tuveep hunting operation takes its hunters to the Hill Creek Hunting Lodge.
NEW DELHI, Oct. 7 -- The first snows are sifting down on the rocky mountainsides of Kashmir where Indian troops keep watch in posts they seized from Pakistan.
As the world moves into the third decade of the postwar period it is becoming increasingly urgent to refocus an American foreign policy that essentially was shaped in the first.
The new Norwegian liner Sagafjord received royal honors when she arrived here yesterday on her maiden voyage.
The picking of a jury began yesterday in Supreme Court in the trial of Richard Robles, a 22-year-old narcotics addict accused of the killing of Janice Wylie and Emily Hoffert.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 11 (AP) -- A member of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today there have been surpluses from overbuilding in many major housing markets since 1964.
OSLO, Oct. 11 -- Premier Einar Gerhardsen resigned today, formally ending almost 30 years of continuous Labor rule in Norway.

Elihu H. Morson, a rent control official for the last 15 years, has been named deputy administrator for operations of the City Rent and Rehabilitation Administration. Mr. Morison, who joined tile agency in 1950 as chief of the methods and procedures division, has since served as director of field operations and director of the Brooklyn rent office.

MIAMI, Oct. 11 -- The refugees involved in the shooting incident said today they had left from Las Villas Province rather than from Camarioca because they feared reprisals against relatives in prison if they sought formal approval to leave the islands.
Thousands of Manhattan-bound commuters on the Long Island Rail Road were delayed for periods of up to an hour during the morning rush yesterday.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Oct. 11 -- "If ours were a rational country there is no doubt that we would have a coup d'etat any moment now," a high Uruguayan official said yesterday. "But Uruguay does not conform to the political patterns usually seen in Latin America," he went on.
LONDON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Charles Clore, British real estate executive, made a takeover bid tonight for Selfridges, the well-known London department store.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The British Foreign Secretary, Michael Stewart, and his aides passed through Washington today and delivered a muted message of change in British defense policy that promised still greater trouble for the Western alliance.

If computers could cheer, the electronic components of the International Business Machines Corporation would have raised the roof yesterday as the company announced its highest quarterly and nine-month sales and earnings figures in its 51-year history.
A number of industrial price changes were announced yesterday by various companies.
ROME, Oct. 11 -- Pope Paul VI headed off a discussion of celibacy at the Vatican Council today.

The continuing runoff from last weekend's rain in the watershed areas increased the city's water reserves by one-tenth of 1 per cent in the 24 hours ended at 3 P.M. yesterday, raising the supply to 177.6 billion gallons, or 37.3 per cent of capacity.

A privately owned 25-acre tract in downtown Houston will be offered at auction on Nov. 3. The tract, which is mostly vacant land, is owned by the McCullough Tool Company of Los Angeles. It is believed to be the largest undeveloped area in the heart of a major city in the United States in private hands.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 11 -- Willie Davis froze in deepest center field in the fifth inning when Harmon Killebrew's violent swing produced a soft fly ball. Too late, he made his break. He raced in frantically and made a headlong dive for the ball. He caught it, but impact with the ground jostled it from his glove.

The Damon Runyon Fund, all of whose receipts are used for cancer research, will benefit Thursday at a preview of "On a Clear Day You Can See Forever." The Alan Jay Lerner and Burton Lane musical is scheduled to open Sunday at the Mark Hellinger Theater.

The love-hate feelings that Ranger fans show for their team year after year mellowed somewhat last night as the Blues continually surprised and delighted a crowd of 7,621 at Madison Square Garden in scoring a 5-2 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs.

Haryou-Act's failure to meet two administrative conditions has kept it from receiving any funds from a new $5 million city grant offered the Harlem antipoverty agency for the fiscal year that started last July 1.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- The Supreme Court dismissed today, for want of jurisdiction, an appeal involving apportionment of the County Board of Supervisors in Suffolk County, L.I.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Some 40 scientists and diplomats from 27 countries were flown to Montana today to inspect a large, experimental seismic station built by the United States for the detection of underground nuclear explosions.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
THE Wally F. Galleries, ordinarily the very model of a model East Side art gallery, is, at the moment, a gallery of displaced paintings because the Georges Braque jewels are in town.

MRS. MARY PARTRIDGE of Beacon Hill, in Boston, drifted with confusion through the displays in Macy's new store in Queens yesterday, and ran into a man who looked as though he might work for the store.

SEATTLE, Oct. 11 (AP) -- A new way of detecting life in unborn babies less than two inches long -- with a device producing sounds that the mother can hear -- was described today at a meeting of the National Academy of Sciences.

PARIS, Oct. 11 -- Algeria's Foreign Minister, Abdelaziz Bouteflika, made a flying visit to President de Gaulle today to seek financial and diplomatic support for Col. Houari Boumediene's four-month-old regime.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The National Society of Daughters of the American Revolution marked its 75th anniversary today.
The National Footwear Manufacturers Association, trade organization for about 400 footwear producers, announced yesterday in Chicago the election of John B. Reinhart Jr. as president.

The auxiliary of the Manhattanville Community Centers will be the sponsor of a luncheon and fashion show Thursday in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom. Mrs. Charles Rheinstrom is general chairman of the afternoon. Mrs. Neville Gordon Hart and Mrs. W.F.P. Keenan 3d are co-chairmen.

CRAWFORDVILLE, Ga., Oct. 11 -- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. said here tonight that the Southern Christian Leadership Conference was considering developing a full-scale civil rights movement in this little country town to dramatize Negroes' impatience with token desegregation of Southern schools.
INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 11 (UPI) -- The Indianapolis Times ended publication with today's editions after 78 years as an afternoon newspaper.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The United States, West Germany and the Inter-American Development Bank announced today new financing of $10.1 million for Bolivia's tin mines.
The swing to color television is painting a brighter picture for many companies in allied fields.

SEVERAL bridge tournaments in Europe attract an international field, including two in France and one in the Lebanon. In 1966, for the first time, there will be an open international tournament in Israel.
DETROIT, Oct. 11 -- The 1966 model automobiles, now getting their first showroom notices from the buying public, are safe, fancier -- and more expensive.
A long-standing labor dispute between shiplines of the American Merchant Marine Institute and the Staff Officers Association has been settled.
These words were written by Miguel Cervantes in "Don Quixote," published in the 17th century, not a time when books abounded in the ever-increasing numbers they do today.
ANKHE, South Vietnam, Oct. 11 -- United States and South Vietnamese units set a trap today around Communist forces in an upland valley northeast of Ankhe.
KEY WEST, Fla., Oct. 11 -- Another boatload of refugees arrived today in the exodus from Cuba authorized by Premier Fidel Castro.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 11 (AP) -- The sign "Go Dodgers" hung conspicuously over Maury Wills's head as the Dodger shortstop sat in front of cubicle in the Los Angeles dressing room and prepared game ball for presentation Sandy Koufax, the winning pitcher today.
Maria Tallchief, a ballerina of the New York City Ballet, denied yesterday a newspaper report that she was "quitting" the company.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11 -- Americans will buy about a billion pairs of shoes next year at prices somewhat above 1965 levels, footwear executives said today as the National Shoe Fair, the largest trade event in the industry, entered its second day.
The mere existence of a ceasefire between India and Pakistan won't solve the Kashmir problem. However, there is a solution that would be good for both nations.
SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Oct. 11 -- Governor Rockefeller galloped out of remote Adirondack Mountain country today, leading a column of 17 horsemen who had spent 24 hours on a conservation expedition.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Under strong handling by Paul Kallai, Farewell Address carried the yellow and blue silks of Peter De Paul to a length victory in today's feature race at Atlantic City.
KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Oct. 11 (Reuters) -- The police used tear gas today to break up a demonstration by stone-throwing university students and unemployed people.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 11 -- The police sealed off the University of Brasilia today after the university rector declared it had become a "center of subversion." At least four professors were arrested.

" THERE'S only one thing you can say about the action of the Dow-Jones industrial average," declared Robert H. Stovall yesterday. "It's bullish." That sentiment expressed by the vice president in charge of research for E.F. Hutton Co., Inc., summed up Wall Street's view as the Dow-Jones industrials boomed to a new closing high of 942.65, up an impressive 4.33 points.

LONDON, Oct. 11 -- Lord Hill of Luton, chairman of the Independent Television Authority, denied today that there was any anti-Americanism in his recent decision to reduce American-produced material during the evening peak viewing hour on Britain's Independent channel.
The Norfolk Western Railway and the Chesapeake Ohio formally filed their merger plans yesterday with the Interstate Commerce Commission.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The Administration forcefully condemned today as harmful and irresponsible attempts by private groups to organize boycotts against American companies trading with Communist countries.
LONDON, Oct. 11 -- Iain Macleod is resigning as editor of The Spectator because of his new duties as shadow Chancellor of the Exchequer on the Conservative front bench.

BRUSSELS, Oct. 11 -- The news over the weekend that Italy's Foreign Minister, Amintore Fanfani, had injured his leg and probably would be unable to preside over the Council of Ministers meeting Oct. 25 has pushed the already low morale of the European Economic Community down another notch.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- A Minnesota Representative absolved Roger L. Stevens today of conflict of interest charges he had raised against Mr. Stevens last month.
President Johnson ignored the advice of Robert F. Kennedy and Arthur J. Goldberg in appointing Federal District Court Judge Wilfred Feinberg to the United States Court of Appeals here yesterday.

Traffic engineers throughout New York and New Jersey appealed yesterday to all political candidates to advise party workers to stop defacing traffic signs with political stickers. The engineers stressed that such defacement not only was illegal and costly but also could result in serious accidents to motorists who were unable to read warning markers.

The Slattery Construction Corporation, one of the nation's largest contractors, and one of the company's general supervisors were indicted yesterday on charges of grand larceny and falsifying the description of materials used in building the Staten Island Expressway.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The Supreme Court left standing today a reorganization of the Malverne, L.I., elementary schools that is aimed at reducing racial imbalance.

Lucy Brown, pianist, gathered a varied group of musicians for a comfortable evening of chamber music by Schumann last night at Carnegie Recital Hall. It was the first in a series of three concerts that Miss Brown will devote to that composer this fall.
The process of integration of the Common Market is "irreversible" and no one nation can interrupt this process, Dr. Emilio Colombo, Italy's Minister of the Treasury, said here last week.

Lawyers for both sides in the fight for control of the Paramount Pictures Corporation may begin meeting today in an effort to thresh out an agreement that would lead to an early trial of the issues in the case.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- "This is one the President can't afford to lose," was the estimate by one of his closest and most influential official advisers of the proposal to invalidate the state "right-to-work" laws. But the vote by which the Senate today seemed to foreclose any prospect of action by Congress at this session strongly indicated that this is a battle he could well afford to lose.
FAIR LAWN, N.J., Oct. 11 -- A 12-year-old girl was kidnapped from her school here today, raped and thrown out of a car in Massapequa, L.I., five hours later, the police reported.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 11 -- The team physician of the Minnesota Twins, Dr. William E. Proffitt Jr., is a relaxed, stocky man who used to play halfback for the University of Minnesota, who now faces more crises than Ben Casey and who regards Sandy Koufax with mixed feelings as a medical marvel.
BROOKVILLE, L.I., Oct. 11 -- The Metropolitan Golf Association pro-amateur event over the par 36, 36 -- 72, 6,615-yard Tam O'Shanter Golf Club course finished in a five-team deadlock today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. (AP) -- The House threw out today an election contest against Iowa's only Republican House member, Representative H.R. Gross.
Some 1,000 Cuban-Americans moved yesterday to let Mr. Castro know that they expect him to keep his promise and allow their relatives to join them in the United States.
A ROMAN centurion, a witch on a broomstick, a tiny glass lampshade for $850 -- these are among the valuable curiosities that opening-day visitors saw yesterday at the New York Antiques Fair.

HARRISON, N.Y., Oct. 11 -- Toby Lyons, the club professional, and Sam Mason of Burning Tree, shot a 33, 32 -- 65 at the Harrison Country Club today and won the final pro-amateur event of the Westchester County Golf Association season.
The respective achievements during this session of Congress of Senate Interior Committee and House Interior Committee form a disturbing contrast.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 11 -- Col. L. Gordon Cooper Jr., who has flown longer in space than any other man, said today he foresaw greater space cooperation between the United States and the Soviet Union.
ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 11 -- The Justice party is now practically certain to come to power alone following Turkey's general election yesterday.
A really good way to help people break the cigarette smoking habit has yet to be developed, a survey of such efforts suggests.
Steel production fell 2.5 per cent last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

" AN EVENING'S FROST" isn't the least bit chilly. It is a warm portrayal of Robert Frost, an evening when the poet spins out his own story, the sweet and the following bitter, the tragedy and triumph, in words creating laughter, but even more often tears.

RYE, N.Y., Oct. 11 -- The Adoption Service of Westchester, Inc., will benefit again from Westchester County on Saturday. They will be at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club in Scarborough, the Bedford Golf and Tennis Club and at the Westchester Country Club in Rye.

A Sunday tour of eight brownstone and town houses recently renovated on the Upper West Side is being sponsored by the West Side Montessori School of 210 West 91st Street. The proceeds will aid its scholarship and development programs.

The Committee of American Steamship Lines announced yesterday that its 14 member companies had submitted to the Maritime Administration ship construction plans that would cost $1.6 billion to implement over the next five years.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The Senate dealt an all but fatal blow today to the Administration's bill to nullify state laws prohibiting the union shop.

FOR any New York turophile (Clifton Fadiman's coinage for a cheese lover), there is irritation, frustration and dismay when visiting most of the town's restaurants whether grand luxe or bistro. The cheeses, if available at all, are more often than not overripe or underaged, too cold or too few, all of which would seem to reflect the restaurateur's general underestimate of the customers' palates.
Most issues on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter market surged ahead yesterday in heavy trading.

Representative John V. Lindsay has endorsed the concept that "the moment a person is arrested" he should be advised of his legal rights and that, if he cannot afford counsel, a lawyer should be appointed by the court for him "without charge."
The bond market advance that began a week ago continued yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Thurgood Marshall was presented to the Supreme Court today as the nation's 33d Solicitor General. He is the first Negro to hold the post.
In a recent news story there was a reference to a copy of the 1225 Magna Carta leaving Britain for the first time.

Two persons instrumental in having the Supreme Court strike down last June the 1879 Connecticut birth-control law, forbidding the use of contraceptives by anyone, will receive the Albert L. Lasker Award of the Albert and Mary Laker Foundation.
THE shape of things to come around the house -- if the National Decoration and Design Show qualifies as cyrstal ball -- might include the following:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- President Johnson took his first unassisted steps today as his recovery proceeded on schedule.
Theodore W. Kheel suggested yesterday that an industry-wide approach offered one of the best possibilities for the solution of automation and job protection problems in the New York newspaper field.

The Italian Historical Society began a scholarly vendetta yesterday with Yale University, which announced Sunday that it had cartographic evidence that Leif Ericson, a Norwegian, reached the New World before Columbus, an Italian who sailed under the Spanish flag.
The closure vote in the Senate yesterday on the bill repealing state "right-to-work" laws was ill-conceived and untimely. It was thus in keeping with the whole history of this unfortunate bill.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 11 -- Sandy Koufax pitched the Los Angeles Dodgers to their third straight victory of the World Series today with a dazzling four-hitter that beat the Minnesota Twins, 7 to 0.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Treasury bill rates dipped sharply today after their strong rise of the last several weeks, the Treasury disclosed tonight.

HARRISON, N.Y., Oct. 11 -- Mrs. Murray Gordon of Elmwood shot 42, 42 -- 84 on the West course at the Westchester Country Club today and won the final one-day tournament of the Women's Tri-County Golf Association season by one stroke.
NEW HAVEN, Oct. 11 -- Miss Sarah Franklin Robbins and John Dexter Jenks plan to marry in December.
TOKYO, Oct. 11 -- The Ministry of International Trade and Industry recommended a five-point program today for increasing Japan's lagging economic aid to developing countries.

The stock market made history yesterday as price averages surged to new highs. Volume swelled to 9.6 million shares, the main most active session seen the New York Stock Exchange was organized in 1792.

At this time of rising tension with Red China, a word on behalf of the Chinese people seems in order. Anyone familiar with the conditions under which they lived prior to the revolution must concede that great strides have been made to ameliorate their condition -- despite enforced isolation from the Western world and lack of Western aid.
Traffic on the St. Lawrence Seaway in September continued to increase for the sixth consecutive month, according to the St. Lawrence Seaway Authority.

It may be true, as Edwin L. Dale Jr. suggests in his report of Sept. 7, that Vice President Humphrey and various writers and commentators committed a blooper when they cited monthly changes in unemployment rates to show that the vigorous expansion of the economy had left the Negro behind.
ORADELL, N.J., Oct. 11 -- Gov. Richard J. Hughes and State Senator Wayne Dumont Jr., his Republican opponent in the New Jersey gubernatorial campaign, debated the issues here tonight.
CROWN PRINCE HARALD of Norway was not in New York on the eve of Columbus Day as a reminder that the Vikings had a primary role in the discovery of the New World.
Heublein, Inc., Hartford, was the successful bidder yesterday for the Theo. Harem Brewing Company, St. Paul.

The first Negro Roman Catholic Bishop in the United States said yesterday that his selection had been based on "religious'' factors but the fact that he was a Negro "seemed to have been important" to the Cardinal who first told him of his appointment.
An illuminated fountain -- using real water -- was turned on at Columbus Circle yesterday as the city formally accepted its latest gift from George T. Delacorte, the publisher and philanthropist.
A bill that would put a brake on the free-wheeling of irresponsible ship-cruise operators has passed the House and is now awaiting consideration in the Senate.

The city, which has permitted scores of groups to use the Mall in Central Park for speech-making, was upheld yesterday in its refusal to allow a rally to be held there Saturday to protest United States policy in Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Retail sales declined somewhat in September, mostly because of a drop in sales by automobile dealers, the Commerce Department reported today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- This has been the best year in history for airline-equipment orders, Stuart G. Tipton, president of the Air Transport Association, said today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- It is becoming harder and harder to buy a new car without psychiatric help. As the ads for the new models show all too clearly, what Detroit is now selling is not so much a car as a personality, and to make matters worse the variety is overwhelming.

LA JOLLA, Calif., Oct. 11 (UPI) -- One of the third team of aquanauts from Sealab 2 developed "the bends" today in a surface decompression chamber, delaying the finale of the 45-day "man in the sea" project.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Following is the vote by which the Senate today refused, 47 to 45, to invoke its closure rule to cut off debate on a House-passed bill to revoke the right of states to ban the union shop (a two-thirds majority was required to put the rule into effect):
The Nina, the Pinta and the Santa Maria sailed together in 1492, but today's observance of Columbus Day finds members of the financial community charting separate courses.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Oct. 11 (AP) -- President Sukarno directed his Government today to "normalize the situation" in Indonesia in the wake of the attempted coup of Oct. 1, the Jakarta radio reported.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 11 -- Major foreign petrochemical investments in fertilizer production are close to approval by the Brazilian Government.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Fears of the effects of Mexico City's altitude on athletes began fading today in the face of sterling performances in cycling, the first event of the "little Olympics."
Seven persons heard the screams of an Israeli nurse who was beaten and raped on Thursday night but did not call the police or go to the aid of the 28-year-old woman, the police disclosed yesterday.
WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 11 -- Dartmouth taught the long-shot players a lesson tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. It was: "If you don't want to bet on a solid, 2-to-5 favorite, don't bet against him."
LONDON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Five pirate radio stations presently bombarding the British Isles from beyond the territorial limit will be joined by a sixth when Radio Scotland starts next month.
ROME, Oct. 11 -- Roman Catholic prelates received today arguments defending changes in the draft declaration exonerating Jews of collective guilt in the Crucifixion of Jesus.
PARIS, Oct. 11 -- The French Government borrowed $200 million today for the benefit of selected companies. It is the selecting -- favoring some and not others -- that makes it controversial.

The Pure Oil Company, which became a division of the Union Oil Company of California through merger last July, has a new president. He is Claude S. Brinegar, 38 years old, vice president of economics and corporate planning for Union Oil, which he joined as an economic analyst in 1953.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Legislation on bank mergers failed to advance today as the House Banking Committee fought through a two-hour session that broke up automatically when the House convened.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Senator George S. McGovern, Democrat of South Dakota, called on the Administration today, as he had previously, to drop its "foolish, self-defeating" shipping restriction against commercial wheat sales to Communist countries.
HARTFORD, Oct. 11 -- Delegates to the Connecticut Constitutional Convention livened a slow day today with an argument over, whether a recently approved article on religion 'contained bad English.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 11 -- The life of a perfectionist can be very demanding and perhaps even dull. That was the impression Sandy Koufax, probably the greatest pitcher of modern times, gave today after shutting out Minnesota with four hits and sending Los Angeles ahead in this turnabout 1965 World Series.

Trading on the London St Exchange was listless without a definite trend yesterday as buyers held back in expectation of new trade figures to be issued today. The unsettled political situation in Rhodesia also had a restraining influence.

The Pan-American Coffee Bureau, trade organization for 15 Latin American coffee-producing countries, announced yesterday the installation of Alexandre Fontana Beltrao as president, chairman of the executive board and chief executive officer.
This is a story about how not to go about seeking the services of an advertising agency. Some names have been omitted to protect the guilty.
The stock market surged ahead yesterday as the Dow-Jones industrial index rose to a record level in heavy trading.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- A number of school boards across the nation, some in the larger cities, are refusing to participate in a test ordered by Congress to determine educational opportunities for racial minorities.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The University of Maryland said today that a series of talks by Bayard Rustin, civil rights leader, would be closed to the press to preserve them as "an educational experience." The scheduling of Mr. Rustin's speeches, which will be heard by policemen of the Washington area, has been bitterly protested.

AFTER the St. Louis team dismembered his Washington Redskins on Sunday, the losing coach, Bill McPeak, said: "The Cardinals are the best we've seen in our division. They have the best offensive line, the best backs."

" A Thousand Days," the book by Arthur Schlesinger Jr. about President Kennedy, grows steadily in length. Houghton Mifflin, which will issue the book on Nov. 29, reports that the manuscript is now more than 300,000 words.

The Pure Oil Company, which became a division of the Union Oil Company of California through merger last July, has a new president. He is Claude S. Brinegar, 38 years old, vice president of economics and corporate planning for Union Oil, which he joined as an economic analyst in 1953.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Senator George S. McGovern, Democrat of South Dakota, called on the Administration today, as he had previously, to drop its "foolish, self-defeating" shipping restriction against commercial wheat sales to Communist countries.
HARTFORD, Oct. 11 -- Delegates to the Connecticut Constitutional Convention livened a slow day today with an argument over, whether a recently approved article on religion 'contained bad English.
MONTICELLO, N.Y., Oct, 11 -- Under a clear and chill mountain sky, Monticello Raceway ended its manic-depressive season tonight, convinced it must be doing something wrong.

A benefit art show for Channel 13 -- 80 paintings and sculptures from the Larry Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art in Ridgefield, Conn. -- is on view at Alexander's, the new department store at Lexington Avenue and 58th Street.
The World's Fair moved into its final week yesterday, doubling its security detail in an effort to prevent the thievery and vandalism experienced in the final days of the 1939-40 fair.

I was appalled to read in The Times of Sept. 6 that Councilman Paul O'Dwyer would propose to help musicians (and other artists) "during their incubation period. We have good facilities for the artist after he is successful, but none during the period of struggle."

DETROIT, Oct. 11 (AP) -- The United States auto industry will write another page into its record book tomorrow when the seven-millionth car of calendar 1966 rolls off an assembly line, 38 days ahead of the old record. The previous mark was set Nov. 19, 1955.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Congress completed action today on a four-year, $787,500,000 program aimed at heading off a shortage of physicians and other medical personnel.
The Chase Manhattan Bank, which has carried its neck-and-neck competition with the First National City Bank around the world, is expanding its stake in the economic development of the South Pacific.
John V. Lindsay, the Republican-Liberal candidate for Mayor, dropped his seeming unconcern about William F. Buckley Jr. yesterday by delivering a stinging denunciation of the Conservative candidate.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 11 -- This pleasant resort in the piney woods of Ocean County reacted angrily today to the apparent deliberate burning early Sunday of two homes being built for Negro families in a predominantly all-white section of the town.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 11 -- A $30 billion tax bite now facing half the communities in the country might be averted under a revolutionary sewerage system outlined today by one of the nation's leading experts on sanitation.

The political heirs of Adnan Menderes have won a decisive victory in a free election in Turkey five years after the overthrow of his Government and four years after his execution for violating the Constitution. By way of rubbing it in for old Menderes foes, his eldest son and a daughter of former President Celal Bayar were among the victorious Justice party candidates for the Grand National Assembly.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The Supreme Court cleared the way today for the election of a new Legislature in New York State on Nov. 2 by disposing of four interlocking appeals concerning the election.
THERE'S not much new, pussycat, in "Drat! the Cat!" The musical that rumbled into the Martin Beck Theater Sunday night is broader and more obvious than the Keystone Kops and nowhere near so funny.

Sammyren of the Harbor View Farm won the $28,450 Discovery Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday, to the surprise of most of the 28,068 customers on hand. The 1 1/8-mile race for 3-year-olds attracted nine starters, and Sammyren was the next to the outsider in the betting. As a consequence, his straight return was $52.80 for $2.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- The Supreme Court denied today a hearing to three Negroes who asked a ruling that North Carolina's law against kidnapping is invalid because of vagueness.
GENEVA, Oct. 11 -- A Dutch-born United States citizen left his Swiss home under police escort today after overstaying by 12 hours the Government-set deadline for his departure from the country.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- The Veterans Administration said today that the Prudential Insurance Company of America, Newark, had been selected as primary insurer for the new group life insurance program for all American military personnel.

Five new television shows and 10 old ones made the "Top 15" in the first national Nielsen popularity report of the new season. In the "Bottom 15" there also were five new and 10 old shows. The report covered a total of 96 shows on the three networks.
ADO-ODO, Nigeria, Oct. 11 -- A young electoral official stepped glumly from a police van here this morning and was escorted up the steps into the police chief's office.
LONDON, Oct. 11 -- The power of economics over political decisions will have been strongly demonstrated if Rhodesia decides to move away from the brink in her confrontation with Britain.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UPI) -- The nation's airlines marked the 10th anniversary of their first jet order today by announcing they have ordered 704 new jet-powered transports valued at $3.7 billion for delivery by the end of 1969.
MOSCOW, Oct. 11 -- The guardians of the ideological purity of Soviet arts are becoming less inhibited about publicizing literary experimentation in the early years of the Soviet regime.

Haryou-Act, the Harlem agency that is the focus of several investigations, is easily the most controversial and the most unorthodox of the antipoverty programs.

A Brooklyn grand jury is expected to exonerate a Federal narcotics agent and a city policeman of any crime in connection with charges that they used a former convict in an attempt to shake down a Mafia figure.

Lawyers for both sides of the fight for control of the Paramount Pictures corporation met yesterday in the first of what is likely to be a series of discussions aimed at preserving the status quo. No agreement came out of the meeting.
PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 12 -- A planned protest by Presidential scholars to the President's policy in Vietnam apparently has died on the vine.

CAIRO, Oct. 12 -- The United States is understood to be moving toward a new economic aid agreement with the Egyptian regime provided Cairo agrees to pay for part of its purchases of American food shipments in hard currency.

Subtle opposition to the new law ordering equal employment opportunity for women may require them to march on Washington to obtain their rights, a woman Professor of Law at Yale University said yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 12 -- The Secretary General, U Thant, appealed urgently today for voluntary contributions from member states to meet obligations outstanding on United Nations accounts.

Two games ago the New York Giants were struggling with the foe, as has been their habit Against the league's weakest team, the Pittsburgh Steelers, they were ahead by four points as they moved to the Steeler 29-yard line late in the fourth quarter.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- A delegation of angry residents from the Lower East Side of New York picketed the Housing and Home Finance Agency here today to protest what they called the city's "inhuman" urban-renewal plans for the Cooper Square area.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The Johnson Administration's effort to nullify state laws prohibiting the union shop died tonight, the victim of a Senate filibuster.
El Tiempo, a Spanish-language weekly newspaper published in New York City, has announced that beginning Friday it will publish five times a week, Monday through Friday.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Oct. 12 -- The sky was bright today and the roads were clear, so Al and Joe and Charlie and Jack left their wives back in South Philadelphia and East Flatbush and drove up to the Catskills to to spend their day-off wit Chubby, who was lonely.

The impressive gains made by the Xerox Corporation this year are not likely to be equaled by many other industrial companies, according to the financial results going to some 65,000 stockholders today.

LONDON, Oct. 12 (UPI) -- The world's mercantile fleet grew by more than 7 million tons last year, reaching 160, 392,000 tons by July of this year figures from Lloyd's Register showed today. The fastest growing major fleets in the last two years were the Liberian, Russian, Norwegian and Japanese.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) -- The sugar bill, the final controversial measure on the House agenda this year, easily survived its first skirmish, amid sniping about lobbyists, and moved toward passage tomorrow.
LONDON, Oct. 12 -- Britain's trade last month took a favorable turn with a substantial drop in imports reducing the trade gap by 22 million ($61.6 million), the Government reported today.

The United States Steel Corporation raised prices yesterday by 2 to 3 per cent on its full line of electrolytic tin-coated steel products.
Corporate bond trading was active enough yesterday -- a semiholiday with banks and insurance companies closed for Columbus Day -- to be a pleasant surprise for dealers.

A two-for-one stock split of the common shares of the Tri-Continental Corporation was proposed here yesterday by directors of the company, a leading closed-end investment company with assets of about $550 million.

Shipments by the Procter Gamble Company in the fiscal first quarter, ended Sept. 30, were the highest for any quarter in the concern's history, stockholders were told yesterday at the annual meeting Cincinnati.

IN honor of the 20th anniversary of the death of Bela Bartok, the Philadelphia Orchestra opened its New York season last night with a program of the Hungarian composer's music. It was a fine program, too.

TOKYO, Oct. 12 -- Obeying the low-voiced instructions of Takehiko Matsukawa, a district school official and a self-taught hypnotist, nine fourth-grade boys and girls closed their eyes and imagined themselves walking slowly down a long flight of stairs.

TORONTO, Oct. 12 -- John Campbell, the director of the Ontario Securities Commission during the wild speculation in Windfall Oils and Mines Ltd., in July, 1964, was charged today with breach of trust.

Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. caustically criticized Representative John V. Lindsay yesterday for saying that Controller Abraham D. Beame "couldn't wait for the passing" of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and former Senator Herbert H. Lehman to "double-cross" the Democratic Reform Movement.
SRINAGAR, Kashmir, Oct. 12 -- Three boys were killed and two were wounded yesterday when policemen opened fire in the old city section of Srinagar.

Prentice-Hall, the publishers, will build a book-distribution center in West Nyack, N.Y., capable of shipping 100,000 books a day. Paul R. Andrews, president of the company, announced yesterday that the plant would be ready by the middle of next year.

BOSTON, Oct. 12 -- Bostonians believed today that Frank Morrissey would charm the Senate Subcommittee on the Judiciary during its hearing on his nomination to the Federal District Court here. He has been charming Bostonians for 20 years or more, even though few know him intimately.
Governor Rockefeller authorized yesterday the immediate recruitment of therapist and teachers for the Willowbrook State School for Mental Defectives.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 12 -- Comdr. Charles Conrad Jr., who spent eight days in space aboard the Gemini 5 spacecraft in August, was honored by Philadelphia, his native city.
BILLINGS, Mont., Oct. 12 (AP) -- A vast $10 million global listening post, designed to detect earthquakes and nuclear blasts, was dedicated here today by representatives of 30 nations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Stephen A. Mitchell, a former Democratic National Chairman, described the Federal antipoverty program today as "political dynamite" that might bring a popular reaction against the Democrats.

Now the optimists have taken over. The quickened pace of business activity and the climb to new highs on Wall Street has driven the pessimists, who were in command when the stock market broke last spring, into a ragged retreat.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) -- A Texas food expert was named today to fill a new post at the White House -- "food coordinator."

SOFIA, Bulgaria -- The United States has three kinds of diplomatic attitudes toward East European Communist lands. We have no relations whatsoever with East Germany and Albania. We exchange embassies on a normal basis with Yugoslavia, Poland, Czechoslovakia and Rumania.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., Oct. 12 -- Dr. Arthur Wayne Brown was inducted here today as the fifth president of Adelphi University.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Bayard Rustin, the civil rights leader, said he would tell a group of law enforcement officers tonight that they should be the first to advocate creation of civilian boards to review charges of police brutality.

President Johnson has deliberately rejected a splendid opportunity to make an outstanding appointment to one of the most important courts in the entire Federal system of jurisprudence. The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, embracing New York, Connecticut and Vermont, has stature second only to that of the Supreme Court itself.
The No. 1 college football team in the nation is Nebraska. Or maybe it's Texas. It depends on whom you believe -- the coaches on one hand or writers and broadcasters on the other.
The search for the slayer of a 28-year-old subway passenger last Saturday night continued yesterday, but the police said they had no clues to the killer's identiy.

Roman Brother left little doubt of his superiority among the handicap horses now campaigning, by the manner in which he won the $56,600 Manhattan Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. The 4-year-old gelding owned by the Harbor View Farm took the 1 5/8-mile test by eight lengths over El Peco Ranch's Hill Rise, with Mrs. Henry Obre's Knightly Manner three-quarters of a length farther back in the field of eight.

Britain has now made another -- and last-ditch -- effort to deflect Rhodesia's white minority government from a seizure of independence that could ignite racial war in Central Africa. WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (UPI) -- Senator John C. Stennis said today that United States troops would have to stay in Vietnam "possibly for 15 years or longer" after the fighting ends.

ROME, Oct. 12 -- A French priest has launched quiet efforts to persuade the Roman Catholic hierarchy that proposed changes in the church declaration on the Jews weaken the impact of its message of Catholic-Jewish conciliation if not its substance.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Oct. 12 -- As soon as the World Series ends, baseball will turn its attention to its most important immediate task, the choice of a new commissioner. No formal announcement has been made, but the owners have scheduled a meeting at Chicago next week, and it is expected that the successor to Ford Frick will be announced then.

Cuban refugees again beseiged the office of Catholic Charities yesterday in a continued rush to obtain application forms that they hoped would clear the way for close relatives to get out of Cuba and join them here.

NAHA, Okinawa -- When Premier Eisaku Sato of Japan visited a sugar mill in the Ryukyus recently, rows of employes in their best business suits held aloft signs and banners saying: "We thank the Japanese Government for buying Ryukyuan sugar."

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation increased its third-quarter earnings by 18 per cent raising its net income for the first nine months by 49 per cent above the corresponding period last year, D.C. Burnham, president, reported yesterday.
Whether he discovered America or not, Christopher Columbus was honored yesterday by more than 80,000 of his spiritual descendants who marched up Fifth Avenue in the traditional Columbus Day parade.
Although Representative John V. Lindsay has become the underdog in the mayoral race against Controller Abraham D. Beame, he is planning to stick to his basic campaign strategy.

The stock market in recent months has proved once again that it can behave just as mysteriously as a woman. Everybody tries to figure out what it is going to do, but, heeding some inexplicable inner voice that defies logic, it goes right ahead and pulls a surprise.

The Association Home for elderly women will benefit from a dinner to be held on Monday at the Versailles Suite of the Astor. Reservations may be made at the home, 891 Amsterdam Avenue.

American Airlines announced yesterday a low-fare air-taxi service between the metropolitan area's suburban airports and the major air terminals.
Eugene Caldwell, a member of the Atlanta investment concern of Montag Caldwell, has been elected a director of the Butler's Shoe Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The State Department acknowledged today that it had expurgated a display of surrealist paintings in its exhibition hall sponsored by the Belgian Embassy. And there were unconfirmed reports of demands that the eliminated pictures be rehung.

ALBANY, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Six National Guard units in New York State will become part of the Army's select new backup force, guard officials reported today.

Four of five contributors to a study of the question of a "Fair Trial vs. the Free Press" have agreed that self-regulation by mass media will assure "fair trial by an impartial jury." Four seasons -- and some $1 million -- later, Philharmonic Hall has a new look, physical and acoustic. The latest renovations, finished just in time for the season's opening, at something over $330,000, are the most drastic attempted up to now.

Personnel and equipment problems of increasing severity are facing the armed services as the United States military commitment in Vietnam becomes larger.

Automobile deaths decreased 6 per cent in the city in the first nine months of this year compared with the similar period of 1964.

Third-quarter net income of the Commonwealth Oil Refining Company rose to a record of $4,723,903, or 40 cents a share, from $2,705,407, or 23 cents, in the 1964 quarter, it was reported yesterday. Revenues rose to $32,231,540 from $25,662,841.
Runoff from the rains of the first 12 days of October added 19 billion gallons of water to the city's stores, equivalent to a 20-day supply at the current rate of use.
TOKYO, Oct. 13 -- The chairman of the Tokyo Stock Exchange voiced cautious optimism for the future today as the fluctuating market continued its latest spurt.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 13 (AP) -- The president of Rutgers University, replying to proposals by Wayne Dumont Jr. that the state university reconsider its decisions in the case of Prof. Eugene Genovese, said today that "freedom of spirit" is a fundamental aim of education.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -President Johnson's recovery from gall bladder surgery five days ago appears to be proceeding on schedule today. Despite occasional bouts of fatigue, the President displayed increased mobility and a good appetite.
The State Supreme Court overruled the Board of Elections yesterday and ordered the reinstatement of the Socialist Workers party on the Nov. 2 ballot.

Bullfights in Mexico City will be televised here by tape recording each Saturday from 8 to 10 P.M. by station WNJU-TV (Channel 47) beginning Nov. 13. It marks the first time for a regular schedule of bullfight shows in this area.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Senator Robert F. Kennedy proposed today that the United States explore new avenues to world disarmament by inviting Communist China to participate in the 17-nation Geneva disarmament conference.

A newly discovered comet that has been visible in the southeastern sky every dawn since Oct. 5 has caused a tenfold increase in the number of calls to the Hayden Planetarium, officials there said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The time to decide who is going to manufacture and market synthetic life is now. Science is already well along in its attempt to create life synthetically in the laboratory, and it is doubtful that the process is going to be stopped by humanistic appeals not to foist this thing on the world.

A wide-ranging proposal, designed to help the theater abolish legislation that hampers ticket sales, has been submitted to theater owners and producers.

Leif Ericson may or may not have discovered America. But the Scandinavian Airlines System has certainly discovered Leif Ericson.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 13 -- A special board has recommended that in most cases South Vietnamese villages should not be bombed from the air before the villagers have been warned to leave the area, informed sources said today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The Senate Judiciary Committee questioned Francis X. Morrissey for more than an hour tonight and then approved his appointment to the Federal bench in Massachusetts by a 6-to-3 vote.

Moscow's "collective leadership" has maintained its grip on power, but it has little other ground for self-congratulation as it surveys the year that has now passed since Khrushchev was so unceremoniously evicted from his offices. WESTBURY, L.I.; Oct. 13 -The astute horse player among the 16,039 harness-racing buffs at Roosevelt Raceway tonight obviously was in the minority. Dick Barnett, whose strange shooting style has accounted for his nickname of "Fallback Baby," was traded to the New York Knickerbockers last night by the Los Angeles Lakers. The Lakers got Bob Boozer in a straight player deal.

BRIGHTON, England, Oct. 14 -- The Conservative party, in a change of policy significant for American as well as British defense strategy, moved today toward a call for abandonment of Britain's military commitment east of Suez.
HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 14 -Barry Goldwater repeated today his call for Republicans to resign from the John Birch Society.

Pocket billiard players, like the golfers and the bowlers, probably will be able to make a living on a professional tour.

At Philharmonic Hall last night, Leonard Bernstein conducted the New York Philharmonic in a program of three symphonies two of them 20th-century works that are far less familiar than they ought to be.
LONDON, Oct. 14 -- Britain's 23,000 family physicians were offered a "new deal" on fees by the National Health Service today.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 14 -- Senator Robert F. Kennedy, campaigning in New Jersey for the re-election of Gov. Richard J. Hughes, voiced strong support here today for Francis X. Morrissey, the controversial nominee for a Federal district judgeship in Massachusetts.

The State Insurance Department rejected yesterday a Blue Cross request for rate increases affecting 7.5 million subscribers in New York City and 12 nearby counties.
