PARIS, Oct. 14 -- The French National Assembly ratified tonight the controversial Sahara oil-and-aid accord with Algeria, after Premier Georges Pompidou took the floor to parry sharp criticism from centrist and right-wing deputies.

A freighter collided with a tug and barge in Long Island Sound last night, then struck one of three barges being towed by another tug, the Coast Guard reported. No one was injured.

BONNEVILLE SALT FLATS, Utah, Oct. 14 (UPI) -- Craig Breedlove flirted with the world land-speed record and possible disaster again today in a pulsating 534-mile-an-hour ride across the salt flats. However, the attempt ended in failure.

Moore-McCormack Lines and the International Business Machines Corporation are shaping a statistical "miracle" in which owners of the 41-ship fleet will know in an hour the financial results of the next year. The details were announced yesterday.

Philip H. Gilsten, who was dismissed by Mayor Wagner from a city job in 1961 on charges that he had acquired unexplained sums of money that he kept in a "tin box," is drawing an annual state pension of $7,218.

Two leading diversified producers of chemicals and pharmaceuticals -- the American Cyanamid Company and Chas. Pfizer Co., Inc. -- achieved record sales and earnings in the three and nine months ended Sept. 30, their reports disclosed yesterday.

DAN BLUE, the author of "Play That on Your Old Piano," grew up in Chicago during the Depression and evidently has arrived at that mellow age when he can look back on those harrowing days and try to write a comedy about people of the period.

KEY WEST, Fla., Oct. 14 -Three more boatloads of tired refugees arrived from Cuba late today. One of the groups, four men and 14 women and children, was plucked by the Coast Guard from a small cruiser as it began sinking in the Florida Straits.
Mayor and Mrs. Wagner are honorary chairmen of the John F. Kennedy Peace Award Dinner, for the benefit of the Jewish National Fund, Thursday in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

BERLIN, Oct. 14 -- The Western Allies ordered today the institution of civil defense measures in West Berlin to include, among other things, an early warning system and the construction of shelters for the civilian population.

Physicians at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center said yesterday that knee surgery was being considered for early next week for Amintore Fanfani, President of the United Nations General Assembly. The Italian Foreign Minister's right leg is in a cast as a result of a fall last Saturday.
Kaoru Chuma, the mayor of Osaka, Japan's second largest city, announced last night that his industrial city of 3.5 million residents would hold a world's fair in 1970.

EAST NORWICH, L.I., Oct. 14 -- Ralph Johnston of Garden City C.C. and Mrs. John Newman of Brookville scored a four-over-par 39, 36 -- 75 today and won the Long Island Golf Association's Scotch mixed foursome championship at the Pine Hollow Country Club.

The Tishman Realty and Construction Company has become the general contractor for the 29-story office tower planned for the Seventh Avenue side of the Pennsylvania Station property, and has become a part owner of the $50 million project.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Oct. 14 -- One of the most intriguing questions faced by a major league manager in years was the one Walter Alston wrestled with last night and this morning: Who should pitch the game that would decide the World Series -- Sandy Koufax or Don Drysdale?
KABUL, Afghanistan, Oct. 14 (Reuters) -- King Mohammed Zahir Shah opened Afghanistan's first democratically elected parliament today with a speech declaring a new era had begun.

The expressions of pious shock registered by the editorial in your International Edition of Oct. 1 "The Geneva Convention" seems to me a little overdrawn. American aviators are, indeed, ruthlessly bombing North Vietnam, which in itself is bad enough, although a prisoner of war is legally protected from retribution for his acts.

The New York Times endorses Timothy W. Costello for President of the City Council and Milton Mollen for Controller. They are well qualified by character, intelligence and ability, and, furthermore, it is important that Mr. Lindsay -- whom yesterday we endorsed for Mayor -- have with him a team sympathetic to his program and purpose, to increase his effectiveness at City Hall.

VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Oct. 14 (AP) -- A dragon fly-shaped satellite called OGO 2 was lofted into orbit over the earth's poles today with instruments designed to measure radiation that might be hazardous for astronauts.
TRENTON, Oct. 14 -- Establishment of two-year colleges in Bergen, Burlington and Somerset counties were authorized today by the State Board of Education.
WASHINGTON, Conn., Oct. 14 -- This residential community of 2,500, where the sole industry is education, is involved in a controversy that is shaking the quiet 231-year-old town to its foundations.
The whole-sale commodity price index fell to 105.3 on Wednesday from the revised figure of 105.6 on Tuesday.
If anyone has ever had any fears that the American modern dance has lost its first fine impetus, he should take himself to a performance by the Paul Taylor Company and get his faith back.

PARIS, Oct. 14 -- Daniel Wildenstein the international art collector and publisher of scientific art catalogues, asserted yesterday that 15 of the paintings from Russian museums now on display at the Louvre and attributed to French masters were fakes.
LONDON, Oct. 14 -- The British national anthem, "God Save the Queen," is again being criticized as going flat.
Governor Rockefeller, disturbed that Federal aid has been bypassing Albany on its way to local areas, set up a special cabinet committee yesterday to look into Federal-state relations.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Oct. 14 -- Sanford Koufax will return to New York City, his home town, on Monday, just long enough to pick up one of the more tangible rewards for becoming "the outstanding player in the 62d World Series"

Dr. Alonzo S. Yerby, the new Commissioner of Hospitals, proposed yesterday to meet a critical nursing shortage in the city's Morrisania Hospital by letting its voluntary sister hospital, Montefiore, contract to do the nursing.
A new bus line that eventually is to ring the city, touching all three major airports and many intermediate points, will begin operating Monday over the first of its three sections.

The Class A stock of the National Video Corporation -- one of the highest flyers on the American Stock Exchange -- ended active trading yesterday with a 14 3/8 point gain, to 111 1/2. The year's low is 16 7/8.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 14 -- A grandmother who is a Democratic candidate for the now all-Republican Mount Pleasant Town Board told neighborhood rallies today that the town was being run for the benefit of the Rockefellers.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Oct. 14 (AP) -- A Negro minister has become the second member of his race in little more than a year to win a seat on the Augusta City Council.

GALVESTON, Tex., Oct. 14 -- Leaders in the shipping industry strenuously pressed their views today in the continuing debate with Federal maritime authorities over shipping subsidies and related matters.
Regretfully, it must be reported that Julius Monk's "Pick a Number XV," which opened last night, is a bore.
MOSCOW, Oct. 13 -- The first anniversary of the removal of Nikita S. Khrushchev from power was ignored today by the controlled Soviet press.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 14 -- A Jakarta newspaper has accused Chinese intelligence agents of having plotted and financed the attempted coup d'etat.
HONG KONG, Oct. 14 -- Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the chief of state, claims an unusual achievement in keeping Cambodia "an oasis of peace" in turbulent Southeast Asia.

BONN, Oct. 14 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer said yesterday that he was opposed to any move by West Germany "at this time" to acquire nuclear weapons. But he added that he would not be able to commit himself on this point "forever."
A funny thing happened to S. Hurok on the way to the office yesterday: He lost David Oistrakh and Mstislav Rostropovich.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Oct. 14 -- A Federal court today gave Crawfordville, Ga., Negroes a victory in their campaign against the closing of Taliaferro County's white schools and the busing of white students to segregated schools elsewhere.

Advance sales rolled up by new shows for the 1965-66 season already amount to $6,059,975, according to various managements. This total applies only to shows that were ready with figures; several were not.

CHARLES AZNAVOUR comes here trailing clouds of popularity. It was gracious of Sammy Davis Jr. to take time off to introduce the French singer-composer at the Ambassador Theater, where he began a limited New York run last night.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 14 -- More than five battalions of South Vietnamese troops clashed last night with a large force of Vietcong guerrillas 10 miles from a major military headquarters town and suffered "moderate casualties."

The Kennedy family and friends have contributed reminiscences and pictures to create a book, "John Fitzgerald Kennedy . . . As We Remember Him," which Atheneum will publish on Nov. 9. The book was edited and produced under direction of Goddard Lieberson, president of Columbia Records.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (UPI) -- A national suicide prevention center is being established here to seek better ways of helping people through periods of anxiety and depression when they may consider taking their own lives.
The Children's Cancer Fund of America will give its 16th annual Fan Ball next Friday in the grand ballroom of the Plaza. Mrs. Stephenson Fenelon-Young is chairman of the evening.

A $30 million offering of Northwest Bancorportion debentures priced to yield 4.785 per cent sold out quickly yesterday after it was marketed by a syndicate led by the First Boston Corporation and Blyth Co., Inc.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 14 -- The Secretary General, U Thant, reported today that India and Pakistan had failed to comply with the Security Council's demand that all armed personnel withdraw from the battle zone in Kashmir and along the two countries' borders.
ILARO, Nigeria, Oct. 14 -- Chief Edetunji Fadayiro slumped wearily in his parlor armchair yesterday as he listened to the hourly news.
SYRACUSE, Oct. 14 -- The defensive platoon of Syracuse's painfully deflated football team has been reconstructed for Saturday's game here with Penn State.

THE feathers that have been flying all over the European and New York fashion scene have just settled about the ankles. At the showing of Jean-Louis Scherrer's designs at Bergdorf Goodman Thursday afternoon, the first two mannequins strode forth in greige and plum wool dresses and guinea hen feather coats, hats and boots.

TORONTO, Oct. 14 (Canadian Press) -- A confidential report prepared three months ago on the insolvent Atlantic Acceptance Corporation found that practices and procedures considered "normal and necessary in the conduct of a commercial financial business" were missing.

The rapidly advancing frontier of molecular biology -- the science that probes life's most fundamental secrets -- is one of the most exciting and promising areas of contemporary research. This year's Nobel Prize for Medicine and Physiology has gone to three outstanding figures in this field: Francois Jacob, Jacques Monod, and Andre Lwoff of the Pasteur Institute.
Two Pavlova films, one new and one 30 years old, ran into copyright difficulties at the Museum of Modern Art last night. Both films showed Anna Pavlova in her most famous dance, "The Dying Swan".

ON a clear night on West 51st Street, you can see Mrs. Wyatt Cooper (Gloria Vanderbilt) in green brocade by Mainbocher, Joan Bennett in mink-collared gold brocade, and acres of gold-shot or silver-shot pink, yellow, white and blue brocade, accompanied by matching coats or handy little mink stoles.

Strauss' "Arabella," back in the Metropolitan Opera repertory this season after four years on the shelf, was given its third performance last night. And while it was not an inspiring evening, there were some bright spots.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The Defense Department announced today a military draft call of 45,224 men for December, the biggest quota since the Korean War.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The Administration's higher education bill, carrying a first-year price tag of $841.4 million, won conference approval today but faces a stiff floor fight from House Republicans.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 14 -From Chicago came word today that Bob Farrington, the Richwood, Ohio, mason-turned-reinsman, plans to campaign standardbreds at Roosevelt Raceway next January. Farrington, the American record-holder, with 312 victories last year, has applied for 25 to 30 stalls, in which to quarter his trotters and pacers while here.
The Harris-Intertype Corporation made known yesterday that it had acquired a major interest in Officine Meccaniche Cigardi, S.p.A., of Milan, Italy, a large manufacturer of printing presses.

The former head of United Nations operations in the Congo, Dr. Conor Cruise O'Brien, said yesterday that only military leaders and large corporations had an interest in continuing the United States' policy in South Vietnam.
Two documentary programs filmed in the White House -one about President Johnson and the other about his aides -will be televised next week.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- As President Johnson strives to preserve the natural beauty of the countryside, he is being overcome by ugliness "right on his doorstep," Carlisle H. Humelsine, president of Colonial Williamsburg and chairman of the Virginia State Department of Conservation, said tonight.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Oct. 14 -- The Government took the first major steps today to enforce censorship of the press and radio since it suspended constitutional guarantees last Thursday to smother a threat of labor violence.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The control of nuclear weapons is undoubtedly the most difficult question in world politics today, and unfortunately it is being made even more difficult by the raising of false hopes and misleading issues.

Moving into the lead only after the final jump, Susto won the 15th running of the $11,250 Rouge Dragon Hurdle Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. The 5-year-old gelding, owned by Mrs. John R.H. Thouron, beat the favored Jumping Jupiter by three-quarters of a length in the contest of 2 1/2 miles.

AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 14 (UPI) -- The Texas Railroad Commission ordered today a drastic increase in the state crude oil allowable rate, setting the November pro-ration factor at 30 per cent of potential production.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Republican orators marked former President Dwight D. Eisenhower's 75th birthday tonight by denouncing the Democrats at about 40 fund-raising dinners from coast to coast.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Oct. 14 (UPI) -- Baseball Commissioner Ford Frick said today that a World Series incident involving coach Billy Martin of the Minnesota Twins and Ed Hurley, an umpire, was a closed matter.
Directors of the Syntex Corporation voted yesterday to split the common stock two for one, subject to shareholder approval. The board's action was not unexpected.

Carl Byoir Associates, one of the largest public relations companies in the nation, yesterday announced two top level executive changes.
The United Parents Associations charged yesterday that many junior high schools in the city had serious shortages of staff and supplies.

The Cruikshank Company, a real estate concern founded in 1794, has announced the election of Warren Lott Cruikshank as president. Mr. Cruikshank is the fifth generation of his family to be associated with the company since it was founded by his great-great-grandfather.

BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 14 -- The Vietnam Day Committee said today that it would hold its Peace March tomorrow even though the City of Oakland has refused to issue a parade permit. National Guard troops have been alerted for possible duty.

Undaunted by high prices, Americans have been consuming more bacon than ever this year. At the same time, hog prices have been rising in recent weeks because of the relatively small numbers brought to market.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Oct. 14 -- American publishers at the Frankfurt Book Fair are finding the major business here -the buying of publishing rights -has slowed down perceptively from previous years. Sales are steady, but not spectacular.

A retired Air Force Major General, who says he answers to "General," "Doctor" "Professor," "Mister" or "Just plain, 'Hey you!'" was chosen yesterday as chairman and chief executive officer of the Communications Satellite Corporation.

Although he considered this symptom as being related to the field of geriatrics -- or, as he more delicately put it, the "nearing" of "our journey's end/ Where time and eternity meet and blend" -- exhaustion is today more a question of advancing status than advancing years.

WENTWORTH, England, Oct. 15 (UPI) -- Gary Player rallied for a sudden-death playoff victory over Tony Lema and Peter Thomson defeated Arnold Palmer in the semi-finals of the Piccadilly world match-play golf tournament today.

John V. Lindsay tackled some of New York's most stubborn and chronic problems in his recent comprehensive "white paper" offering a seventeen-point program for expanding the city's economy. The Republican-Liberal nominee for Mayor sets a goal of creating 200,000 new jobs for the next four years, a full employment economy for New York, and a doubling of the city's present economic growth.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (UPI) -- The Senate Civil Service Committee approved today a one-year, 3.6 per cent Federal pay increase, tailored to avert a Presidential veto.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) -- A thorough reappraisal of the Public Health Service and the relationshiip of its activities to other governmental health programs is being undertaken at the direction of John W. Gardner, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 15 -- Vice President Humphrey reaffirmed tonight the Administration's commitment to the guidepost policy of wage and price restraint in the face of what appears to have been a strong attack on the concept by a top official of the United States Steel Corporation.

A task force of more than 200 decorators, electricians, carpenters, painters and metal workers is occupied these days in refurbishing 17 Shubert theaters on Broadway and out of town.

PARIS, Oct. 15 -- Regine Crespin, returning after a two-year absence abroad, was accorded a triumphant ovation tonight at the Paris Opera for her superb singing in Gluck's "Iphigenia at Tauris." WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The Soviet Union plans to send four economic specialists from Moscow to an Asian Development Bank meeting opening next Thursday in Bangkok. Thailand, in a move that has aroused the curiosity of the Johnson Administration.

A vision of Mary Poppins floating down on the Harvard Yard is evoked by news that Pamela L. Travers, the creator of that almost perfect governess, has accepted Radcliffe College's invitation to become its first writer in residence.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 15 (AP) -- The small United States contingent failed to gain a first place on the opening day of track and field competition today in the Little Olympics. One of Austria's most ambitious cultural exhibitions, featuring paintings, tapestries, drawings, graphic art and original music manuscripts, will be held in Dallas for two weeks starting tomorrow.

BECAUSE the Dodgers won the World Series there was no formal complaint from any of the Hollywood script writers. Being professional craftsmen, though, they had to be appalled by the total lack of drama in the production. For the most part the scenario was dull and pedestrian with virtually all of the emotional impact crowded into the last inning of the last game.
FOR the year 1952-53, the Charles Eliot Norton professorship of poetry at Harvard, a prestigious plum and one especially so for a son of Harvard, was awarded to e.e. cummings.

The New York constitutional requirement providing for the dismissal of public officials who refuse to sign waiver of immunity when called to testify before grand juries may be in jeopardy as a result of a ruling by the United States Supreme Court.

Columbia's football team beat Yale yesterday at Baker Field, 21-7, and not for the first time in the Ivy League's oldest rivalry that began 93 years ago. But it was the first time a Yale team came equipped with girl cheerleaders, an octet of sopranos recently recruited from Connecticut College for Women in New London.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Oct. 16 -- The showcase of contemporary art, "Art Across America," will continue at the Toledo Museum of Art through Oct. 31.
The April in Paris Ball, usually the season's most lavish charity event, will return this year to the Waldorf-Astoria, where it was first held in 1951.

By order of President Johnson, modern artificial limbs for Vietnamese military and civilian amputees are being sent to South Vietnam. Casts for them were taken by a prosthetist early last month when he accompanied this writer on a trip to war-torn Vietnam made at the request of the President.
Four Western Hemisphere journalists will receive Maria Moors Cabot prizes at Columbia University Thursday.
NEWARK, Oct. 16 -- A 23-year-old off-duty rookie policeman was shot dead in the street here today by the motorist whose car had bumped the one in which the policeman was a passenger.

CAIRO, Oct. 16 -- In Cairo this week, the charismatic figure of Gamal Abdel Nasser was temporarily in the background. The Egyptian Cabinet, quietly reshuffled two weeks ago, discussed a speeded-up housing program and Egypt's population problem.

New York has plans to use every available distribution device from pop bottles to Department of Sanitation trucks to get water to the city's eight million residents should there be a severe water crisis.
DAKAR, Senegal -- This capital city has become tourist conscious to an extent unusual in West Africa, because next April it will be the scene of the first World Festival of Negro Arts.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Forrest Rudolph had obviously been harboring a severe psychic problem for several weeks, but nobody realized quite how bad it was until, one day at lunch, he blurted, "I don't understand football."

It is disturbing that Joseph Kasavubu and Moise Tshombe were unable to work out their differences and agree to continue in tandem through the next critical phase of the Congo's political development. It could be disastrous.

IN setting the story of Tancred and Clorinda to music, Monteverdi chose a situation perfectly made for his special talents: a heart-rending human drama in a cloak of classic grace.
The steel industry, which has not always had the greatest reputation for subtlety, demonstrated last week that it is not the way it used to be.

AMERICAN tourists returning from abroad are coming home to lower duty-free exemptions and tighter controls on liquor importation. The new Customs rules, which became effective Oct. 1, were instituted to improve the nation's foreign trade balance by reducing tourist spending.

BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 16 -- A surprise assault by about a half dozen members of a motorcycle club broke up another confrontation between the Oakland police and the Vietnam Day Committee this afternoon.
EAST LANSING, Mich., Oct. 16 -- Unbeaten Michigan State held Ohio State to a minus-22 yards rushing today and romped to a 32-7 Big Ten football victory before a crowd of 75,288.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 16 -- Mrs. Richard C. du Pont said today that her five-time horse of the year. Kelso, would not be able to help represent the United States in the Washington, D.C., International Nov. 11.

The choice of winners of the five National Book Awards for 1965 will rest on the judgment of 15 literary authorities who include two winners of Pulitzer prizes, two winners of National Book Awards and 10 college teachers who are themselves authors or editors.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Gemini astronauts will move about outside their spaceships on five flights in the next year or so.
NEW DELHI, Oct. 16 -- Most of the "infiltrators" who entered the Indian part of Kashmir in August have withdrawn, according to authoritative Indian sources.

As the United States' commitment in Vietnam has grown, pockets of opposition have developed in the U.S. against the Administration's policies. Some opponents contend that U.S. participation in the Vietnamese war is illegal and that Americans should not be sent to fight; others object on moral grounds to the U.S. bombing in both South and North Vietnam.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 16 -- "Politically speaking, Brazil is like an obstacle course without a known destination," a federal Deputy said today.

ARTUR RUBINSTEIN'S continuing superiority as a Chopin player is shown again in his latest recording of the Polonaises and Impromptus. The 79 year-old pianist replaces his old mono recordings of the music with stereo disks of the best quality.

THE music of Mendelssohn, all but a few examples of which had been written off as old-fashioned not so long ago, seems to be returning to favor little by little. Last April, for example, the New York Philharmonic gave an all-Mendelssohn program (William Steinberg conducting, with Rudolf Serkin in the two piano concertos), the first such offering by any organization hereabouts for years.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Oct. 16 (UPI) -- A sophomore fullback, Bob Mitchell, scored a pair of touchdowns today to carry Vermont to a 23-7 victory over New Hampshire. It was Vermont's fourth victory. New Hampshire has not won a game.
The 19th century German thinker Friedrich Nietzsche shocked the philosophical world with his famous cry, "God is dead." Today that same cry is being heard in theological circles as well.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Navy combined a stunning defense and a 96-yard touchdown drive to beat Pitt, 12-0, at the Distract of Columbia Stadium today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- The rise of the stock market to new peaks early this week was hardly surprising in light of the continued amazingly strong performance of the economy.

Less "psychiatric real estate" and more trained personnel to care for the increasing number or mentally ill children were called for yesterday by Mike Gorman, executive director of the National Committee Against Mental Illness.
On Oct. 13 The Times reported that the British Government has announced plans for establishing an ombudsman to receive and act on citizens' complaints against public officials.

BOSTON, Oct. 16 (AP) -- The Boston Celtics opened their bid for an eighth straight National Basketball Association championship by beating the Cincinnati Royals, 102-98, tonight. Willie Naulls's 15-foot push shot and a pair of free throws by Sam Jones in the final 15 seconds clinched the victory.

If the decision of the Supreme Court of "one man, one vote" is sustained and followed up, it will mean eventually doing away with the United States Senate and one house of each State Legislature. The framers of our Constitution in their wisdom decided that the House of Representatives should be elected on the basis of population and that each state should be represented by two Senators regardless of population.
PINEVILLE, La., Oct. 16 (AP) -- Four world outboard speed records were set today over the Buhlow Lake course during the first day of the world outboard racing championships.

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 16 -- The headquarters of the National Coordinating Committee to End the War in Vietnam is situated not far from the University of Wisconsin campus in a long, narrow, unpainted frame building.
CHILDREN will be taught how to grow plants in terrariums and nature crafts in two Saturday morning plant workshops offered during October at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.
The Museum of the City of New York will open its Dutch Galleries at a gala preview reception and dance on Nov. 4.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- A relatively large underground nuclear explosion in Soviet Central Asia last week was clearly detected by a new American detection station, 5,700 miles away in southern Montana, Pentagon officials disclosed today.
The Pennsylvania Supreme Court has followed a landmark Federal ruling that voluntary confessions are inadmissible in evidence where suspects were not advised by the police of the right to a lawyer.

AFTER one of the longest and most durable careers in Hollywood (over 35 years and more than 80 movies) Barbara Stanwyck has finally achieved a long-cherished ambition -- to play the lead in a Western TV series.

THE Pennsylvania Turnpike, the first of the great modern toll routes, grows older and broader, and undoubtedly would grow longer if the state had elastic boundaries. But the toll rate that prevailed on opening day in 1940 has not grown by so much as a decimal.
The Union Pacific Railroad will start a piggy-back program by Dec. 1 that many other roads look at askance.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 16 -- The Administration has in formed Congressional leaders that President Johnson will veto the pending bill for a Government wage rise if the increase exceeds the Government's guideposts for noninflationary agreements, Vice President Humphrey disclosed today.

It is inevitable, I suppose, that in these days of moon shots and Moholes, we should be looking around for new worlds to conquer; but I wonder if we are quite ready for the conquest now being urged upon us by Secretary of Commerce John T. Connor.

MIWAUKEE, Oct. 16 (AP) -- A group of Roman Catholic priests and nuns rejected a Bishop's directive "with sorrow and regret" tonight and said they would aid a civil rights boycott of Milwaukee's public schools.

BRUSSELS -- If uncertainty is the enemy of prosperity, as most businessmen and many economists believe, then it is plain that the three-month-old Common Market crisis is doing no good for the economy of Western Europe.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Oct. 16 -- The Williams eleven rolled over Bowdoin today to score a 42-13 victory on Weston Field before an Alumni Day crowd of 6,500.
More than 10,000 demonstrators against the war in Vietnam marched down Fifth Avenue yesterday in a parade that drew jeers and sporadic violence from crowds of hecklers.

ROME, Oct. 16 -- Augustin Cardinal Bea, head of the Vatican's Secretariat for the Promotion of Christian Unity, warned today that Roman Catholicism must not appear to teach that the obligation of celibacy "flows from the very nature of the priesthood."
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 16 -- The mood and tone of the General Assembly of the United nations changed rapidly last week -- and not for the better.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 16 -- Harvard and Cornell played to a 3-3 tie today in a football game so dominated by the defense that neither team was able to penetrate inside the opponent's 20-yard line. It was the first draw in the history of this Ivy League rivalry.
Mrs. Robert F. Wagner, who has been pinch-hitting for her ailing husband, has imposed one condition in her job as substitute for the Mayor; no speeches.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Oct. 16 -- Student leaders from 63 colleges and universities indicated today general support of the Johnson Administration's Vietnam policy and mixed reaction to the demonstrations against it.

ROME, Oct. 16 -- Britain's senior Roman Catholic prelate said today that it was no bad thing to see priests "qui coniunctim pila ludunt" -- or, from the Ecumenical Council Latin, "who play golf together."

INTEREST in the uses of hollies for landscaping purposes continues to increase. With the great number of species and named varieties available, the gardener can choose from many different forms, fruiting habits and foliage textures for any possible ornamental use.

POSTMASTER General John A. Gronouski has had a change of heart. He has abandoned his recent regulation, by which no single order for less than $25 worth of stamps would be filled by the Philatelic Sales Unit, and restored the service, in effect since 1921, under which stamp collectors can order stamps in any amount.

Another of New York's largest department-store groups has decided to construct an additional floor on one of its existing branches. In itself, this is not particularly startling. But, when considered in light of the fact that only a few years ago the same branch was hardly earning its keep, after almost two years of existence, the significance of the decision becomes clear.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 17 (AP) -- A woman was shot to death today while she and a male companion tried to swim away from a kidnapper who stood on shore and reloaded his weapon, the police reported.

Members of the New York Chapter of the American-Scandinavian Foundation have arranged a theater party at Thursday evening's performance of "Iolanthe" at the Jan Hus Theater, 351 East 74th Street. But it is evidence that the Kremlin is interested in bolstering its prestige and presence in Asia.

CAMARIOCA, Cuba, Oct. 17 (UPI) -- Approximately 42 ships ranging from 14-foot homemade outboards to a former Coast Guard cutter jammed this tiny port today, ready to take hundreds of anxious Cubans to freedom in the United States.

TO THE vast astonishment and intense delight of those passionately devoted followers of the New York Football Giants, their heroes gave them a joyous coming-home party yesterday at Yankee Stadium. IN a status-struck society, there is something like a closet-upmanship, according to Thalbert Duncan, the well-traveled president of De Pinna who returned from a trip abroad last week. He says the international set's latest gambit in going one better is the wig closet.

THE MANDELBAUM GATE -- "hardly a gate at all, but a piece of street between Jerusalem and Jerusalem" -- is the single land checkpoint between Jordan and Israel, or what Jordanians call "occupied Palestine." The Gate is rigidly controlled from both sides; visas and baptismal certificates must be in order (no Jews can enter Jordan), and there is a strict limitation of those allowed through -- third-country diplomats, Christian pilgrims, few others.

Sammy Davis and the National Broadcasting Company are negotiating a television contract under which the entertainer would be the host of a one-hour weekly variety show, beginning early in 1966. It would be televised in color on Fridays at 8:30 P.M. as a replacement for "Convoy."
Members of New York Mailers Local 6 voted 208 to 22 last night to accept a new two-year contract with the Publishers Association of New York City.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 17 -- Mr. Cajun, a 2-year-old sorrel owned by the Sterling Farms of Reedsville, W. Va., won the quarter-horse conformation stallion championship today at the Pennsylvania National horse show.

Young physicians will be helped to finance the purchase of their office equipment in a plan devised to promote the renting of professional suites in a new medical arts building in Brooklyn's Bensonhurst district.

TWO familiar and popular figures at major bridge tournaments are Dr. Lois Wiley, a chiropractor of Oak Park, Ill., and her seeing-eye dog. Dr. Wiley has earned more than 600 master points, and is the only blind woman player ever to reach the rank of Life Master in the American Contract Bridge League.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 17 (UPI) -- The Cleveland Browns combined the pinpoint passing of Frank Ryan with an iron defense and three field goals by Lou Groza today for a 23-17 victory over the Dallas Cowboys.
Nicolai Gedda, tenor, as heard last night in recital at the Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum was a model of refined musicianship and near-perfect vocal control.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 17 -- The use of major surgery was described here today as a drastic, but reportedly effective way of losing weight.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Oscar Robertson and Jerry Lucas went on a scoring spree in the second half to give the Cincinnati Royals a 144-124 National Basketball Association victory over the Baltimore Bullets tonight.

SARDIS, W.Va., Oct. 17 (AP) -- One of seven coal miners trapped underground by a fire was found alive tonight but died before he reached a hospital. Rescue teams pressed on with their search but had found no sign of the six men still missing.

The portents by which political soothsayers make their judgments indicate that Controller Abraham D. Beame, the Democratic standard-bearer, is entering the homestretch of the mayoralty campaign slightly in the lead. But both camps acknowledge that Representative John V. Lindsay, his Republican-Liberal opponent, is pressing him strongly in the closest race in three decades.

ROME, Oct. 17 -- Pope Paul VI said today that he was praying for all non-Christians, "especially those who, deriving their beliefs from the father Abraham, have a spiritual kinship with our faith -- the Jews and also the Moslems."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- President Johnson is close to a decision on the first of a series of politically and diplomatically sensitive tariff cases.

GENEVA, Oct. 17 -- The trade gains of the developing countries in their commerce with the West in the last two years was more than offset by the losses they suffered in their dealings with the Communist bloc.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- President Johnson celebrated his 10th day of convalescence from gall bladder surgery today by dressing up for the first time.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Oct. 17 -- A calendar portraying President Joseph Kasavubu and former Premier Moise Tshombe warmly clasping hands hangs in an office in the Ministry of Information that is temporarily being used by the Congo's new Premier, Evariste Leon Kimba.

Heinz Hammerman, a pianist who has given several recitals here since his debut in 1955, returned to Town Hall late yesterday afternoon to play Beethoven, Schubert, Chopin, Liszt, Debussy, Scriabin and Rachmaninoff.

JERUSALEM, (Israeli Sector), Oct. 17 -- George Thomson, Minister of State in the British Foreign Office, assured Israel today that London's efforts for greater understanding with the Arabs would not be at Israel's expense.

A three-alarm fire at the New York Hilton Hotel forced more than 2,000 guests, most of them barefoot and in their nightclothes, to flee their rooms at 5:30 A.M. yesterday. Sleepy-eyed women with mink stoles over their nightgowns and men in their shorts stumbled from their rooms as dense smoke poured from air-conditioning ducts and the fire's heat spread through the 46-story structure on the Avenue of the Americas at 53d Street.

Voters on Nov. 2 will, besides acting on candidates for public office, say yes or no on nine proposed amendments to the New York State Constitution. One "question" and three "propositions" will also be on the ballot, making thirteen levers to pull, in all.
LONDON, Oct. 17 -- Prime Minister Wilson, who is not usually given to hand-wringing, said last week that in the Rhodesian crisis he felt he was living with "a nightmare."

Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts began yesterday a concert series called "Great Performers at Philharmonic Hall." The artist, appropriately, was Birgit Nilsson, one of the greatest dramatic sopranos of our time.

Red Sullivan's New York Rangers, who had been doing so well recently in their pre-season exhibition contests, had their unbeaten streak of eight snapped last night when they bowed to the Stanley Cup champion Montreal Canadiens, 4-2, at Madison Square Garden.
KANSAS CITY, Oct. 17 (UPI) -- The Buffalo Bills exploded for 20 points in the final period at the expense of Kansas City mistakes and scored a 23-7 American Football League victory today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17 -- Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach told a news conference here today that the Justice Department had started a national investigation of groups behind the antidraft movement.

Earl Morrall, the team's new quarterback, brought the big play back to Giant football yesterday and his three long touchdown passes were at the heart of New York's victory over the Philadelphia Eagles.
With this weekend's protests against the war in Vietnam ended, organizations opposing the war are turning their attention to a nationwide movement against the military draft.
BOGOTA, Columbia, Oct. 17 -- Sixteen persons were killed this morning when a Colombian Avianca DC-3 and a private light plane collided about 200 miles northwest of here.
Richard Szaro ran for a touchdown and kicked a 13-yard field goal and 2 extra points in St. Francis Prep's 23-8 victory over Cardinal Hayes at Boys High Field yesterday.
A NEW kind of fashion fireworks passed through United States Customs a few weeks ago in the trunks of Mila Schon, a Milan designer on her way to Texas to show her collection at Neiman-Marcus.
Municipal bond dealers face their busiest week in 11 years.

Affectionately, Mrs. Ethel Jacobs's great mare, will miss the $25,000-added Interborough Handicap today at Aqueduct. But Ballet Rose, who finished second to Affectionately in the race last year, will compete in the six-furlong test for fillies and mares along with seven other entrants.

LAS CRUCES, N.M., Oct. 17 -- Students are donating blood for Vietnam in a move apparently gaining momentum on the campus of New Mexico State University here. It is a countermove to action by groups protesting United States involvement in Vietnam.

DAVID OISTRAKH, doubling as conductor and violinist, cast a warm hand over the concert of the Moscow Philharmonic yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. It was his American debut as a conductor, and he showed many of the qualities that have made him beloved here as a soloist.
TORONTO, Oct. 17 -- Another Toronto finance company is being squeezed by the tight Canadian money market.
HONG KONG, Oct. 17 (UPI) -- A 49-year-old British missionary for the Jehovah's Witnesses arrived here today after seven years in a Chinese Communist prison on spy charges.

WHAT is wrong with Balanchine's "Swan Lake?" In one sense, nothing. In another sense, almost everything. It all depends what you want out of a "Swan Lake." Seen again on Saturday afternoon at the New York State Theater at Lincoln Center, with Mimi Paul as Odette/Odile, one wondered once more about the strange nature of this Balanchine production.

The American Civil Liberties Union announced yesterday that it had urged the United States Supreme Court to abandon its eight-year-old test of obscenity and declare that all published material is protected by the First Amendment unless it creates a "clear and present danger" of antisocial conduct.

The rivalry between Arkansas and Texas is taking its place among the classics of the college gridiron, along with such traditional favorites as the Army-Navy, Yale- Harvard, Notre Dame-Southern California and Michigan Minnesota games.
The Eastman Kodak Company reported yesterday the highest sales and earnings in its 85-year-history in the 12-week and 36-week period ended Sept. 5.
The Citizens Budget Commission, Inc., announced yesterday it favored a "yes" vote on Proposition No. 1 on water pollution, which will be on the Nov. 2 ballot.
PEREDELKINO, U.S.S.R., Oct. 17 -- The grave of the previous Russian winner of the Nobel Prize for Literature was lonely today.

The following is a supplementary list of over-the-counter stocks prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. It consists of securities less widely held or those that, for other reasons, do not appear on the daily Over-the-Counter list. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

ARLINGTON, Tex. -- The Greenhouse, Neiman-Marcus's $2 million answer to such beauty and health resorts as Elizabeth Arden's Maine Chance, has been open for less than a month. But it already has a long list of satisfied customers.
WARSAW, Oct. 17 -- Giuseppe Saragat, President of Italy, flew back to Rome today after a three day-visit that pleased his Communist hosts without antagonizing his country's Western allies.
Four appointments at the top-executive level have been announced by three leading ad agencies.
The 89th Congress, nearing the end of its first session, has been the best Congress since World War II.

Robert Moses, whose World's Fair closed yesterday, will begin a new career as columnist for Newsday, the Long Island newspaper, on Oct. 30, its editor and publisher Harry F. Guggenheim announced yesterday.

A recent letter to The Times suggests that our Constitution be altered to permit a maximum of one demonstrator to dramatize publicly social ills which affect a large segment of our society (and therefore all of it) so that respect for all laws he adhered to by all other people of similar sentiment pending juridical disposition of the grievances.

While no one can gainsay the vital importance of nuclear nonproliferation, there is concern in Germany over recent American proposals at the Geneva conference. These proposals may not only prove ineffective, but may -- if accepted -- irreparably damage the Western alliance upon which we all so much depend.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The Patent Office and its friends in and out of Government will start their busiest week of the year tomorrow. The proceedings will get under way, if all goes well, with a man flying by his belt above the Washington Monument grounds.
Did Jack L. Ruby, Dallas nightclub owner who killed Lee Harvey Oswald, President Kennedy's assassin, receive a fair trial? Was the penalty imposed -- death in the electric chair -- the right one?

HIGH POINT, N C., Oct 17 -- There will be no gilt ballroom chairs waiting for the buyers and reporters who gather in North Carolina tomorrow for what the furniture industry likes to think of as its fashion shows.
Coach Weeb Ewbank of the New York Jets didn't know yesterday whether to be happy or sad. He was a little of each.

The original building of Sailors Snug Harbor, on the north shore of Staten Island, still looks just about as it did when it opened its doors on Aug. 1, 1833. Others flanking it are in the same stately style -- "one of the most notable groups of Greek Revival buildings in the United States."
Three Thursday lectures will be given at the Cosmopolitan Club by the Council of Goodwill Industries to finance its training program for the handicapped.
The leaders of the antiwar demonstrations that took place Saturday throughout the country indicated yesterday that they were well-pleased with the results.
MARIRANGWE, Rhodesia, Oct. 17 -- For people supposed to be on the point of rebellion, the Rhodesians appeared to be remarkably at ease today.

MONTEREY, Calif., Oct. 17 -- Walter Hansgen of Bedminster, N.J., drove one of John Mecom Jr.'s Lola-Fords to victory today in the 200-mile Grand Prix of Monterey. The 46-year-old sports car driving expert from the East Coast was first in both the 100-mile heats.
YONKERS, Oct. 18 -- "For-deen, for-deen, for-deen. I got for-deen, for-deen," Laddie Dance droned.
MAMARONECK, N.Y., Oct. 10 -- Four boys from the fashionable Shore Acres section here were arrested today and charged with damaging the homes of several neighbors on vacation.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (UPI) -- Two Gemini astronauts will try to photograph the comet named Ikeya-Seki that scientists consider the most exciting solar-system visitor of the century.

As he has done every day for the last two months, Vito Battista, candidate for Mayor on Row G, drove his battered turquoise station wagon up to a curb yesterday, climbed onto the roof and declaimed to an empty sidewalk:
The National Steel Corporation added a twist yesterday to the spreading revision in prices of tinplated steel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) -- The Supreme Court rejected today an appeal by heirs of Al Capone, the Chicago gangster, on their complaint of invasion of privacy by the showing of a television series entitled "The Untouchables."

Without wishing to prolong an argument that could unnecessarily divide persons more in agreement than otherwise, it may be of use to note that in September the unemployment rate of white and nonwhite workers once again moved in opposite directions.
The Aluminum Company of America reported yesterday a marked improvement in third-quarter earnings.
A policeman was discharged yesterday because he fell asleep while on duty and in the process lost his hat.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Personal income surged by $13.3 billion in September to an annual rate of $545.3 billion with broader Social Security benefits and increased military pay accounting for most of the increase.
Mayor Wagner issued from his sick bed last night a philosophical appraisal of his 12 years at City Hall in which he said the city had become a model in many vital phases of municipal administration.

WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 18 -Westchester County Executive Edwin G. Michaelian and his aides were notified by the State Investigation Commission today that it had cleared them of alleged misconduct in the removal of earth fill from county-owned property in Yonkers.

The Latin-American Times, an English-language daily newspaper that began publication here on June 30, has suspended publication because of a "lack of funds," its publisher, Leonard Saffir, said yesterday.

HAYNEVILLE, Ala., Oct. 18 -- All but seven of 32 white men examined for jury duty today in the second trial of Collie Leroy Wilkins Jr. for the murder of Mrs. Viola Gregg Liuzzo described themselves as white supremacists.

PINEHURST, N.C. Oct. 18 (AP) -- David Goldman of Dallas shot a 65 today over Pinehurst Country Club's No. 2 course and took the first-round lead in qualifying for the 14th annual North and South invitation seniors golf championships.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 18 -The establishment of a halfway house to help rehabilitate an estimated total of 70,000 chronic alcoholics in Nassau County was unanimously endorsed today by the Board of Supervisors.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -"Who appears for Barbour County, Alabama?" intoned the hearing examiner today in a small room deep inside the main office building of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare. There was no response.
A two-year contract between the New York Typographical Union No. 6 and the Publishers Association of New York City was signed yesterday by officials of both sides. It is retroactive to March 31.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 18 -The Syrian regime of President Amin el-Hafez appeared today to be solidly in power after a week of reported problems and disagreements within the ruling Baath party.
LONDON, Oct. 18 -- Prime Minister Wilson tonight sent to Prime Minister Smith an "11th-hour" appeal not to declare the independence of Rhodesia illegally.

Earnings of the American Can Company in the three months ended Sept. 30 were the highest for any quarter on record. In addition, the nine-month profit topped any full year's earnings in Canco's history, William F. May, chairman and chief executive officer, reported in the financial statement issued yesterday.

" Secret Agent," the spy series that was a spring replacement this year on the Columbia Broadcasting System network, will become a winter replacement Dec. 4. It will be televised on Saturdays from 8:30 to 9:30 P.M. as a successor to "Trials of O'Brien," which moves to 10 P.M. Fridays.
The scheduled opening of a trial to determine liability for last Thanksgiving's collision between the Israeli luxury liner Shalom and the Norwegian tanker Stolt Dagali was delayed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- A bill to create a delegation of 18 "eminent Americans" to explore the possibility of transforming the North Atlantic Treaty Organization into a "Federal Union" was introduced in the Senate today.
One of the Beatles, Britain's mop-haired beat singers, was indirectly responsible yesterday for the enjoyment of Shakespeare.
" Our journals have been silenced," read a mimeographed flyer distributed anonymously by Brooklyn College students yesterday, as two teachers resigned as faculty advisers of two publications.
Princess Irina Youssoupoff denied yesterday that she had ever known Rasputin, the lecherous mystic who her husband says he assassinated in 1916 in the cellar of their Petrograd palace.

TWO plays of reminiscence opened last night at the Cherry Lane Theater. Both dealt with reminiscence, which is a polite way of saying exposition substituted for plot, and both were reminiscent, which is a polite way of saying that originality is hard to come by these days.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Led by President Johnson, official Washington erupted today with criticism of the nationwide demonstrations last weekend against the war in Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -Legislation loosening the application of the antitrust laws to bank mergers was apparently defeated for this session of the Congress when the House Banking Committee failed today to muster a quorum to consider the measure.

Winners of the 63d National Gold Medal Competition of the Architectural League of New York were announced yesterday as the league opened its exhibition at the United States Plywood Corporation's hall at 777 Third Avenue.
Walt Alston of the Los Angeles Dodgers was named the National League manager of the year yesterday by United Presss International.

If ferryboats had real hawse-pipes like freighters and liners, Capt. Harry E. Parker would be what seamen call a "hawse-pipe skipper". This is the way old mariners referred to the man on the bridge if he started as a fo'c'sle seaman and figuratively climbed through the anchor chain aperture or hawse-pipe to the rank of master.

WESTBURY, L.I, Oct 18 -- Armbro Flight, the filly who recently won the Kentucky Futurity at Lexington, Ky., will be among the starters in the $85,000 Dexter Cup for 3-year-old trotters on Nov. 10 at Roosevelt Raceway.

THE night after the World Series caravan winged into Los Angeles from the Twin Cities, the Baseball Writers Association of America made an unusual gesture. The press box tenants tossed a farewell dinner for a distinguished alumnus, Ford Christopher Frick. Supposedly he is about to retire as the Lined High Commissioner of baseball.
Two San Diego Charger football players, Bob Zeman and Walt Sweeney, were arrested here yesterday on a charge of felonious assault. They were released in $500 bail.

ANUMBER of college football coaches acted like members of a mutual admiration society yesterday, making things sound as if the losers were equal to the winners last weekend. The biggest surprise was Ben Schwartzwalder of Syracuse, who said, "That Penn State team may be the best team we've beaten in a long time.
The city received about 2.6 billion gallons of water during the weekend from the run-off of recent rains, the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity reported yesterday.

ROME, Oct. 18 -- The declaration of Roman Catholic respect for other world religions and denial of collective Jewish guilt for the Crucifixion will become official church teaching Oct. 28 with its promulgation by Pope Paul VI.
Steel production declined again last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

Twenty-five persons picketed the United States Court House at Foley Square from 5 to 6 P.M. yesterday in support of Mr. Miller. They distributed a leaflet saying that 10 of the pickets had "destroyed or returned" their draft cards.
Trading on the American Stock Exchange continued hectic yesterday as the turnover surpassed three million shares for the fourth consecutive session.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Oct. 18 -- Prime Minister Ian D. Smith rejected today a British proposal to send a team of Commonwealth Prime Ministers to Rhodesia to try to break the impasse over the country's demand for independence.

Two leading business publishers and statistical service organizations -- McGraw-Hill, Inc., and Standard Poor's -are planning to merge under a proposed exchange of stock involving more than $50 million.
The three men who stole the Star of India star sapphire and 23 other precious jewels from the American Museum of Natural History were flown to Miami yesterday to testify before a Federal grand jury.
ONE of the most effective liberating forces this country has known was a French nobleman called Rochambeau. Here is a superb portrait of him by Arnold Whitridge.

BRUCE HUNGERFORD may have changed his first name (it used to be Leonard) since he last played in this city, but in his recital last night he showed that he is still a fine pianist and a thoroughly equipped technician.
A holdup man shot and killed a manager of the Post and Coach Inn, a bar and restaurant in the Port Authority Bus Terminal at 41st Street and Eighth Avenue, at 5:30 P.M. yesterday.

TIMMY BROWN, the big-little halfback of the Philadelphia Eagles, thinks the New York Giants will beat the Cleveland Browns here this Sunday. That may be like believing Bill Buckley will become New York's next Mayor.
The New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx, plagued by increasing vandalism in the last year, will soon be patrolled by a trained guard dog.
Lehigh Valley Industries, Inc., a diversified manufacturing company, announced yesterday the election of Everett A. Sisson as president and chief executive officer.
Representative John V. Lindsay swung into an intensified campaign yesterday with the end of his five-month drive to capture City Hall only 15 days away.
ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 18 -- Tommy Eboli is out and Sammy Davis Jr. is in.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 18 (UPI) -- The four children of a former Kansas legislator were shot to death as they slept early today. Their 37-year-old mother was charged with first-degree murder.

Fun and frolic reigned supreme at the Pocket Theater last night as the Music Drama Workshop romped through its crackling new production of Francis Poulenc's 21-year-old opera-bouffe, "Les Mamelles de Tiresias," which states its theme bluntly and repeatedly:
SELMA, Ala., Oct. 18 (AP) -- An Alabama State Circuit Judge ruled today that the Federal Voting Rights Act of 1965 is unconstitutional.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -The prevalent theory of the Administration that price inflation can be kept within "manageable" limits by its present economic policies is being increasingly challenged by the facts.
ANKHE, South Vietnam -They sit like enormous grasshoppers on the top of a knoll, four of them, lined up along the edge of the largest heliport in the world.
ATLANTA, Oct. 18 (AP) -Gov. Carl Sanders said today he had asked the Attorney General's office to look into a possibility of revoking the charters of five Ku Klux Klan organizations in Georgia.

HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 18 -- The nation's two leading unions representing film directors announced their merger today, but six directors have filed suit challenging the loyalty oath requirement of the newly merged organization.
MANCHESTER, N.H., Oct. 18 -- A soft-voiced college graduate who says the draft is immoral was arrested today as the first person charged under the new Federal law banning draft card destruction.

The Lehman Corporation disclosed yesterday that it had made new investments in three life-insurance companies -- Aetna Life, Lincoln National Life and Connecticut General -- during the third quarter of 1965.
Mayor Wagner announced yesterday his expected endorsement of Controller Abraham D. Beame in the contest to succeed him.

NEW DELHI, Oct. 18 -- A serious split appears to have developed within the Kashmir self-determination movement. Radical elements are showing increasing dissatisfaction with the moderate leaders who have guided the movement in recent years.
DETROIT, Oct. 18 (AP) -Auto makers made liberal use of Saturday overtime last week as they stepped up production schedules to meet customer demand for 1966 cars.
ABOUT 10 years ago Countess Caterina Gilda Vincenza Gualtieri di Morrone bought some wool yarn in a shop in her native Turin and asked a woman with a knitting machine to make it into a sweater.

The Selective Service Act of 1948 provides that every person born after Aug. 30, 1922, must carry his draft card and his classification notice if he has one, or face the risk of arrest for failure to register.

A scientific study of a Planned Parenthood program offering contraceptive pills to 14,000 women in the Chicago area shows that 70 to 83 per cent continued to use them for 30 months without special encouragement.

Sandy Koufax, the man who has almost everything, picked up his new little sports car yesterday, parked it and flew right back to California to take part in an annual baseball players' golf tournament in Palm Springs.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The number of leaves that can fall onto a forty-foot square of earth is directly proportional to the plot owner's antipathy for yard work.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Oct. 18 -- President Joseph Kasavubu installed today the Government of Premier Evariste Kimba, the successor of Moise Tshombe.

ROGER VIVIER settled into the St. Regis Hotel last Saturday for the week's stay that visiting firemen from the French fashion world seem to consider de rigueur this fall. The gray-haired, blue-eyed Parisian who is considered one of the most influential shoe designers of the century has been resting, seeing friends and staring at women in the street.
ROME, Oct. 18 -- The Ecumenical Council is ready to move into the final stretch.

Eight young engineers and students in the United States and Canada have won the Daniel and Florence Guggenheim Fellowships for graduate study in jet propulsion, space flight sciences and flight structures, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -Ellsworth T. Bunker, the United States representative to the Organization of American States, expressed optimism today that the United States and Cuba would reach agreement this week on arrangements for orderly movement of Cuban refugees.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 18 -- Three United States Navy F-4 Phantom jets were shot down over North Vietnam yesterday, a military spokesman announced today.

American banks in London have begun tying their lending rates there to the cost of money, J. Howard Laeri, executive vice president of the First National City Bank, said yesterday. He predicted that in time the practice would spread to the United States and might supplant lending at rates tied to the prime rate.

Part of an article associating President Johnson with Robespierre, Mao Tse-tung, Fidel Castro and Prime Minister Henrik F. Verwoerd of South Africa has been removed from a mimeographed program of the Lincoln Center Repertory Theater.
The Rural Electrification Administration expects that it will have to provide about $225 million a year of new capital by 1975 in order to meet the needs of the rural telephone industry.
E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., continued to make impressive progress in all phases of its operations.
PINEVILLE, La., Oct. 18 (AP) -- Bud Cowdery of Birmingham, Ala., and Ted May of Azusa, Calif., each set two world outboard time-trial speed records on Lake Buhlow here today.
ALMOST without exception, the leading experts use an opening bid of two clubs to show hands of great power that can guarantee, or practically guarantee, a game contract.

On the 13th floor of 115 Broadway, where the brokerage firm of Shields Co. conducts its back-office operations, activity was only a bit more brisk than usual yesterday. Because of recent heavy trading, yesterday marked the establishment of an esoteric record for the New York Stock Exchange.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Oct. 18 -- The Communist leaders of the National Labor Convention are seeking a quick settlement of the convention's wage dispute with the Uruguayan Government.
A $2.9 million Brooklyn elementary school that was opened last month was damaged by teen-age vandals late Sunday night or early yesterday morning.

ON the seemingly far-fetched, assumption that someone somewhere needs an elephant ladder, a jack-in-the box desk, a collapsible what-not table, and a commode with a skinny, 57-inch-long drawer ideal for holding a family supply of umbrellas, Sloane's has doubled the size of its antiques department on the store's main floor.
LONDON, Oct. 18 -- A fire-breathing, six-legged dog will soon be transformed into an Esso oval in one of the biggest transactions in the oil industry here in recent years.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 18 -- Senator Edward V. Long castigated the Internal Revenue Service today for "lack of cooperation" with a Senate investigation into wiretapping.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) -- The Supreme Court refused today by a vote of 4 to 2 to reconsider its decision of May 17 rejecting California claims to vast submerged oil rights in the Pacific Ocean beyond the three-mile territorial limit.
" It is the public's interest which must prevail."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Passenger traffic on the domestic airlines rose almost 19 per cent in September from the level in the comparable period of 1964, the Air Transport Association said today.

Dr. Timothy W. Costello, the Republican-Liberal candidate for City Council President, charged yesterday that the issue of religion in the campaign had been introduced not by him but by William F. Buckley Jr., the Conservative candidate for Mayor.
The Jewish Child Care Association began a search yesterday for foster parents who are interested in adoption and are willing to take a chance.
HARTFORD, Oct. 18 -- The Connecticut Constitutional Convention approved an amendment today to comply with the one-man, one-vote ruling of the Supreme Court.

CRAWFORDVILLE, Ga., Oct. 18 (UPI) -- Authorities disclosed today the arrest of seven members of an armed Ku Klux Klan group known as the "Black Shirts," including two men acquitted in the night rider slaying of a Negro.
A Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that Mark Fein, the former executive serving 30 years to life for murdering his bookmaker, is "civilly dead" and cannot be sued by his victim's widow.
SINGAPORE, Oct. 18 -- The powerful Communist party in Indonesia was put under a ban tonight.
The British pound gained slightly yesterday in quiet dealings in foreign-exchange markets here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- A divided Administration united temporarily today behind a new statement of policy that endorsed arrangements by which West Germany would be able to "participate" in its nuclear defense without acquiring a national nuclear force.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 18 -- "Always keep in mind that a Smithie is looking at you not only as her date, but also as the man who may some day be footing the bills to send her daughter to Smith."

The principal and primary task of public leadership is not only to solve problems but to alert citizens to the urgent need to do so. Today, unless action is planned and executed, all great metropolitan areas will become virtually uninhabitable twenty-five years hence.

THE small blonde in hiphugger pants with an urchin's cap perched on her little-boy hairdo swaggered down the runway yesterday at a hairdressers' show and the audience thought she was one of the models. She wasn't.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Retired Supreme Court Justice Charles E. Whittaker has given up his disability pension to accept a legal position with the General Motors Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) -- The Navy is considering building about 20 big, fast military cargo ships that would be loaded with tanks, other heavy equipment and supplies and stationed near potential trouble spots.

MOSCOW, Oct. 18 -- Tens of thousands of Russian Jews, young and old, sang and danced in the streets outside Moscow's Central Synagogue tonight in celebration of the Jewish festival of Simchat Torah, the Day of Rejoicing in the Law.

" ABOUT New York, Night and Day: 1915-1965," is the promising title of a rather disappointing exhibition opening today at the Gallery of Modern Art on Columbus Circle, celebrating the 50th anniversary of the Women's City Club of New York, Inc.

Governor Rockefeller moved yesterday to invoke Federal action against air pollution from New Jersey. The Governor stressed that this pollution was believed to be "adversely affecting the health and welfare" of New Yorkers.

The Rev. Leo P. McLaughlin, the new president of Fordham University, announced yesterday an experimental program under which 40 to 50 students will be able to receive the bachelor's degree six years after they finish the seventh grade.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 18. -- Ten shops in miniature will make up the Christmas boutique that is being sponsored by the women's auxiliary of the Princeton Hospital on Nov. 2 and 3. Proceeds will aid the hospital's building fund.

On the world's most expensive patch of ice, the New York Rangers were honored yesterday by the city for getting through 40 years of hockey with their corporate teeth in place and for bringing "thrills and joy to the hearts of countless millions."

The Federal bench is a place of honor. A judge who sits there has to make decisions on the life or liberty of his fellow man, on disposition of property of enormous value, and of grave and often subtle constitutional issues.
HONG KONG, Oct. 18 -Communist China accused Indonesia today of condoning a wave of anti-Chinese activity
William A. "Pat" Patterson, head of United Air Lines, Inc., since its organization in 1934, has spoken a few times recently of his impending retirement at the age of 65.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) -- The Senate Finance Committee approved today a sugar quota bill considerably closer to President Johnson's recommendations than the version passed by the House.

BONN, Tuesday, Oct. 19 -- A dispute that had threatened to disrupt Chancellor Ludwig Erhard's coalition was settled early today, less than nine hours before the opening of the Bundestag, or lower house of Parliament.
Few pianists anywhere could sustain interest throughout the monumental program that Hans Helmut Schwarz chose for his American debut at Town Hall last night. Mr. Schwarz, alas, is not one of them.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The National Export Expansion Council began today an intensive study of three problems that some members of the council believe may be holding back American exports -- export credit, ocean freight-rate differentials and taxes.
BERLIN, Oct. 18 -- The horrors of Auschwitz will resound on the stages of 15 German theaters tomorrow when "The Investigation," a documentary play by Peter Weiss, has its premiere.
State Senator Wayne Dumont Jr. of New Jersey charged last night that the student teachins at Rutgers University were "part and parcel of an organized conspiracy to undermine our position in Vietnam."
The transfer of ownership of two major Manhattan properties through a trade exchange rather than an outright sale has been negotiated by Abbott Adams, brokers.

A champagne dinner dance will be held aboard the new Italian liner Raffaello on Nov. 3, for the benefit of Make New York Beautiful, Inc. The guests will board the ship after attending the benefit premiere showing of the movie "Juliet of the Spirits" at the R.K.O. 58th Street Theater.

The prosecution in the murder trial of Richard Robles charged yesterday that the 22-year-old youth had admitted "freely and voluntarily" to several police officers the 1963 slaying of Janice Wylie and Emily Hoffert.

Less than an hour after he had scoffed at warnings of a Negro revolt in Harlem, Representative Adam Clayton Powell had to call for the police yesterday to extricate himself and Abraham D. Beame, Democratic candidate for Mayor, from a small group of hecklers.
PORTSMOUTH, Va., Oct. 18 (AP) -- The disabled and crewless Liberian freighter Marlin is presumed to have sunk in heavy seas off the North Carolina coast, the Coast Guard said today.
PARIS, Oct. 18 (Reuters) -- The word "Scotch" means more than whisky to the French these days. It connotes a new fashion trend.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 18 -Skin testing of cancer patients might help identify those whose malignancies have spread throughout the body, a report given here today suggests.
Dallas awarded $16 million of bonds yesterday to an underwriting syndicate headed by Phelps, Fenn Co. and Shields Co.

ROME, Oct. 18 -- Eighty-one Roman Catholic laymen from 12 nations have petitioned the fathers of the Vatican Council to set up a post-council committee "to reconsider the present combination of pastoral duties with celibacy."

HAVING a facial -- the modern term is skin care -- is an electrifying process at Henri Bendel. During a one hour, $15 skin care session there, a woman's complexion is cajoled by at least two out of five machines.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The Administration hopes to withdraw a substantial part of the American military contingent in the Dominican Republic in the near future.

BIENHOA, South Vietnam, Oct. 17 -- On Saturday night in downtown Saigon, glasses and the voices of bar girls tinkle, waiters deftly scoop the meat from lobster tails, and blasts of music and stale air escape through night-club doors on Tudo Street.
JACKSON, Mich., Oct. 18 (UPI) -- Four convicts on a narcotics raid invaded the Southern Michigan Prison hospital today, took five hostages and barricaded themselves in a penthouse surgical suite.
Carl J. Weinhardt Jr., director of New York's newest museum, the Gallery of Modern Art, is resigning for "personal reasons," it was learned yesterday.
The municipal bond market began yesterday its second most active week in history, and the early results were inconclusive.

CLARKSBURG, W. Va., Oct. 18 (UPI) -- Spurred by directions scribbled in chalk, rescue workers struggled through a smoke-filled coal mine today only to find the bodies of six miners who had died when their supply of fresh air gave out.

Through conversations with friends it has come to my attention that there is a groundswell of sentiment for voting for William Buckley for Mayor as a protest. Apparently a significant percentage of jaded New Yorkers are entranced by Mr. Buckley's wit, candor and sincerity, while by no means favoring his position.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 (AP) -- The Borg-Warner Corporation reported today earnings of $6,653,000, or 71 cents a share, for the three months ended Sept. 30, compared with $6,962,000, or 74 cents a share, for the period last year.

GALVESTON, Tex., Oct. 17 -- Adm. Ralph E. Wilson (retired) criticized Maritime Administrator Nicholas Johnson today for what he termed the administrator's "landlubber approach" to maritime problems. Mr. Wilson made the attack in a speech as he turned over the presidency of the Propeller Club of the United States to Edward D. Vickey, a Houston admiralty lawyer.

ST. STEPHEN, N.B., Oct. 18 -- One impressed writer called him "The Stranger From the North," but he's really not. He's a solid citizen who travels widely and he's known by more than two score names, many of which have a flavor of antiquity and are passing into disuse.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- The United States said today that there was hope for an agreement with the Soviet Union on a treaty to stop the spread of nuclear weapons.
BOGALUSA, La., Oct. 18 (AP) -- A band of Bogalusa Negroes, most of them school-age youths, broke a two-month lull in demonstrations today and marched through the city streets.
The World's Fair yesterday was like a nightclub the morning after the wildest kind of New Year's Eve party.
Reports were being circulated yesterday that Mayor Wagner was seeking to be the man to succeed Ford Frick as baseball commissioner when Frick retires on Dec. 31.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs said today several problems would have to be solved before any agreement could be reached on the creation of a new international reserve asset to supplement gold, dollars and pounds.
Ian H. Wilson's long letter published Oct. 13 opposing the union shop is short on logic.

PUT a conservatively dressed man on a ski slope, sailboat, surfboard or golf course and he will leave his drab, button-down cocoon and appear in an uninhibited splash of color. This was the message delivered yesterday in song and patter to more than 500 members and guests of the National Association of Men's Sportswear Buyers at the New Yorker Hotel.
School volunteers were urged yesterday to take on a new assignment in the campaign against poverty -- helping to train the poor for paying jobs as school aides.

ALBEMARLE, N.C., Oct. 15 -- Labor and management militancy and a bitter two-week strike at the big carpet mill here have plunged this small city deeply and unwillingly into the renewed union struggle in the southern textile industry.
MOSCOW, Oct. 18 -- A Moscow literary critic suspected of having published clandestine anti-Soviet works abroad has been arrested, according to usually reliable sources.
LONDON, Oct. 18 -- The heir to the British throne, Prince Charles, who is almost 17, is to spend a term at a school noted for its physical toughness, in the Australian bush country.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art has begun a new series of period rooms, some to reflect the reign of Louis XV and one the Renaissance in Switzerland.

Individuals, philanthropic foundations and labor unions have contributed about $660,000 for the construction of an addition to Gracie Mansion, the Mayor's residence, but $140,000 is still needed to complete the $800,000 project.

Copper futures managed to surprise some metals experts again yesterday by setting life-of-contract highs. In recent weeks futures prices have been setting new highs so regularly as to lead traders to wonder how long they could continue to move up.
The stock market put on its strongest performance in many weeks yesterday with many issures scoring sizable advances on heavy volume.
BRUSSELS, Oct. 18 -- The Chase Manhattan Bank of New York has been exploring the possibility of making a major investment in a Belgian bank.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -"Ku Kluxing," Robert M. Shelton Jr. said recently, "is my entire dedication."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Francis X. Morrissey's prospects for Senate confirmation as a Federal judge improved today as a report by the Federal Bureau of Investigation supported his testimony about his early legal studies in Georgia.

The recent demonstrations in New York and other cities calling for United States withdrawal from Vietnam have stirred understandable anger among many who believe that their chief effect will be to encourage Peking and Hanoi in resisting a negotiated peace. Out of that anger have come demands for investigations and for prosecution of the demonstrators as "traitors."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) -- The Communications Satellite Corporation proposed today to buy four super Early Bird satellites from the Hughes Aircraft Company of Culver City, Calif., for about $11,730,000.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -Scientists told in glowing and sometimes envious terms today of contributions that astronauts had made to man's knowledge.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 18 -- Premier Nguyen Cao Ky has given assurances to soldiers and their families that bureaucratic delays in paying death benefits to survivors will be corrected within 30 days.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 -- Students for a Democratic Society drafted today a new master plan to enlist high school students in its antidraft movement opposed to United States participation in the Vietnam war.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) -- The Supreme Court overturned today a contempt judgment against the First Security National Bank and Trust Company of Lexington, Ky., and its executive officers and directors.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 18 -- Kathy Kusner rode two perfect rounds in the international jumping event at the Pennsylvania National Horse Show tonight and won the 28th Infantry Division Trophy before a crowd of 4,000.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange sagged yesterday as buyers displayed reserve in the face of the continuing political crisis in Rhodesia.
