BROOKVILLE, L.I., Oct. 18 -- Fred Annon of Ridgeway scored a three-under-par 69 today to lead a field of 84 players in the qualifying round of the Long Island Metropolitan Golf Association pro-pro championships.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 18 (AP) -- An ecclesiastical controversy, bubbled within a civil rights crisis today as Roman Catholic priests and nuns publicly supported a boycott to protest alleged racial imbalance in this city's public schools.
The negotiated public offering of $40 million of Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company debentures is expected to be made today at a yield of 4.78 per cent.

Ballet Rose tripped the light fantastic to victory in the Interborough at Aqueduct yesterday, winning the six-furlong contest by four lengths. Braulio Baeza kept the Templeton Stables' representative in front all the way in the 44th running of the handicap for older fillies and she encountered no opposition to speak of in registering her triumph.

THE long-cherished dream of educational station WNDT to be able to offer drama came true last night under the happiest of circumstances. The New York Television Theater made its bow with Jack Richardson's hilarious "Gallows Humor."
Following is the text of Mayor Wagner's endorsement yesterday of Abraham D. Beame, the Democratic candidate for Mayor:

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Oct. 18 -- The Dominican Army moved tanks into this city's port area tonight after several hours of intermittent waterfront fighting during which an anti-Communist labor leader was killed and at least three persons were critically wounded.
DETROIT, Oct. 18 -- Some 6,000 local units of the United States Jaycees will disclose the names of "leftist" supporters of the peace movement, the organization said here today.

Paul Robeson, the Negro actor who found fame singing "Ol' Man River" and playing "Emperor Jones" on Broadway before embracing Communism, was found lying in a semi-conscious condition Saturday in a vacant uptown lot.

On two of the nine proposed amendments to the New York State Constitution that will be on the ballot Nov. 2, The Times advises a "no" vote. These, as we indicated yesterday in briefly discussing all the amendments, are Nos. 3 and 6.

Presbyterian officials said yesterday that the name of the Rev. Dr. Stuart Hamilton Merriam would be "erased from the roll of Presbyterian ministers" as a result of his letter of resignation from the denomination.
DALLAS, Oct. 18 (AP) -- District Judge Louis T. Holland granted today a defense motion for a postponement of a sanity hearing for Jack Ruby, killer of President Kennedy's assassin.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The Treasury bill rate rose substantially at today's auction after a drop last week, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
Following are attendance figures for the World's Fair and for individual pavilions for the two seasons:
Eight National Leaguers were named yesterday to the 10-man major league all-star team in the annual Associated Press poll.
The prospect that the Federal and State Pavilions may escape the wrecker's ball, which is already swinging at the World's Fair, was reported yesterday to be good.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- President Johnson took a half-hour stroll outdoors today, and his press secretary said later that the President had told him the walk had "tired him very greatly."
A man described as a quiet Bronx father of four was arrested yesterday morning as a soldier who more than 20 years ago deserted from an Army base in Massachusetts.
Britain's Princess Margaret and her husband, the Earl of Snowdon, will be dinner guests of President and Mrs. Johnson on Nov. 17, marking the high point of the couple's 20-day tour of this country.
Reports of the arrest of Andrei D. Sinyavsky may presage the beginning of a new drive against the liberal wing of the Soviet intelligentsia, some observers here suggested yesterday.

Federal District Court Judge Edmund L. Palmieri set Dec. 6 as the trial date in Paramount Pictures Corporation's antitrust suit against dissenting directors of the company, Herbert J. Siegel and Ernest H. Martin.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 19 -- A portion of the assets of Rose Marie Reid, the once-prosperous company that discontinued manufacturing last month, was sold under an auctioneer's gavel here today. Manufacturing equipment and office furniture owned by the swimsuit maker were sold in a 20-hour session.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Robert M. Shelton Jr., Imperial Wizard of the largest Ku Klux Klan organization in the nation, refused today to produce his records and to answer 73 questions put to him by the House Committee on Un-American Activities.
Girls' schools in the East showed more apathy than anger yesterday to a new "inside guide" to women's colleges written by Princeton students.

LINDENHURST, L.I., Oct. 19 -- The body of a strangled 15-year-old girl was found in an abandoned excavation near her home at 101 South Travis Street here this morning. The girl, Ann (Cookie) Rudolphi, a junior high school student, disappeared last night.

The heat generated over Yale's 1440 map must be amusing to anyone of balanced mentality. All reasonable men recognize Columbus as the discoverer of America on the same basis that Fulton is recognized as the in ventor of the steamboat.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- A bipartisan group of members of the House Banking Committee -- who may or may not have constituted a majority -- held a special committee session today and approved legislation liberalizing the application of the antitrust laws to banks.
Bon Nouvel's scheduled attempt to make steeplechasing history at Aqueduct yesterday never got off the ground.
JACKSON, Miss., Oct. 19 (UPI) -- The Freedom Democratic party asked a Federal court today to order reapportionment of the Mississippi Legislature and the state's Congressional districts.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- The owners of the 20 major league clubs met today to elect a successor to Ford Frick as commissioner of baseball, but indicated they were having as much difficulty as some of their employes had last season swinging against Sandy Koufax.

Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., has become the first company primarily engaged in the distilled spirits industry to pass the $1 billion sales mark, it was announced yesterday by Samuel Bronfman, president of the Montreal-based concern.
Supreme Court Justice Walter R. Hart of Brooklyn is suing the Cunard Steamship Company for $300,000, because, he charges, he was poisoned by food during a voyage on the Mauretania last summer.

Two steel manufacturers reported a decline in earnings for the third quarter of 1965 yesterday, attributing the drop to increased labor costs and a reduction in shipments following the labor settlement on Sept. 3.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 19 -- The Secretary General U Thant, warned today that the cease-fire between India and Pakistan must be considered "precarious."
A comprehensive plan to maintain labor - management peace here was proposed yesterday by Theodore W. Kheel, the city's chief mediator of labor-management disputes.
The American President Lines, one of the major subsidized steamship companies, announced yesterday that it had applied to the Maritime Administration to build four, large bulk-carrier ships.

Net earnings of the Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company in the third quarter this year declined to $4,448,164 from $5,008,374 in the three months of 1964. The report yesterday also showed a drop for the first nine months to $24,149,946, or $2.29 at share, from $26,610,518, or $2.54 a share, in the period last year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The State Department will announce tomorrow that the United States plans to denounce a 36-year-old treaty limiting the amount of an airline's liability to passengers, unless the carriers waive the limits in favor of a far higher figure.

The New York Giants have established new heroes this season, for example Earl Morrall, Tucker Frederickson, Spider Lockhart and very lately Homer Jones. There is another, Jerry Hillebrand, and he might be called a re-established hero.

PINEHURST, N.C., Oct. 19 (UPI) -- David Goldman of Dallas, Tex., became the medalist and set a 36-hole qualifying record of 133 today in the 14th North and South senior golf championship at the Pinehurst Country Club.

A KING-SIZE inscribed rosewood cigarette box is on Mildred Custin's classic mahogany desk today. It is the first award accepted by the dulcet-voiced, chain-smoking executive since her appointment nine months ago as president of Bonwit Teller, New York.

Nothing suits Russian artists so well as Tchaikovsky. Since that composer figured throughout the first half of the Moscow Philharmonic Orchestra's program in Carnegie Hall last night, there was a good deal of electricity in the air.

CAIRO, Oct. 19 -- Kamal Eddin Hussein, long-time intimate associate of President Gamal Abdel Nasser and one of the United Arab Republic's Vice Presidents only 19 months ago, has been placed under arrest, usually reliable sources said today.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 19 (AP) -- A New York surgeon said today that a growing but still small number of internal injuries were being traced to automobile seat belts. He stressed, however, that these injuries were "a small price to pay for the lite-saving powers of the belts."

Columbia University announced yesterday the award of its $1,000 Brevoort-Eickemayer Prize for 1965 to Edwin Dickinson. The painter's long career will be honored, beginning today, with a retrospective exhibition at the Whitney Museum of American Art.

WASHINGTON, Ga., Oct. 19 (UPI) -- Superior Court Judge Robert Stephens ordered civil rights demonstrators today not to interfere with classes at a Negro school here. However a rights leader said the order would be ignored.
A State Senator who is a leader in the mayoral campaign of Abraham D. Beame was accused yesterday of having reneged on a promise to get the candidate to support a Greenwich Village housing plan.
WASHINGTON, Oct 19 (AP) -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today President Johnson's nominations of four ambassadors.

I am in complete agreement with the sentiment expressed in the Oct. 15 news article of Douglas Robinson and Clayton Knowles on the nurse shortage in city institutions. The nurses employed by the Bureau of Nursing in the New York City Department of Health are in a similar plight.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The United States is putting a new cover on its magazine Amerika to be distributed in the Soviet Union for October because the original was not acceptable to Moscow.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Oct. 19 -- Dominican Army troops and tanks advanced into the downtown area today in heavy block-to-block fighting against extreme leftists.
The president and the chairman of Time, Inc., were in sunny Southern California yesterday, and painted a very sunny picture of the company's corporate growth.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The latest sign in the worldwide "Leave-It-to-Uncle Sam" movement comes from Britain, where the Conservatives are talking about reducing or abandoning Britain's military commitments east of Suez.
The conviction of Mark A. Fein, 34-year-old former Park Avenue executive, of the second-degree murder of his bookmaker was unanimously upheld by the Appellate Division yesterday.

The priority that the Johnson Administration is placing on eliminating the outflow of dollars poses a new test for its relations with businessmen. While Washington and the business community have been getting along famously, thanks to the continuation of economic expansion, the course of their true love may be in for rougher going if Washington decides that fresh action is necessary to stem the dollar outflow.
ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Oct. 19 -- A meeting of the Village Board ended abruptly last night with shouting, protests and the arrest of a village official on a charge of slapping a Negro woman.

A citizens group charged yesterday that prescription drug pricing here is so unfair and mystifying that the public often pays a high price when the identical drug is available at a fraction of the cost.
Customers' net debit balances, which show the borrowings of individual investors on margin, rose by $108 million during September, the New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 19 -- The United States Embassy said today that Laszlo Szabo, Second Secretary of the Hungarian Embassy here, who disappeared last Saturday, applied yesterday for political asylum in the United States.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 19 -- The shocks are still reverberating from Yugoslavia's latest economic reform.
The Russian prince who assassinated Rasputin, the powerful "mad monk" at the court of Czar Nicholas II, derided his victim as a religious impostor before a jury here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The Senate today postponed action until probably tomorrow on the controversial nomination of Francis X. Morrissey to be a Federal District judge.
The Magnavox Company announced yesterday an increase of 5 to 8 per cent on about one-fourth of its color-television receiver models.
The Ogden Corporation has announced the election of Robert DiGia as controller. Mr. DiGia formerly was a principal with Haskins Sells.
More than $100 million of tax-exempt bonds were sold at competitive bidding yesterday, and investors appeared slow to come in to buy them.

YONKERS, Oct. 19 -- All Aflame, a 3-year-old Blaze Hanover trotter, and Red Carpet, a 4-year-old Shadow Wave pacer, brought the two top prices today at the second afternoon of the Old Glory Sale at Yonkers raceway.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 19 -- Tex Tankersley's all-weather thermoplastic race track, installed for the current harness racing meeting at Roosevelt Raceway at a cost of approximately $250,000, has proved skiddy, slow and unpopular with a majority of owners, trainers and drivers.
National Airlines, Inc., reported yesterday record net income of $3,799,000 for the three months ended Sept. 30, its first fiscal quarter, for a gain of 93 per cent over the level in the 1964 period.
Reversing Monday's pattern, prices of most stocks on the American Stock Exchange declined in very active trading.
BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 19 -- Tougher controls on anti- Vietnam demonstrations originating on the University of California campus here appear, in prospect.
The Department of Parks lost another round yesterday in its perennial struggle with poets and musicians in Washington Square Park.
The Carnegle Recital Hall at 9 o'clock on a Tuesday morning is not the most exciting place in the world -- unless your future depends on what is about to happen there.

A letter from Howard G. Crane published in the Oct. 15 edition of The Times suggested that the 1949 Geneva Convention for the Protection of Prisoners of War did not apply to Americans captured in North Vietnam, since a state of war did not exist between the United States and North Vietnam.
The tiny Paris Review will lend its literary luster to a new line of books published by Doubleday Company, the counary's largest book publishers.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 19 -- The new Minister of Justice, Juracy Magalhaes, asked today that "all revolutionaries of goodwill" unite around the Government "for the salvation of democracy" in Brazil.

Perhaps no ballet company in the world could provide such a diverse program as the New York City Ballet offered at the State Theater at Lincoln Center last night with "Harlequinade" and "Episodes." Certainly one cannot think of a choreographer other than Balanchine who could embrace with such certainty the very opposing muses of Riccardo Drigo on the one hand, and Anton Webern on the all-so-different other.

MOSCOW, Oct. 19 -- The subtle truce between the post-Khrushchev leadership and the rising generation of politically unorthodox Russian writers and artists has gone through a period of trial in the last two months.
A 30-story blockfront skyscraper is to be erected on the south side of John Street, between Pearl and Water Streets, in the downtown financial district.

So now the United States Jaycees, some 250,000 strong, plan to mount their chargers and gallop off in all directions to hunt down and expose "leftists" among American "peace" demonstrators. President James A. Skidmore Jr. promises that the Jaycees -- formerly called the Junior Chamber of Commerce -- will work "as closely as possible with the local police and the Federal Bureau of Investigation."

Chocolate bars should be bigger and possibly less expensive because of continued low cocoa-bean prices, according to a forecast made yesterday by a study group of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The present decision by the In dian Government not to build an atomic bomb was not expected to reduce the Johnson Administrations sense of urgency in obtaining a treaty to prevent the spread of atomic weapons.
The small-apparel merchant is seeking to hold on to an affluent, more sophisticated customer amid growing competition and retail giants.

The Argentine horses that will compete at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden starting next Tuesday were expected to arrive in Savannah, Ga., by freighter today or tomorrow, Walter B. Devereux, the show's president, said yesterday.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 19 -- The Rhode Island Pilotage Commission has raised pilotage rates by $1 a draft foot and minimum charges by up to $34. These rates apply to foreign and United States flag vessels that come under state pilotage laws.
United States Lines will join other subsidized American steamship companies seeking to diversify their activities, William B. Rand, president, announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- Major league baseball awarded the National Broadcasting Company a $30.6 million contract today to continue televising the World Series and All-Star Game for two years and to carry a "game of the week" for three years.

The combined sales of the European Common Market's 100 largest industrial concerns rose 10.9 per cent in 1964, compared with a gain of 7.8 per cent in 1963. The result is given in the latest Report on Western Europe, issued every two months by the Chase Manhattan Bank.
HONG KONG, Oct. 19 -- Asian Communists say they are "profoundly thankful" for the series of demonstrations in the United States against the American military effort in Vietnam.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Oct. 19 -- A flash revolt against the King of the new Central African nation of Burundi apparently has been crushed, reports from its capital said tonight, but the Premier was reported to be near death from wounds.

LAUREL, Md. Oct. 19 (AP) -- Undefeated Mocassin arrived at Laurel Race Course early today with designs on adding the Selima Stakes on Saturday to her credentials for the 2-year-old filly championship of 1965.

The formidable Mr. Dupee -- formidable because his tastes and experiences in letters are so catholic -- has few equals as a literary critic who is eminently readable. The pieces he has collected under a catchy title are mostly undisguised reviews, brief but encompassing, more often judicious than eloquent in their appraisals of winters past and present.
WASHINGTON, Oct, 19 -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that Communists were seeking to exploit recent demonstrations against American involvement in Vietnam.

HIGH POINT, N.C., Oct. 19 -- The push-button gadgetry of the space-and-spy era has inspired the furniture-makers who are showing designs to buyers and reporters at the North Carolina furniture markets.
NEW DELHI, Oct. 19 -- Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri said today that India would not build a nuclear bomb despite growing pressures here to do so.
Both independent and Bell System telephone companies outlined plans yesterday for continuing the fight against the inroads of unauthorized foreign attachments" to existing telephone lines.

The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation set records in revenues, sales and net income for the three and nine months ended Sept. 30. Donald C. Power, chairman and chief executive officer, reported yesterday.
Representative John V. Lindsay promised yesterday that if he was elected Mayor he would begin a 13-point program to ease the physical and psychological burdens of the city's elderly residents.
A matching collection of swim wear and surfboards was shown yesterday at the office of McGregor-Doniger, Inc., a men's sportswear manufacturer.

Three young women described to a Manhattan jury yesterday their conversations with Janice Wylie and Emily Hoffert on Aug. 28, 1963, the day the two women were found slain in their East Side apartment.

MONTEREY, Calif., Oct. 19 -- Walter Hansgen's victory here last Sunday in John Mecom Jr.'s Lola-Ford produced significant firsts for both car and driver. It was the first time in six years of trying that Hansgen had finished in front in the 200-mile, two-heat Monterey Grand Prix.
Frederick Zissu, chairman of Vornado, Inc., told the New York Society of Security Analysts yesterday that a "private foreign investor" had purchased and exercised a warrant for 42,000 common shares.

" Scroll of Agony: The Warsaw Diary of Chaim A. Kaplan," translated and edited by Abraham I. Katsh, will be published by Macmillan on Nov. 1. The title comes from the diary of a noted Hebrew scholar. He wrote this entry: "I will write a scroll of agony in order to remember the past in the future."

OLD BROOKVILLE, L.I., Oct. 19 -- Fred Annon of Ridgeway and his partner, Tony Morosco of Bel-Aire, led the field in the second round of the Metropolitan Professional Golf Association pro-pro match play championship tournament today by defeating Tom Devine of Seawane and Bill Schaaf of Silver Mine on the 20th hole at the Cedar Brook Golf Club.

THE tall, kindly white-haired woman with spectacles can still remember the days when people thought that the education of women was a waste of time. "My answer used to be that it was cheaper to educate a few women than to build a battleship," says Dr. Helen Brooke Taussig, "and a lot more profitable to the country."
The East River Savings Bank announced yesterday the election as a trustee of Alfred C. Middlebrook, senior vice president in charge of security investments.

As could have been predicted, Representative Adam Clayton Powell expressed his support for Abraham Beame for Mayor in the crassest and most demagogic terms. There are ethnic and religious undertones in most political campaigns; but leave it to Mr. Powell to argue that "it is time for New York to prove we can elect a Jew as Mayor."
I read with distress and alarm your headline news on Oct. 17, regarding the heckling and violence which accompanied the demonstrations for peace taking place in New York and elsewhere.

William F. Buckley Jr., Conservative party candidate for Mayor, said yesterday that he would file a detailed complaint against Representative John V. Lindsay with the Fair Campaign Practices Committee.

Macy's New York has acquired a 94-acre site straddling the boundary of Smithtown and Brookhaven, L.I. on which it will build a full-line department store. The announcement of the new Nesconset Shopping Center was made by David L. Yunich, president of Macy's New York.
GENEVA, Oct. 19 -- The United States formally asked its trading partners today for permission to break the first rule of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

WHAT an old-fashioned thing for Michael Dyne to do! In "The Right Honourable Gentleman" he has written a straightforward, realistic play with an interesting beginning, a logical, well-developed middle and a touching end.
E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. plans to raise capital in Europe through the sale of a bond issue denominated in West German marks equivalent to about $25 million.

James Miltenberger, the pianist who made his local debut in Carnegie Recital Hall last night, proved before he sat down to perform that he was not just another member of the piano-playing fraternity. This he did by letting it be known in advance that his program would consist entirely of 20th-century music.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 19 -- The latest mystery in a city already filled with mystery is who did what to the Chinese Communist Commercial Center in Jakarta.

VIENNA, Oct. 19 -- Broadway numbers were turned into arias tonight on the revolving stage of the Vienna Volksoper as "Porgy and Bess" was introduced to the Viennese public. It was presented as George Gershwin wanted it to be almost 30 year ago -- as a pure traffic opera with stylized Negro jazz elements.
" I don't, I don't, I don't" said Emile Griffith, the welterweight champion, giggling. "I really don't know what color it is. Hey, Gil."

The Travelers Aid Society ended its two-year celebration of 60 years of service here with the Diamond Jubilee Ball last night at the New York Yacht Club. Two hundred guests dined and danced in the club's historic headquarters at 37 West 44th Street, which were opened for a charity event for the first time in many years.
Some city-supported museums will be kept open every night except Sunday this winter, Robert W. Dowling, the city's cultural executive, said yesterday.
Now that new steel columns are popping up all over the big construction project at Pennsylvania Station, the view has become spectacular for tire dust-covered, noise-ridden passengers and employes.
The executive council of the United Church of Christ opposed unequivocally yesterday the organized effort to induce young men to escape the draft.
The Swedish American Line announced yesterday that Capt. Per-Erik Sjolin has been given command of the company's new 25,700-ton passenger liner Kungsholm.

LISTENING to the Juilliard String Quartet last night at Hunter College was almost like rediscovering music. There was the absolute of the four strings, skillfully played, in three wonderful pieces of music, and the sheer emphasis on form and content, purged of dross, every idea set forth with clarity and beauty.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 19 -- The Fibreboard Paper Products Corporation fought today for a preliminary injunction against an acquisition effort of the Evans Products Company. If granted, the injunction might be in effect for at least a year before a trial of Fibreboard's antitrust suit could be concluded.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 19 -- Elisa Fernandez of Mexico, the youngest rider in the field, stopped the streak of United States victories in international jumping tonight at the Pennsylvania National Horse Show, but the men riders in the field were still without a victory.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Theodore C. Sorensen, former counsel to President Kennedy, may join the former Washington law firm of Associate Justice Abe Fortas of the Supreme Court.

The Buildings Department issued a permit yesterday authorizing the Peninsula General Hospital to build a landing area for helicopter ambulances on its property, about 100 feet from its emergency room entrance.

A new club -- it's strictly promotional -- is being organized for the express purpose of getting millions of American husbands away from TV sets and returning them to their families on Sunday afternoons during the months of October, November and December.

VANCOUVER, B.C., Oct. 19 -- The national ambitions of two smaller parties that originated in western Canada are standing in the way of the establishment of a majority government through the present election campaign.

" A WELL-WRITTEN life is almost as rare as a well-spent one." When Thomas Carlyle dropped this remark in 1827 the number of well-written biographies was small indeed. Whether Carlyle's own biographies of Cromwell and Frederick the Great belong among them is doubtful. But today the state of biography is much healthier and every year a number of good biographies are published.

BOGALUSA, La., Oct. 19 (UPI) -- A State District Judge issued a temporary restraining order today designed to end student boycotts at four Negro schools here. The order came after students stayed away from classes for the second day in a row.

HONG KONG, Oct. 19 (UPI) -- Morris R. Wills, one of 21 American G.I.'s who elected to stay in Communist China after the Korean war, refused to comment today after having crossed over from Chinese territory.
The Koppers Company, a Pittsburgh producer of tar products and wood-preserving chemicals, announced yesterday the election of Andrew W. Mathieson as a director.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Oct. 19 -- President Joseph Kasavubu flew to Accra, Ghana, today for the heads-of-state conference of the Organization of African Unity.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- President Johnson navigated a mile and a half of parking lots, sidewalks and driveways at Bethesda Naval Hospital today. It was his third stroll in as many days and, from the President's point of view, the most successful and least tiring.
Motor scooters used by the police in Central and Prospect Parks will be tested to determine their value on street patrol, Commissioner Vincent L. Broderick said yesterday.

Defying Harlem leaders who warned against "inflammatory" statements, Livingston L. Wingate Jr. repeated yesterday his admonition that the youth of Harlem would rise in violent revolt if anything happened to Haryou-Act, the Harlem anti-poverty program he administers.

At Princeton Airport early this year, the bulldozers and construction crews moved in and ripped up the field. But instead of putting up a housing project or a shopping center -- a fate that has overtaken many an airport in this country -- the builders redesigned and transformed the field.

The Black Arts Repertory Theater School, a half-dozen of whose members were accused of taunting and threatening Representative Adam Clayton Powell and Controller Abraham D. Beame on a Harlem street on Monday, received $44,000 from Haryou-Act this summer to put on "cultural field demonstrations."

CINCINNATI, Oct. 19 (UPI) -- Paul Neumann sank a 20-foot field goal with nine seconds left in the game tonight that gave the San Francisco Warriors a 100-99 National Basketball Association victory over the Cincinnati Royals.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The Peace Corps is seeking more young people with a high degree of political and intellectual motivation, a top official of the agency said today.

ST. STEPHEN, N.B., Oct. 19 -- A fairly well-kept outdoor type hanging around George Welock's Loon Bay Lodge for the bird-shooting peered thoughtfully into his malted the other night and unburdened himself to a sympathetic listener.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- President Johnson's controversial new program of rent subsidies for some poor families won a respite in the Senate today, but its chances of survival in the waning hours of Congress appear doubtful.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Senator Mike Mansfield, the Democratic leader, denounced today the unidentified Government officials responsible for recent newspaper articles giving the impression that the United States would seek a policy of total military victory in Vietnam.

The Presbyterian Church in New York City declared yesterday that a political "change is needed in the city." The church charged that "a lack of imagination and vigor has crippled City Hall in administering the affairs of the greatest urban center in the world."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- A coalition of 31 labor unions representing one million Federal workers has called for the Government to stop introducing technological change until a master plan is developed to cushion the impact on Federal employes.

HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 19 -- An aura of subdued panic pervades many studio offices around Hollywood this week. Hundreds of actors, directors and producers who are involved with the season's new television shows are awaiting indications on whether their shows will fold or survive.

The three national television networks plan live coverage of next week's recovery of the Gemini 6 astronauts aboard the aircraft carrier Wasp several hundred miles into the Atlantic Ocean. This would be the first live transmission from the recovery area at the end of an orbital flight.

WORLD bridge championships in recent years have generated a curious paradox. The Italian stars are more daring than any of their opponents in making overcalls, yet seldom seem to suffer a heavy penalty.
Maryland sold $43.59 million of bonds yesterday to an underwriting syndicate headed by the Harris Trust and Savings Bank of Chicago, the First Boston Corporation, the Bank of America and Drexel Co.
BONN, Oct. 8 -- "It's good to be going home," the old man from Dresden said at the Munich railroad station. "Everyone's been nice to me but it didn't come from their hearts."
The London Stock Exchange closed steady yesterday with generally minor gains.

The Horse Show Ball, the social highlight of the 82d National Horse Show, will be held on Oct. 29 in the Imperial Ballroom of the Americana. Walter B. Devereux is president of this year's show, which will run from next Tuesday through Nov. 2 at Madison Square Garden.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 19 -- An experimental technique for telling quickly whether or not a drug treatment is helping a cancer patient was described here today.
The stock market continued yesterday its climb into new high -- and unexplored -- ground, but profit taking in the afternoon restricted most popular averages to modest gains.

Sterling Drug, Inc., achieved record sales and earnings for the first nine months and for any quarter in its history in the periods ended Sept. 30, the report of J. Mark Hiebert, chairman, disclosed to stockholders yesterday.
The Chase Manhattan Bank is reviving its plan for a statewide holding company but on a smaller scale than the original plan the bank officially abandoned two weeks ago.

BELGRADE -- Recent months have seen striking changes in the international alignment, changes in which both paramount powers, the United States and the Soviet Union, appear to have benefited, but in neither case at the other's expense.
NEW DELHI, Oct. 19 -- The Indian Government made another effort today to unearth gold that is in clandestine circulation throughout the country.
MONTREAL, Oct. 19 -- There were no banners in this sun-drenched city today proclaiming tomorrow night's National Hockey League All-Star game.

The Cuban delegation to the United Nations has made public a diplomatic note in which Premier Fidel Castro offered to exchange some of the 70,000 political prisoners in Cuban jails for Cubans being held in other Latin American countries.

THE television version of Theodore H. White's "The Making of The President, 1964" was a crisply written, candidly photographed and thoroughly professional summary of last year's campaign. That last night's 90-minute photographic treatment over the Columbia Broadcasting System was not in the same league with its 1960 predecessor was hardly of Mr. White's doing.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 19 -- A priest who has become the symbol of Roman Catholic involvement in the public school boycott here was ordered by church authorities today to stop participating in the demonstrations.

ACCRA, Ghana, Oct. 19 -- Cairo has its Hilton, Addis Ababa has its Africa Hall. And now, for a weeklong conference of the Organization of African Unity, Ghana has erected a 20th - century African Versailles.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- A fascinated audience was led today on a special tour of the klaverns of the Ku Klux Klan, inhabited by klaliffs, klokards and kludds and ruled by a wispy wizard from Tuscaloosa, Ala.
Jewish Communists here and in Israel have attacked a Soviet move in the United Nations to condemn Zionism along with anti-Semitism and Nazism.
WHAT really happened is as clear as the piece of transparent food wrap that will be hung this afternoon in the lobby of the Union Carbide Building on Park Avenue:

BONN, Oct. 19 -- Chancellor Ludwig Erhard's reunited coalition re-elected Dr. Eugen Gerstenmaier president of the Bundestag by a decisive majority today when the fifth session of West Germany's lower house of Parliament convened.
The World's Fair Corporation may find itself left with a lot of unwelcome souvenirs.

" May at 85." "Twenty for March." With shouts like these and with hands waving, 30 brokers crowded intently around the copper futures trading ring at the Commodity Exchange, 81 Broad Street, yesterday. It was the usual frenzied .last-minute trading that begins at 2:49 P.M., just ahead of the 2:50 closing time.

BUFFALO, Oct. 19 -- The failure of Senator Jacob K. Javits to appear at the New York State A.F.L.-C.I.O. convention today, as well as the remarks he had prepared for delivery there, precipitated an angry attack on the New York Republican from Raymond R, Corbett, head of the labor organization.
PARIS, Oct. 19 -- The city's second version of Le Drugstore, which opens tomorrow, has changed the face of one of the most famous neighborhoods on the Left Bank.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- Leaders of Students for a Democratic Society reacted with defiance today to expressions of dismay and anger by President Johnson, other Government officials and leaders in Congress over the antidraft movement.
The Young Women's Christian Association will take to the road in a mobile clubroom next Monday "to help a girl be a girl."

As the shouts of children at play echoed through his mansion one day John Golden, one of the giant figures in the history of Americn theater, turned to his friend Newbold Morris and said: "After I go I want to be sure the children will continue to play here."

The Administration's reaffirmation of American support for nuclear-sharing in NATO is a response to pressure from many sides to give priority to an East-West non-proliferation treaty. It comes against the background of United Nations debate on disarmament and also of two major developments elsewhere, one ominous, the other hopeful.

Frank E. Taylor, after more than 10 years of producing paperback reprints, is returning to an earlier occupation of editing hardcover originals. He becomes editor in chief of trade books at the McGraw-Hill Book Company today.

The first Community Development Theater program is being organized by the Peace Corps to operate in Chile Venezuela, Costa Rica and Panama at the request of school heads and theater groups in those countries.
The Bank of America, San Francisco, the nation's largest commercial bank, reported yesterday third-quarter earnings of $26,693,000, or 94 cents a share, up 3.3 per cent from a year earlier.

Earnings of the Sinclair Oil Corporation for the third quarter and first nine months this year were the second highest in the company's 49-year history. The increases were 42 per cent and 41 per cent, respectively, over the levels in the periods last year.

We were shocked and distressed by the approval of Francis Xavier Morrissey's appointment to the Federal bench by the Senate Judiciary Committee. Government officials at the highest level have emphasized the current importance of the rule of law and of a qualified judiciary.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission announced today that it would require the New Haven Railroad to continue to operate its passenger trains until next July 1, pending a commission decision on the railroad's application to discontinue all passenger service.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Oct. 20 -- A United States Air Force jet fighter-bomber was brought down by North Vietnamese antiaircraft batteries Monday during an unusually intense series of bombing raids against the North.

Theodore Kalem, drama critic of Time magazine, was re-elected president of the New York Drama Critics Circle yesterday. Others returned to office were Norman Nadel, vice president; George Freedley, secretary, and Ethel Colby, treasurer.
LONDON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The Moscow radio says it has solved Britain's Great Train Robbery: The British Secret Service did it to finance clandestine operations.
ROGER DENNIS is an economics major at Columbia University. He is also a student of Buff Donelli's late-afternoon lecture series, How to Play Winning Football.
IRENE GILBERT should have been a bit breathless Monday afternoon when James and Jean Spadea gave an informal reception for her at their Murray Hill home.

HAYNEVILLE, Ala., Oct. 19 -- State Attorney General Richmond M. Flowers interrupted the second Liuzzo trial today and asked the Alabama Supreme Court to purge some racists from a Lowndes County jury panel.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Oct. 19 -- The leader of the black Opposition in the Rhodesian Parliament again called on Prime Minister Ian D. Smith today to resign.

Faithful to the Democratic party regardless of provocation, Mayor Wagner has finally endorsed Abraham D. Beame to succeed him at City Hall. The embrace was cool, as well it might have been after the Controller's almost cruelly bitter criticisms of the administration in which he had served by Mr. Wagner's choice.
If New Yorkers are lucky, they may be able to see Comet Ikeya-Seki this afternoon or early tomorrow morning.

ONE of the most famous and intriguing of all short-story classics is the provocative "The Lady or the Tiger." It ends on a teasing note as the main character has to choose between two doors. Behind one is a beauteous maiden. Behind the other is a ravenous jungle beast.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 20 -President Johnson's surgeons may have faced a key decision in deciding whether or not to take out one or both of two kidney stones when they removed his gall bladder.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 20 -- The men finally ended the domination of the winner's circle by women riders at the Pennsylvania National Horse Show's international jumping when Billy Steinkraus of Noroton, Conn., won the "take your own line" competition.

A public offering of $15 million of 6 per cent debentures of Eriksberg Mekaniska Verkstads Aktiebolag, a Swedish company that is one of Europe's largest shipbuilding concerns, was placed on the market yesterday.

" The Barrios of Manta," by Earle and Rhoda Brooks, a memoir by two Peace Corps volunteers of their experiences in an Ecuadorian fishing village, will be published by New American Library on Nov. 17. The young couple taught sewing, cooking and carpentry to residents of Manta and guided them in sanitation, nutrition, community cooperation projects.

An ominous new element has been added to Moscow's tangled and bitter literary politics by the reported arrest of Andrei Sinyavsky, a literary critic, on the charge that he is the pseudonymous "Abram Tertz" whose writings have appeared in the West.

NYMPHOMANIA is naughty. It can be an annoyance, too, especially if the husband of a woman who has it -- and gives way to it with other men -- finds it out. This is the simple, singular moral that is prissily and painfully spelled out in an absolutely dismal movie version of John O'Hara's popular novel "A Rage to Live."
The Rhodesian political crisis continued to act as a brake on trading on the London Stock Exchange.
A majority of the city's elementary school pupils did poorer in reading and arithmetic last year than their counterparts throughout the country.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Cuba sent a new diplomatic note today that the State Department hoped would clarify the Castro Government's intention in letting Cubans emigrate to the United States.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (UPI) -- The Senate passed its own version of the sugar bill today, setting up a possible battle with Harold D. Cooley, chairman of the House Agriculture Committee.

The Right Rev. John E. Hines, Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church, said yesterday that there were no theological barriers to prevent a woman from becoming an ordained priest of the church.

BONNEVILLE SALT FLATS, Utah, Oct. 20 (UPI) -- Craig Breedlove escaped injury today on western Utah's Salt Flats when his jet-powered racer became partially airborne and careened out of control at a speed of 600 miles an hour.

JERUSALEM (Israeli sector), Oct. 20 -- Groundbreaking ceremonies for new schools in Israel are not particularly unusual, but there was one today in the immigrant Katamon section of Jerusalem that was a bit special.
SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 20 -- The wreck of the Matthew Flinders ship Porpoise, which foundered in 1803 has been discovered alongside a coral bed off Queensland.
LONDON, Oct. 20 -- The Campaign Against Racial Discrimination asserted today that it would seek to register "enough immigrants in the country" for voting to "offset the declared racists."
A dispute between the two leading mayoral candidates over whether party district leaders should hold Government jobs led to sharp exchanges yesterday.
The Duke of Windsor underwent corrective treatment yesterday to seal a small break in the retina of his right eye, a spokesman for the Duke reported.
IF Black is determined to play for a win after White's first move of 1 P-K4, he can do well to bank his chances on 1 . . . P-QB4.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- After more than 12 years, the Eastern and Western railroads have resolved their differences on the division of freight receipts on traffic moving from the Eastern Seaboard through Chicago and St. Louis to the West Coast.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 20 -- Michael Lockett Garrett is Mike to his mother, "The Duck" or "Charley Horse" to his teammates, and a plain godsend to[ John McKay, who coaches football at the University of Southern California.

A 15-year-old girl tenderly called Napoleon by the nickname of Bony in last night's presentation of "Eagle in a Cage," but the breezy appellation was not of material assistance to Millard Larapell's original consideration of Bonaparte's exile.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Oct. 20 -- Provisional President Hector Garcia-Godoy announced in a broadcast tonight that a special civilian-directed police force would start house-to-house searches for arms throughout the capital tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -- President Johnson transferred all functions of the director of the Food for Peace program from executive offices to the Department of State today.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 20 -- The Indonesian Herald, on English-language newspaper that generally reflects the attitudes of the Foreign Ministry, pointed an accusing finger at Communist China today over the revolt against President Sukarno.
SINGAPORE, Oct. 20 -- President Sukarno of Indonesia openly accused the Communists today of having taken part in the attempt to overthrow him.
WITH the best will in the world and an abundance of musical talent, Channel 13 last night televised the first installment of "The Beethoven Year," a series of specials.

GDANSK, Poland, Oct. 20 -- On the docks here is impressive evidence of the Soviet Union's drive to the sea. It is a Polish yard, but almost every ship being completed has its name in the Cyrillic alphabet.
BUJUMBURA, Burundi, Oct. 20 (Reuters) -- This tiny African kingdom wedged between the Congo and Tanzania was under martial law today after an unsuccessful police revolt Monday night.

WITH a whirr of feathers from Stravinsky's music, a flash of red plumage from the stage and a jump transfixed in a yellow spotlight, Melissa Hayden made her entry last night in Balanchine's production of "The Firebird."

The Continental Oil Company announced yesterday the election of W.J. Turbeville Jr. as vice president and general manager of plant foods. He was also named chairman of the American Agricultural Chemical Company, a plant foods producing and distributing subsidiary.

STRASBOURG, France, Oct. 20 -- A French Deputy, challenging President de Gaulle to hold a referendum, expressed the belief today that the "great majority" of Frenchmen favored keeping France in the Common Market even if the French Government did not.

The screen version of "My Fair Lady," which marks its first anniversary at the Criterion Theater today, has grossed more than $46 million at theaters in this country and abroad, according to Warner Brothers.

Max Wylie, a 61-year-old advertising executive, recounted quietly in a crowded courtroom yesterday how he had found the mutilated bodies of his daughter and her roommate in their fashionable East Side apartment on the night of Aug. 28, 1963.
The Columbia Broadcasting System yesterday removed Steve Allen, temporarily at least, as host of its "I've Got a Secret" television show.
Surely casualty reports of fatalities inflicted upon the Vietcong in any one engagement do not have to be couched in the style usually reserved for hunting and the hunter.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 20 (UPI) -- A strike by ship radio operators against the Pacific Maritime Association ended tonight with agreement on a new four-year contract.
Something funny happened yesterday to an interoffice communication aimed at employes of the Maritime Administration in Washington.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Can a potential draftee claim deferment as a conscientious objector because of a deep moral objection to military service? Or must his action be based on religious beliefs?
ROME, Oct. 20 -- The use of English instead of Latin for virtually all the public parts of the Roman Catholic mass in the United States has been approved by Pope Paul VI, it was announced today.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., Oct. 20 -- Mike Fetchick of Glen Head and Larry Laoretti of Pine Hollow won twice today to gain the semi-finals in the Metropolitan Professional Golf Association's team championship at the Cedar Brook Golf course.

ACCRA, Ghana, Oct. 20 -- Far down the runway at Accra's international airport is a specially built lounge for the African heads of state arriving for a conference of the Organization of African Unity.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- In his first ceremonial bill-signing since he entered the hospital for surgery, President Johnson today placed his signature on controversial legislation that will lead to exhaust controls on all new cars within two years.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 20 (UPI) -- The composer and conductor Leonard Bernstein, a business associate and two music publishers have filed suit against a nightclub here charging unauthorized use of four copyrighted ballads.

Groucho Marx, who acknowledges being a humorist but also classifies himself as "a part-time, on-the-fringe writer," has been asked by the Library of Congress to donate his personal papers, manuscripts and correspondence.
CHICAGO, Oct. 20 -- The University of Chicago set in motion today a 10-year fundraising campaign for $360 million, with a $25 million assist from the Ford Foundtion.
IF an opening suit bid is followed by two passes, the accepted meaning of a balancing bid of one no-trump is that it is weak. It shows a balanced hand with 11-14 high-card points.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The long-stalled move to give Western Europe a voice in its own nuclear defenses is gaining unexpected support in Congress.

The third annual Albert A. Michelson Award of Case Institute of Technology was presented to Prof. Luis W. Alvarez, physicist at the Berkeley campus of the University of California, it was announced last night.
GUATEMALA, Oct. 20 -- Under unfavorable circumstances, Guatemala has begun a new effort to evolve stable democratic institutions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The Johnson Administration's new program of rent subsidies for some poor families survived an attack in the Senate today, though final Congressional approval remained uncertain.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Senator Stephen M. Young, Democrat of Ohio, said today that he had learned that the Central Intelligence Agency hired persons to disguise as Vietcong and discredit Communists in Vietnam by committing atrocities.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 20 -- Yale University students are generally indifferent to proposals by school authorities that would give honor graduates and those with graduate degrees voice in the appointment of faculty members to tenure positions.
WASHINGTON, Ga., Oct. 20 (UPI) --About 300 teen-age Negroes stormed through a Negro school today, hurling bottles, screaming "freedom songs" and turning classes into chaos.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -- The State Department confirmed today that the United States would pull out of an international treaty that sets a limit on damages that may be collected from an airline for a passenger's death or injury, unless a much higher liability can be set.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Advocates of a bill to ease antitrust restrictions on bank mergers failed to make any headway today in efforts to arrange for House action on the measure this session.

YONKERS, Oct. 20 -- Easily the most successful auction of standardbreds in the history of New York State, the Old Glory horse sale, wound up its annual stand at Yonkers Raceway today with the disposal of 144 trotters, pacers, broodmares and weanlings for $283,700.

The Senate vote today on the nomination of Francis X. Morrissey for the Federal District Court in Massachusetts is a severe test of the independence and good judgment of the Senate Democrats. They have it within their power to send the nomination back to the Judiciary Committee for a well-deserved interment or to place on the bench for the rest of his life a nominee whom they know to be professionally unqualified and intellectually inadequate.
Almost every craftsman and professional person must serve an apprenticeship or internship of a sort. Why not the investor?

Paul and Selma Young of the Bronx, with 19-month-old Rebecca in her stroller, had walked into Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts last night just to look around and arrived just in time for intermission at the Vivian Beaumont Theater.

A Gallic Levittown of five exhibit homes was introduced in a Parisian suburb yesterday by Levitt Sons, the American home builder who led the post-war boom of mass-produced houses. Priced from $22,000 to $33.700, the homes are being offered in a planned 650-unit development, Les Residences du Chateau, at Le Mesnil-St.-Denis.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -President Johnson is expected to leave Bethesda Naval Hospital sometime tomorrow, probably in the morning. He will return to the White House by limousine. The Presidential press secretary, Bill D. Moyers, told reporters that Mr. Johnson "hopes to leave tomorrow, and I expect he will."
The huge volume of municipal bonds up for sale this week so far has been a disappointment to tax-exempt bond dealers.
MOSCOW, Oct. 20 -- An enterprising attempt by a would-be capitalist to satisfy the Russian working men's thirst for hard liquor has been uncovered by the police in Taganrog, in southern Russia.

The Campus, City College's oldest undergraduate newspaper, announced yesterday that it was ending a self-imposed suspension of publication, now in its third week. The 58-year-old newspaper suspended in a dispute with the student government over the right to determine its own choice of a printing shop.
The short interest on the New York Stock Exchange climbed 652,911 shares, to 8,443,177 shares, in the month ended Oct. 15, the Big Board reported yesterday.

I should like to add a concurring opinion to your Oct. 14 editorial endorsing John Lindsay for Mayor. While I agree that "Mr. Lindsay brings youth, energy and intelligence," I cannot agree that rule by the Democratic party fosters mediocrity in government.
The Fairfield County (Conn.) chapter of the Leukemia Society is sponsoring a "Salute to Eddy Duchin" luncheon and fashion show, to be held on Nov. 4 in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- President Johnson signed the $3.2 billion foreign aid bill today and declared that future aid programs would reward those countries that undertook economic and social reforms.

BERLIN, Oct. 20 -- The people filed silently from the Volksbuhne theater last night. Peter Weiss's attempt to translate the horrors of Auschwitz for the stage had obviously made a strong impact on the emotions of the audience.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- The United Nations is reducing its allowances for travel by delegations to the General Assembly from a luxury to an austerity level.

The bulk of the announced support from the Reform Democratic leadership -- most of it late in coming -- is going to Controller Abraham D. Beame, the Democratic candidate for Mayor.

City College students, supported by the administration, will soon start grading members of their faculty.
The nation's electric power production rose 9 per cent in the week ended Oct. 16 from the level in the corresponding 1964 week, it was reported by the Edison Electric Institute yesterday.

MOOSE JAW, Sask., Oct. 18 -- Canada's wheat harvest, damaged and delayed by a rainy September, is finally nearing completion. Although the crop is not meeting earlier expectations of a record, it probably will be Canada's second largest.

Are the railroads running downhill, as some observers have maintained? Hardly, according to Daniel P. Loomis, president of the Association of American Railroads. In a talk to the 29th annual meeting of the National Association of Shippers Advisory Boards in Los Angeles, Mr. Loomis cited yesterday some statistics that went far to refute the "railroads-are-dying" thesis.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- In this, the largest American community of experts in the art of vote-getting, professional attention is becoming concentrated on a mass-psychology factor which is emerging in the New York City mayoralty contest.

New Jersey is one of two states to elect a Governor this fall. Since the other is Virginia, the Garden State offers the Republican party its only hope of regaining control of a state government. CHICAGO, Oct. 20 (AP) An 18-year-old girl and a 65-year-old man have been named champion egg cookers at the National Egg Cooking Contest here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -Vice President Humphrey joined the fight today to win Senate confirmation of Judge Francis X. Morrissey by assuring Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts he would give all possible help.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The International Brotherhood of Teamsters has spent $570,397 since 1962 for the legal defense of its president, James R. Hoffa, according to its report issued today by the Labor Department.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -- A Senate judiciary subcommittee questioned New York Civil Court Judge James L. Watson today about possible affiliation with questionable political groups.

BONN, Oct. 20 -- Dr. Ludwig Erhard's coalition Government got off to a shaky start today when it appeared that some members of his coalition abstained and others might have voted against his re-election as Chancellor.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -New trouble for a Presidential appointee arose today when the Senate Judiciary Committee unexpectedly canceled a hearing on the nomination of David G. Bress to be United Sates attorey for the District of Columbia.

The first concert in Carnegie Hall's third annual International Festival of Visiting Orchestras will be a tribute to the memory of Adlai E. Stevenson, late United States representative to the United Nations. Sixten Ehrling will conduct the Detroit Symphony Orchestra in Eugene Ormandy's arrangement of Bach's "Komm slisser Tod" to open the concert at 8:30 P.M. next Thursday.

Prince Felix Youssoupoff testified yesterday that his only motive for killing Rasputin, reputed power behind the last Russian Czar, was repugnance over the monk's debauchery and not for any political reasons.
NEW HAVEN, Oct. 20 -- The director of athletics at Yale University today banned girl cheerleaders for the home team from Yale Bowl.

The widow of man for whom Fairleigh Dickinson University was named has given the northern New Jersey institution $1 million to provide scholarships for students who might not otherwise be able to attend college.

With all the comment on the views of the demonstrators and counter-demonstrators at the anti-Vietnam war parade on Fifth Avenue, one feature has been overlooked. That noteworthy feature is the performance of the New York City Police Department.
LONDON, Oct. 20 -- British industrialists agreed reluctantly today to give the Government advance information on contemplated price increases for major products.
Copper producers in Chile and Africa announced yesterday that they were raising their prices by 2 cents a pound to 38 cents.

BOSTON, Oct. 20 (UPI) -- Sam Jones scored 30 points and the Boston Celtics displayed a tough final-quarter defense tonight to turn back the Los Angeles Lakers, 100-96, in a National Basketball Association contest.
The New York Mets' search for an established power hitter ended yesterday with the acquisition of Ken Boyer, the 34-year-old star third baseman of the St. Louis ardinals.
New York City and a New York State agency sold $190,625,000 of bonds yesterday.
ALGIERS, Thursday, Oct. 21 (Reuters) -- Algeria was requested today to sound out all the African-Asian countries on whether they wish their top-level conference here to be held as planned Nov. 5.

William F. Buckley Jr., Conservative party candidate for Mayor, charged Representative John V. Lindsay and his associates yesterday with using "a deliberate and continuing strategy to exploit fear and prejudice" during the remaining days of the mayoral campaign.

The Los Angeles Department of Water and Power sold yesterday $24 million of revenue bonds to an underwriting syndicate headed by White, Weld Co., Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., and Salomon Brothers Hutzler.
DETROIT, Oct. 20 (AP) -- The Detroit Pistons routed the New York Knicks tonight, 116-103, for their first National Basketball Association victory.
Matthew Chandler Cowles, 21 years old, will act the star role of a 15-year-old boy in "Malcolm," in his first Broadway appearance.

Adopting the unusual tactic of running in front all the way in a distance race, Dr. Loren Guy's Munden Point won the 1 5/8-mile Lawrence Realization at Aqueduct yesterday. Sammy Boulmetis guided the son of Counterpoint to a neck victory over Selari, with Sammyren next in the field of seven.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- A leading student antidraft group called today for draft exemptions for youths who prefer humanitarian work to military service.
Changes in basic prices of two commodities had an impact on futures trading yesterday.

Representative Charles S. Joelson, New Jersey Democrat, said yesterday that he would turn over today to the House Committee on Un-American Activities a reported statement by Frank W. Rotella, Jr., head of the Ku Klux Klan in New Jersey, concerning a campaign to organize Klan units throughout the state.

MONTREAL, Oct. 20 -- Gordie Howe of the Detroit Red Wings overshadowed the greats of hockey tonight as his two goals lifted the National Hockey League All-Stars to a 5-2 victory over the Montreal Canadiens.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The Administration won a last-ditch fight for a national teacher corps today as Congress gave final approval to a $2.3 billion higher-education bill.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 20 (AP) -- A sharp earth tremor, which one scientist called an earthquake, rocked the Midwest at 9 o'clock tonight. There were no reports of injury or serious damage.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities alleged today in its questioning of a reluctant Grand Dragon and a silent Imperial Wizard that the two Ku Klux Klan leaders diverted the organization's money for their personal use.
Plans for a new Bronx Civic Center, covering a six-block site over a New York Central Railroad freight yard, were disclosed yesterday at ceremonies in the Bronx County Building.

HAYNEVILLE, Ala., Oct. 20 -- An all-white jury dominated by self-proclaimed white supremacists was chosen here today for the retrial of Collie Leroy Wilkins Jr., a Ku Klux Klansman charged with the civil rights murder of Mrs. Viola Gregg Liuzzo.

ST. STEPHEN, N.B., Oct. 20 -- It really isn't difficult to solve some of the world's more pressing problems. One has only to be organized for the task, with a willingness to mesh mental gears and use imagination.
Councilman Theodore R. Kupferman announced yesterday that he and three Republican-Liberal candidates for the City Council would pool their efforts to form "a creative government team."
" Il Trovatore" returned to the Metropolitan Opera last night after an absence of one season.
The Republic Steel Corporation said yesterday that profits in the nine months ended Sept. 30 rose to $63.8 million, or $4.05 a share, an increase of 28.4 per cent.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 20 -- The attitude of American troops serving in Vietnam toward antiwar demonstrators in the United States seems to vary from anger to contempt or indifference.
Yesterday was balmy and the air smelled nice, like summer with a wee dash of fall, but throughout the city, as in the whole Northeast, people rubbed their eyes and wondered why they smarted.
BUFFALO, Oct. 20 -- The New York State A.F.L.-C.LO. called today for repeal of the 2 per cent state sales tax and urged adoption of a system of progressive income and profit taxes to replace it.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 20 -- Although seven juveniles will go postward in the $29,321.55 Dan Patch Pace, a one-mile stakes test for 2-year-olds, tomorrow night at Roosevelt Raceway, most observers agree that it will be a two-horse race.

Third-quarter earnings of the Socony Mobil Oil Company, Inc., reached the highest level for any quarter in the company's 100-year history, lifting earnings for the first nine months to a record, the report disclosed yesterday.
Abraham D. Beame, the Democratic candidate for Mayor, made a stinging attack on the Presbyterian Church in New York yesterday for demanding a political change in the city.

Both Joey Giardello, the champion, and Dick Tiger, the former champion now challenging, worked out briefly at Madison Square Garden yesterday, an unusual action the day before their scheduled 15-round middleweight title fight.
The Chase Manhattan Bank confirmed yesterday that it had worked out an arrangement for an "affiliation" with the Liberty National Bank and Trust Company of Buffalo.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Oct. 20 -- Prime Minister Ian D. Smith strongly suggested today that the Government had decided to declare Rhodesia's independence from Britain. In a message delivered to Prime Minister Wilson of Britain, Mr. Smith said it was still in Britain's power to grant the colony its independence on honorable terms and thereby avert the disastrous consequences that have been threatened.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The Pennsylvania and the New York Central railroads assured the Interstate Commerce Commission today that they were fully agreeable to all the conditions to their planned merger that were suggested last March by two I.C.C. examiners when they recommended its approval by the commission.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 20 (AP) -- A national Methodist organization went beyond the official church position today and urged the United States to withdraw its opposition to the seating of Communist China in the United Nations.
The spot rate on the British pound was unchanged at $2.8029 yesterday in quiet trading in foreign-exchange markets here.

The best hope for labor peace in the newspaper industry lies in the creation of a joint union negotiating committee with a single spokesman, John J. Gaherin president of the Publishers' Association of New York City, declared yesterday.

A group of real estate investors announced yesterday an agreement to purchase the Bethlehem Steel shipyard in Brooklyn. Preliminary plans call for a futuristic, 80-story "city within a city" on the Brooklyn waterfront.
The American Jewish Committee charged yesterday that 50 mutual savings banks in New York City had "systematically excluded" Jews from top-management and policy-making positions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission cleared the way today for live television coverage from the aircraft carrier Wasp of next week's recovery of the two Gemini 6 astronauts in the Atlantic Ocean.
MILWAUKEE, Oct. 20 -- A conflict within the Roman Catholic archdiocese here today overshadowed other developments in a boycott protesting alleged racial imbalance in the public schools.
Several leading commercial banks announce promotions and appointments yesterday.

THE two major items of business on last night's New York Philharmonic program were the Stravinsky Violin Concerto and the Saint-Saens "Organ" Symphony. The third piece was the Shostakovich Ninth, repeated from last week's programs.

THE larcenous Dodgers did more than highjack their way to a pennant and World Series victory. They jolted the thinking of some of the more perceptive baseball men. One of the first to recognize the revolution they may have triggered is Bobby Bragan, the imaginative manager of the Braves -- the Atlanta Braves, if you-all don't mind the change.

When you're reading in bed and it's too much trouble to go to the big dictionary to look up "charisma" or "panache" or "ambience,'' this economy-size dictionary is handy to have beside you. Its definitions, though the stingiest possible, are mostly adequate, but there are no etymologies. Its pronunciation guides are simple and clear.
ROME, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Pope Paul VI has made the archdiocese of Washington, D.C., an autonomous ecclesiastical province, the Vatican announced today.
PEAPACK, N.J., Oct. 20 -- Mrs. John F. Kennedy has leased for the next several months a secluded weekend home in Somerset County's exclusive fox-hunting region.
As the newly discovered "hairpin" comet neared the sun last night, astronomers in many parts of the world became increasingly elated at its spectacular performance.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 20 -- Akram Hourani, a one-time vice president of the United Arab Republic when it included Syria, but now an extreme antagonist of rapprochment between the two countries, was arrested today.
Port Newark, through which a large part of New York harbor's cargo moves, celebrated its 50th anniversary yesterday at a luncheon in Newark's Robert Treat Hotel, attended by 800 area business men.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement by President Johnson as he signed the Clean Air Act Amendments and Solid Waste Disposal Act:
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 20 -- The Chief Justice of Brazil's Supreme Court accused the military today of exerting pressure on behalf of a proposal to increase the size of the court.

Give James Mathis some fiery music to get his teeth into, and he can be a stimulating pianist. The young musician, who made his Carnegie Hall debut in 1962, returned there last night, and at least in Bartok's Six Dances in Bulgarian Rhythm he generated some fire.

HARTFORD, Oct. 20 -- The constitutional convention completed action today on a proposed new constitution for the state, but a sudden fight over the form in which to present it in a referendum on Dec. 14 imperiled the document.
NEW HAVEN, Oct. 20 -- Pass interceptions and runbacks of kicks have sent Yale down to defeat in three of its first four football games, despite the fact that it leads the Ivy League in total defense.

THE New York farewell parties for Herve Alphand, retiring French Ambassador in Washington, and Mrs. Alphand got under way last night with what Mrs. Charles B. Wrightsman, the hostess, accurately called "a very small dinner."

CHICAGO, Oct. 20 -- Two officials of the regional office of the American Friends Service Committee, a Quaker organization, condemned today any attempt to recruit conscientious objectors as a "political tactic."

The New York Public Library staff and carpenters, electricians and handymen are entering the final weeks of work before the new Library and Museum of the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center is officially opened.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Oct. 20 -- Proposed zoning standards for the existing communities within the Fire Island National Seashore's boundaries were approved here today by the new park's advisory commission.
The election of Peter A. Nenzel as president of the United States Independent Telephone Association was announced yesterday at the group's annual convention here.

" I REGRET that I do not know M. Joyce's work," Marcel Proust said. "I have never read M. Proust," James Joyce replied. All in all, it was not an awfully matey meeting between two titans of our age's literature.

LONDON, Oct. 20 -- Qualified hope was expressed at high levels tonight that Prime Minister Smith's proposal for a treaty binding Rhodesia to progress toward majority rule would form a basis for renewed negotiations.

Parades, rallies, information programs, blood donations -- even the sending of gifts to combat units -- were being planned across the country yesterday as a show of support for the United States' military commitment in Vietnam.

Bruno Sammartino, Italy's most successful wrestler in the United States, defeated Cowboy Billy Watts, last night at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- New orders for durable goods rose in September from the level in August despite a dip in steel orders the Commerce Department reported today.
THE raciest knitted dresses this side of the Via Veneto are taking shape in a six-week-old factory in Ridgefield, N.J.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 20 -- A large force of Vietcong guerillas was repulsed with heavy losses during a predawn attack today on a Government outpost in Balong Valley, near the North Vietnamese border, a United States military spokesman reported.

Surely there is some mistake on Page 1 of The Times of Oct. 13. A photograph is printed which purports to show a photographer being beaten by a Klansman who wears army-style boots, dark shirt and trousers, a military-looking cap and a beard.

Trans World Airlines, Inc., and American Airlines, Inc., reached new peaks in sales and revenues for the third quarter and first nine months this year.

THE Ithaca College football team is doing things well in a small way. Not one of the Bombers' four primary running backs stands over 5 feet 10 inches and three of them are under 5-9. The undefeated team has even carried the little-man theory to the defense, where its three secondary men are 5-9 or shorter.

IT takes a brave actress to attempt a one-woman evening in the theater, and Gale Sondergaard is hereby cited for bravery. Last night she presented a solo program of readings on a weighty and virtuous theme: "The emergence of Woman into fuller status as a human being in relation to her man."

WHO knows what would have happened if Wilson McNeil Lowry had triumphed as a playwright 30 years ago? Perhaps luckily for the arts, he didn't. Art industrial designer displayed pictures yesterday of water storage tanks that, besides holding water, would provide observation decks, strolling plazas, shop and office areas and ice-skating rinks.

Hilliard J. Coan, chairman of E.J. Korvette, Inc., said yesterday corporate insiders of the discount chain had sold only 500 shares of Korvette common stock since Sept. 1.

A modest tightening of the mortgage market and some firming of rates has been predicted by the president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards in reporting the results of a countrywide survey.

The Kennecott Copper Corporation registered dramatic increases in earnings for the three and nine months ended Sept. 30. The gains reflected increases in metals prices and sales volume and improved profits on metal-fabricating operations.

The steel industry's increase in the price of tinplated steel for can-making continued to move closer to the consumer yesterday.

State Selective Service headquarters across the nation were unanimous yesterday in reporting there had been no significant increase in the number of youths attempting to evade the draft or seeking exemption from military service as conscientious objectors.
Dick Tiger, frustrated by the two-year wait imposed upon him by Joey Giardello, followed his fight plan perfectly in regaining the world middleweight title last night.

A TELEVISION study of President Johnson as chief executive and personality marked the return last night of "The March of Time," one of the pioneer names in documentaries for radio and film.
DALLAS, Tex., Oct. 21 (AP) -- A marker to be placed were President John F. Kennedy was assassinated will include maps and descriptive material in bronze, officials said today.

Joey Giardello, as slow and perplexed as an old grad in the alumni-varsity basketball game while losing his middleweight title at the Garden last night, said after it was over he was calling it a career.

Stockholders of the SCM Corporation approved yesterday an increase in the company's authorized common stock to 10 million shares from 4 million.
KEY WEST, Fla., Oct. 21 (AP) -- More than 250 Cuban refugees -- the largest number since Premier Fidel Castro relaxed the exit ban two weeks ago -- crossed the choppy Florida Strait today.

ALONG Seventh Avenue, skirts are above the knees this fall and in Green Bay, Wis., the pigskin is in the air. Fashions do change in pro football, too, but who would have thought that Vincent Lombardi, the coach of the unbeaten Packers and a dedicated infantryman, would be directing an aerial circus in the woods of Wisconsin?
Amid demonstrations and demands for repressions against Indonesia's 3,500,000-member Communist party, the Government has ordered a series of curbs since the Oct. 1 coup.

Jack W. Schiffer's Smoky Dale won the featured $7,500 Freeport-Roosevelt purse at Aqueduct yesterday, but the thoroughbred that created the biggest stir in the crowd of 22,060 fans did it in the race that preceded the main event.

Two of the five counties that make up New York City will elect district attorneys this year. In New York County this is no problem. Frank S. Hogan will be elected without opposition and with the endorsement of every legal political party to his seventh term of office, as has been the case on six preceding occasions beginning in 1941. This is a remarkable tribute to one of the great public servants of our generation.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 21 (UPI) -- Billy Casper, with a habit of success, set a fast pace for a pack of professionals today by duplicating yesterday's round of five-under-par 66 to hold first place in the $100,000 Sahara invitation golf tournament.

Sales of the nation's leading chain organizations swept past the nine-month mark with a solid gain over the level in the 1964 period. If the upward pace continues, the 1964 mark of $19.5 billion will be surpassed.

FASHION competed with poker chips and political aspirations Wednesday evening in the Grand Ballroom of the Astor Hotel.

Cocoa futures dropped the maximum permissible limit at the opening of trading yesterday. The decline amounted to 100 points, or 1 cent a pound, in five of the seven contracts. The two most distant contracts, December, 1966, and March, 1967, opened down 99 points each.
