The Parks Department said yesterday that it was planning to take over the New York Port Authority's heliport at the World's Fair site and build a zoo next to its base. It will be the city's first zoo in Queens.

The New York Rangers will open the National Hockey League season Sunday night without their top scorer, Rod Gilbert. Gilbert, whose 61 points placed him seventh in the league last season, was admitted to St. Clare's hospital yesterday with a muscle spasm in the spinal fusion area and will be hospitalized from seven to 10 days.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Vice President Humphrey said today that many demonstrators against the Vietnam war were young idealists whose energies should be enlisted for the Peace Corps.

The Autumn in New York dinner dance of the Boys' Club of New York was held in the Plaza last night, and the club will receive a contribution from the annual event that will help finance its work. Some 500 guests attended the dance in the Grand Ballroom, which took on the colors of autumn with yellow tablecloths and centerpieces of chrysanthemums in orange, brown and brick tones.
The Chromalloy Corporation announced yesterday that a plan to acquire the American Transit Corporation, St. Louis, had been approved in principle by the directors of the two companies.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (UPI) -- Senator John Stennis, Democrat of Mississippi, today was named chairman of a Senate watchdog committee created in the wake of the Robert G. Baker case.

The stock market forged ahead to another historic high yesterday on huge volume. The Big Board made history of another sort, too, when the daily list of fifteen most active stocks failed for the first time, according to Wall Street observers, to include one issue of investment grade.

The New York Telephone Company reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the September quarter and the 12 months ended Sept. 30. Operating revenues for the three months rose to $345,362 from $324,260,000 a year earlier.

THE Bermuda Bowl World Championship contests, which began as head-to-head matches between the United States and Europe, have gradually become worldwide in scope. Since 1958 the South American champions have been contestants, and beginning in 1966 the Far East champions will take part.

Thomas Dunn conducting, with Jorge Bolet, pianist, Philharmonic Hall, 8:30.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- The executive vice president of a grocery chain said today his concern had trimmed its gross markup nearly 18 per cent after having dropped trading stamps.

The costs of the Vietnam war mount. A candidate for Governor of New Jersey would purge the state university of dissenting professors. The United States Attorney General finds those who protest the war to be tainted with Communism.
WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 21The win bettors among the 17,014 punters at Roosevelt Raceway for tonight's $29,321.55 Dan Patch pace had need to inquire, "Romeo, wherefore art thou ?"
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -Senator Edward M. Kennedy, in a surprise retreat, abandoned his fight today to win Senate approval of Francis X. Morrissey's judicial nomination.
Governor Rockefeller announced yesterday that he had requested and the legislative leaders had agreed to the allocation of $860,000 for stepped-up statewide water resources planning.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- The Teamsters Union has won a key victory in its long-term effort to make major inroads in organizing employes of the country's airlines.

The International Longshoremen's Association indicated yesterday that unless maritime craft workers employed at the Naval Supply Base in Bayonne became members of the union, the Military Sea Transportation Service at Bayonne would face a strike.
Business loans at New York banks fell $105 million in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yeesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 21 -- Britain warned today that the existing arrangements of the Western powers for the nuclear defense of Europe were "not negotiable."
PARIS, Oct. 21 -- Defense Minister Pierre Messmer said tonight that President de Gaulle's controversial nuclear striking force had become a reality.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 21 (AP) -- The Very Rev. William Reilly, president of Lemoyne College, said today he doubted the wisdom but not the sincerity of a former student charged with destroying his draft card.

PARIS -- Soviet foreign policy has displayed considerable subtlety during recent months. With quiet persistence it has succeeded in simultaneously encouraging divisive trends between the United States and Western Europe and also divisive trends in Western Europe itself.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- The Air Transport Association said today that the withdrawal of the United States from an international treaty governing the accident liability of air carriers would throw American air passengers and shippers "into a chaos of foreign laws."
LONDON, Oct. 21 -- Although the pound is recovering its strength in the exchange markets, Britain's two most important economic officials warned tonight against premature relaxation of restraint.

The National Broadcasting Company announced yesterday that it had leased 15 existing motion pictures from Universal Pictures. Universal also will produce at least six two-hour feature films for use by N.B.C. television in the 1966-67 season.

PARIS, Oct. 21 -- The United States served notice today that it would press for increased integration within the North Atlantic Treaty Organization among "those nations" that are "ready, willing and able" to cooperate.
A Cornell University faculty committee recommended unanimously yesterday that students undertake the appraisal of the effectiveness of their teachers.
MILWAUKEE, Oct. 21 -- A three and a haft day boycott of the public schools here was called off by civil rights leaders at noon today, and the children returned to classes for the afternoon session.

Executives at Doubleday have got the idea that a finely bound book ought to be at least as attractive as a Christmas-wrapped bottle of liquor for other business executives planning to send out holiday presents.

Representative John V. Lindsay proposed yesterday six changes in the organization of the city government that would help eliminate what he called "the total lack of coherent planning."

Two debuts marked the season's fourth performance by the Metropolitan Opera last night of Tchaikovsky's "Queen of Spades." Felicia Weathers appeared as the heroine, Lisa, and Loretta Di Franco took the brief part of Chloe in the second-act ball scene.
STRASBOURG, France. Oct. 21 -- The Gaullist spokesman stormed out of the European Parliament today moments before a unanimous vote that in effect criticized France's role in the Common Market crisis.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Oct. 21 -- Man's first chance to see and photograph a comet from space will be a secondary mission on the Gemini 6 flight next week.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Invoking a rarely used constitutional power, the Justice Department asked the Supreme Court today to affirm the constitutionality of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 and to end obstruction of the act in three Southern states.

President Johnson is expected to endorse Controller Abraham D. Beame for Mayor next week. Democratic sources said yesterday they understood Vice President Humphrey would read a message of endorsement from the President at a dinner honoring Mr. Beame on Tuesday.
Mayor Wagner is giving serious consideration to a Transit Authority request for nearly 600 new transit policemen. The additional men would bring the transit police force to about 2,600.
A statewide campaign to restrict the powers of public authorities to spend funds collected from motorists on non-highway projects was initiated yesterday by the New York State Automobile Association.
TORONTO, Oct. 21 -- Seven Arts Productions, Ltd., probably will begin to earn money on its investment in the film, "Cleopatra," when it has grossed $58 million, according to Elliot Hyman, president.
A loud S-major chord of happiness resounded through the world of the American symphony orchestra with yesterday's announcement of the Ford Foundation's $85 million grant.

Rube Goldberg, a newspaper cartoonist for 59 years, is having his first sculpture show and is enduring a mild case of jitters because he wants his bronze figures to be regarded as funny but also recognized serious sculpture.

For one thing, status symbols aren't nearly so plentiful on British waters, where sailboats outnumber powerboats by 3 to 1, as in the United States, where the ratio is 10 powerboats to every sailboat.

Frank Howard, the towering former Dodger who became a big man in Washington, was chosen yesterday as the American League's comeback player of the year for 1965.

The Federal National Mortgage Association announced yesterday plans to sell $375 million of participation certificates in the Government mortgage liquidation trust. The sale is expected Nov. 1.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Rail carloadings of revenue freight in the latest week ended Oct. 16 reached a 1965 high and were the highest since last year's peak, reached in the final week of October. Intercity track tonnage in the latest week was considerably above the corresponding 1964 period.

The appointment of James H. Evans as chairman of the executive board for Greater New York of the American Red Cross was announced yesterday by E. Roland Harriman, chairman of the American National Red Cross. Mr. Evans is president of the Seamen's Bank for Savings.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- A member of the Federal Reserve Board warned today of "potentially disruptive effects" on the nation's capital markets if corporations and others should shift funds from certificates of deposit to other money market instruments.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The Senate approved today, 49 to 14, the nomination of David G. Bress to be United States attorney for the District of Columbia. Republicans led both the attacks against him and his defense.

The American Friends of the Hebrew University have arranged a convocation dinner for Monday at the New York Hilton. Mrs. Abraham F. Wechsler, national chairman of the Society of the Book of the American Friends group, will receive an honorary fellowship from the university.
Three wild dogs backed a 10-year-old schoolboy against a wall in Washington Heights yesterday. He obeyed a passing woman's call to remain still and was not bitten.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 22 -- Ailing horseplayers who had hoped to get well with Moccasin tomorrow at Laurel Race Course can forget it.

Houghton Mifflin will publish on Nov. 8 "The Eleanor Roosevelt Story," script written by Archibald MacLeish for a 90-minute documentary film. The book will contain 140 photographs, many never published before.

The new Madison Square Garden, expected to open in late 1967, will have unusually wide spacing between the rows of theater-type seats in the arena, a Garden spokesman said yesterday.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 22 -- Nick Rassas wanted to play football for Notre Dame ever since he can remember. A proposal to take the Maritime Administration out of the Department of Commerce and reorganize it as an independent agency is gaining support in Congress.
Beer drinkers, invited by industry, are drinking more beer from cans. Apparently it makes them happy.
TROY, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- A 4-year-old English setter, Ch. Merry Rover of Valley Run, was named best in show today at the 845-dog Troy Kennel Club fixture.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 24 -- Auto plants apparently will take a little more steel in December than originally anticipated. If early commitments for December are representative, a sales official said, orders from the auto industry will be up from both October and November.
AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 24 -- President Johnson intends to press in the next session of Congress for legislation to rejuvenate the nation's transportation system.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Congress has completed an unusually productive 10-month session marked by the enactment of much ground-breaking legislation.

A former campaign worker for John V. Lindsay said yesterday that he had been asked by a district coordinator for the Republican-Liberal Mayoral candidate to solicit votes for William F. Buckley Jr., the Conservative nominee.
A program to teach traffic safety to children from the day they first enter school is scheduled to get its first test this winter.
ROME, Oct. 24 (AP) -- A church mural -- with likenesses of prominent Marxists, recent Popes, President Kennedy and other world figures -- stirred controversy today.

THE Yiddish theater, long rumored to be on a Goodbye Charlie basis, burst forth at the Anderson Theater on Second Avenue Saturday night with "Hello Charlie" and betrayed no signs of sitting in mourning for itself.
MANY players dislike freakish hands because they frequently involve crucial guesswork and nobody likes to guess wrong.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 24 (AP) -- The unbeaten Green Bay Packers, held to fewer than 100 yards in total offense against a strong Dallas defense, turned two third-period fumbles deep in Cowboy territory into 10 points and scored a 13-3 National Football League victory today.

OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 24 (UPI) -- Dick Wood threw two touchdown passes to Art Powell in the second half and Mike Mercer kicked three field goals today as the Oakland Raiders defeated the Boston Patriots, 30-21, in an American Football League game.

A Notre Dame team reminiscent of the Rockne masterpieces of old in its running and blocking and in shifting from the T to the I (instead of the box) stood transcendent in the bewildering panorama of action in college football across the country Saturday.

A Columbia University historian says he has proof that France, soon after entering the Revolutionary War as an ally of the United States, was preparing to negotiate secretly to end the conflict with less than full independence for the 13 states.

A miniature by Stravinsky, which later became a miniature by Balanchine, returned to the New York City Ballet repertory at the State Theater in Lincoln Center last night and left a far from miniature impression. This mighty atom is the "Monumentum pro Gesualdo," and it is a work of powerful simplicity.
ACCRA, Ghana, Oct. 24 -- The future of the three-year-old Organization of African Unity is in grave doubt, according to Diallo Telli, its secretary general.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Congressional investigators will recommend tightening of the Food and Drug Administration's procedures for checking on mislabeling and other drug manufacturing practices, Representative L.H. Fountain, predicted tonight.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 24 -- Richie Ginther, a redheaded, freckled-faced little man from Los Angeles, drove a Japanese-built Honda to victory today in the Grand Prix of Mexico. The exciting triumph on a 3.2-mile course was witnessed by a crowd estimated at 50,000.

About 1,900 persons went to the opera in Flushing, Queens, last night. The work was Mozart's "The Magic Flute," and it was presented by the North Shore Friends of Opera, starting their fifth season at the Charles S. Colden Center at Queens College.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 24 -- President Sukarno has angrily accused non-Communist political factions of making some left-wing organizations the "victims of false slander."

" KITCHEN appliances should fit us, not force us to fit them," said Michael Farr, head of Michael Farr (Design Integration) Ltd., wrinkling his British nose at a cup of American bag-brewed tea. "But all the time everything is rooted to the floor, it is impossible to tailor appliances to the 6-foot girl and the 5-foot girl as well as the girl in between."
PLEINEUTE, South Vietnam, Oct. 24 -- Communist pressure seemed to have eased today on the besieged United States Special Forces camp at Pleime.
Two floors of office space in the new 31-story tower at 201 East 42d Street, at the northeast corner of Third Avenue, have been leased by the D.H. Overmyer Company of Toledo, Ohio.
The New York Council of the Navy League of the United States will hold its 63d anniversary dinner on Wednesday in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The main impact of the first session of the 89th Congress on the nation's economy is all the money it voted.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Representative Emanuel Cellar, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, backed today the Federal Communications Commission's proceeding to restrict network corporation ownership and control of evening prime time programs.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Legislation aimed at making it more difficult for outside elements to move in and take Over corporations was introduced in the final hours of the Congressional session by Senator Harrison A. Williams, Jr., Democrat of New Jersey.
With the stock market continuing its move into new high ground last week, the big question Wall Street will be trying to answer this week will be: "Where Do We Go From Here?"
The roll of drums and a fanfare of trumpets echoed yesterday through the nave of the Cathedral Church of St. John Divine as the Salvation Army marked its 100th birthday.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct 24 -- The Dartmouth, America's oldest college newspaper, today pirated The Harvard Crimson, a younger college newspaper.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 24 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Rams gave Johnny Unitas a second chance today and the Baltimore Colts' quarterback threw three touchdown passes in the last period for a 35-20 victory.
BOSTON, Oct. 24 (UPI) -- Ken Wharram and Doug Mohns scored two goals apiece tonight and paced the Chicago Black Hawks to a 6-2 rout of the Boston Bruins.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24 (AP) -- The rejuvenated Chicago Bears turned three fumbles and an interception into four touchdowns today and routed the Detroit Lions, 38-10, for their third straight National Football League victory.
The leader of a Republican "truth squad" said here yesterday that the Republicans would go into court if necessary to stop "the idiotic scheme for a dome on Shea Stadium."

Hector Garcia, a Cuban guitarist now living in Albuquerque, N.M., gave his first recital here last night in Town Hall His program and his performance showed him to be a serious musician. He has formidable technique and the imagination to go with it.

George Schiller, who came here from Russia 60 years ago but delayed seeking citizenship until last June, now faces still further delay. This is because the Immigration and Naturalization Service is investigating his association in a labor relations firm with Carlo Gambino, head of a major Mafia group.
Your endorsement of John V. Lindsay for the reasons given is indeed difficult to comprehend.

PORT LARGO, Fla., Oct. 24 -- For three long days and nights at sea, Lionel Sierra, Enrique Dunand and Napoleon Arango tried to find the Cuban coast, driven by a deep longing to "look on" their mothers again and return with them to the United States.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Oct. 24 -- All is ready for the Gemini 6 flight tomorrow but complete success will be at least 100 times as elusive as on earlier manned missions, space experts said today.

Vincent Sardi, whose restaurant has become a theatrical tradition and who is nearing 80, made his first visit last night to The Player, the 77-year-old club whose membership has always been part of that tradition.

VIENNA, Monday, Oct. 25 (Reuters) -- Sir William Hildren, director general of the International Air Transport Association, said in an address prepared for the association's 21st annual meeting today that proposed supersonic jet airliners would face stiff competition from giant subsonic jets expected on international airways by 1967.
ELMONT, L.I., Oct. 24 -- Volunteer "teacher-moms" are being used in this school district as part of a community effort to aid the emotionally disturbed child.

The post time for the first race at Aqueduct race track will be moved up one hour to 12:30 P.M. beginning today.
ROME, Oct. 24 -- The Vatican has sanctioned the full-scale resumption of the "worker priest" experiment in France, it was announced today.

Former United States Senator Kenneth B. Keating and Supreme Court Justice Owen McGivern have been riding the campaign circuit up and down New York State in quest of votes. But they haven't directly asked for them.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Was approval of the Pennsylvania-New York Central railroad-merger by Interstate Commerce Commission trial examiners based on entirely false assumptions about the future of the railroads and of the national economy?

Edgar B. Young, executive vice president of the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, is withdrawing from that post to resume his duties on Jan. 1 as an associate of John D. Rockefeller 3rd, chairman of the center's board.

IT is no easy task to write a comprehensive, critical -- and still readable -- history of anything. It is particularly difficult when the subject is one as broad, complex, diverse in detail and surrounded by myth and controversy as the history of the American theater. In tackling it at all, Howard Taubman deserves a medal for bravery, if not for champion adroitness in avoiding all pitfalls.
Moscow, Oct. 24 -- An American folk singer, Pete Seeger, sang a Vietnam protest ballad today before an auditorium filled with Moscow University students.

NEWARK, Oct. 24 -- A sad, quiet 7-year-old girl missing for 10 days told the police today that she had been hiding in a musty stairwell in a house where a friend lived, and that she had eaten nothing during that time.

The New York Giants were confronted with the enormity of Jim Brown yesterday and they could not cope with him. The Cleveland fullback, football's mightiest runner, was the pivotal figure in a game easily won by the Browns, 38-14, before a crowd of 62,864 at Yankee Stadium.
Malvina Leshock, who gave a recital at Carnegie Hall last night, offered some moments of full-bodied, romantic pianism. But she did not have a rich enough tone to support this old-style playing.

BONN -- Industrial and private water consumption 40 years hence are calculated on previous growth rates during the first 10 years of West Germany's rapid postwar industrialization. During this span, industrial water consumption rose year to 16 billion cubic yards, while household consumption increased from 2.8 billion cubic yards annually to 3.4 billion.

HADDAM, Conn., Oct. 24 (UPI) -- One marine reservist was killed and two others were wounded early this morning when a sudden burst of live tracer-lit machine-gun fire interrupted a weekend training maneuver.

MADRID -- Spain is winning attention as a leader in large-dam construction. It now occu pies fifth place in the world in the number of dams more than 50 feet high and third place in number of dams completed in the past 25 years.

Rear Adm. Ralph K. James, executive director of the Committee of American Steamship Lines, said yesterday that the organization's new program to increase American foreign trade was developing rapidly.

LONDON -- The Water Resources Act was passed by Parliament in 1963 to attempt to grapple with the problem of Britain's present and future needs. The purpose of the act is to insure that the growing demands for water are met.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Senator J.W. Fulbright renewed today a call for a temporary suspension of bombing raids against North Vietnam to create a better atmosphere for negotiations to end the Vietnamese war.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The old order changed in the 1965 session of Congress -- sharply in the House and subtly, for the most part, in the Senate. In the process, some new faces appeared in places of influence and some old ones disappeared or faded.

The Ericsson Group, worldwide Swedish telecommunications company, reported yesterday gross earnings of $31,022,000 for the first eight months of 1965 -- a new high. This compared with $18 million for the same period a year earlier.

The 15th annual luncheon of the Friends of the Philharmonic will be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria on Nov. 30. Mrs. Edward R. Wardwell is chairman for this year's event, which is sponsored by Elizabeth Arden, the cosmetics company headed by Mrs. Elizabeth N. Graham.
CHICAGO, Oct. 24 -- A research and training institute dedicated to spurring the development of emerging nations of the world will be established in memory of Adlai E. Stevenson.

TWO 18-year-old experts, Andrew Soltis and Marc Yoffie, wound up in a dead heat for first place in the 1965 New York City Junior Championship at the Henry Hudson Hotel recently.
W.R. Grace Co. has offered to acquire through an Australian subsidiary a majority interest in the capital stock of Cresco Fertilizers, Ltd., a superphosphate producer, of Adelaide, Australia.

The three television networks plan extensive coverage today of the scheduled two-day Gemini 6 space flight. They will also televise the earlier launching of an Agena rocket with which the Gemini space craft will attempt the first rendezvous and docking in space-flight history.

ACCRA, Oct. 24 (AP) -- The Organization of African Unity pledged itself today to fight subversion, whether it origin ates on African soil or abroad.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Oct. 24 -- Tension heightened today as a showdown seemed near between Provisional President Hector Garcia-Godoy and military leaders.

William F. Buckley Jr. predicted yesterday that his Conservative party slate would outpoll the Liberals in the Nov. 2 election, and he said he could even be elected Mayor. It would be the first time the 21-year-old Liberal party had been surpassed in the city by the Conservative party, which was founded in 1962.
Controller Abraham D. Beame berated his Republican-Liberal opponent yesterday for "trying to paint me with a Goldwater brush."

SOME institutions complement each other beautifully, and that's the way it is with the Kennedy family and France's foremost gift to American gastronomy, Henri Soule. Twice over the weekend the family chose his elegant and august Pavillon restaurant as a point of farewell feasting for the departing French Ambassador, Herve Alphand, and his wife.

Because of the more than usual interest in this year's mayoralty race, there is danger that voters may overlook the four important housing referenda that will be on the ballot. Passage of all is important for the future of the low-income and middle-income housing programs in New York State.

CALGARY, Alberta -- In fairy tales, a pot at the end of the rainbow is filled with gold. In the Rainbow Lake area of northwestern Alberta, the pot may be overflowing with oil.

LONDON, Oct. 24 -- Prime Minister Wilson left today for Rhodesia on one of the boldest political missions of his career. He hopes to break the deadlock between Britain and Rhodesia over the demand for independence by Prime Minister Ian D. Smith's white settler Government.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Oct. 23 -- The sound of new money is being heard once again throughout this land as the Colombian Government and foreign groups complete formalities for the resumption of aid after almost a year of trying to stare each other down.

Making one mistake against the Montreal Canadiens is tantamount to handing them the decision. The New York Rangers found that out last night as they lost to the Stanley Cup champions, 4-3, before a crowd of 15,024 at Madison Square Garden.

The Free Southern Theater has suspended production activities until Jan. 1, by which time it hopes to raise $50,000. If the money is not obtained, "we will postpone our operations for another month or until we do raise the necessary amount," John O'Neal, general manager, said yesterday.

The water problem is by no means confined to the United States, where a continuing drought this year produced a potentially serious water shortage in the Northeast. This is a worldwide problem, affecting Asia, Africa and even industrially strong and wealthy Western Europe.

Carl J. Weinhardt Jr., who recently resigned as director of the Gallery of Modern Art, has been named director of the Art Association of Indianapolis, which operates the Herron Museum of Art and the Herron School of Art.

The volume of municipal bond sales this week will drop almost $300 million from last week's near-record total. Corporate securities sales will increase moderately.
Two researchers at Jefferson Medical College in Philadelphia have found what they believe is a form of extrasensory communication between certain identical twins.

The Erie-Lackawanna Railroad may break even this year and possibly report a slight profit, William White, chairman, said over the weekend.

A pioneer in cooperative housing was honored yesterday in the lower East Side neighborhood he helped to rebuild.

Litton Industries, Inc., announced over the weekend its entry into the office-copying machine market with the introduction of its Royfax 7 electrostatic desktop unit, first of a line of new copiers.
Prices of some pork belly futures climbed the daily limit yesterday while corn prices set some life-of-contract lows.

The mounts that were brought into Madison Square Garden yesterday for today's start of the National Horse Show did not include Untouchable, one of the great ones in the United States Equestrian Team's string.

DETROIT, Oct. 25 (AP) -- The United States auto industry continued its record pace last week as production of 1966 models surged to a high.

Sandy Koufax and Sam McDowell, two left-handers, captured major league earned-run-average championships in 1965, the final averages showed yesterday.

FOR an old instrument the harpsichord has come a long way lately. A few decades ago, a harpsichord recital was still a rarity. More recently, a harpsichordist of stature could draw an audience to a series of three programs.

The offering of $40 million of United Merchants and Manufacturers, Inc., convertible debentures scheduled this week is expected to be offered today with a 4 per cent interest coupon and at a price of 102, to yield about 3.87 per cent.

In his search for bright spots in the German past. Prof. Kurt-Conrad Arnade [letter published Oct. 11] has, I fear, selected two rather poor examples. He credits Bismarck with the introduction of social legislation in the 1880's, implying this was done as a result of the Chancellor's public spirit.

IN the offices of the New York Giants at Columbus Circle yesterday, Coach Al Sherman displayed the movie of the losing game against the Cleveland Browns. Jim Brown was as dominant on Monday as on Sunday and the record on film proves the Cleveland fullback's unique ness.

Directors of the Boeing Company declared yesterday a special dividend of 50 cents a share along with the regular quarterly dividend of 50 cents. Both are payable Dec. 10 to holders of record Nov. 5. This was the first special cash dividend paid by the company in several year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Exports fell back slightly in September after encouraging increases in July and August, the Department of Commerce reported today. The Sep tember export total of $2,297,700,000, seasonally adjusted, was down about 2 per cent from the August figure. Import figures for September have not been reported.

Pan American Airways reported that net income for the nine months ended Sept. 30, before special items, rose to $38.9 million, or $2.72 a share, from $34.2 million, or $2.49 a share, in the period last year.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Bob Ross and Ike Turner combined for a five-under-par 32, 33-65 today and won the pro-pro golf tournament of the Philadelphia Professional Golfers Association at the Atlantic City Country Club.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The Department of Justice opened a new campaign today against the exclusion of Negroes from Southern juries.

IN T-formation or I-formation football, the formula for success is a good passer plus one or even two good runners. But last Saturday Notre Dame demonstrated in crushing Southern California that it could succeed easily without the first part of the formula.

The New York State Banking Department has cut from $1 million to $100,000 the minimum permissible denomination at which the state's commercial banks are allowed to offer unsecured, non-negotiable promissory notes.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 25 -- Frank Aiken, Ireland's Minister for External Affairs, submitted today a plan to circumvent the power in the Security Council to veto peacekeeping missions.

ALGIERS, Tuesday, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Communist China gave notice today that it would boycott the African-Asian conference of heads of states scheduled to open here Nov. 5. The decision was announced after Peking's delegates found they could not prevent conference sponsors from issuing an invitation to the Soviet Union.

AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 25 -- The White House reaffirmed today President Johnson's willingness to halt United States air strikes against North Vietnam whenever there is any indication that such a suspension would lead to negotiations for a peaceful settlement of the conflict.

A chief witness in the murder trial of Richard Robles testified yesterday that he had been promised immunity from prosecution on an unrelated homicide charge after he had implicated Robles in the Wylie-Hoffert case.
The stock market, after six successive advances, lost ground yesterday along a broad front.

TRENTON, Oct. 25 (AP) -- The New Jersey Supreme Court threw out a 65-year-old doctrine today and ruled that a person could collect damages for an automobile accident, even though he was not struck but simply became frightened.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (UPI) -- The Communications Satellite Corporation announced today agreement on a contract for construction of three earth stations to be used in the space race to the moon.
Reports were presented at two meetings here yesterday pointing at cigarette smoking, rather than air pollution, as largely responsible for the recent rise in lung cancer in the United States.

The "haute couture" in business equipment went on display yesterday at the New York Coliseum as the companies that set the fashions and standards for modern business operation introduced their new fall lines at the Business Equipment Exposition.

SEATTLE, Oct. 25 -- The first Arches of Science Award was presented here tonight to Dr. Warren Weaver of New Milford, Conn., a mathematician who is now a trustee of the Alfred E. Sloan Foundation and for 28 years associated with the Rockefeller Foundation.

" A brave new world" where a nationwide file on the credit standing of virtually every American wage earner would be created and maintained on computer tape by the Federal Government was proposed today by a New York banker.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) -- The Labor Department named 34 additional cities today where youth opportunity centers will be set up to help unemployed youths 16 to 21 find training and jobs.
Long-term Government bonds declined fairly sharply yesterday in light trading that was confined mostly to professionals in Wall Street. Some issues were down as much as 10-32 of a point.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Joseph P. Kennedy's work for the election of John F. Kennedy to the Presidency is described in a privately printed book of tributes to their father by Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

Seven alleged New Rochelle bookmakers were arrested yesterday by Federal agents acting on information supplied by aroused citizens, many of them members of the community's largest Presbyterian church.

Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey arrives in New York today at a critical moment for the city's liberal, reform-minded Democrats. Since Abraham D. Beame, Democratic party candidate for Mayor, is no liberal and no reformer, the Reform Democrats are in the unhappy position of knowing that their ideals can win only if their party loses.
LONDON, Oct. 25 -- The desperate search for some way out of the Rhodesian dilemma is focusing now on a novel idea that borrows from American experience.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) -- The Supreme Court affirmed today a decision that the Morton Salt Company and the Diamond Crystal Salt Company violated the Sherman Antitrust Act by fixing the price of rock salt.

Most freshmen who had succeeded in gaining admission to Ivy League colleges were still happy with the institution they chose, a survey at six of the eight highly selective colleges has found.
A new British-built Triumph 2000, designed by an Italian for the American market, made its debut here yesterday.

A $110,000 contract to pick a site for a combination bus terminal and parking garage to serve the ever-burgeoning East Side Manhattan business area was awarded yesterday by Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes.
With the new 1966 automobile models now officially introduced and crowds filling dealer showrooms from coast to coast, it is apparent the public response is highly favorable.

UNDERWEAR is catching up with the modern fashion spirit. It is losing its ruffles and frills, breaking into vivid colors and prints and narrowing the fashion differences between what women wear on the outside and what they wear underneath.
Steel production fell sharply last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

WHEN it doesn't rain for months, what do the rain-coat designers do? They try harder. They forget about trusty beige poplin and reach for dress fabrics instead, shrewdly disguising the coat's original purpose.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art picked up a $500,000 bargain created by Leonardo da Vinci or Andrea del Verrocchio when it bought a 26-inch sculpture for $225 at an auction on Friday, a prominent dealer said yesterday.

The city's water supply, continuing to benefit from runoff from earlier rains, dropped 200 million gallons in the 24 hours that ended at 8 A.M. yesterday, leaving the upstate reservoirs at 37.1 percent of capacity.
William F. Buckley Jr., the Conservative party candidate for Mayor yesterday called for the establishment of "massive quarantine centers" for narcotics addicts.

BRIDGEHAMPTON, L.I., Oct. 25 -- Sayrelands, a 1734 homestead here on Montauk Highway, has been presented as a historic landmark to the Society for the Preservation of Long Island Antiquities. Built by D. Halsey, the house was constructed of white oak from nearby forests on a foundation of stone that was brought across Long Island Sound from Connecticut.

KEY WEST FLA., Oct. 25 (AP) -- Sixty Cuban refugees, including 17 children, arrived tonight in the first ship to reach Florida since last Friday, and the Coast Guard rescued 27 others from choppy seas.

McGraw-Hill, Inc., the publishing company, has leased the five upper floors in tile six-story building being completed by Irving Maidman at 620 Eighth Avenue, at the northeast corner of 40th Street. With this lease the entire building, which will be ready for occupancy in December, has been rented.

The giant Travelers Insurance Company won approval from its shareholders yesterday of a reorganization plan that will put its life, property and casualty insurance components under the protective umbrella of a holding company.
A new portable pension arrangement has been put into effect for 50,000 union carpenters in the New York metropolitan area.
OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 25 (AP) -- Assistant Secretary of State William P. Bundy called on Japan today to join with the United States in "helping advance the good of all Asian peoples."
The Pennsylvania Railroad and its merger partner, the New York Central Railroad, both reported yesterday sharply improved results for the September quarter and the first nine months this year.
It's a long, long time from now to next autumn, but for the producers of fabrics for men's outerwear it's none too early.
The Columbia Broadcasting System's radio and television stations here endorsed political candidates for the first time yesterday.

The National Maritime Union advised the Department of Defense yesterday that two foreign-flag ships chartered to carry United States military supplies to Vietnam were being delayed by refusal of their crews to sail.

Dr. Carl Goldmark Jr., president of the New York County Medical Society, called last night for revision of New York State's "archaic" abortion laws.

" The Half-World of American Culture," by Carl Bode, which Southern Illinois University Press will publish on Nov. 1, is a collection of essays. The author, Professor of English at the University of Maryland, who was cultural attache at the American Embassy in London several years, follows the theme that American literature and life go hand in hand but are not always friends.
DUBLIN, Oct. 25 -- Of the $815 million spent by Americans visiting Europe last year, only $20 million flowed to Ireland.
Representative John V. Lindsay was assured last night of a third line on next Tuesday's ballot when the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court voted to restore Row E to him.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 25 -- Among themselves, Californians don't ordinarily talk about the weather as much as other people, even though it's one of the state's fabled assets. Seasonal changes are so consistent that, for instance, vintage designations on most California wines are superfluous.

The Maritime Administration has been sharply assailed by leaders of the country's two largest maritime labor unions for allowing subsidized steamship lines to charter temporarily foreign-flag vessels.

The newest campaign in the drive on poverty -- a nationwide program of group parent counseling aimed at strengthening the family life of the poor -- began here yesterday with an orientation meeting for staff personnel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The Treasury bill rate showed mixed movements at today's auction, the Treasury disclosed tonight, with three-month and six-month bills showing small changes in opposite directions.
OSLO, Norway, Oct. 25 -- The United Nations Children's Fund was named winner of the $57,000 Nobel Peace Prize for 1965 today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 25 -- The annual Halloween "trick or treat" campaign of the Children's Fund had just been given its send-off my Danny Kaye today when the organization learned of the award of the Nobel Peace Prize.
Two Off Brodaway producers have made full restitution of funds they used without authorization for an unrelated theatrical venture.

PARIS, Oct. 25 -- Liberal Roman Catholic Circles here greeted with deep satisfaction today the Vatican's consent to a revival of the highly controversial worker-priest movement.

New York University will help open Madison Square Garden's 32d college basketball season on Dec. 9, more than three decades after the Violets and Notre Dame played the first game in the arena.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The Justice Department is organizing a major new program to fight crime by improving the quality and efficiency of local police departments and local court and penal practices.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (UPI) -- The late Justice Felix Frankfurter, who served 23 years on the Supreme Court, was eulogized today as scholar, teacher and friend at a special memorial session of the Court.

Several thousand barbers, many of whom prefer to be called hair stylists, crowded into the Statler-Hilton Hotel yesterday to study the latest techniques in curling, straightening, brushing, drying, dyeing and even cutting men's hair.
DANANG, South Vietnam, Oct. 25 -- Senator Edward M. Kennedy and three other legislators met United States marines and Vietnamese villagers near this port town today.
MOSCOW, Oct. 25 -- The newly expanded rights and responsibilities of Soviet plant managers have been codified in a "factory charter" just published here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- McGeorge Bundy, in an optimistic assessment of the war in Vietnam, said today that the initiative in the fighting had passed from the Communist insurgents to the United States and South Vietnamese forces.

CAIRO, Oct. 23 -- A former German Waffen SS lieutenant who fled West Germany to avoid trial on a charge of distributing Nazi propaganda has asked the Egyptian Government for political asylum and permission to do business here as a book publisher.

Seretse Khama, the Prime Minister of Bechuanaland, received an honorary doctor of laws degree yesterday from Fordham University. The citation said that "under his rule men of all races live in peace and work together."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- It was time to go in for an annual consensus check-up. "You're looking moderate enough," said the doctor. "How are you feeling?"

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (UPI) -- The Swiss Ambassador to Cuba said today after a conference with Secretary of State Dean Rusk that an agreement was near between the United States and Cuba for an orderly evacuation of Cuban refugees to this country.

The annual autumn cocktail party and dance of the young leadership division of the United Jewish Appeal will be held Sunday in the Grand Ballroom of the Statler-Hilton. Miss Rachelle L. Meyer, Miss Susan Prober and Martin H. Wexler are co-chairmen of the event, which was attended by 2,000 guests last year.
Most issues on the American Stock Exchange fell on profit taking yesterday. National Video, a recent speculative favorite, took one of the sharpest dives.

A bystander was killed yesterday by a gunman who also seriously wounded the owner of a Bronx lamp shade company during a payroll holdup.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The insides and outsides of the first session of the 89th Congress having now been thoroughly examined by anatomists and dermatologists of politics and the press, a summary of their findings discloses a mixture of established facts and plain presumptions.
Mayor Wagner ordered yesterday that the transit police force be increased by 703 men to help prevent crime. The increase will bring the force up to 2,721.

Earnings of three leading oil companies spurted to peak levels in the first nine months this year, according to the reports issued yesterday by the Standard Oil Company (Indiana) the Union Oil Company of California anti the Phillips Petroleum Company.

The National Can Corporation said yesterday it had obtained a license from the American Can Company for the manufacture of a tin-free beverage can. National said it expected to "follow soon" the initial commercial marketings of the can by American early next year.

The first fall meeting of the New York chapter of the American Institute of Architects will be held Thursday evening at the new C.B.S. Building at 51 West 52d Street. There will be a guided tour of the structure.

The color television equipment exhibited at the World's Fair by the Radio Corporation of America has been purchased by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, Cardinal Spellman announced yesterday. It will be used for an educational television system serving schools in the Archdiocese.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25 -- Leo Durocher signed a three-year contract to manage the Chicago Cubs today, returning to an active baseball role after one year as a television broadcaster and to managing for the first time since he left the New York Giants in 1955.

NEW DELHI, Oct. 25 -- India has recalled her High Commissioner in Pakistan for consultations in protest against alleged Pakistani violations of Indian diplomatic privileges.
New records in earnings and sales for the third quarter and first nine months of the year were reported yesterday by the Ford Motor Company.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- A Wilmington, N.C., gun dealer who held a state office in the Ku Klux Klan acknowledged on a Congressional witness stand today that he had sold firearms to fellow Klansmen and had been convicted of selling illegal tear gas kits.
Two hundred teachers and Supervisors have been reassigned from jobs at Board of Education headquarters to positions in the schools this fall.

PLEIKU, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Oct. 26 (AP) -- A South Vietnamese armored column that began reaching Pleime last night consolidated its position just outside the camp and at dawn reported only sparodic fire from the Vietcong.

The Russian Prince who assassinated Rasputin, 49 years ago collapsed on the witness stand here yesterday after being asked repeatedly whether he had used his wife as "bait" to lure the lecherous monk to his death.

PAU, France, Oct. 24 -- In the Salle d'Honneur of the French Army's busy Paratroop School here, the biggest room is reserved for maps and carefully tended mementoes of the 1945-54 struggle for Vietnam.

John Corigliano will end his long service as concertmaster of the New York Philharmonic at the end of this season. Next August he will be 65 years old, the mandatory retirement age. He will not retire; next fall he will become concertmaster of the San Antonio Symphony Orchestra.

TORONTO, Oct. 25 -- Canada has signed one of the biggest wheat-sale contracts in history in a deal with Communist China worth at least $400 million, Mitchell Sharp, Minister of Trade and Commerce, confirmed here tonight.
WASHINGTON. Oct. 25 -- The vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board indicated today that the sharp decline in the liquidity of the nation's banking system was becoming a "cause for concern."
The eyes of 18 students at a Columbia University seminar last week moved back and forth as if they were watching a tennis match.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 25 -- Nunzio Ciampi of Glen Head dropped a 10-foot putt for a birdie 3 on the first hole of a sudden-death playoff and he and his partner, Jim Turnesa, of Mill River, won the Long Island Professional Golfers Association senior and junior pro-pro championship at Nassau County Park today.

Puccini's "Manon Lescaut," which has not been given by the Metropolitan Opera since the 1960-61 season, was reintroduced into the company's active repertory last night in a performance that was quite good.

What had promised to be a routine week-day program at Aqueduct, filled mostly with claiming and maiden races, turned into a session filled with unusual developments yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 26 -- The Beatles, in dark suits and ties, stood still long enough today for Queen Elizabeth II to make them Members of the Order of the British Empire. There were reports that Ringo had had a haircut for the occasion.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 26 -- "What is happening now is typically Indonesian and no doubt hard for most of the world to understand," an Indonesian scholar said today in discussing the turmoil that has shaken Jakarta's politics since the attempted revolt.

Coeducational colleges and universities that discriminate against women in their admissions policies should be deprived of Federal funds, Representative Edith Green declared yesterday.
A court decision to move the 13 special questions to the bottom of the city ballot Tuesday evoked dismay yesterday from supporters of the measures. They feared that the move would cost them votes.

Merck Co., the drug concern, announced yesterday the election as a director of Ben S. Gilmer, executive vice president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. The action increases the board to 13 members.
MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 26 -- John F. English, Nassau County Democratic chairman, charged today that a telephone at his party's headquarters here had been tapped by District Attorney William Cahn.

Eastman Dillon, Union Securities Co., has announced the admission of Robert C. Johnson as a partner. Mr. Johnson was formerly a partner in Kidder, Peabody Co., and is a past president of the Dollar Savings Bank.

On the basis of a preliminary tabulation, the Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation announced yesterday that it was buying 540,891 shares of its stock from shareholders in response to its offer to buy at $26.50 a share. The offer expired Monday.

E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., the nation's largest chemical company, was presented yesterday with the first "excellence in public relations" award of the Financial Public Relations Association in a ceremony at the New York Hilton.

ACAPULCO, Mexico, Oct. 26 -- "Richie Ginther is a happy little man with a brilliant future in the business of automobile racing." That is what was written about him in a newspaper six years ago when he got his first job as a driver in first-class international competition.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Oct. 26 -- Technical detective work on the Agena failure that cut short the Gemini 6 mission yesterday began shifting to the West Coast today as engineers here prepared the Gemini 7 for man's longest space flight -- a 14-day flight that may begin on Dec. 2.
ATLANTA, Oct. 26 (UPI) -- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. called today for new civil rights protests to force the Government into making the slaying of a civil rights worker a Federal crime.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Increased draft calls have prompted Selective Service boards throughout the country to reexamine their rolls with an eye to summoning young men they otherwise might have deferred.

HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 26 -- George Stevens, the film director, today filed a $2 million law suit against the National Broadcasting Company and Paramount Pictures to prevent what he called the mutilation and dismemberment of his motion picture "A Place in the Sun" when it is shown on television.
Park Commissioner Newbold Morris approved plans yesterday for a $2 million combination ice skating rink and convention hall in Coney Island.

Roy M. Cohn reported yesterday that he was being investigated by the Internal Revenue Service. The New York lawyer said the tax-collecting agency was using information gained in a 1963 watch on his mail to carry out the investigation.

The establishment of a $25 top policy for choice theater tickets, as a means of cutting down speculation and stimulating advance sales, was strongly urged yesterday by John F. Wharton, a theatrical lawyer.

Fast horses and skillful riders produced victories for the United States Equestrian Team in both of the international jumping events that were highlights of opening day at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden yesterday.

PRINCETON'S defensive secondary, which has had to face more passing than expected from its first five victims, will have its toughest challenge this week against Bob Hall of Brown.

KODIAK, Alaska, Oct. 26 (UPI) -- The Greek freighter Ekaterina G. aground on Great Sitkin Island in the Aleutians about 50 miles aest of Adak Strait, is reportedly foundering in heavy seas and 80 knot winds.
The stock market rebounded vigorously yesterday from Monday's decline. A wave of sharp corporate earnings and dividend increases swept most popular averages to records.

UNION, N.J., Oct. 26 -- State Senator Wayne Dumont Jr. campaigned for Governor today through Union and Essex Counties, attacking the record of Gov. Richard J. Hughes, the Democrat running for a second term.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- An open fight over the influence of the John Birch Society in the District of Columbia Young Republican Club appeared likely today. The dispute threatens to attract national attention.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Oct. 26 -- Police Commissioner Edward F. Carey of this city said today "there's a lot more than meets the eye" in the charge of the Rev. Albert Fay Hill, pastor of the North Avenue Presbyterian Church, that professional gambling is flourishing here.

NAT BADER is not a modest man. The chairman of the board of Originala says frankly that the 37-year-old coat and suit concern's collars fit better than Balenciaga's -- "there's no comparison." He refers to its as-yet-unveiled, spring ready-to-wear collection as "custom made."

Participants in the American Trucking Association's convention at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel were urged yesterday by one Government official to be reasonable in solving tax and regulatory differences, and by another to help block unauthorized trucking operations.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 26 -- The $28,321.55 Proximity, a one-mile stakes test for 2-year-old trotting fillies in which four juveniles trained by Frank Ervin finished 1, 2, 4, 6, proved tonight at Roosevelt Raceway that a race can be interesting, even exciting, without any betting involved.
The National Maritime Union said yesterday that it had resisted successfully attempts to reduce the number of its men aboard a new automated United States Lines freighter.

AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 26 -- Alabama's Attorney General Richmond M. Flowers said tonight that he would announce within the next 35 to 45 days whether he will be a candidate for either Governor or for the United States Senate next year.

Representatives of major cruise ship lines operating out of the Port of New York told State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday that they were opposed to the adoption of a code of ethics covering cruise ship operations.

The General Motors Corporation reported yesterday that it had made the highest profit of any company in history. And the United States Steel Corporation, a major supplier to the automobile industry, said it had record sales and sharply improved profits.

The Gulf Oil Corporation and the Cities Service Company both added sugar coating yesterday to their already sweet earnings reports with announcements of increased dividends.
Some 430 persistently unemployed workers in Long Island and upstate New York will be relocated by the New York State Division of Employment to other states where jobs are more plentiful.

Representative John V. Lindsay the Republican-Liberal candidate for Mayor, is leading Controller Abraham D. Beame, his Democratic opponent, by $200,000 ill campaign receipts, according to reports that must be filed with the Board of Elections 10 days before the balloting.
ACCRA, Ghana, Oct. 26 -- The Organization of African Unity wound up its third annual conference of heads of state early today as somberly as it had begun it.
The Jersey Central Power and Light Company awarded yesterday $20 million of first mortgage bonds to a syndicate headed by White, Weld Co.
RIDGEFIELD, Conn. -- When the weather is temperate, and it has been recently, October is one of the nicest months for visiting restaurants in the environs of the city.
Michigan State edged out Arkansas and Nebraska for first place in The Associated Press and United Press International college football ratings yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 26 (UPI) -- The Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company and the Bethlehem Steel Company have been fined $5,000 and $6,000, respectively, in Federal Court on their no-contest pleas to price fixing indictments.

PARIS, Oct. 26 -- Prince Andre de Bourbon de Parme modestly put out more than 40 bottles of a domestic champagne -- yard near Reims -- for a few a brut 1953 from his own vine-friends who dropped by last week to see his new furniture boutique.

ANDERSEN AIR FORCE BASE, Guam, Oct. 24 -- When the B-52 bombers of the Strategic Air Command roar out of Guam to pound a Vietcong sanctuary, the pilots carry target instructions proposed in Saigon and approved in Washington.
An intensification of the Administration's program of wage and price restraints next year was forecast yesterday by a leading economist.

The nation's 56-month-old economic expansion "may come to an inglorious end" unless steps are taken to slow the growth rate in bank credit and to curb Federal spending on civilian programs, Dr. Arthur F. Burns warned yesterday.
CHERRY HILL, N.J., Oct. 26 (AP) -- Lucky Eagle, a New York invader, scored a 2 1/2-length victory in today's feature race at Garden State Park, living up to her 8-5 favoritism.

In the past two days The Times has recommended candidates for election to the State Senate and Assembly from the five boroughs. We now list our preferences for both houses of the Legislature from Westchester, Nassau and Suffolk. Incumbents are designated by an asterisk.
The McCrory Corporation announced yesterday the appointment of Stanley Maer as vice president and national store merchandise manager of its McCrory-McLellan-Green variety-store division.
The directors of R.H. Macy Co., Inc. raised the quarterly dividend yesterday to 35 cents a share on the common stock.

In your Oct. 22 issue you published a letter from Timothy Costello in which he once again repeats his charge that William F. Buckley Jr. insinuated the religious issue into the current campaign in a speech delivered in Queens on Oct. 14.
NEW DELHI, Oct. 26 -- An Indian official said tonight that India should reconsider whether she was bound by a 1954 agreement to recognize Communist China's suzerainty over Tibet.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art took a closer look yesterday at the $225 bargain it snapped up at a Parke-Bernet auction last week. It tapped the sculpture with tools and studied it with magnifying lenses. Then it pronounced itself delighted.
After heated debate, the City Council by a 28-to-2 vote approved a resolution yesterday designating next Saturday as Support American Vietnam Effort Day.

Earnings of the International Minerals and Chemicals Corporation in the first fiscal quarter ended Sept. 30 rose 29 per cent above the comparable period of last year, T.M. Ware, chairman, reported to the annual meeting yesterday in Chicago.
Using toy shovels and a few dozen bricks, 30 Bronx housewives laid a symbolic foundation yesterday for a new elementary school that the Highbridge neighborhood has been waiting for since 1954.
The Southern Railway reported yesterday that its profits in the third quarter fell to $6,913,000, or 93 cents a share, from $7,405,000, or $1 a share, in the similar 1964 quarter.
OTTAWA, Oct. 26 -- Near unanimity of opinion in the major parties has all but removed United States policies and relationships as an issue in the present election campaign.
A meeting of European ship-owners and shippers at Brussels reached agreement yesterday on four major points.
LONDON, Wednesday, Oct. 27 -- A British airliner veered off a fog-shrouded runway, struck a building and burst into flames on landing at London Airport early today.

JOHANNESURG, South Africa, Oct. 26 -- An Afrikaans newspaper close to Prime Minister Hendrik F. Verwoerd today called on the Johnson Administration today to keep Senator Robert F. Kennedy from visiting South Africa as the guest of a multiracial students' organization.

The Moscow Philharmonic Orchestra programed only two works for its concert in Carnegie Hall last night, Beethoven's Violin Concerto and Mahler's Ninth Symphony. Kiril Kondrashin again conducted. David Oistrakh was soloist in the concerto, thus making it an old story that one never tires of hearing but that needs no comment at this point.

The Curtis Publishing Company said yesterday it had agreed "in principle" to sell 251,000 acres of mineral and timberland in Ontario and Pennsylvania to the Texas Gulf Sulphur Company for $24 million.

The New York State Legislature's Joint Committee to Revise the Banking Law, headed by Senator Jeremiah B. Bloom, Democrat of Brooklyn, plans to hold hearings next month to determine whether "national banks have any competitive advantage over state-chartered banks."

Dr. Bernard E. Donovan, Superintendent of Schools, has recommended that every city school be given a "business manager" to relieve the principal of routine paper work so he can spend more time as an educational leader.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The Administration, under some diplomatic pressure from New Delhi, is considering a renewal of surplus-food aid to India on a long-term bals.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct. 26 (UPI) -- T. Graydon Upton, executive vice president of the Inter-American Development Bank, urged today the development of active Latin-American securities markets as a way to transform local savings into productive investment.
At least six of the 49 Reform Democratic clubs have decided to stay neutral in the mayoral campaign between Controller Abraham D. Beame and Representative John V. Lindsay.
A survey of 53 investment companies shows that common-stock purchases totaling $652 million barely tipped the balance against sales of $649 million during the third quarter of 1965.

There was another opening of another show last night -- the 82d edition of the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden -- and numbers of the socially prominent joined other show enthusiasts for the festivities.
SINGAPORE, Oct. 26 -- The Indonesian Army today defied President Sukarno's pleas for calm and carried its anti-Communist drive to his Government's doorstep.
With the city's water storage showing a 24-hour drop of 200 million gallons at 8 A.M. yesterday, Mayor Wagner commended New Yorkers for achieving a saving of about 250 million gallons a day.

Two more manufacturers have changed their minds about moving out of the city after receiving long-term, low-interest loans from the City Industrial Development Commission, Commerce Commissioner Louis Broido reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Even when you make allowances for all the anxiety, discomfort and pain, President Johnson's gall bladder operation probably was a bargain.
Police Commissioner Vincent L. Broderick asked the City Planning Commission yesterday to include funds in the 1966-67 capital budget for seven "vitally needed" new station houses.
Ten more former employes of the Internal Revenue Service and a certified public accountant were indicted on bribery charges yesterday by a Federal grand jury here.
Representative John V. Lindsay was greeted with a cascade of boos and cries of "pinko" on Wall Street yesterday when he tried to address a lunch-hour crowd on the problems of air pollution.
BRUSSELS, Oct. 26 -- In the first show of unity in the European Common Market's four-month-old crisis, the five active member states agreed today on how to deal with France.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- The Associated Press asked the Federal Communications Commission today to set a policy that would permit news media to lease satellite communications channels for transmission of news and pictures.

ANCHORAGE, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Thirty-six Russian whaling and fishing vessels, presumed to be equipped with electronic gear, were reported in the area of the Aleutian Islands today as preparations continued for an underground nuclear blast.
Is the Johnson Administration going to short-change the City of New York and discriminate against its interests in carrying out Federal programs if the city elects a fusion candidate as Mayor?

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Oct. 26 -- Prime Minister Wilson of Britain agreed today to consider seriously a treaty with Rhodesia guaranteeing that the colony, if it got its independence, would not deprive its black citizens of their constitutional rights.

The Brooklyn Home Builders Association and the Queens Home Builders Association, which have been operating as separate divisions of the Long Island Home Builders Institute, have merged and will ,henceforth function as a single unit of the institute.

Tucker Frederickson was one of those awestruck by Jimmy Brown at Yankee Stadium last Sunday. Frederickson, observing the rival fullback from the sidelines for the first time, came to his backfield coach, Harry Wright, and said, "What's he got?"

ALBANY, Oct. 26 -- "Very substantial profits" on textbooks and food were made on State University campuses by so-called nonprofit faculty-student associations, the State Department of Audit and Control said today.

A CONCERN that all soceties everywhere have in common is the care of the very young. The concern is biologically rooted -- without it, the human species could not survive -- and it is universally structured in the concept of family and kinship. The family constellation varies in form from society to society, but is present in all, primitive and sophisticated.
The Illinois Building Authority sold yesterday $21.29 million of revenue bonds to a syndicate led by seven banking concerns.
SRINAGAR, Kashmir, Oct. 24 -- The gondola slipped silently up the canal, weaving a thread of black water through the pale green ferns.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 26 -- Vietcong guerrillas fought their way to within 20 yards of the beleaguered Special Forces camp at Pleime this afternoon before being repulsed.

THE salient characteristics of "The Royal Hunt of the Sun" are its high intelligence and its bold, imaginative reach. In return for these blessings one can forgive affectations of style and a certain amount of theatrical hocus-pocus.

" English History 1914-1945," by A.J.P. Taylor, will be published by Oxford University Press on Nov. 4. This is Volume XV of "The Oxford History of England." The author is an Oxford historian, journalist and leading figure on British television.
The General Motors Corporation, world's largest manufacturing enterprise, reported yesterday the highest profit ever achieved by any company.
The General Electric Credit Corporation announced yesterday it was entering the export-finance business.
Sixty prominent New York businessmen gathered yesterday, at the invitation of the New York Urban League, to plan an advisory council to find better jobs for Negroes and Puerto Ricans.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Was it true, the Wilmington, N.C., sheriff was asked by a Congressional committee today, that at one time half of his officers were members or sympathizers of the Ku Klux Klan?

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 26 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Lakers stormed from behind and defeated the New York Knickerbockers tonight, 104-102, in the Lakers' National Basketball Association home debut before a crowd of 8,648 at the Sports Arena.
CHICAGO, Oct. 26 -- Nothing is sure in Chicago but death, taxes and the Krebiozen fraud trial.
ROME, Oct. 26 -- From the beginning the Vatican Ecumenical Council's declaration on religious liberty has been called the "American schema."
MOSCOW, Oct. 26 -- Soviet economists are painting a glowing picture of an affluent Marxist society arising out of the reform of the nation's industry decreed last month.
Carmine Lombardozzi, the reputed Mafia leader and delegate to the 1957 convention of gangland figures in Appalachin, N.Y., was arrested yesterday as a traffic scofflaw.
ROME, Oct. 26 -- The center-left Government of Premier Aldo Moro won a confidence vote toight over a cotroversial "censorship" article in a bill aimed at aiding the Italian film industry.
LONDON, Oct. 26 -- Parliament reconvened today and elected a new Speaker in a ceremony that mixed pageantry with a political gain for the Labor Government.
The United States Steel Corporation reported yesterday a sharp increase in third-quarter earnings to $1.21 a share from 90 cents in the 1964 period.
The Ford Foundation announced yesterday the donation of $5 million in grants in a number of fields where it has been active.

PARIS -- France is eager to start bilateral talks with the United States early next year and this could be one reason General de Gaulle has replaced his senior diplomat, Herve Alphand, who served nine years as Ambassador in Washington. Alphand, who becomes Secretary General of the French Foreign Office, is being succeeded in the U.S.A. by Charles Lucet, hitherto Political Director at the Quai d'Orsay.
AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 26 -- President Johnson signed today the $2 billion rivers and harbors authorization bill, but said he would not abide by one of its provisions.

KEY WEST, Fla., Oct. 26 (UPI) -- A young Cuban exile armed with a pellet pistol threatened today to kill the crew and blow up a National Airlines plane unless the pilot agreed to take him to Cuba to rescue his family from the Communist island.

The continuing resurgence of the textile industry was emphasized yesterday by Burlington Industries, Inc., which announced a capital investment program for 1966 of about $123 million. At the same time Charles F. Myers Jr., president, reported record sales and earnings for the fiscal year ended Oct. 2.

LAUREL, Md. JESSE DAVIDSON had just ridden a $58.60 daytime winner, his first of the Laurel meeting. There had been a few wild "yah-hoos," as there would have been at any track after a $58.60 winner, but no boos.

ALBANY, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Governor Rockefeller tonight told the Democratic majority leaders of the Legislature that they had raised doubts about their "willingness or ability" to draft a reapportionment plan for the 1966 legislative elections.

Sammy Davis has signed a television contract With the National Broadcasting Company to be the host of a weekly musical variety show. The network said yesterday that the "Sammy Davis Show" would make its debut at 8:30 P.M., Friday, Jan. 7.

The Allied Chemical Corporation said yesterday it had entered into an agreement with Iran's National Petrochemical Company to erect a $100 million petrochemical complex at the port of Bander Masshur, in the extreme west of the Persian Gulf.

Forces clamoring for bold action in and against Rhodesia are not those responsible for making the decisions nor those certain to suffer immediately from the consequences. Prime Ministers Harold Wilson and Ian Smith deserve credit for holding off their respective "hawks" long enough to have yet another try in Salisbury at finding an acceptable path to Rhodesian independence -- dim though the prospects of success may be.
ROME, Oct. 26 -- A preliminary vote by the Roman Catholic world hierarchy indicated today that there would be heavy majorities for a new church declaration on religious liberty.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Two Government officials took issue today with organized labor's recent emphasis on earlier retirement as a means of creating jobs.
A lawyer for the Columbia Broadcasting System yesterday characterized Prince Felix Youssoupoff's 1.5 million invasion of privacy suit against the network as "lint picking by a murderer."

" GUESS WHICH YEAR" is a fashion game Vera Maxwell likes to play. She almost always wins, because she made up the rules and because she designs clothes that work for the accolade "timeless" or the word she prefers, "constant."
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 26 (UPI) -- George Royal, Canada's representative in the $150,000 Washington D.C. International, arrived at Laurel Race Course today for the 14th running of the classic on Nov. 11.
The Chicago North Western Railway, which since June, 1963, has been battling for control of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad, won a strong ally yesterday.

James L. Robertson, the former F.B.I. agent from Broken Bow, Neb., who is a member of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System, took a swipe yesterday at a recent -- and potentially highly significant -- ruling by the Controller of the Currency, James J. Saxon.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 26 (AP) -- United States District Judge Lloyd H. Burke today denied Ampex Corporation a new trial in an antitrust damage award to the MVR Corporation.
GENEVA, Oct. 26 -- The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade will begin consideration next month of a Yugoslav request for full membership at an early date, informed sources said today.
Willie Mays won the National League slugging title last season for the fifth time, the final averages showed yesterday.

Plans to build the world's first gas turbine rail passenger car and test it on a 20-mile section of the Long Island Rail Road were announced yesterday by the Metropolitan Commuter Transportation Authority.
NASHVILLE, Oct. 26 (UPI) -- A coroner ruled today that an 11-year-old polio victim had died of lobar pneumonia, and not because the electric power to his iron lung had been cut off.
The State of Texas has become a passer's paradise during the 1965 college football season despite the fact that the top Texan -- Bill Anderson -- got away.

As with the moth and the flame, Richard M. Nixon on the stump is drawn inexorably back to the dangerous and mostly irrelevant themes that helped him to early success in California but probably cost him the Presidency.
The National Collegiate Athletic Association lost parity yesterday with the Amateur Athletic Union and other national governing bodies on United States Olympic committees.

Arthur J. Benline, the Commissioner of Air Pollution Control, and six Radio City Music Hall Rockettes, dressed in what for them are working clothes, launched 25 red and yellow helium-filled balloons yesterday in an experiment designed to trace the path of air pollution.
The Transit Authority expressed hope yesterday that it would get increased Federal aid to help improve and expand the city's subways.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 26 -- Snipers fired today on armed helicopters that were escorting a copter carrying Senator M. Kennedy to an American Special Forces camp near the Cambodian border, about 100 miles southwest of Saigon, eyewitnesses said.

Oscar Robertson missed most of the Cincinnati Royals' preseason training because of a salary dispute, but the National Basketball Association statistics issued yesterday, show he hasn't lost his scoring power.

Bennie Middaugh, a baritone who teaches at Alabama College, made his New York debut last night at Carnegie Hall. Accompanied by Robert Drumm, he offered a program that consisted of a cantata by Handel ("Dalla Guerra Amorosa"), seven songs from Wolf's "Morike Liederbuch," five songs by Faure and Bennie Beach's new "Songs of Remembrance."
Fifty of the most violent minutes in boxing history, packaged as a feature film called "Knockout." will open Friday at the Trans-Lux Broadway Theater, Broadway and 49th Street. It's a tough show.

Squash tennis, a game unknown to many, was praised at the Harvard Club last night. So was Johnny Jacobs, who taught the sport and its more popular counterpart, squash racquets, during a 50-year tenure as the club's professional.

Tobacco, department store and chemical shares were the leaders on the London Stock Exchange yesterday in a day that started out slowly, picked up strength during the afternoon and closed with some profit taking in top issues.

The American Tobacco Company's little known Sweet Caporal brand is being sold in the New York metropolitan area in redesigned packages. The main feature of the new pack is a warning printed on one side: "Caution: Cigarette Smoking May Be Hazardous to Your Health."
BONN, Oct. 26 -- The 21 members of Chancellor Ludwig Erhad's new Cabinet, which was formed after weeks of bitter in-fighting, were sworn in today before the Bundestag (lower House of Parliament).
Tong Il Han, a 23-year-old pianist from Korea, won the 24th International Leventritt Competition finals yesterday at Carnegie Hall.

BONN, Oct. 26 -- West Germany took another step today in its economic "push to the East" as the Foreign Ministry announced an agreement with Bulgaria to increase trade between the two nations by 30 per cent next year.

CREUSE is the name of new cheese made partly from skim milk that is being imported from France by Cheese Unlimited, 1263 Lexington Avenue (85th Street). The golden amber, semisoft cheese, which is described as a cross between Munster and Swiss, has a mild, slightly nutty flavor that makes it suitable for buffets or for serving as a dessert cheese.
Life on the horse show circuit is no cup of tea if you're a lone Briton trying to uphold the honor of the Union Jack.
As pediatricians in a rural area of New York State we support with enthusiasm the efforts of the State Association for Helping Retarded Children to improve the care of these children.

In the opinion of the undersigned, it is one of the tragedies of the present city administration that it felt it had to yield to pressures in amending the City Charter to reduce the power of the Board of Estimate and of the Borough Presidents.
Perhaps the most interesting aspect of wheat trading yesterday was the reaction that didn't take place.

To write about Balanchine's "Movements for Piano and Orchestra" is like trying to paint the wind. This brief, sweet capsule of a ballet returned to New York City Ballet's repertory at the State Theater, Lincoln Center last night.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Senator Vance Hartke came down off Capitol Hill today to have lunch with officials of the business-mail industry. And he told them just what they wanted to hear.
