SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Oct. 26 -- Hundreds of Dominicans, led by young Communists, staged noisy "Yankee, Get Out!" demonstrations today against United States troops occupying the downtown area.
A three-man British scientific party and its over-snow vehicle have been lost down a crevasse in Antarctica, it was learned here yesterday.

THE only children's dresses ever designed by the late Christian Dior -- three styles -- are to become a part of the permanent collection of the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Costume Institute. They were originally gifts to Larry Aldrich, Seventh Avenue dress manufacturer, for his daughters, Susan and Kate.

The criminal anarchy trial of William Epton, a 33-year-old Progressive Labor party candidate for State Senator, was adjourned to next Wednesday, "the day after election," by Supreme Court Justice Arthur Markewich yesterday.
Reversing Monday's performance, the majority of issues on the American Stock Exchange advanced yesterday on a broad front in moderate trading.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (UPI) -- The General Accounting Office called today for a crackdown on post office employes who abuse sick leave to sell liquor in Philadelphia, drive cabs in New York, teach school in Boston or sweep floors in San Francisco.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The Treasury auctioned $1 billion in one-year bills today at the same average discount rate as the $1 billion in six-month bills drew yesterday.

" You Can't Take It With You," the Moss Hart-George S. Kaufman Pulitzer Prize comedy of the 1936-37 season, will receive its first Broadway revival on Nov. 23 at the Lyceum Theater for an engagement of six weeks. Five previews will start Nov. 18.
The British pound declined slightly in light trading on foreign-exchange markets here yesterday. Its closing quotation was $2.8030, down 2 points from Monday.
CHERRY HILL, N.J., Oct. 26 -- Gov. Richard J. Hughes said today that apathy was "the biggest problem" in his effort for re-election, and invited Republicans to cross party lines to support him.
IT has been said of Elwood Ricardo Quesada that "when he isn't giving somebody hell he's getting it from somebody."
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 26 -- George Christopher, Greek-born former Mayor of San Francisco, made official today his long-contemplated candidacy for Governor of California.
CHICAGO, Oct. 26 (AP) -- The Food and Drug Administration has requested that warning labels be put on preparations containing three drugs because of possible injury to unborn babies.
NEW YORK big-game hunters eager for a reasonably good chance at bagging a deer would do well to give consideration to the 50,000 acres of the Moose River Valley in northern Hamilton County.
It wasn't a session that proved very much about the bond market yesterday.
President Johnson sent his "warm regards" -- but not his endorsement -- to Controller Abraham D. Beame, the Democratic mayoral candidate, last night.

James B. Fisk, president of the Bell Telephone Laboratories, has been named a trustee of the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation. Also announced yesterday was the election of Robert N. Kreidler, the foundation's director of educational affairs as vice president and assistant to Everett Case president.

William F. Buckley Jr. said yesterday that the election of John V, Lindsay as Mayor would be "merely a routine victory for left-wing" Democrats and would have no national importance to the Republican party.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Both the birth rate and the number of babies born in the United States continued to drop through August, the Public Health Service reported today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 26 -- The Indian delegation announced tonight that it would boycott tomorrow's meeting of the Security Council, called to discuss the Indian-Pakistani dispute.

Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., announced yesterday plans for reducing prices on a wide range of household and industrial commercial fluorescent, incandescent and other types of lamps by 4.7 per cent. This would be equal to the Federal excise-tax cut that becomes effective next Jan. 1.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- United States foreign policy was hauled into a global courtroom tonight, where it ended a withering cross-examination from foreign students from four countries and received a stout defense from three prominent -- but somewhat embattled -- Americans.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 26 (UPI) -- Don Heffner, a coach with the New York Mets for the last two years, today was given a contract to manage the Cincinnati Reds for the 1966 and 1967 seasons.

Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., chairman of the Equal Opportunity Employment Commission, said last night that "a major employer in the New York metropolitan area" avoids hiring members of minority groups by recruiting in small colleges in the Midwest.
Most of the stock of the Dreyfus Corporation -- the company that manages the $1.1 billion Dreyfus Fund -- was sold to the public yesterday.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 27 (AP) -- Gov. Richard J. Hughes ordered the State Department of Conservation and Economic Development today to assess whether a fourth major airport is needed in the New York-New Jersey metropolitan area in light of two conflicting reports.
Business is good at the Vivian Beaumont Theater, despite the mixed notices received by "Danton's Death," the first production at the new house.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 27 -- Gov. George C. Wallace is growing increasingly serious about running his wife, Lurleen Burns Wallace, for Governor of Alabama in 1966.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27 -- Directors of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, meeting in Chicago today for the first time in the company's 60-year history, reported increased earnings for the first nine months of this year, but announced that third-quarter profits declined.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- A member of the John Birch Society said tonight that the ultra-conservative group had instructions from Robert H.W. Welch Jr., its leader, to "take over" local Parent Teacher Associations, but not the Republican party.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Bill White and Dick Groat, the remaining two St. Louis Cardinal infield regulars of 1965, and a reserve catcher, Bob Uecker were traded today to the Philadelphia Phils for an outfielder, Alex Johnson; a pitcher, Art Mahaffey, and a reserve catcher, Pat Corrales.
The American Stock Exchange reported yesterday the following changes in the share holdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The Federal Government is quietly seeking to force removal of all racial barriers in the American Dental Association.
Brentano's, which for many years has cherished the slogan, "booksellers to the world," is expanding into a new kind of shop that Leonard Schwartz, its president, calls a cultural department store.
ROME, Oct. 27 -- A parish priest from suburban Philadelphia has apparently had the last word of regular debate in the four years of Ecumenical Council Vatican II.

Proposition No. 1 -- the Pure Waters Bond Act on the ballot Nov. 2 -- is of immense importance to the future of New York City and the metropolitan area. Approval by the voters of Proposition No. 1 is the key to an all-out, decisive attack to end the blight of water pollution throughout the state.
PERTH AMBOY, N.J., Oct 27 -- Gov. Richard J. Hughes struck back vigorously today against what he called his Republican opponent's "raw, disgraceful appeal to emotionalism."

The president of the Publishers Association of New York City said yesterday that both the publishers and the newspaper unions should speak through a single authorized spokesman for their respective sides in future labor negotiations.
The first Negro Postmaster in New York State was sworn in yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The newest member of the Federal Reserve Board took his first public look at the economy today. He found fears of inflation exaggerated and saw no present need to tighten monetary policy.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 27 -- The Security Council was unable to agree today on a resolution to hasten the withdrawal of Indian and Pakistani armed forces from the border combat zone and consolidated peace in the subcontinent.

The nonprofessional politician -- the businessman seeking a seat on his community's governing council or school board -- will be checking next Tuesday's election returns just as closely as the major candidates.
The New York Telephone Company announced yesterday it planned to issue $100 million of mortgage bonds and $200 million of common stock.

Among the decrees being proclaimed today by Pope Paul VI the one that has created the greatest interest and the bitterest debates has been the declaration expressing the Roman Catholic Church's attitude toward Judaism and the Jewish people. Although the text has been weakened a little from its original form, the basic purpose which Pope John XXIII had in mind from the beginning has been preserved.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27 (UPI) -- Sixteen Republican conservatives held a secret meeting in Illinois last August in an attempt "to decide on a new champion to carry the conservative banner." The Chicago Daily News said today in a copyright article.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Oct. 27 -- The master plan for the Fire Island National Seashore, publicly disclosed here today, calls for a 10-year development program and facilities to handle six million visitors a year on the sunwashed barrier beach.
The appointment of Curt S. Townshend as manager of Socony Mobil Oil Company's Gulf and East Coast marine operations was announced here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Adm. David C. McDonald, Chief of Naval Operations, said here today that vessels of the Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service and the merchant marine "are moving 98 per cent of the military equipment and supplies lifted to Vietnam by transportation agencies of the Department of Defense."
AN industrial designer who is a champion sailor has come up with a moderately priced vacation house that adapts the efficient compactness of a cruising sailboat to the needs of a landlubber.
The Hudson River may become the permanent source of additional water for the city, Arthur C. Ford, president of the Board of Water Supply, said yesterday.

The wives of faculty and students at Yale University will be allowed to enroll formally for the first time in February in the men's undergraduate school, the university said last night. But co-education is not around the corner for Yale.
The nation's electric power production rose 8.2 per cent for the week ending Oct. 23 from the level in the corresponding 1964 week, it was reported by the Edison Electric Institute yesterday.

The United States balance of payments, which showed a small surplus in the second quarter of 1965 for the first time since 1957, slipped sharply into deficit during July, August and September -- though not so badly as many analysts had been projecting.

ANDY McGRAW, running on both the Democratic and Republican tickets, is a sure bet to become the next Justice of the Peace in South Fayette Township, Pa., in Tuesday's election. So his date in New York this weekend won't hamper his campaign, which has not really been hard fought.

HAVANA, Oct. 27 -- A much-visited exhibit here suggests that the life of the Cuban bureaucrat is marked by biweekly illness, continual visits to the water cooler, a hot pursuit of office intrigue and a cold indifference to the public.
IT has been said of Esquire magazine that the editors play a little game each month. They slyly prevent Arnold Gingrich, the publisher, from filling it with fishing and hunting articles.
For the first time in more than a quarter century there are definite prospects for a divided Legislature -- the Assembly controlled by the Democrats, the Senate by the Republicans.
Leonard Bernstein moderated a panel discussion, "The Future of the Arts in New York City," Tuesday night at Philharmonic Hall.
ALBANY, Oct. 27 -- Republic Aviation of Farmingdale, L.I., will try to develop a car so safe that its occupants would not be injured seriously in a 35-to-40-mile-an-hour head-on collision.

ANDREE VON KRACKOWIZER is an associate in a business called Clotheshorse, Inc. It is not a catchy or trick name; it outfits jockeys and horses. More recently, it has taken to dressing ordinary men and women in a like but modified fashion.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Thursday, Oct. 28 -- The Jakarta radio said today that a state of war had been officially declared in Central Java, where the Indonesian Army reports that Communists have been massacring civilians.

The American Broadcasting Company said yesterday that "Amos Burke, Secret Agent" would be discontinued after the show of Jan. 12. The television series stars Gene Barry as an undercover operative for a United States intelligence agency.
THIS is a California-size novel about Californians. Its intended stature is tall as a redwood tree. Unfortunately, its execution is fogged in great blurs of words, words, words.

Walter W. Heller, former chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers and the economist most closely associated with the $14 billion income tax cuts voted by Congress in 1964, said yesterday he sometimes felt that the "tax cut lesson may have been learned not wisely but too well."

WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 27 -- A plan for the acquisition and development of new Westchester parks of 7,000 acres was announced by county officials tonight at a meeting of the Westchester Recreation and Park Society in the County Center.
Continental Air Lines, Inc., in an application filed with the Civil Aeronautics Board yesterday, asked for authority to extend its routes to the East Coast and to the Far East.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 27 -- A group opposed to American involvement in Vietnam charted a route today for a new parade from the University of California's Berkeley campus to the Oakland Army Terminal on Nov. 20.

G. Fox Co., a 118-year old, family-owned store in Hartford, has been acquired for more than $41 million in stock by the May Department Stores Company, St. Louis. Fox Co. was one of the few remaining large independent department stores in the United States.
The New York Jets have not pushed the panic button yet. But their finger is on it.
Good news continued to flow from the nation's oil companies -- with one exception.

The registered voters of New York City will be called upon Tuesday to elect a full complement of 37 City Councilmen -- two more than at the last election. Each ballot is cast for a single contender to represent his Councilmanic district plus one choice for Councilman at Large, of which there are two to a borough. Here is our selection of especially qualified candidates. The incumbents are designated by an asterisk.
Last night at the Hunter College Assembly Hall, the Contemporary Chamber Ensemble gave its first concert here since taking up residence at Rutgers University under a Rockefeller Foundation grant.
Alfred Hayes, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, argued last night against the creation of a "synthetic international currency" and a "full-fledged international central bank."
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 27 -- Advocates of a "hard line" took control of Brazil's revolutionary Government today.
The election of Dr. Grayson Kirk as president of the Association of American Universities was announced yesterday.

EGG HARBOR, N.J., Oct. 27 (AP) -- Steve Shurko is running unopposed in the current election campaign for the job as the city's harbor master. It's not strange that no one else wants the job -- there is no harbor here anymore.
It pays to win the World Series.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Oct. 27 -- Black men and women roamed in large groups through the streets of Salisbury today, sometimes singing and chanting, sometimes silent, sometimes scattering into parks and buildings and converging again in day-long demonstrations against Rhodesia's white Government.
ATLANTA, Oct. 27 -- Twenty-three selected prisoners of Atlanta Federal Penitentiary here are being taught computer programing, equipping them for jobs paying up to $20,000 year when they get out.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Alabama authorities have scheduled a December trial for three men accused of the civil rights slaying of the Rev. James J. Reeb, though the prosecutor says the chances of a conviction are doubtful.
Both major candidates for the mayoralty have presented detailed programs for the city's parks and for recreation.
CHICAGO, Oct. 27 (UPI) -- Illinois released today to the Chicago public schools $6 million of the $30 million in Federal aid funds that had been withheld by the United States Office of Education.

UNIVERSITY chancellors, like footballs and life, can take some mighty funny bounces. Consider the case of Edward H. Litchfield. A couple of years ago, as chancellor of the University of Pittsburgh, he became a topic for sports pages throughout the country by telling his football coach how he wanted the game played.

The recently announced opposition of the New York Chamber of Commerce to Question No. 1 on the state ballot, relatdated to the calling of a constitutional convention, has stimulated considerable interest -- and deserves further explanation.

LIKE many European bankers, Andre Meyer has a distaste for publicity. "Maybe it's an excess of humility," he says. Originally, he hoped to keep his $2.5 million gift to New York University anonymous, but he yielded to the insistence of university authorities that his name be made public in connection with the gift, which was announced yesterday.

The two defense lawyers in the murder trial of Richard Robles spent, yesterday in the District Attorney's office listening to tape recordings in which Robles allegedly discussed with friends the slaying of Janice Wylie and Emily Hoffert on Aug. 28, 1963.

Democratic leaders of the Legislature turned over yesterday the assignment of drafting a new state reapportionment plan to a commission of six prominent citizens. They were chosen from a panel of 18 picked by the presidents of leading universities of the state.

CHERRY HILL, N.J., Oct. 27 (UPI) -- Meadow Stable's Hula Girl won the first big race of her career today with a photo-finish triumph in the $10,000 Gardenia Trial for 2-years-olds that resulted in a $68.40 payoff at Garden State Park.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Oct. 27 -- Communist Yugoslavia made an approach last week to one of Western Europe's two trading blocs -- the European Free Trade Association -- in search of a deal, it was disclosed here today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27 -- During a speech to the annual meeting of the American Academy of Pediatrics yesterday, Dr. Sadusk said that the Food and Drug Administration had asked that warning labels be placed on a group of antinausea drugs that might cause deformities in babies if taken by pregnant women.
The Sylvania Entertainment Products Corporation, a marketing unit of Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., announced yesterday the appointment of John T. Morgan as president.
The American Stock Exchange enjoyed another strong rally yesterday until late profit taking reduced the number of advances.
ROCKY HILL, Conn., Oct. 27 -- Gov. John N. Dempsey opened today the last link in a chain of superhighways on which a motorist can drive from New York City to Boston without meeting a stop light.
The appointment of Frederick L. Bissinger as a vice president was announced yesterday by the Allied Chemical Corporation.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Oct. 28 -- Vietcong guerrillas staged a devastating mortar attack late last night on the United States Marine airfields at Danang and Chulai in Central Vietnam. They destroyed at least 20 aircraft and damaged 27.
Representative John V. Lindsay promised yesterday that if he were elected Mayor he would investigate whether judgeships were sold in New York City.

Leo Brown, Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, ruled yesterday that 133 municipal ferry employes involved in last May's strike on the Staten Island ferries had automatically severed themselves from their employment from the time the strike started.
Domestic production of new cars this year will reach 9.5 million, according to a General Motors Corporation executive.
Stock prices continued to ascend to record levels yesterday as most of the popular averages chalked up their ninth gain in the last 10 trading sessions.
SOUTHBURY, Conn., Oct. 27 -- The sign on the door of Moira Wallace's antique-filled red barn in nearby Woodbury says: "Please do not bring handbags for baskets in this shop."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- The American Red Cross said today it had no connection with any efforts to collect blood, funds or other relief supplies for Communist North Vietnam or the Vietcong.

Wheat futures prices rose yesterday in active trading. Buying by commission houses, some covering of short positions and the continued strength in export sales did the trick that news of the Canadian-Red Chinese wheat deal failed to do earlier in the week.
AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 27 -- Two products of central Texas that have previously had little commercial value -- rocks and calf droppings -- have finally developed a market.

James A. Farley said yesterday he could not see how anyone "of Irish or Italian extraction'' could vote for John V. Lindsay for Mayor if he heard a recording of alleged conversations between Lindsay campaign aides.
No one who has visited the redwood forests of northern California needs to be persuaded that these magnificent trees are among the great natural wonders of the world. Some are nearly 2,000 years old.
Supreme Court Justice Abraham J. Gellinoff ruled yesterday that no license is required for department store booths offering theater tickets at box office prices.

Controller Abraham D. Beame's aides were dejected yesterday over the failure of President Johnson to send his endorsement Tuesday, but the Democratic mayoral candidate said he was "confident" it would come "in due time."

LONDON, Oct. 27 (Reuters) -- London's bright young designers of ready-to-wear clothes, currently working 17 hours a day in preparation for their first joint invasion of the American market, yesterday gave buyers from 50 countries a glimpse of the British look they will present in New York next week.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The Federal Communications Commission ordered an investigation today of the entire cost, rate and earnings structure of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, one of the nation's most profitable corporations.
Company presidents appeared before security-analyst societies across the country yesterday and addressed audiences with a zeal that would do credit to a Presidential candidate.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 27 -- Senator Edward M. Kennedy said today that he was encouraged by what he had seen on his five-day visit to Vietnam but warned that the struggle against the Vietcomg guerrillas was likely to be a long one.
The Public Works Department is so far behind in meeting sewer construction needs throughout the city that it will take at least 40 years to catch up with projects now on the books.

TWENTY-EIGHT players from all over the globe, all under 21 years old, gathered at Barcelona recently for the Junior World Championship. Five preliminary qualifying groups were formed with five or six players in each.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Oct. 27 -- Premier Suleyman Demirel, whose conservative Justice party won a majority in the Oct. 10 national elections, announced today the formation of a new Cabinet.
The Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority and the Port of New York Authority were sharply criticized yesterday by civic leaders at a state hearing here.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Robert Kimball, a 37-year-old United States aid employe who admitted he had killed his boss and a Vietnamese woman, was sentenced tonight to five years in prison.
PARIS, Oct. 27 -- President de Gaulle let it be known today that he would address the nation by radio and television Nov. 4.

Unless New York and other states take "definitive and courageous action to stop the upward surge in traffic accidents" complete Federal controls are in the offing, Governor Rockefeller warned yesterday.
Jeanne-Marie Darre came to Carnegie Hall last night armed with her usual vitality, pianistic zip and a Chopin program.
Directors of Textron Inc., approved yesterday a two-for-one split of the common stock and an increased quarterly dividend of 2.5 cents a share on the new stock.
DECATUR, Ga., Oct. 27 (AP) -- Walters O. Brooks, a 45-year-old member of the Georgia Pardon and Parole Board, shot and killed the divorced husband of a board employe early today.
The president of the College Entrance Examination Board called yesterday for a re-examination of guidance and admission tests to determine whether they will be adequate for the future.
Advertising agencies were told yesterday by a Federal official that, in general, they must share responsibility for deceptive or false claims made by an advertiser.

The future of the American merchant marine, now under attack by Federal officials, should be settled by Congress after it has heard testimony from all those who have a valid interest in shipping, a leading steamship industry executive said yesterday.
SINCE the word for the Chinese delicacy is a transliteration, it is spelled variously dim sim, dem sem and deem sum. Florence Lin, a local authority on Chinese cooking, prefers deem sum.

One of the myths which nurtures most white South Africans is that the United States faces a race problem in common with their own. So the importance of Senator Robert Kennedy's projected visit to give an address at the University of Cape Town cannot be overestimated.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 27 (AP) -- The theory that man and the apes evolved from the same ancestors -- the central issue in a dramatic trial in Tennesse 40 years ago -- stirred new controversy today with cancellation of a school play about the trial.

JOLIET, Ill., Oct. 27 (AP) -- Margaret Truman, daughter of former President Harry S. Truman, received two curtain calls last night as she began a starting role in "The Happy Time" at the Piccolo Playhouse.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- A home remedy for poisoning has been ruled safe enough to be sold without a physician's prescription, the Food and Drug Administration announced today.
New York University announced yesterday that Andre Meyer, an investment banker, had given $2.5 million for the construction of a new physics building at the school's Washington Square campus.
Some World's Fair note-holders are protesting because the fair corporation is defaulting on $22,421,750 in promissory notes.

PLEIME, South Vietnam, Oct. 27 -- A battalion of United States troops leaped from helicopters today to a burned and scarred slope just outside the barbed wire of the Pleime Special Forces camp, which has been under attack for eight days.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 27 -- A Yale football team that appeared to be plummeting to the nether regions of the Ivy League with its loss to Columbia, found itself last Saturday against Cornell, and the Bulldogs' 24-14 victory has started a rush to the box office that points to a crowd of 50,000 for the Dartmouth game here Saturday.

Kathy Kusner, the gifted young Virginia horsewoman, displayed her talents with special verve at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night. She won the Frederick D. MacKay Memorial Challenge Trophy in international jumping for the second straight year and became the leader for the individual championship she had won in the Garden last fall.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (UPI) -- Vice Adm. Hyman G. Rickover warned today against uncontrolled exploitation of science that "may become a Frankenstein monster, destroying its creator," man.
NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 27 (AP) -- A Federal judge rebuked Bogalusa civil rights leaders today for encouraging Negro pupils to stay out of school to take part in protest demonstrations.

" I have to do my homework -- my playing isn't satisfactory," Vladimir Horowitz, who has been playing the piano for 55 years, said yesterday as he practiced for an hour and a half on the stage of Carnegie Hall.

William F. Buckley Jr. said yesterday that if he were elected Mayor he would try to stop out-of-city cars from coming into Manhattan, raise the subway and bus fare to put the transit system on a pay-as-you-go basis and possibly permit taxis to carry more than one fare at a time.
The Boston Stock Exchange said yesterday that its rules had been amended to permit member firms to split commissions with nonmembers. The new rule goes into effect Monday.

A special committee has agreed tentatively to hold public hearings on proposals for providing financial assistance to victims of violent crimes, or their families, Governor Rockefeller said yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 27 -- A venerable Hollywood establishment called Barney's Beanery unexpectedly emerged this week as one of the town's cultural landmarks. Every evening, crowds of art fanciers, artists and curiosity seekers have formed long lines outside the Beanery to pay their homage to culture.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Schoolchildren in a Utah county that has experienced more nuclear fallout than any other county in the United States may have an abnormally high incidence of small lumps on their thyroid glands, the Public Health Service said today.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 27 -- Brazil's decision to invoke revolutionary powers and the instability of the Dominican situation have intensified debate in diplomatic circles here about the wisdom of holding the conference of foreign ministers of the Organization of American States in Rio de Janeiro next month.

Volunteers and amateurs, working out of noisy, cramped and generally dirty storefronts throughout the city, have fashioned a formidable political weapon for the Republican-Liberal nominee for Mayor, John V. Lindsay.

ROME, Oct. 27 -- Prelates of the Roman Catholic Church have in effect ruled out any chance of removing from the schema on religious liberty the controversial declaration that proper use of such liberty should lead all men to truth in Catholicism.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The Rev. George F. Dorsett of Greensboro, N.C., is a very versatile Kludd, a House inquiry was told today.
ALGIERS, Oct. 27 -- A Foreign Ministry spokesman asserted tonight that, despite Pekings announced boycott, the African-Asian chiefs of state will meet here Nov. 5 as planned.

IF there is a prevailing look in the resort and spring knits that will turn up in stores starting in late November, nobody has told the manufacturers about it. In fact, the only thing that three of the major New York houses have in common is that each uses knitted fabrics.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- For the first time in a dozen years, the number of babies born annually in the United States is expected to fall below 4 million.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Indonesia has agreed in principle to accept international controls over the atomic materials and equipment for peaceful purposes that she receives from the United States.
The 24-day strike, from Sept. 16 to Oct. 11, by the New York Newspaper Guild against The New York Times cost The Times an estimated $1.7 million in lost earnings.

MONTREAL, Oct. 27 (UPI) -- Jean Beliveau pushed Dick Duff's rebound past Ed Giacomin late in the third period tonight as the Montreal Canadiens fought off three New York comeback attempts to beat the Rangers, 4-3, in a National Hockey League game.
A major event for all bridge enthusiasts is the publication today of "The Complete Book of Duplicate Bridge" by Norman Kay, Sidney Silodor and Fred Karpin. (495 pp.; G.R. Putnam's, New York, $6.95).
LONDON, Oct. 26 (Reuters) -- The British Government ordered a public inquiry tonight into the cause of an Edinburgh-to-London airliner crash that killed 36 at fog-shrouded London Airport early today.

ALBANY, Oct. 27 (AP) -- The judiciary committee of the State Bar Association gave today an equal rating of "well qualified" to Justice Owen McGivern of State Supreme Court and former Senator Kenneth B. Keating in the contest for a seat on the Court of Appeals.

It is hard to see the logic in Albert J. Zack's argument [letter Oct. 19] that unions require the power of compulsory membership in order to represent employes "most effectively." History and logic alike argue that the strongest and most effective societies are those based on voluntary association.

A pair of repeaters -- Charles E. Wilson's Blue Thor and William Haggin Perry's Batteur -- came through in the separate divisions of the New York Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. Blue Thor took the first section of the turf fixture for older fillies and mares by a length over Margarethen and Batteur the second division, by a half-length over Good Jane.
VIENNA, Oct. 27 -- The annual conference of the International Air Transport Association decided tentatively tonight to introduce a passenger charge of $2.50 for movies shown in airliners in flight.

Comet Ikeya-Seki is putting on a spectacular display for those able to see it. It will remain visible to the unaided eye in most of the Northern Hemisphere for the rest of this week, astronomers said, and will be visible with binoculars most of the next month.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that there must be special limitations on the rights of unions to picket subcontractors at construction sites.

Franklin Book Programs, the nonprofit organization that helps developing countries with their publishing industries, yesterday elected five new directors at its annual meeting. They are Archibald S. Alexander, Harding F. Bancroft, Harold G. Helm, William G. Saltonstall and Theodore Waller.
A group of tenants and homeowners have protested that the noise of helicopters flying low over mid-Manhattan is making conversations impossible and causing intolerable vibration in their apartments.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 27 -- The Government's copper Chile-anization bill -- designed to make this country the No. 1 producer of copper by 1970 following some $420 million in new investments here -- moved back to the Senate today.
ALBANY, Oct. 27 -- The Court of Appeals got the job tonight of deciding on the final line-up of city candidates on the voting machines for Tuesday's elections.
Treasury bond dealers reacted favorably yesterday afternoon to the Government's plan to refund $9.7 billion of notes maturing in November with an 18-month note priced to yield 4.37 per cent.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 27 -- The United States disclosed today that its proposal for reduction of nuclear arms stocks would involve the destruction of "several thousand" nuclear weapons by the United States and a similar number by the Soviet Union.
The Society of Colonial Wars in the State of New York will hold its 68th banquet dinner on Wednesday at the Plaza.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 27 -- Prime Minister Terence M. O'Neill told Parliament today that it would be dissolved next month and that a new election would be held Nov. 25.
The effort by the city's organized owners of liquor package stores to prevent a substantial influx of new retailers has won promises of support from both major candidates for Mayor.
A Republican candidate for the State Senate gave 450 unplucked chickens to a scrambling crowd of women and children on the Lower East Side yesterday.

ALBANY, Oct. 27 -- Proposals for a "modern matrimonial statute" will be introduced in the 1966 session of the Legislature, Senator Jerome L. Wilson, chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee on Matrimonial and Family Laws, said today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Government experts say that higher food costs all along the line -- from farmer to processor to shipper to grocer -- are partly responsible for higher grocery bills.

PINEHURST, N.C., Oct. 27 (AP) -- Mrs. Reinert M. Torgerson of Forest Hills, Queens, carded a 10-over-par 80 over the difficult Pinehurst Country Club's No. 4 course today, but maintained her lead after two rounds in the eighth annual North and South women's senior golf championship.

Industrial shares were favored in trading on the London Stock Exchange yesterday, although the pace was much slower than on Tuesday. The Financial Times index of 30 industrials rose 2 points to close at 351.2.

KEY WEST, Fla., Oct. 27 (UPI) -- The largest number of refugees since Premier Fidel Castro gave permission for Cubans to leave the island came streaming out of Cuba today in small boats despite heavy seas that swamped four of the craft.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The chief and deputy chief of the Navy's Bureau of Ships submitted their resignations today in protest against the increasing centralization of authority in the Defense Department.
Students supporting United States policy in Vietnam and others opposing it clashed briefly yesterday at a rally on the campus of Manhattan College in Riverdale, the Bronx.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct 2, -- The police were looking today for an unidentified man who tossed two Molotov cocktail bombs Tuesday night at the synagogue of Congregation, Bikur Cholim, in the west end of Bridgeport.

THEY were great years for painting -- the years from 1865 to the beginning of the new century. Manet, Degas, Monet, Renoir, Pissarro, Sisley, Cezanne, Van Gogh, Gauguin, Toulouse-Lautrec and Seurat -- their vitality is inexhaustible.

Striking employes of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies ended a two-week sit-in at the organization's headquarters yesterday and announced that they would continue the walkout in the traditional manner.

PARIS, Oct. 27 -- Foreign Minister Maurice Couve de Murville will fly to Moscow tomorrow for a five-day visit that is part of a large-scale French effort to establish closer relations with the Soviet Union and other Communist countries.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Stepped-up draft calls have focused attention on the jurisdiction and considerable leeway local draft boards have in classifying registrants under the Selective Service System.
TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Imre Foldi of Hungary retained his bantamweight title today in close competition with two Japanese competitors at the world weightlifting championships.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 27 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury returned a kidnapping indictment today against 20-year-old Walter R. Mott, of Massapequa, N.Y., who is being held in connection with the abduction and rape of an 11-year-old Fair Lawn girl.
Joseph C. DiCarlo, commissioner of licenses, said yesterday that he had been legally powerless to take action against lurid marquee announcements on two Times Square movie houses.

Knopf has published 14 Nobel Prize winners, now that Mikhail Sholokhov has been selected to receive the literary award for 1965. The publisher brought out "And Quiet Flows the Don," "The Don Flows Home to the Sea" and "Tales of the Don."
RICHARD STRAUSS spent a good part of his creative life composing operas. As one of the outstanding professionals of his day he was greatly concerned with the relationship of words and music.

Frank Wille, New York State Superintendent of Banks, stepped yesterday into the burgeoning controversy over whether Federally chartered banks operating in the state can, or cannot, offer to sell negotiable unsecured promissory notes.

Jamaica, the young Caribbean republic fighting for economic self-sufficiency, brought its case to New York yesterday by opening a display of goods that her people hope to sell on a larger scale to United States consumers.
BONN, Oct. 27 -- Chancellor Ludwig Erhard's new Cabinet held its first meeting today and the first order of business was West Germany's big projected budget deficit for 1966.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Oct. 27 -- The regime of provisional President Hector Garcia-Godoy today resumed a gingerly search for weapons in the hands of civilians.
Colleges continued to report yesterday that draft boards had evidently begun to tighten up on student deferments, especially for graduate students.
BOSTON, Oct. 27 (UPI)-The Toronto Maple Leafs ended /a two-game scoring drought with goals by Ron Ellis and Frank Mahovlich tonight for a /2-1 triumph over the Boston JBruins.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, former Ambassador to South Vietnam, expressed the opinion tonight that "success" in the war in Vietnam required no formal surrender.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 27 -- The arrest of a woman barber was cited in a hefty, 1,300-page District Attorney's report issued today as being a major cause of the Los Angeles riots last August.
MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 27 -- District Attorney William Cahn accused John F. English, the Nassau County Democratic chairman, today of "perpetrating a last-minute election eve hoax upon the people."

DETROIT, Oct. 27 (AP) -- The Chrysler Corporation ended weeks of speculation today when it announced that Perrysburg, Ohio, near Toledo, had been picked as the site of a new multimillion-dollar parts manufacturing plant.
The double impact of record sales and earnings plus an all-time high in orders practically assures the Georgia-Pacific Corporation of the best annual results in its 38-year-history.
GEELONG, Australia, Oct. 27 (UPI) -- Ron Clarke, Australia's record-smashing distance runner, added world records in the the 20,000 meters and one-hour run today to his previous list of five.
LONDON, Oct. 27 -- A Prague broadcast denouncing Communist China's attitude toward the war in Vietnam is the subject of puzzled fascination among diplomats here.
Bargaining between milk dealers and three Teamsters Union locals continued on an hour-to-hour basis yesterday in an effort to reach a new contract agreement and avert a citywide strike.

Ed Kelly of Baltimore strengthened his hold on first place in the national invitation pocket billiard championship, defeating Onofrio Lauri of New York, 150-13, yesterday at the Riviera Terrace. Kelly's high run was 68 balls for the eight-inning match.
BALTIIvIORE, Oct. 27 (UPI)I } -- Bill Buntin sank six foulI shots in the last two minutes l tonight to spark the Detroit Pistons to a 108-107 victoryi over the Baltimore Bullets.
Two Brooklyn real estate dealers associated with Carmine Lombardozzi, reputed Mafia leader, have lost their license to practice after an eight-month investigation by the New York Department of State.
AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 27 -- President Johnson signed today a House-Senate resolution authorizing the expenditure of up to $22 million for payment of 180,000 Okinawan claims.

The Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations of America announced yesterday that it had established a special commission to cope with what it described as "the alarming proportion" of intermarriage on college campuses throughout the country.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., Oct. 27 -- State Senator Wayne Dumont Jr. declared today that Gov. Richard J. Hughes "doesn't understand the dangers and perils of Communism -- he never did and never will."
Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation reported records yesterday for operating revenues and net income for the September quarter and for the 12 months ended Sept. 30.

LONDON, Oct. 27 -- Reports are circulating in London that the Indonesian Army has prevented Foreign Minister Subandrio from leaving for the African-Asian Foreign Ministers' meeting that starts tomorrow in Algiers.
BRASILIA, Oct. 27 -- President Humberto Castelo Branco, overriding Congress and the Supreme Court, armed his revolutionary regime today with sweeping new powers.
Active demand from New York and Europe helped the British pound register a net gain of 0.095 against the United States dollar on London foreign-exchange markets yesterday.
Boston Garden, home of the Boston Celtics basketball team and the Boston Bruins hockey team, has been put up for sale by its owner, the Boston and Maine Railroad.

The American Express Company was designated yesterday as the exclusive distributor in this country of advance discount admission tickets to Expo 67, Canada's international exposition that will be held in Montreal in 1967.

Although Christmas is 58 days away, there were toys aplenty at the Hotel St. George in Brooklyn yesterday. One, a Manchester terrier, was the best of the 149 at the 33d annual Progressive Dog Club show.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 27 -- Roosevelt Raceway's crowded calendar of stakes events -- two or three each week -- lists the Lady Suffolk for 3-year-old trotting fillies tomorrow night, the Lady Maud for 3-year-old pacing fillies Monday night, the Roosevelt Futurity for 2-year-old pacers Thursday night Nov. 4, and the Westbury Futurity for 2-year-old trotters on Friday night, Nov. 5.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The Treasury offered today an issue of 18-month notes yielding 4.37 per cent as a replacement for $9.7 billion of securities maturing Nov. 15.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- People who never deign to cruise through the sports pages are missing out on one of the most rousing philosophical debates of the day. The question is: What is the national pastime?
JAKARTA, Indonesia Oct. 27 -- Reports of clashes between non-Communists and Communist party groups in central Java reached here today.

The Boston Symphony Orchestra was back at Philharmonic Hall last night in all its silken perfection. This was its first concert in its 79th consecutive New York season, and it sounded more glittering than ever in the auditorium's improved acoustics.

KANSAS CITY, Oct. 27 (UPI) -- Ed Lopat, an American League pitching star and a manager and coach since the end of his playing days, was named today executive vice president of the Kansas City Athletics.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The testimony of the United States mails arriving at this desk is that only in the New York City mayoral campaign has the right of Christopher Columbus to the title of "Discoverer of the New World" been removed as a public issue.

Details of the offer by Heublein, Inc., the liquor and food producer, to acquire the outstanding shares of the Theo. Hamm Brewing Company, St. Paul, made early this month, were announced yesterday by Ralph A. Hart, president of Heublein.

BLUE, white and BANG! -- firecracker orange were the colors of the first three spring outfits paraded yesterday into the showroom of Mallory, a leather and suede house. The message of Anne Klein, the designer, was clear:
Texas Instruments, Inc., has registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission a Statement covering a proposed offering of $50 million of debentures.
Once upon a time two Yale men set out to rescue the great city of New York from a plague of pygmies. Handsome John and Witty Bill, they were called, and both were members of the Grand Old Party.

SOME people would say that Philadelphia abounds in ghosts and goblins -- even on a normal weekend. That may be a facetious opinion, but on this Halloween weekend John Yovicsin and his Harvard football team have good reasons to be wary of their visit to Philadelphia's Franklin Field tomorrow.
In a terse five-line announcement, the Chase Manhattan Bank served notice yesterday that its rivalry with the First National City Bank would intensify.
The city approved a pilot program yesterday to strengthen nursing service for better patient care in its hospitals.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz suggested today that Federal agencies consider using racial designations on their personnel forms to insure compliance with antidiscrimination laws.
RIVER VALE, N.J., Oct. 28 -- State Senator Wayne Dumont Jr. predicted today that he would win the governorship by a narrow margin. The Republican said he would carry 13 of New Jersey's 21 counties.
JIM GUARD, the biggest winner at last night's Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound awards dinner here, says it's "the little things" that add up to sailboat victories.
DEAL, N.J., Oct. 28 -- Ed Famula of Scotch Hills won in both events of the last scheduled New Jersey Professional Golfers' Association pro-amateur golf tournament today at the Hollywood Golf Club.
A $40 million tunnel bypass of the Rondout Reservoir near Liberty, N.Y., was unanimously approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate.
Orville Wright, Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr., Jane Addams and Sylvanus Thayer were added yesterday to New York University's Hall of Fame for Great Americans.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 28 -- The impending formation of a new political "Party of the Revolution" to carry on President Humberto Castelo Branco's economic program and foreign policy was announced today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The domestic petrochemical industry's need for oil-import quotas was debated today before a special Interior-Commerce Department hearing.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Despite a large drop in the prices of some foods, the Consumer Price Index rose in September to reach a record high again.

The Detroit Symphony opened Carnegie Hall's third annual International Festival of Visiting Orchestras last night, and from every angle, it was a notable occasion. The concert was in memory of Adlai E. Stevenson and was under the patronage of his successor as the United States representative at the United Nations, Arthur J. Goldberg, who spoke after the intermission.

LINCOLNTON, Ga., Oct. 28 -- A group of about 45 Negro laborers halted a civil rights protest march here today and solemnly told the demonstrators that their children were afraid to attend classes at the segregated county school "because of this marching."

A flood of selling of American Telephone and Telegraph shares by small investors depressed the price of the nation's biggest equity issue yesterday and set in motion a general decline in the stock market.
Bronx voters face a problem in philosophies:

The Golden Anniversary Ball of the Grosvenor Neighborhood House at the Plaza last night evoked an aura of nostalgia. It was a tribute to the settlement's 20 founding members, four of whom were present, and a re-enactment of the debutante presentations at the Grosvenor Balls of the last 22 years at the hotel.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The Gateway Arch, memorializing the pioneers and symbolizing the future of America's heartland, was finished today with insertion of the keystone 630 feet above the Mississippi River's bank.

A simulated brick wall was made higher and higher during successive jumpoffs in Madison Square Garden last night. When it reached 7 feet 1 inch only one horse in the international jumping competition of the National Horse Show took aim and conquered it.

In accordance with the great tradition of The Times for complete and objective coverage of the news you might want to carry statements I made on the Genovese case which were omitted in The Times news story of Oct. 25.
ALGIERS, Oct. 28 -- After a one-hour "semi-official" meeting, African and Asian foreign ministers decided tonight to put off the official opening of their meeting here until Saturday.

Undercover work by a Treasury Department agent who took bets for an alleged $10-million-a-year gambling syndicate in Westchester County led yesterday to the indictment of 10 men and a woman on charges of violating Federal gambling laws.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, indicated today that if he voted in New York, he would support Abraham D. Beame for Mayor.
BRUNSWICK, Ga., Oct. 28 (UPI) -- A three-judge Federal panel formally accepted today Georgia's plan to solve Taliaferro County's school segregation problems.
A voluntary appointment system to speed truck deliveries and pickups at piers here is to go into effect early in December.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 28 -- Coach Dick Colman is as touchy about anyone anticipating out loud as is a pitcher with a no-hitter going, but Princeton could be on its way to duplicating the two successive perfect records of Charlie Caldwell's football teams of 1950 and 1951.
Five tenements on 100th Street in East Harlem, once considered "the worst block in the city," will be rehabilitated by a Chicago foundation with Federal aid.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The proposal to fly two Gemini spacecraft at once came from the spacecraft's manufacturer a day after the Gemini 6 mission ended in failure, a space agency official said today.

DANANG, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Sgt. John Anderson, a 25-yearold marine from Far Rockaway, Queens, placed his 12-man squad for an ambush last night on a trail three miles south of the Danang air base. There was a 22-minute wait.
Vietnam protest movements on American college campuses involve only a small hard core of dissenters, top officials of 85 colleges and universities told the Associated Press yesterday.

The repertory for the American Opera Society's 13th annual subscription series of opera in concert form was announced yesterday by the society's director, Allen Sven Oxenburg. Of the five works to be presented in Carnegie Hall, four have not been heard before in New York during this century.
Delegates to the United Nations filled Carnegie Hall last night for a memorial concert honoring the late Adlai E. Stevenson. Sixten Ehrling conducted the Detroit Symphony Orchestra.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported the following spot primary market prices for the dates shown:

THE Grande Maison de Blanc, which used to sell linens to the Vanderbilts and once made napkins for the White House, is about to move off Fifth Avenue where it has been since its establishment 77 years ago. The Trousseau House of America, as it likes to call itself, will move Monday to 68 East 56th Street.

There are those in this city who believe that most municipal problems -- inadequate schools, crime, drug addiction, heavy welfare costs, high taxes -- can be attributed to the presence in New York of large numbers of Negroes and Puerto Ricans. The impulse of those who feel this way is to attack the people, not the problems.

TORONTO, Oct. 28 -- People on the street, friendly people, are always stopping Ernie Terrell and asking "If you're the champion, what is Cassius Clay?" And Terrell leans down from 6 feet 6 inches, wrinkling his great overhanging brow, and starts from the beginning, like a pre-recorded announcement.
Control of the 1966 Legislature could swing on the outcome of a handful of close Senate and Assembly seats in New York City's suburban area, many Republicans and Democrats believe.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 28 -- Del Insko, driving a victory-starved trotter he never had seen before and knew nothing about, and without instructions from a trainer whose name he didn't know, guided Arabesque home first in the Lady Suffolk Trot for 3-year-old fillies tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- One of two admirals who quit yesterday in protest against the centralization of power at the Pentagon was called before the Chief of Naval Operations and the Deputy Secretary of Defense today to explain himself.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 28 -- President Arturo U. Illia flew to the western provincial capital of Mendoza today for talks with president Eduardo Frei Montalva of Chile, which, Mr. Illia said, would be "vitally important."

The American Trucking Associations, before adjourning its 32d annual convention yes terday, elected Calvin G. Zwingle, 58 years old, as its president for the coming year. Mr. Zwingle succeeds John E. Amos, who for the next year will serve as chairman. John M. Akers, chairman for the last year, was elected a member of the executive committee.

William F. Buckley Jr. accused Representative John V. Lindsay yesterday of "trying to appeal to the Jewish voters by scaring them" during the mayoral campaign. The Con servative party candidate made the charge, one of the sharpest of the campaign, during a three-way radio debate between himself, Mr. Lindsay and the Democratic nominee, Abraham D. Beame.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 28 -- The Security Council reached a deadlock today on the wording of a resolution that would enforce the Indian-Pakistani cease-fire and complete within 78 days the withdrawal of the two nations forces from the battle zone.
Alexander Calder has made an "immobile" in the back yard of a Madison Avenue art gallery, but it belongs to the people next door, who have to go around the corner to see it.
With a blending of solemnity and festive joy, members of the congregation of the Garment Center Synagogue abandoned their old quarters yesterday for a modern house of worship.
IT'S a far cry from the homely functionalism of most table games to four highly decorative diversions just arrived here from Denmark.

THE spring costume that will be in fashion without being high is likely to be a slightly fitted coat or jacket over a matching or lighter-hued skimmer dress, if four moderate-priced Seventh Avenue manufacturers that showed their spring lines yesterday bear any weight.
The British pound continued in demand against the United States dollar on London's foreign exchange markets yesterday and moved to a new 2-year high of $2.80395.
An advertising slogan has been spreading across the city that is not as frivolous as it sounds.

We list today our recommendations where contests exist for judges to be elected to state and local courts. Our choices rely heavily on the evaluations made by the City Bar Association, the bar associations of the various boroughs, and the nonpartisan Citizens Union. We believe, as we have often said, that the caliber of judges would be improved if they were appointed from a panel of carefully screened candidates.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 28 (UPI) -- The Los Angeles Lakers routed the New York Knicks, 140-116, tonight and moved into a first-place tie with San Francisco in the National Basketball Association's Western Division.

LONDON, Oct. 28 -- Labor and Liberal members of Parliament rallied today to support of the Archbishop of Canterbury, assailed by Conservative M.P.'s for his support of military action to prevent the white minority of Rhodesia from seizing independence.
News from Washington yesterday ruffled the wheat futures market. Speculators liked the sound of it and bought new long positions. Shorts were disappointed and bought to even out positions.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The Southern Pacific Company reported today adjusted net income of $70.1 million, or $2.58 a share, for the first nine months of 1965.

The 43-story office building on the southeast corner of Madison Avenue and 40th Street, formerly known as the Johns-Manville Building, has been sold by the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company to Wellington Associates for more than $5 million.

The music of Saint-Saens will be mined by Robert Wright and George Forrest for the songs in a musical play, tentatively called "Dumas and Son." Jerome Chodorov wrote the story, which concerns the relationship of Alexandre Dumas and his son with Madeleine du Plessis, the courtesan who inspired the younger Alexander Dumas to write "La Dame aux Camellias."
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Friday, Oct. 29 -- Israeli Army units struck two Lebanese border villages late last night in raids intended as retaliation against terrorist acts in Israel.

Texaco, Inc., said yesterday its earnings for the first nine months of 1965 rose 10.7 per cent to a new record of $463,823,694, or $3.43 a share. This compares with $418,804,266, or $3.10 a share, in the period of 1964.

AN injury to Edward Villella caused a rearrangement of the program at the State Theater, Lincoln Center, last night, as "Swan Lake," with Melissa Hayden and Andre Prokovsky, replaced the scheduled "Donizetti Variations."

Peter La Farge, a folk song writer and performer who championed the American Indian in many of his ballads, was found dead Wednesday by his wife in their apartment at 409 East 50th Street. He was 33 years old.

HARTFORD, Oct. 28 -- The third state Constitutional Convention in Connecticut's history ended its four-month session today after the 84 delegates had unanimously approved a proposed constitution that will be submitted to the voters on Dec. 14.

PARIS -- Certain basic facts must be kept in mind when analyzing current French policy. Despite vigorous dislike of NATO's organization, France recognizes that for years Western Europe could only be defended in a war by U.S. nuclear power.
CHERRY HILL, N.J., Oct. 28, (AP) -- Priceless Gem, who is battling unbeaten Moccasin for the 2-year-old filly title, was withdrawn today from the $170,000 Gardenia at Garden State Park on Nov. 6.

The Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association assured its members last night at its annual meeting that it was within its rights to abolish the Long Island and Westchester divisions of its organization.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The 15-million member merged labor federation today again strongly endorsed President Johnson's course in the Vietnam war and criticized the "cultivated rowdyism" of many of those opposing him.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28 -- Whitney M. Young Jr., executive director of the National Urban League, urged housing and renewal officials yesterday to push for integration of housing for the good of the entire community, not just for Negro residents.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- In the last days of the recently ended session of the 89th Congress, the Senate Foreign Committee decided to "pass over" President Johnson's nomination of three prominent diplomats for the rank of Career Ambassador, the highest rung in the Foreign Service.

Capt. William Willis, a 72-year-old skipper who has sailed alone across 12,000 miles of the Pacific, skid yesterday that he would set out to establish another world record for sailing alone in a homemade craft.

WINNIPEG, Man., Oct. 28 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian Wheat Board announced today it had signed a three-year agreement with Communist China for the sale of at least 112 million bushels of wheat starting next Aug. 1.

SAN JOSE, Calif., Oct. 28 (UPI) -- Al Geiberger, a two-time winner of this event, and Steve Oppermann, a rookie, tied for the first-round lead today in the $46,000 Almaden open golf tournament with seven-under-par 65's.
NOT long ago, a woodcock decided he was safer flying than hugging the ground between Jim Salvato, a hunting companion from Paterson, N.J., and me.

The State Court of Appeals yesterday knocked Representative John V. Lindsay out of Line E on next Tuesday's ballot and drew from the Republican-Liberal candidate for Mayor a cry that he was being "robbed by the Beame machine."
MALVERNE, L.I., Oct. 28 -- White parents kept their children out of two elementary schools today to protest a plan to end racial imbalance by Jan. 1.

You write rather heatedly in your Oct. 23 editorial denouncing me for various crimes against your code. Please understand that I presume to have if not higher, at least other, ambitions than to please you. But I do believe that your readers should hate me for what I do in fact believe and say, rather than for your lucid transcriptions thereof.
Members of the Baptist Ministers Fellowship of Queens, which embraces 73 churches in the borough, agreed at a meeting this week to support Controller Abraham D. Beame for Mayor.

ROME, Oct. 28 -- Five Ecumenical Council documents have been proclaimed in addition to the five promulgated today by Pope Paul VI during the first of three public meetings of the Council's fourth and final session.

ROME, Oct. 28 -- Pope Paul VI formally promulgated as church teaching today five documents embodying significant changes in Roman Catholic policies and structures and offering friendship and respect to other great world religions.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange ran a respectable 7.23 million shares yesterday. But that's paltry, compared with what happened at the Big Board 36 years ago today.

The Right Rev. Horace W.B. Donegan, the Episcopal Bishop of New York, said yesterday that his support of the civil rights movement had resulted in the withdrawal of several substantial gifts pledged for the completion of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The Pentagon will begin next month to accept volunteers for military service on the basis of "slightly lower" standards in order to reduce the number of persons who must be drafted to meet military manpower requirements.

Screen rights to "The Royal Hunt of the Sun," Peter Shaffer's dramatization of the conquest of the Inca empire by Francisco Pizarro, which opened at the ANTA Theater Tuesday, have been acquired by Filmways, Inc.
The London Stock Exchange closed up yesterday, although many issues did not maintain their highs for the session.

PARIS, Oct. 28 -- The chief United States negotiator in the Kennedy round of tariff talks warned today that the continuing stalemate within the Common Market threatened the outcome of the worldwide effort to liberalize trade.
GENEVA, Oct. 28 -- A projected international agreement would make a licensed skipper mandatory on all sea-going fishing vessels of 25 tons or more.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The United Klans of America has been instructing some of its members in the use of explosives, incendiary devices, firearms, booby traps and guerrilla warfare, a Congressional inquiry was told today.

ROME, Oct. 28 -- Following are the texts of the Decrees on the Bishops and on Christian Education and of the Declaration on Relations to Non-Christian Religions, and excerpts from the Decrees on Religious Life and Priestly Training. All were promulgated today by Pope Paul VI at the Ecumenical Council. The translations, by the National Catholic Welfare Conference, are endorsed by the Bishops of the United States.

" T" fell. And so did the market. Why? The answer was simple: The millions of small investors who hold shares in the world's largest corporate entity were scared. They had read and heard about the forthcoming Federal Communications Commission investigation of the rate-making procedure of their company and they were afraid.

Two pacifists who had planned to burn their draft cards during an antiwar demonstration in Foley Square yesterday were balked in their attempt, first by the police and then by an unruly throng of newsmen.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Senator Maurine B. Neuberger, Democrat of Oregon, has definitely decided not to seek re-election next year.

AUSTIN, Oct. 28 -- President Johnson's failure thus far to endorse Controller Abraham D. Beame, the Democratic candidate for Mayor of New York, appeared today to be based partly on the assessment of the President's advisers that Mr. Beame might lose the election.
Profit taking depressed prices on the American Stock Exchange yesterday as many issues fell in quiet trading.

Lily Keleti, Hungarian-born and educated pianist who now lives in Greensboro, N.C., gave a recital at Town Hall last night. She is a thoroughly grounded musician in the old-fashioned sense, plays with a strong tone, and projects a patient personality and plenty of feeling.
Ten major league rookies, one minor leaguer and Bill Shea were honored yesterday at the seventh annual awards luncheon of the Topps chewing gum rookie all-star team at the Americana Hotel.
The roar of the sixties has reached its highest pitch. This year in the corporate world, business is enjoying the greatest profits in history.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28 -- Margaret Gest, Philadelphia painter and bibliophile who died last month, left her estate, valued at $2 million, to Haverford College to support annual lectures "in perpetuity" on the "fundamental unity of religions."

Kenneth Drake, the pianist who made his local debut in Carnegie Recital Hall last night, played four Beethoven sonatas on a handsome old Broadwood piano restored by John Challis. The instrument may approximate the sound of the one Broadwood sent to Beethoven in 1817, but it proved to be an obtrusive factor.

Heavy trading of Trans Caribbean Airways shares on the American Stock Exchange yesterday was attributed to a leak of information concerning the possible award of new routes to the air carrier by the Civil Aeronautics Board.

DUBLIN -- About 250 motor assembly workers marched in protest through the streets of Dublin on a recent Saturday carrying placards reading "Cars imported, men exported" and "Free trade spells doom for the motor assembly industry."

Dr. Bernard E. Donovan, Superintendent of Schools, informed the City Planning Commission yesterday that the Board of Education was going ahead with plans for educational parks although they were "an unknown quantity."
REGINE, who prefers that "les femmes sont bien habillees" when they come to her Paris nightclub, New Jimmy's, is going to be very well-dressed herself in the four days she will spend in New York.

MOSCOW, Oct. 28 -- Foreign Minister Maurice Couve de Murville of France arrived in Moscow today. He was the first official visitor from a Western Government to be received by the Soviet leadership since Nikita S. Khrushchev was deposed a year ago.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Oct. 28 -- Prime Minister Wilson of Britain is planning to fly to Zambia in a show of solidarity with the black African members of the British Commonwealth if he fails to come to terms with the Rhodesians in their demand for independence.
Henry H. Anderson Jr. of Manhattan was re-elected to a third term as president of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound yesterday at the group's annual meeting in the New York Yacht Club.
PALO ALTO, Calif., Oct. 28 -- The Stanford Repertory Theater made its debut as a professional resident company last night with a Moliere comedy, "That Scoundrel Scapin."
ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 28 -- A fire at 2:30 A.M. today in an Ithaca College fraternity house left one student dead, one close to death, three others in the hospital and 20 others homeless.
WASHINGTON, Oct 28 -- References to the University of Colorado in connection with "anti-Vietnam agitation and the teach-in movement" have been deleted from a Senate staff report.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The United States gained gold in September for the first time this year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

BONN, Oct. 28 -- A 22-year-old United States Army private from Queens, New York, sat down to his first meal tonight after a three-day hunger strike staged to dramatize his desire to fight for the United States in Vietnam.
Against the backdrop of an impending $9.7 billion Treasury refunding operation, Federal Reserve open market operations in the week ended Wednesday followed a classic "even keel" course.

HAWORTH, N.J., Oct. 28 -- Walt Zembriski, an amateur from the Northwood Golf Club, shot a one-over-par 73 today and took a two-stroke lead in the second annual Bergen County invitation open golf championship at the White Beeches Golf and Country Club.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Total Federal Government spending will rise a minimum of $10 billion and a maximum of $13 billion in the calendar year 1966 over 1965, according to reliable estimates circulating here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Intercity truck tonnage in the latest week ended Oct. 23 was considerably ahead of the volume in the corresponding week of 1964. Rail carloadings during the same period declined.

The Chrysler Corporation made it unanimous among the Big Three of the automobile industry by announcing yesterday record sales and earnings for the first nine months of this year. Directors also voted to double the quarterly dividend rate.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Last March 3, a dramatic change came in the life of Donald Thomas Appell. He stopped hunting Communists, a pursuit that had occupied most of his professional life, and went after the Ku Klux Klan.

Many member voluntary non-profit hospitals of the United Hospital Fund have set up, or are making plans to initiate, a service for the elderly and chronically ill patients who need extended care, but who would be happier in their own home environments.
The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation raised its quarterly dividend yesterday on the strength of improved nine-month earnings, but reported a decline in third-quarter profits.

DETROIT, Oct. 28. (UPI) -- Bobby Hull and Doug Mohns scored two goals each to power Chicago to a 5-1 victory over the Detroit Red Wings tonight and lift the Black Hawks into a tie for the National Hockey league lead with Montreal.
One art expert not associated with museums here is trying to resolve the conjecture about the Metropolitan Museum of Art's $225 purchase of a sculpture that may be worth $500,000.
When the Sunday duffer leaves home for exercise, his wife usually becomes a golf widow. When Frank Chapot leaves home for exercise, his wife goes with him -- and sometimes beats him.
MOSCOW, Oct. 28 -- A Soviet astronomer has disclosed that a Russian deep space probe picked up powerful, mysterious radio waves, possibly from a distant planet.

PARIS, Oct. 28 -- Somewhere between the distinctive styles of Al Capone, the Duke of Windsor and Pierre Cardin lies the reason why young Frenchmen suddenly and surprisingly look so well dressed. Capone was a gangster, the Duke was once a King, and Cardin is the couturier who broke through French indifference four years ago with ideas that have become an $8 million business in men's clothes.
DANANG, South Vietnam, Oct. 28 -- Three young United States marines, who had never before fired a rifle in combat, all but annihilated a Vietcong commando unit this morning.
The director of the Citizens Committee for Lindsay charged yesterday that a Beame campaign committee violated the state penal law by receiving corporate contributions for a dinner journal.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Dr. Joseph H. McNinch, who has headed the Veterans Administration medical program since June 3, 1963, will retire Jan. 1, it was announced today.

ALBANY, Oct. 28 -- A "significant change for the worse" in the British narcotic situation in the last seven years has taken place, two state mental health officials have reported to Governor Rockefeller.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y. Oct. 28 -- Members of the Metropolitan Commuter Transportation Authority found today that suburban facilities of the deficit-ridden New Haven Railroad were even worse than they had expected.

The Pentagon has gone to some lengths to deny that the resignations of the chief and deputy chief of the Navy's Bureau of Ships represented a revolt against Secretary of Defense McNamara. But the two admirals were obviously protesting against the Defense Department's consolidation of authority and its downgrading of command personnel -- policies initiated by Mr. McNamara and his immediate staff.
PURCHASE, N.Y., Oct. 28 -- There was a noisy student demonstration on the campus of Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart here today that had nothing to do with war, peace or nuclear fallout.

ALBANY, Oct. 28 -- (AP) A woman who contended that her husband concealed a Nazi background and "fanatically anti-Semitic" views has valid grounds for seeking an annulment, the Court of Appeals ruled today.
New York City will have its participation in the Neighborhood Youth Corps program cut during the next eight months, the United States Labor Department said yesterday.
LONDON, Oct. 28 -- A London house made famous by the man who owned it for 20 years was sold at auction today for the equivalent of $287,000.

GEORGE SZELL relieved Leonard Bernstein last night as commander of the New York Philharmonic. It may have been the brisk autumn air, which sets the blood a-tingling. It may have been sheer exhilaration; it may have been a dinner of raw meat.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Despite South Africa's thorough policy of racial separation, Mary Oppenheimer, one of the world's wealthiest heiresses, has invited blacks as well as whites to her wedding.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 28 (UPI) -- The Indonesian Army said tonight it was holding 97 members of a Communist youth group that had attacked an infantry battalion last week in support of the unsuccessful attempt to overthrow President Sukarno.

Two hurdle races occupied the featured spots as the United Hunts began a two-day stand at Aqueduct yesterday but from the standpoint of chalk players the featured aspect had to be the preponderance of winning choices in the flat races.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Oct. 28 -- Seven nonmembers of the European Common Market tangled today over what to make of the Common Market's growing trade crisis. Their consensus was to keep hands off.

Plans by American Export Isbrandtsen Lines to build replacement ships in a "wholesale" lot for its around-the-world service have brought protests from the shipbuilder who had submitted the lowest bid for four of the eight freighters involved.
Mayor Wagner will soon propose to Federal authorities that the Lower Manhattan Expressway be built entirely below street level.
The Brooklyn Union Gas Company reported yesterday a gain in operating revenues for the first nine months, but net income declined slightly from the like 1964 period.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 28 -- A formal dinner attended by the Spanish Ambassador and his wife marked the opening tonight of the Pittsburgh Opera Company season.
A fear that recently enacted Federal-aid programs will lead to Federal control over local school policies was reported yesterday to be widespread among the nation's large-city school administrators.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 28 -- One characteristic of a guerrilla war is the extreme difficulty of telling how it is going.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 28 -- A 25-year-old African, a former convict, was found guilty today on a charge of having made a false statement to The Rand Daily Mail about brutality in South African prisons.

MORE than 600 sectional bridge tournaments are staged each year in some part of North America. The oldest of these, dating back to 1929, is the American Contract Bridge League's Metropolitan Championships, which begin this afternoon at the New York Hilton Hotel.
Independiente of Argentina, a powerful club that has reached the world soccer finals the last two years, faces Napoli of Italy tonight at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island, at 8:30.

Governor Rockefeller warned yesterday that local taxpayers would have to pick up the entire $1.7 billion cost of antipolution control projects if "Clean Water" Proposition 1 loses in next Tuesday's election.

" The Bedside Phoenix Nest," by Martin Levin, will be issued by Ives Washburn on Nov. 5. The pieces that make up the book have been written in the last five years by contributors to Mr. Levin's column in The Saturday Review.
Prices of long-term Government bonds declined yesterday, some sharply, in the first full day of trading after the announcement of the Treasury's plan to refund $9.7 billion of notes maturing Nov. 15.

Communist China's dreams of political leadership over the underdeveloped nations appear to be proving as illusory as was the "great leap forward" a few years ago. Peking has suffered one disaster in Indonesia, and seems headed for another at the "Second Bandung" meeting scheduled to open in Algiers next month. Despite Chinese threats of boycott, that conference of Afro-Asian countries will probably be held, and with the Soviet Union in attendance.
MOSCOW, Oct. 28 -- Two great Soviet antagonists, Stalin and Trotsky, are among the historical figures portrayed in a new movie about the 1917 Bolshevik Revolution previewed here today.
Police Commissioner Vincent L. Broderick accused the three top candidates for Mayor yesterday of "indiscriminately misusing" statistics on crime in the city.

The arts and handicrafts of handicapped children will make up the ninth Clothesline Art Show at the Carnegie Endowment Center in United Nations Plaza from Nov. 11 through Nov. 13. Sponsoring the exhibition is the Easter Seal Home Service, a division of the Easter Seal Society.
BOSTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The president of the Boston Maine Railroad and two former officials were convicted today of having received kickbacks in the sale of 10 cars owned by the railroad.
