ADELAIDE, Australia, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Gary Player completed the first nine holes of the 6,550-yard Kooyonga golf course in a nine-under-par 28 today and finished the first round of the Australian open championship with a spectacular 62.
LONDON, Oct. 28 -- Capital punishment was brought to an end in Britain today.

AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 28 -- The White House announced tentative plans today for two manned spacecraft to meet in orbit and fly together in formation. It would be the first time such a feat had been performed.
CINCINNATI Oct. 28, (AP) -- Wayne Embry sparked a third-period surge tonight that gave the Cincinnati Royals a 113-108 victory over the Boston Celtics in a National Basketball Association game.

Secretary of Commerce John T. Connor spoke softly yesterday, but nonetheless issued a carefully worded warning to business to increase its efforts to improve the nation's international payments position.

The American Broadcasting Company has started an extensive search for performers and scripts to televise next season on its one-hour weekly series titled "The Hour of Innovation." The series would offer a wide variety of shows.

ROME, Oct. 28 -- The Ecumenical Council's promulgation of the declaration dissociating the Jews from any collective guilt for the Crucifixion of Jesus closes a five-year effort to change a position taken for 19 centuries.

HAVANA, Oct. 28 -- Having virtually reached agreement with Washington over the orderly transportation of refugees to the United States, the Cuban Government ordered an end today to the small-boat traffic between Cuba and the Florida Keys.
ROME, Oct. 28 -- One effect of the second Vatican Council is that the bishops of the Roman Catholic Church are now more closely tied to one another than they have been for centuries.
CHICAGO, Oct. 28 -- Franziskus Cardinal Konig, Archbishop of Vienna, is quoted in a Roman Catholic publication to the effect that the days of conflict between Christians and atheists are over.

DREW MIDDLETON, foreign correspondent for The New York Times since 1942 (currently reporting from the United Nations), has worked in Europe for 25 years, and has written many studies on Europeans and Western European defense problems. Never, however, has he been so pessimistic as he is today.

RICHMOND, Oct. 28 -- Virginia Democrats, facing the most spirited Republican challenge in 12 years, have rallied an impressive variety of support behind their candidate for Governor in text Tuesday's election.
PARIS, Oct. 28 (Reuters) -- The French Government is making a study of birth control, including the safety of contraceptive pills, a Health Ministry spokesman said today.
The Metropolitan Opera's production of Verdi's "Falstaff" may have lost some of its stylistic polish since its revival two seasons ago, but it remains one of the company's outstanding presentations.

ROME, Oct. 29 -- The Roman Catholic hierarchy approved liberalized rules today for Biblical research and rendered an open verdict on the relative importance of Scripture and tradition as sources of religious truth.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The retirement of two Navy admirals in protest against what they considered to be overcentralization at the Pentagon focuses attention again on what has been called the "McNamara monarchy."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (UPI) -- The American Newspaper Publishers Association asked the Federal Communications Commission today to permit wide use of communications satellites by newspapers and wire services.
The New York Board of Rabbis, an association of more than 850 Orthodox, Conservative and Reform rabbis in the metropolitan area, has designated today as Federation Sabbath.

Accounts by historians of the assassination of Rasputin in Russia 49 years ago were legally discounted as "hearsay" in court here yesterday when matched against the testtimony of a living participant in the slaying.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 29 (AP) -- United States District Judge John K. Regan said today to planned to accept a change in pleas from not guilty to no contest for 18 oil products concerns charged with antitrust violations.

Soviet consumers must have experienced mixed feelings when they read their Government's recently published report on the performance of Soviet industry this year. On the positive side, production of television sets, refrigerators and washing machines increased sharply to record levels. But Soviet output of such necessities as clothing, shoes and textiles was virtually unchanged, though the population grew and Soviet wardrobes were modest to start with.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Oct. 29 -- Secretary of Commerce John T. Connor predicted here today that there would be "quite a debate next year" over many aspects of international trade.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The Government announced today that it would conduct a "quickie" survey next month of business plans for capital spending abroad this year and next.

SEOUL, Korea -- Officials see signs that the drastic upward revision of the nation's interest-rate structure three weeks ago is begining to produce important new sources of domestic capital for economic development.
WASHINGTIN, Oct. 29 (AP) -- The Interior and Commerce Departments concluded a joint hearing today on the relationship between the mandatory oil-import control program and the petrochemical industry.

Donald F. Turner, assistant attorney general in charge of the Justice Department's Antitrust Division, flew to New York yesterday for negotiations with lawyers representing the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company.

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 29 -- The San Francisco Giants may have lost the National League pennant race this season, but the club is banking on three, young pitchers to alter the standings next year. And despite their second-place finish, it was a profitable season for the Giants stockholders.
Official help appeared yesterday to be a possibility for home owners near airports who have complained about the noise of aircraft, especially of jets.
Daylight time ends at 2 A.M. tomorrow when it will be 1 A.M. for those who have remembered to turn their clocks back an hour.
Indications are that President Johnson's public endorsement of Controller Abraham D. Beame was precipitated by wide speculation that his silence had meant he opposed the Democratic mayoral candidate.
Representative John V. Lindsay and William F. Buckley Jr. intensified their attacks on each other yesterday.

PAWTUCKETT, R.I., Oct. 29 (AP) -- Photo-finish victories by long shots in the first two races at Narragansett today resulted in a $3,513 for $2 daily double payoff, the largest of the 1965 New England racing season.

CONTEMPORARY materials are the stuff of which Paul l Secon's retail dreams are made. When Paul Secon, Inc., opened recently at 7 East 53d Street, furniture and accessories of molded plastic, preshaped plywood, brushed steel and shiny chrome were among the merchandise on display.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 29 (UPI) -- A United States Army court has ordered stockade sentences at hard labor for three members of the First Cavalry Division, convicted of having resisted their transfer to Vietnam.
The stock market bounced back yesterday from its small dip on Thursday and closed the week with a substantial gain.
Four important exhibitions not covered on this page should be included in the list of the conscientious gallery trotter.
Two University of Ottawa psychologists have developed a technique that they say promises to make possible the measurement of human intelligence by timing the brain's response to a flash of light.

Lyndon B. Johnson's fidelity to the tradition of Franklin D. Roosevelt obviously has one big hole. The President does not share the belief of the founder of the New Deal that New York City's election has no connection with national politics.

The integration of work forces at three uptown Manhattan construction sites is proceeding at a generally satisfactory pace, according to field investigations made by the City Commission on Human Rights.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 29 (AP) -- The caviar-and-champagne wedding reception of South Africa's wealthiest heiress will not be multiracial as she wished, a friend of her family said today.
MOSCOW, Oct. 29 -- The Soviet Union is deemed to have seized the initiative in its struggle with Communist China and is pressing the advantage after a series of sharp setbacks for Peking.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 29 (UPI) -- Marie McDonald died from "acute drug intoxication," either by suicide or accidentally, the coroner reported today.
Winter may be almost two months away, but in some of New England's ski country yesterday the focus was on snow. Bulldozers cleared roads, lodge keepers shoveled walks and ski enthusiasts dreamed.

BOSTON, Oct. 29 -- Dr. Thomas Curtin, Deputy State Commissioner of Education, said today that Boston could lose nearly $7 million in state and Federal aid if the school committee failed to take steps to eliminate racial imbalance.

Three more buildings have been designated as New York City landmarks. They are the Friends Meeting House in Gramercy Park, the old Bronx Borough Hall in Crotona Park, and the former Astor Library at 425 Lafayette Street.
A new record-and-book album that reviews the life of President Kennedy will help build the library being dedicated to him.
ALBANY, Oct. 29 -- An effort to roll back the tide of Democratic gains that swept their upstate political preserve a year ago is a major goal of New York Republican leaders in Tuesday's election.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 29 (UPI) -- Jury trials were granted today to seven dissident parishioners of the Rev. Fred L. Shuttlesworth who were charged with disorderly conduct at a church service on Oct. 17.

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- The Archbishop of Canterbury is clearly a man to shock others with his comments on all manner of things. The Most Rev. Dr. Arthur Michael Ramsey has been under attack for calling for support of the Government if it decides to use force to insure the rights of the African majority in Rhodesia, and today Canterbury Cathedral was desecrated by vandals.

As a dedicated Democrat I intended until recently to vote for Abraham Beame. My reasoning was that despite Lindsay's status as a progressive and internationalist in his party, his victory in New York would be misinterpreted elsewhere in the country as a Republican victory pure and simple, and would give aid and comfort to the Birch, Ku Klux Klan and yahoo elements in the Republican party as well as the moderates.

ADELAIDE, Australia Oct. 29 (AP) -- Jack Nicklaus shot the lowest round of his professional career today -- a 10-under par 63 -- and went four strokes ahead of Gary Player with a 129 in the second round of the Australian open golf championship.
Supporters of United States policy in Vietnam will participate in a parade down Fifth Avenue today that has been publicized as an answer to large-scale antiwar protests two weeks ago.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (UPI) -- The Federal Communications Commission urged the National Collegiate Athletic Association today to take a second look at its ban on television broadcasts of University of Notre Dame football games by a South Bend, Ind., station.
The position of candidates and parties on the city's voting machines in Tuesday's election, the subject of three state court decisions in the last eight days, was thrown into doubt again yesterday.

Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Wagner walked a debris-strewn sidewalk yesterday, sidestepped an abandoned refrigerator, and toured a Lower East Side apartment in a bipartisan appeal for two housing propositions on next Tuesday's ballot.
Directors of Delta Air Lines Inc., elected Charles H. Dolson a former airline pilot, as president yesterday.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Oct. 29 -- Senator Edward M. Kennedy slithered through mud and heavy rain today to meet Pathet Lao defectors and Meo refugees from Communism.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 29 -- Billy Haughton of Oyster Bay Cove, L.I., joined Bob Farrington of Richwood, Ohio, and Don Busse of Kingston, Ill., as the only American harness-racing drivers to score 200 victories in one season. He reached the magic number for the first time in his 25-year career by bringing home four winners tonight -- one in a dead heat -- at Roosevelt Raceway.
PARIS, Oct. 29 -- Ezra Pound has come back to Paris, a city he left half his long life ago. Tomorrow he will be 80 years old.
The maritime industry reacted yesterday to a talk by Maritime Administrator Nicholas Johnson before his speech was delivered.
MONTEREY, Calif., Oct. 29 (AP) -- A 32-year-old Navy flier who lost his lower legs in a crash says he is ready to match any other rival in competition to become an astronaut.

" REMEMBER," warned the French painter and theorist Maurice Denis about 75 years ago, "that a picture -- before being a battle horse, a nude woman, or some anecdote -- is essentially a plane surface covered with colors assembled in a certain order."

For 5 minutes 33 4-5 seconds at Aqueduct yesterday, Mrs. Theodora Randolph's Bon Nouvel showed 21,493 patrons why he is still the best steeplechase horse in America. Not all of them appreciated what they were seeing.

Now that the Morrissey appointment has been shelved, it is appropriate to take a careful look at the whole system of selecting Federal judges. Most Federal judges are able, conscientious, dedicated men who maintain the administration of justice at a high level. Nevertheless, few informed observers would dispute the assertion of The Journal of the American Judicature Society that politics rather than merit is the dominant factor in most Federal judicial appointments.

AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 29 -- The White House announced today that President Johnson was sending a top-level mission to Miami Monday to help work out plans for coping with the influx or refugees expected from Cuba.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The head of the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute's Department of Aeronautical Engineering and Astronautics was granted a patent this week for ways of propelling torpedo-like cars carrying passengers through tubes between cities.
GUATEMALA -- Guatemala has grown so much coffee this year that pressure has built up against the quota she has been allocated under the International Coffee Agreement.

George Whitmore Jr., the man first indicted in the Wylie-Hoffert murder case and later absolved, was ordered yesterday to appear for the defense at the trial of Richard Robles, now accused of the 1963 slayings of career girls Janice Wylie and Emily Hoffert.
Seven Cosa Nostra figures, including two caretakers of the powerful Vito Genovese "family," were arrested yesterday afternoon while sipping coffee in a Little Italy restaurant.

The Independiente Football Club of Buenos Aires beat the strong Napoli Football Club, 1-0, at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island, last night. A goal by Raul Savoy at 35 minutes of the first half gave the Argentine soccer team the victory.

AMERICA becomes a Mardi Gras of individualists in Philip Hamburger's eyes. Conformity's grim formations are broken up by his light humanistic touch. No other book has made our towns seem so believably fanciful.
AUSTIN, Oct. 29 -- President Johnson today gave Controller Abraham D. Beame the endorsement that the Democratic mayoral candidate had so anxiously awaited.
A new kind of telescope whose mirror jiggles at 20 times a second has disclosed that the sky, when viewed in the deep infrared, "dazzles" with a multitude of strange bodies.

The United Auto Workers Union in Los Angeles has protested the Federal Government's participation in the proposed transfer of unemployed Long Island aircraft workers to Long Beach, Calif., to work for Douglas Aircraft Company.

RIVERSIDE, Calif., Oct. 29 -- Speed records are almost certain to fall here on Sunday when the eighth annual grand prix for sports cars is run over the Riverside Raceway 2.6-mile course. The lap record was lowered three times within an hour today during the first session of practice and qualifying, with most of the 68 cars entered taking part.
Lower selling prices and reduced product shipments were primarily responsible for the sharp drop in earnings of the United States Gypsum Company in the quarter and nine months ended Sept. 30.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 29 -- Dr. Morris Fishbein, who once led the American Medical Association's fight against "socialized medicine," said today he supported medicare and other Federal health measures.
A Texas scientist has reported the discovery of a substance in the brain of hibernating animals that appears to block the temperature regulation mechanism of the body.

The camps of the Democratic candidates for City Council President and Controller are both saying privately that they expect their candidates to run ahead of Abraham D. Beame, the Democratic candididate for Mayor.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) -- The people who direct the Washington International Horse Show, which will resume Thursday and run through Nov 9 after a year's lapse, have made the rueful discovery that tons of carefully selected show-ring dirt is missing.

The Times is to be commended for its Oct. 19 editorial urging defeat for Amendment No. 3, which would double the length of term of both State Senators and Assemblymen and provide that the entire membership of both houses be elected in every fourth year starting in 1966.

THERE is a style well established on the American art scene to which no one has yet given a name. Compounded of equal parts of French and American elements -- Monet, Vuillard, and Bonnard on the one hand, and Edward Hopper on the other -- its outstanding practitioner is Fairfield Porter, but it has a good many minor adherents as well.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Oct. 29 -- The seven countries of the European Free Trade Association -- or Outer Seven -- renewed today their previous unanswered appeal to the European Common Market for "a dialogue" that might lead to closer links between the two trade blocs.

Mayor Wagner's decision to seek the approval of Federal fund-granting agencies for putting the Lower Manhattan Expressway below street level is sound, even though belated. For a year and a half the Regional Plan Association has been urging such a change, with strong support from this newspaper. Both major party candidates for the mayoralty have indicated their sympathy for the proposal.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board today told two major airlines -- United and American -- that they could not now put into effect proposed premium fares on jet service.

The United States Department of Agriculture and the Koratron Corporation, San Francisco, are jointly engaged in developing a permanent-press process for woolens and worsteds, Herman A. Greenberg, the new president of Koratron, has disclosed.
WHEN Mike Taliaferro was a 10-year-old tackle in his home town of Houston, he made the most important move of his football career. He became a quarterback.

It is traditional for a judge seeking election or re-election to high judicial office to refrain from extolling his own qualifications and record. This inhibition may, in some instances, be detrimental to the public interest where, as in the case of Civil Court Judge Harry B. Frank, the public is unaware of his outstanding record of achievement on the bench since 1954.
MOSCOW, Oct. 29 -- Youth leaders in Moscow have decided to try to direct the rebellious energy of young writers, actors and architects into creative channels by giving them a bigger role in the arts.

CAIRO, Oct. 29 -- Three American oil companies were reported today to have begun negotiating for concession rights in Egypt that would commit them to invest more than $25 million during the next three years.

CASTELLARAS, France, Oct. 20 -- At last, something for the art collector who has everything -- a house. A house in the south of France, naturally, on the Cote d'Azur. A house that is at once a home, and a sophisticated work of art, with signed, built-in embellishments on walls and floors by fashionable Paris painters, such as Andreou, Nikos, Malthesius and Mathieu.
THE HAGUE, Oct. 29 (Reuters) -- A head-on clash between the Government and the Dutch royal family over Crown Princess Beatrix's plans to wed her West German fiance appeared imminent today.

Next Tuesday's municipal election in New Haven provides a reminder of what can be done by a community when it addresses itself vigorously to solving its local problems. Across the nation cities are struggling with a stubborn set of interrelated problems whose origins lie deep in the past but whose present forms are new.
Government bond prices declined yesterday in the second trading session since the Treasury announced on Wednesday its plan to refund $9.7 billion of notes maturing Nov. 15.
TUNIS, Oct. 29 -- President Habib Bourguiba today emphasized Tunisia's economic progress and warned "our American friends" against an opposition campaign of vilification against his regime.
The fourth world championship fight of the year a Madison Square Garden was booked yesterday when Emile Griffith agreed to defend his welterweight title against Manny Gonzalez on Dec. 10.
ALBANY, Oct. 29 (AP) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today a number of fingerprints had been found at the scene of the 416,000 burglary of a Brink's Inc. office in Syracuse last week.
LONDON, Oct. 29 -- A record price of $152,880 was paid here today for a Venetian landscape by the 18th century Italian painter Francesco Guardi.
LINCOLNTON, Ga., Oct. 29 -- About 65 civil rights demonstrators, heavily guarded by the state police, staged a quiet protest march on the Lincoln County Courthouse here today.
CHESTER, Pa., Oct. 29 (AP) -- Their three-day suspension ended, Charles Jr. and Peggy Steward went back to school here today and each solemnly handed over a 35-cent check for lunch in the cafeteria.
Nebraska, the highest-scoring college team of the country, is expected to encounter the stiffest opposition today of the six major elevens with perfect records.
The Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation, a relatively minor producer of aluminum, led the industry yesterday in an expected price increase.

It seems that Van Cliburn has been playing nothing but the Rachmaninoff Third Piano Concerto ever since he won the Tchaikovsky International Competition in Moscow in 1958. Well, he played it again, for the umpteenth time, last night with the Moscow Philharmonic Orchestra at Carnegie Hall -- and it sounded like it.

LUSAKA, Zambia, Oct. 29 -- Representatives of 10 countries meeting here today urged their governments to form an economic community for East and Central Africa. The combined area is bigger than India and has more than 50 million people.

Fifty-six paraplegic Vietnamese Army veterans will be airlifted here Nov. 9. Dr. Howard A. Rusk, chairman of the Department of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation at the New York University Medical Center, said today in a news conference.
DETROIT, Oct. 29 (UPI) -- Ray Scott scored two seconds before the end of the game tonight to give the Detroit Pistons a 108-106 victory over the Boston Celtics.
If all goes well, Channel 13 will soon be joining the rush to color television.
MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 29 (AP) -- A Chicago-based group of insurance executives and the Minnesota Insurance Commissioner were indicted today in what a Federal grand jury called a $4 million fraud case.

Because Senator Kenneth Keating's service in Congress was so outstanding, many people are unaware that his fine record of public service is matched by an equally distinguished career as a trial and appellate lawyer.

ALBANY, Oct. 29 -- The Board of Regents today rejected a request by Senator Earl W. Brydges, Republican of Niagara Falls, that the motion picture division of the State Education Department be continued until the next session of the Legislature.
SHREVEPORT, La., Oct. 29 (AP) -- Former Maj. Gen. Edwin A. Walker was awarded a $3 million libel judgment today against The Associated Press and The New Orleans Times-Picayune Publishing Corporation.
Abraham D. Beame, the Democratic candidate for Mayor, called William F. Buckley Jr. yesterday a sinister "clown" whose campaign exploited fear, prejudice and hatred.

The United States Equestrian Team won both in the afternoon and evening in the international jumping competition of the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden yesterday. A nice part about it was that the only member of the team who had not previously scored stepped to the head of a class.

AMCHITKA ISLAND, Alaska, Oct. 29 -- The United States exploded an 80-kiloton hydrogen bomb today 2,300 feet below the surface of this small Aleutian Island. The experiment is expected to produce important data for the monitoring of future bans against nuclear testing.
The Dreyfus Fund disclosed yesterday that it made new commitments in three stocks -- Atlantic Refining, Cleveland-Cliffs Icon and Newmont Mining -- during the third quarter.
The number of block transactions involving 10,000 or more shares on the New York Stock Exchange showed a slight gain in the third quarter, the Big Board reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The index of wholesale primary market prices declined two-tenths of 1 per cent to 102.8 of its 1957-59 base during the week ended Oct. 26, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

Libby Holman, once one of the sultriest of torch singers, will make her first New York appearance in 11 years at two concerts on Wednesday and Thursday in the Dag Hammarskjold Auditorium at the United Nations.

JOHNSON CITY, Tex., Oct. 29 -- President Johnson's daughter Luci, 18 years old, flew to the LBJ ranch tonight to win her parents' consent to be married to Patrick J. Nugent of Waukegan, Ill., her friends said.
Low-priced issues accounted for most of the trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday as the market advanced on good volume.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (UPI) -- Prices farmers received for crops and livestock fell 1 per cent in the month ended Oct. 15, the Agriculture Department reported today.
The salary of Fire Commissioner Martin Scott has been increased from $25,000 to $30,000, and that of Buildings Commissioner Judah Gribetz from $22,500 to $25,000.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Oct. 29 -- The president of the Alaska Conservation Society said today that he was less concerned over the possible destruction of a few sea otter by the nuclear blast at Amchitka than over the "secrecy of the military" in the early stages of planning project Long Shot.
Cocoa futures dropped yesterday following a Department of Agriculture report that estimated 1965-1966 world cocoa production would be somewhat above the recent estimate put out by the United Nations.

" TO make it," the owner of one of New York's dress boutiques said, standing amid the artful clutter of his shop, "you've got to be special. Not just in the clothes -- the whole thing has to be special."

BONN, Oct. 29 -- Franz Josef Strauss, the leading West German champion of President de Gaulle's program for the unification of Europe, has proposed the creation of an autonomous European nuclear force that could be ordered into action without the consent of the United States.
A Manhattan candy store proprietor yesterday became the first person to be found guilty of violating the new anti-pornography law enacted at the last session of the Legislature.

ANDERSEN AIR FORCE BASE, Guam, Oct. 24 -- A new breed of young men, philosophic And intellectually curious as well as technically proficient, is flying the B-52 heavy bombers in the raids against Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- United States and British transportation experts are in Zambia to study the possibility of an airlift to maintain Zambia's trade if Rhodesia bars the landlocked nation's access to the sea.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach assigned voting examiners today to 12 more counties in the South -- in Louisiana. Mississippi, Alabama and South Carolina.

" Tentacles of Power: The Story of Jimmy Hoffa," by Clark R. Mollenhoff, will be published by World on Nov. 10. The author won the Pulitzer Prize in 1958 for national reporting. He covered for The Des Moines Register and The Minneapolis Star and Tribune the Congressional investigations into operations of the Teamster union official.

The Zimrah Chorale, Eugene Malek, director, is holding rehearsals every Thursday evening from 7:30 to 10 at the Educational Alliance, 197 East Broadway, (Room 201). Those interested in participating are invited to attend or to telephone Chaim Grunwald at GR 5-6200.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Oct. 29 -- Winding up his last-minute drive to keep the Rhodesians from seizing their independence, Prime Minister Wilson made plans tonight to leave in the morning. He voiced hope that "the dialogue could be continued."

When we close the books on October each year the best samples of weather in the latitude and longitude of Manhattan Island are likely to be behind us. Some years there is less of the "bright, blue" variety than in others while October is busy with the leaves, first coloring them and then scattering them to the four winds, but not much that is really good can be expected again before spring turns up.

A group of admirers of Alfred A. Knopf surprised the book publisher last night at a dinner given at the Astor Hotel by officers and directors of his concern when they produced a two-volume work, "Portrait of a Publisher 1915-1965."

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 29 -- The Brazilian Foreign Ministry said today it was proceeding with plans to open the Inter-American Conference here Nov. 17 despite criticism abroad of the Government's crackdown on political opponents.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 29 -- Six United States soldiers were killed and three wounded yesterday by shells fired from howitzers on their own side. Reporting the accident today, an American military spokesman said a squad from the First Battalion of the 327th Infantry Regiment of the 101st Airborne Division had inadvertently moved into the line of fire during an operation in a valley 12 miles northwest of the port of Quinhon.

BOSTON, Oct. 29 -- The executive committee of the Boston Maine Corporation said late today that it had asked Daniel A. Benson to remain on as president, despite his conviction for receiving kickbacks.
Industrial issues gained on the London Stock Exchange yesterday after an indecisive start.
The British pound dropped 4 points, to $2.8044, in light trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday.

LAS CRUCES, N.M., Oct. 29 (AP) -- Marilynn Smith and last year's winner, Sandra Haynie, shared the first-round lead today in the $9,000 La Cruces women's open golf tournament, firing four-under-par 68's.
GENEVA, Oct. 29 -- The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) heads a group of international petroleum concerns that plan to take over Switzerland's only crude oil refinery.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The John Birch Society struck back at its Republican critics today and denied it was trying to take over the party.
The Consolidated Edison Company plans to establish another nuclear-fueled electric generating plant at Indian Point on the east shore of the Hudson River south of Peekskill.
THE Metropolitan Championships continue this afternoon at the New York Hilton Hotel with the Open Pair Championship.

SALISBURY, Conn., Oct. 29 -- Two new products -- a mint sauce and a steak sauce -- are now arriving in New York's food shops. They will shortly be followed by a malt vinegar (a lusty vinegar popular in England) and an Italian dressing (which apparently has become more popular than the French variety).

Geraldine (she's a gerenuk) is leaving the Bronx on Wednesday for romantic reasons. She's going to fly out to San Diego to meet a male gerenuk. He is nameless but believed to be the only other member of this species of East African antelope in the country.

MIAMI, Oct. 29 (UPI) -- Sheriff's officers arrested today the Grand Dragon and an Exalted Cyclops of a new Ku Klux Klan group and seized documents saying the only way members could quit the Klan was "feet first."

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- Vandals sprayed red and blue paint today over treasures in Canterbury Cathedral, the magnificent 12th-century structure that serves as the spiritual center of the Church of England.

A CRITICAL shortage of Christmas tree lights is developing because of the virtual cessation of shipments from Japan, and supplies of American-made bulbs, it was learned, may not be sufficient to fill the void.

The April in Paris Ball has art international reputation for being bigger, flashier, more expensive and less visibly organized than any other charity ball in the world, and it lived up to expectations last night for the 14th successive season.

Representative John V. Lindsay, Republican-Liberal candidate for Mayor, and his Democratic opponent, Controller Abraham D. Beame, have agreed on a format for their television debate at 9 o'clock tonight, Station WPIX-TV announced yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29 -- A registered Democrat, who is running for District Attorney on the Republican ticket and has the support of Americans for Democratic Action, is the central figure in next Tuesday's Philadelphia municipal election.

AMONG the nations of the world, Canada remains something of a paradox. It presents a face of glacial calm, dependability (i.e., it doesn't borrow money) and material success. COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Bob Funk booted an 18-yard field goal with 1:17 left in the game today, giving Ohio State an 11-10 victory over Minnesota in a big ten struggle before 84,359. It was the fifth-largest crowd in Ohio history.
CORVALLIS, Ore., Oct. 30 (UPI) -- Washington State held off Oregon State in the second half today and beat the Beavers 10-8, for its sixth victory in seven games.

" SALT OF THE EARTH," the drama about striking New Mexican miners, which produced enough violence, controversy and opposition to frighten away all but a few undaunted exhibitors during its first showings 11 years ago, arrives today at the Fifth Avenue Cinema, as "practically a new, contemporary film," according to Herbert J. Biberman, its director.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 30 -- Sleepy Hollow High of North Tarrytown completed its Southern Westchester Interscholastic Athletic Association season today by routing Rye High, 33-7, at Washington Irving Field. The victory kept Sleepy Hollow in contention for the title with a 3-1-1 won-lost-tied record.

Sir Tyrone, one of the liveliest and most articulate theater men around, admits after 40 years of directing plays, operas, musicals and ballet that he does "not know very well what is good and not at all what will be popular.''

TOKYO, Oct. 30 -- The Japanese Government, which recently carried on an inconclusive debate about the correct name of this country, is now involved in a dispute as to what to call Japan's nearest neighbor, Korea.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Once again President Johnson has outfoxed the prophets and analysts of his political behavior who put their speculations on the public record. Edward N. Costikyan, the campaign manager of Abraham Beame in the New York mayoralty race, stated Mr. Johnson's attitude precisely and reflected his procedure exactly when he said: "The President has a right and a duty to do what he wants to do when he wants to do it."

POCANTICO HILLS, N.Y., Oct. 30 -- Governor Rockefeller has been accused of trying to rewrite Washington Irving's legend of Sleepy Hollow here with plans for a new superhighway that would allegedly destroy picturesque vistas and quadruple the value of 3,000 acres of undeveloped lands of the Rockefeller family.

JACKSON, Miss., Oct. 30 (UPI) -- Steve Sloan threw a 65-yard scoring pass in the opening minutes of the game and David Ray kicked a 27-yard field goal tonight to lead Alabama to a 10-7 victory over Mississippi State in a Southeastern Conference game.

AN Agfa-Gevaert Super-8 color reversal film for home movies -- it is similar to Kodachrome II -is being made available in Europe this month, and is expected to be marketed in the United States by March. The film is Agfacolor CK-17 Super-8; it is balanced for artificial light and has a speed of ASA 40.

BRISBANE, Australia, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Australia defeated the United States, 4-3, today in an international tennis match modeled along Davis Cup lines. Triumphs in the two concluding doubles matches gave Australia the decision.

DAVID L. WOLPER presented another of his instant documentaries Friday night, this one on "The Teen-Age Revolution." The program was a review of the obvious, the popularity of rock 'n' roll music, the madly changing fashions of the younger generation, the advance in scholastic accomplishments of some teen-agers, the drop-out problem of others, the life of a teen-age married couple and the contribution of many youngster. in charity and social work.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Oct. 30 -- Wooden Christmas stalls are already lining the Avenida Duarte, where the pulse of this feverish city throbs. Santo Domingo seems not too sure that there will be as many shopping days to Dec. 25 as the calendar says.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 30 (Reuters) -- Indonesian Government forces said today they had scored their biggest successes against Communists in central Java since the unsuccessful uprising against President Sukarno Oct. 1.

MOSCOW, Oct. 30 (Reuters) -- A court in Riga imposed death sentence today on five Latvians, including one living in the United States and another in Canada, for war crimes alleged to have been committed during the World War II German occupation of Latvia.

ERWIN Piscator, a producer who considers a season wasted if he fails to shock half the town and outrage the rest, has done it again. WASHINGTON -- If you will read the fine print on the back of your next overseas airline ticket, it may shock you to discover that, in the improbable event you should lose your life on the flight, the most your heirs can expect to recover from the airline is $8,300, plus $660 for baggage.

THE NEW YORK CITY BALLET ended its fall season at the New York State Theater in Lincoln Center last night. The company will return to the State Theater on Dec. 24 and will offer through Jan. 16 its customary holiday presentation of Balanchine's "The Nutcracker."

Afghan fanciers refer to their favorite as a king of dogs. Yesterday a representative of this ancient breed proved to be king of a field of 1,173 at the 44th Bronx County Kennel Club fixture at the Eighth Regiment Armory in the Bronx.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 31 -- Net power assets of the Tennessee Valley Authority now exceed the $2 billion mark at $2,122,000,000. This was brought out in T.V.A.'s annual report released today in the form of a 36-page booklet, illustrated with color pictures and charts.
UPPER BROOKVILLE, L.I., Oct. 31 -- Ivan Markovich Pedanyuk, a delegate to the United Nations from the Ukrainian Republic, died early today of injuries received in an accidental fall here last night.
BOSTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- A 19-month series of gangland shootings in Greater Boston claimed its 25th victim today.
LINCOLNTON, Ga., Oct. 31 -- Each time the Negroes march through this small country town in eastern Georgia, hard-eyed white men stare after them.

Piano compositions by Mendelssohn and Brahms were contrasted interestingly in a recital given at Carnegie Hall last night by Sidney Foster, one of the best of the mature generation of American pianists and, incidentally, the winner, just 25 years ago, of the first Leventritt Award.

BUFFALO, Oct. 31 (AP) -- George Blanda kicked four field goals today, including one in the fourth period, in leading the Houston Oilers to a 19-17 upset victory over the Buffalo Bills, the American Football League champions.

" The Rise and Fall of Stalin," by Robert Payne, will be published by Simon and Schuster on Nov. 10. Among Mr. Payne's numerous books is "The Life and Death of Lenin." Of Stalin, he writes: "This small, brooding, pock-marked man with a crooked arm, black teeth and yellow eyes, was the greatest tyrant of his time, and perhaps of all time."
KINGS POINT, L.I., Oct. 31 -- The United States Merchant Marine Academy edged the defending champion, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, by 8 points today to win the Nevins Trophy.

ROCKINGHAM, N.C., Oct. 31 (AP) -- Curtis Turner, driving with a broken rib and virtually without brakes, withstood the challenge of several younger drivers today and won the first American 500 stock car race.
CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- It wasn't too surprising that the Chicago Bears defeated the Green Bay Packers today. After all, the Packers were only slight favorites to continue undefeated.
BOSTON, Oct. 31 (UPI) -- The Boston Celtics rallied from a 12-point deficit with a final-quarter spurt that carried them to a 105-100 victory tonight over the Baltimore Bullets before 7,915 fans.

Laden down with heavy luggage, travelers sometimes have to wait as long as an hour to get a taxicab at Pennsylvania Station or Grand Central or one of the airlines terminals. This is New York's "welcome" at its worst -- especially on a rainy night. The utter lack of any order or control at almost all the terminals aggravates an already indefensible situation.

EDGEWATER, N.J., Oct. 31 -- A general alarm fire fanned by gusting winds destroyed 11 barges owned by four Hudson River boat clubs and about 40 pleasure craft belonging to members here today.

THESE four nontraditional novels are a fair sampling of current trends in serious fiction. All four use the technique of shock and extended fantasy, two with sensitivity, two rather crudely. Three of the novels deal heavily in sexual activity and hallucination (mostly heterosexual, for a piquant change), one in deranged criminality.
An ebullient Controller Abraham D. Beame, apparently confident of victory tomorrow, spent an ambitious day yesterday campaigning in friendly territory.
LONDON -- Despite its natural sympathies for Britain's miners, the Labor Government is planning on sharp contraction in the nationalized industry and the loss of 20,000 jobs in the pits by 1970.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- A Chicago hotel room occupied by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt during World War II was bugged, a former Army Intelligence agent said tonight. Listening devices picked up not only telephone conversations but also conversations in the room, according to Willis R. Adams, who is also a former private investigator in the capital area.

MIAMI, Oct. 31 -- The season's first major charity ball here, sponsored by the Young Patronesses of the Opera, drew an elegantly dressed throng of 300, who had hurriedly changed from damp sneakers to dancing shoes after chaperoning children on trick-or-treat rounds in a steady drizzle.

THE ROYAL WINNIPEG BALLET, now on its first visit to New York, turned up on Saturday night at the Walt Whitman Auditorium of Brooklyn College, where it confirmed and amplified the impression it had left on its debut at Hunter College the previous night.
William F. Buckley Jr. spent the last Sunday of the mayoral campaign at the subdued pace that has consistently characterized his posture as a candidate.

If a half-dozen of the New Christy Minstrels took to singing poems by Edgar Allan Poe and Norman Mailer in a Greenwich Village coffeehouse, the result would be a crude American version of La Contrescarpe, the French troupe that made its United States debut Saturday night at Hunter College.

MADISON, N.J., Oct. 31 (AP) -- The Local Chapter of the American Association of University Professors has criticized the Drew University board of trustees for refusing to renew the contract of James G. Mellen, political science instructor.
A former university professor has been selected by the Metropolitan Package Store Association to lead its fight for further revision of the state liquor laws.
SINGAPORE, Oct. 31 -- The Indonesian Army said today that Communist rebels had seized two areas in central Java and that the position in a third district was uncertain.

TEL AVIV, Oct. 31 -- Israel's intellectual community, which has many Soviet and Eastern European emigres, has shown considerable interest in the recent arrests in Moscow of writers accused of producing anti-Soviet works.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, Oct. 31 -- Tense calm prevailed in British Guiana today as a split in the coalition Government posed a threat to talks in London on Tuesday to determine the constitutional future of this 134-year-old British colony.
It strikes me as ludicrous that Lindsay makes political capital of the fact that Controller Abraham Beame voted only "four times" against the Mayor in the Board of Estimate.
SOMERS, N.Y., Oct 31 -- The mystery of who was conducting the secret political poll that wasn't a secret because each of the mail-in ballots was numbered in invisible ink was apparently solved today.

Safety in the marine industry was reviewed thoroughly last week at the annual safety congress Chicago. Representatives of stevedoring, the inland waterways, ship operators, shipyards and the United States Coast Guard spoke during the four-day conference.

Natalie Lamb, a tall and strikingly proportioned blonde, made the jump from school teacher to blues singer Saturday night at Town Hall, presenting a program ranging from the classic blues associated with Ma Rainey and Bessie Smith to the songs of such contemporaries as Ray Charles.
The 28-year-old manager of a bar in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn was shot and killed early yesterday morning during an argument with one of his customers.
HAVANA, Oct. 31 -- The editors of Cuba's principal newspaper are engaged in a major effort to make it more informative and not so dull.
AMARILLO, Tex. -- Two big bores are the talk of United States Bureau of Reclamation regional headquarters here.
The American Jewish Congress last night presented to Arthur J. Goldberg, chief United States representative at the United Nations, its annual Stephen Wise Award for "advancing human freedom."

TORONTO, Oct. 31 -- George Chuvalo was slightly favored on this cold and liquorless day to beat Ernie Terrell at Maple Leaf Gardens tomorrow night and become the heavyweight champion of any parts of the world that need one.
The first hint of mass audience resistance to the new entertainment shows of the television networks is contained in today's issue of Broadcasting, a weekly trade magazine.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UPI) -- The Washington Redskins blanked the Philadelphia Eagles for most of three quarters today and when Philadelphia pulled close twice, scored two fourth-period touchdowns on passes by Sonny Jurgensen for a 23-21 National Football League victory.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The Stewart-Warner Corporation, manufacturer of appliances and components, reported third-quarter earnings today of $2,701,235, or 71 cents a share, compared with $2,064,920, or 54 cents a share, in the corresponding 1964 period.
With nonresidential construction continuing to lead the way, contracts for construction last month registered a 10 per cent increase over September, 1964.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 31 -- Bombers of the Strategic Air Command pounded a suspected Communist storage dump and training camp early today in the Mekong delta, about 65 miles southeast of Saigon. Throughout the day, naval gunfire blasted a nearby building as South Vietnamese troops prepared to assault it.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 31 -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that it had a description of the man who had purchased a cannon believed to have been used in the $416,000 burglary at the Brink's, Inc., office here last week.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct 31 -- The voice resembles gravel scratching deep into a sidewalk. The grin is wide and innocent. The lips are scarred and cracked and blue, yet when he blows the horn and fondles the notes, the tone is clean and bare.
A THRILLER of a combinative slugfest was played between Walter Browne and Harald Hohenberger in the current Manhattan Chess Club championship preliminaries.
The Admiral Corporation reported yesterday record sales and a two-fold gain in third-quarter earnings.

William Thomas Cavanaugh, a former educator, has been named executive director of the Metropolitan Package Store Association, it was announced over the weekend by Ira Quint, acting chairman of the board of directors.
WALTHAM, Mass., Oct. 13 -- A sharp renewal of Jewish national consciousness in the Soviet Union was reported today at the Brandeis University conference on the status of Soviet ethnic minorities.

The so-called new or "death of God" theologians who argue that Christianity must abandon its traditional belief in God are new only in that they have introduced a new kind of dogmatism, according to the Rev. Walter D. Kring, pastor of the All Souls Unitarian Church.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Oct. 31 -- Britain and Rhodesia laid out in very rough terms today their separate ideas of how a royal commission should go about determining whether the people of Rhodesia want independence and, if so, under what conditions.

SYDNEY, Australia -- An increasing number of determined competitors are slowly cutting into the predominance in the Australian automobile industry of the General Motors Australian subsidiary, General Motors-Holden.
A horse-drawn carriage drew up in front of Governor Rockefeller's office at 22 West 55th Street yesterday afternoon and out stepped a couple in 18th century costume protesting an 18th century law.
The two major candidates for Mayor held an acrimonious hallway debate yesterday after all six aspirants had appeared on a television program.
SAN JOSE, Calif., Oct. 31 (UPI) -- Bob Verwey, a South African, won the $46,000 Almaden open golf tournament today with a 15-under-par total of 273.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 31 (UPI) -- The Detroit Lions, recovering five fumbles and intercepting three passes, handed the Los Angeles Rams their fifth straight defeat today. The score was 31-7.
President Kennedy believed that Presidents who were really great were those who were doers as well as thinkers, Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., the historian who was his adviser, writes.

New Yorkers obviously know a music bargain when they find one. Philharmonic Hall was filled yesterday afternoon for the opening of the Washington National Symphony's new Sunday afternoon series of "Family Concerts," and the remaining four events will be sell-outs, too.
SMITHTOWN, L.I., Oct. 31 -- A 28-year-old Hauppauge mother was arraigned today in Smithtown General Hospital here today following the death by asphyxiation of her 4-month-old son.
About 400 union workers from Ruppert Breweries met at a special meeting yesterday in Schwerin Hall at Myrtle Avenue and Knickerbocker Avenue in Brooklyn.
AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 31 -- President Johnson, described as angry over announced aluminum price increases, moved today to bring pressure on the companies to rescind them.

" The Norman Luboff Choir at Philharmonic Hall" may or may not be the title of that ensemble's next record album. In any event, Mr. Luboff and his 30 young singers sang there last night, and they were as impressive in person as on their recorded collections of folk songs and other light fare.

NORMAN NORELL has outfitted his flappers for the Palm Beach season. Last Thursday afternoon in his Seventh Avenue showroom, his five mannequins took Norell's nonmusical version of "The Boy Friend" on an abbreviated Southern tour.
BRISBANE, Australia, Monday, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Clark Graebner and his wife, Carole, were among six Americans who won first-round matches today in the Queensland lawn tennis championships.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Oct. 31 (AP) -- Nearly 200 youths, members of an organization favoring Puerto Rican independence, picketed a United States Army base today in protest against the Vietnam war and the drafting of Puerto Ricans to fight in it.
READING, Pa., Oct. 31 -- Daniel Burros, 28-year-old Ku Klux Klan leader of New York, apparently killed himself with a revolver this morning after the secret of his Jewish origin had been disclosed.

Rose Battle English, a soprano, and Alfred Bush, a bass-baritone, gave what was listed as a joint recital in Town Hall yesterday evening. There were no duets, nor could there have been, as the individual performances made clear.

The adoption of a voluntary truck appointment system to lessen waterfront traffic congestion is regarded by shipping sources as the opening of a drive that could help cure some of the ills that drive business away from the Port of New York.
A Protestant magazine has proposed that all major faiths call a one-year moratorium on church and synagogue construction and that the millions of dollars so saved be pooled in a "fund for peace."
It will come as a surprise to some music lovers that Yehudi Menuhin, the violinist they first knew as a child prodigy, is now old enough to give concerts with his son-in-law.

As voters throughout New York State prepare to go to the polls, the Citizens Committee for a Constitutional Convention urges all of them to make a special effort to vote on the three propositions, one question, and nine proposed amendments to the Constitution which will appear on all ballots.

MOSCOW, Oct. 31. -- A Soviet architects' congress has called for the restoration of the Academy of Construction and Architecture, a research center abolished by former Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev in August, 1963.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 31 (UPI) -- The Baltimore Colts, with Johnny Unitas throwing four touchdown passes, gained a first-place tie with the Green Bay Packers in the Western Conference of the National Football League today by defeating the San Francisco 49ers for the seventh straight time, 34-28.

Wall Street will be looking north this afternoon -- to the General Motors board meeting at 1775 Broadway. What emerges from that meeting very well may set the tone to stock market trading for the rest of the week, and perhaps for the rest of the year as well.

DIGBY, N.S., Oct. 31 -- Former Prime Minister John G. Diefenbaker, 70-year-old leader of the Conservative party, campaigned through the Maritime provinces this weekend pledging increased Federal assistance to this depressed region.
ST. JOHN'S, Nfld. -- Newfoundland's inshore fishermen, long accustomed to sitting in their 24-foot trap skiffs waiting for the cod to swim by, are experiencing a year of low catches.
Peace Corps officials, who are trying to attract more politically motivated volunteers, are asking student activists for advice on recruiting and training techniques.
LONDON, Oct. 31 -- Prime Minister Wilson returned to London tonight confident that the "terrible disaster" threatening Rhodesia "can be averted."

The country cannot take as an adequate answer President Johnson's quick, almost automatic, "no" to Senator Fulbright's proposal for another pause in the bombing of North Vietnam. Since the too-brief five-day pause last May, significant changes have occurred in the military balance, in the political situation in Saigon, in Soviet policy, in American opinion and in Peking's position in Asia.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Bill Nelsen, who had passed for only one touchdown this season, tossed three scoring passes against Dallas today to pace the Pittsburgh Steelers to a 22-13 victory over the Cowboys in a National Football League game.

Ion Voicu, Rumanian violinist, made his New York debut at Town Hall last night, and it was an uncommonly auspicious one. At 40, Mr. Voicu is no fledgling, nor does he play like one. He is a finished performer with a personality of his own.
Representative John V. Lindsay campaigned as hard yesterday, the last Sunday before tomorrow's election, as he did when he first entered the mayoral race last May but with a difference.
THE Cameo Theatre's latest movie package from Russia, "Ukrainian Festival," is a three-part one, adding up to middling good. The program opened Saturday.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Fran Tarkenton passed for two touchdowns, one a 72-yard play to Tommy Mason, as the Minnesota Vikings upset the Cleveland Browns 27-17 today in a National Football League game before a crowd of 83,505.
New York University had its first feature film premiere last Saturday night, in the packed 487-seat auditorium of its law school.
Gov. Richard J. Hughes closed his campaign for re-election in New Jersey yesterday with an attack on efforts to link him to American military deaths in Vietnam.
THE indefatigably warm and winning Jimmy Durante kept matters aright and amusing in Saturday evening's uneven flirtation with the lively arts over the American Broadcasting Company network.

ELKTON, Md., Oct. 31 (AP) -- About 40 cars of a Pennsylvania Railroad freight train derailed today, setting six of the cars afire and causing the evacuation of more than 400 homes as a precaution against toxic fumes.
Warning of acute capital budget problems, Mayor Wagner urged yesterday that top priority in city construction programs go to public school, city university, transit, hospital and park projects.

SELMA, Ala., Oct. 31 (AP) -- Sheriff James G. Clark Jr. of Dallas County said today a Negro girl had been raped by six of 13 Negro men jailed on charges of having carnal knowledge of a female 12 years of age or under.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 31 -- The announcement of a proposed 13-story building to be erected on the Princeton University campus has stirred widespread opposition among students and Princeton residents.

The Chesapeake Ohio Railway reported yesterday that consolidated earnings in the first 10 months this year were $51.4 million, equal to $5.85 a share, compared with 43.7 million, or $4.97 a share, in the 1964 period.
Reversing a two-month trend, steel production in the United States climbed 1.6 per cent in the week ended Saturday, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 1 -- Agreement was reached here today on a charter for a $1 billion Asian Development Bank.
New Yorkers will vote today in what is generally regarded as the most significant mayoral election since the days of Fiorello H. La Guardia.

Representative John V. Lindsay, Republican-Liberal candidate for Mayor, informed the Architects Council of New York City yesterday that he would insist as Mayor that there be no projects undertaken in the $200 million City Civic Center until studies had been made.
The Sun Oil Company filed yesterday a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering a proposed offering of $100 million of debentures maturing Nov. 15, 1990.
WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 1 -- Governor Rockefeller wrote the Westchester County Board of Supervisors today that real estate taxes in the state will rise an average of 16 per cent if the sales tax ends.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Robert M. Shelton, Imperial Wizard of the Ku Klux Klan, laid the blame for the death of Daniel Burros, a New York Klan official, on the "snooping" of the House Un-American Activities Committee and a "sensation-seeking reporter."
SVETI NAUM, Yugoslavia, Oct. 30 -- All seems peaceful along the 290-mile border between Yugoslavia and Albania, where incidents were frequent two years ago.

ROCHESTER, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The appearance here tonight of the Rolling Stones, a long-haired rock-'n' roll quintet popular with teen-agers, touched off a demonstration that required police control.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Diplomatic sources said tonight that the United States and Cuba had reached agreement on the migration of refugees to this country.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- "You know I can't say anything," was Luci Baines Johnson's reaction today to reports she had asked her parents for permission to be married to 22-year-old Patrick J. Nugent of Waukegan, Ill.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Were it not for two words in the White House press secretary's authorized account of the President's preference for Democratic candidates in all election contests, Mr. Johnson would appear to be advocating a one-party government on every level in the United States.
The New York Stock Exchange gave the computer its official imprimatur yesterday by making its head data processing man, John R. Bermingham, a vice president.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 1 -- United States Navy and Air Force jets knocked out three antiaircraft missile sites in North Vietnam yesterday morning and also destroyed a major highway bridge 35 miles northeast of Hanoi, which the missiles were defending, a military spokesman said today.

HAVANA, Nov. 1 -- Premier Fidel Castro has declared that he does not expect a general improvement of relations with the United States to follow the negotiations over the departure of refugees from Cuba.
AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 1 (AP) -- President Johnson today signed a bill under which the United States may pick up a gross profit of about $18 million.
TORONTO, Nov. 1 -- Sticking and running, jabbing and dancing, Ernie Terrell scored a unanimous decision tonight over George Chuvalo and retained his piece of the world heavyweight championship.

AMCHITKA, Alaska, Nov. 1 -- Virtually no damage to wildlife in the Amchitka area has become evident since a controversial nuclear explosion was set off 2,300-feet underground on this windswept Aleutian island last Friday.
Prices of Government securities declined yesterday. Treasury bills touched their highest rates since early 1960 and many long-term bonds fell to their lowest levels of the year.

The annual dinner dance to benefit the Casita Maria Settlement Houses will be held Nov. 11 in the Waldorf-Astoria Grand Ballroom. Mrs. Frank W. O'Keeffe is general chairman. Assisting her are Mrs. Howard A. Seitz, Mrs. Peter Strife and John Timothy Collins. Ed Sullivan will be master of ceremonies.

Information about 33 Manhattan office buildings, recently completed, under way or in the planning stage, is provided in the seventh annual report on new office structures here by Julien J. Studley, Inc., real estate concern.

Chicago group defeated last spring in an attempt to take control of the Boston Maine Railroad, is seeking options from B. M. shareholders for up to 350,000 common shares and 150,000 preferred shares.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Nov. 1 (UPI) -- The 35-foot sloop Al Viento, one of the smallest in the Long Beach-to-La Paz, Mexico, yacht race, has not been heard from since Saturday night and was the object tonight of a Coast Guard search. The craft carried six men.
Although the comet Ikeya-Seki grazed the sun more than two weeks ago, it is still shining as brilliantly as ever and has proved a scientific bonanza.

THE researchers at the three national networks predictably took exception yesterday to all hints that the size of the television audience had shown any significant decline this fall over earlier years. If there is a problem, one said, it is not why 1965 is down but why 1964 was up.
The Air Transport Division of the Brotherhood of Railway Clerks is seeking the right to represent 7,000 clerical and passenger service employes of Trans World Airlines in collective bargaining.

The directors of the General Motors Corporation declared yesterday a yearend dividend of $2.25 a share on the common stock. The disbursement will total about $640 million, making it the largest such payment ever made by any company.

Profits of Domtar, Ltd., in the third quarter rose to $7,820,000, equal to 53 cents a share, from $6,887,000, or 47 cents, in the corresponding 1964 quarter, it was reported yesterday. Sales increased to $105,381,000 from $99,026,000 a year earlier.

The Hotel Corporation of America and Western International Hotels, Inc., are joining forces for the marketing and promotion of their 72 hotels in the United States, Europe, Latin America and the Middle East.

YORK, Pa., Nov. 1 --Birth control devices paid for by the Federal Government are being given to rural parents near here. Federal officials said the project was the first of its kind, in the antipoverty campaign, to offer birth control assistance outside urban centers.
Vice President Humphrey sent Abraham D. Beame a message yesterday saying he joined President Johnson in wishing the Controller "a strong and compelling mandate" in the mayoral election today.

In discussing the current transportation crisis, recent New York Times articles and editorials have rightly pointed out that the updating of antiquated facilities will not be enough to meet future needs, and have called for an open mind in the assessment of new solutions.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 --Two alleged instructors in a Ku Klux Klan school of violence, neither of whom can read, were questioned by a Congressional committee today about an organization of Klansmen called Nacirema, Inc.

William F. Buckley Jr. has a new subscriber to The National Review, there is one fewer mathematics major in Abraham D. Beame's camp (he is switching fields), and a hamburger shop next to a storefront headquarters for John V. Lindsay has some new customers.

The crew of the British freighter Newfoundland fought a stubborn fire in her two forward holds in heavy weather in the Atlantic yesterday as ships and planes kept a watchful eye on the burning vessel.

TORONTO, Nov. 1 (UPI) -- Ernie Terrell, satisfied with his victory over George Chuvalo, was eager tonight to fight the winner of the Cassius Clay-Floyd Patterson bout for the undisputed world heavyweight crown.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The Federal Aviation Agency said today it had become the first civilian agency of the Federal Government to recover the full cost of developing under Government contract a device made by a private manufacturer and sold to the public.
READING, Pa., Nov. 1 -- A certificate of suicide was issued this afternoon in the shooting here Sunday of Daniel Burros, 28-year-old leader of the Ku Klux Klan in New York.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1 -- The Central committee of Conscientious Objectors, which is issues a booklet to draft-age men who would rather be conscientious objectors than soldiers, is doing a land-office business.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested a 33-year-old automobile mechanic in Garden City, L.I., last night in connection with the $400,000 burglary last week in which a cannon was used to blast open a Brink's vault at Syracuse.
A mother of four children who allegedly held up a Long Island bank with a small silver pistol and escaped with $6,626 on Oct. 27, was arraigned yesterday in Federal Court in Brooklyn.
Industrials showed strength in yesterday's brisk trading on the London Stock Exchange. Most other foreign markets were closed in observance of All Saints Day.
The trouble with the men's wear industry, according to designer John Weitz, is "the industry."
Just when it appeared that the favorite had the race won yesterday, the Saddle Rock Farm's Ornamento came through with a rush that enabled him to take the $28,250 Sport Page Handicap at Aqueduct.

Despite indications of an imminent settlement in their week-old dispute, negotiators for three teamster locals and 200 milk dealers recessed last night without agreement on a new contract.

ALICE SPRINGS, Australia, Oct. 30 -- American oil men here believe this dusty little town in the semidesert heartland of Australia is sitting on the edge of one of the world's major oil and gas deposits.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (UPI) -- Americans received the first of the new silverless coins today. Some said they did not like the looks of the three-layered copper-nickel quarter but most agreed it would spend just like the silver one.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 1 (UPI) -- A Buddhist monk burned himself to death tonight, on the second anniversary of the overthrow of the Ngo Dinh Diem regime. Similar suicides helped to bring about the downfall of that regime.

The four-story limestone town house with a 19th-century bowfront on the Upper West Side had been a shabby member in good standing of the slum around it.
LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 1 -- Duane Earl Pope went on trial for his life today in the murder of three persons.

Algernon Greaves, the dean's verger of Westminster Abbey, opened the British Travel Association drive yesterday to promote tourism for the church's 900th anniversary next year. Wearing the white bow tie wing collar and blue-and-red ceremonial robes of his office, he displayed souvenirs of the Abbey at the association's headquarters, 682 Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The Government's 15-year campaign against the Communist party of the United States returned to court today, but the start of the trial was delayed to permit the judge to study the complicated case.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange declined slightly yesterday, following the pattern of the Big Board.

The United States Equestrian Team was in charge of the international jumping competition of the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden yesterday as usual. In the afternoon, Kathy Kusner rode Unusual to first place in a class in which open jumpers also were participants.
