Haryou Act, the Harlem anti-poverty agency that has been embroiled in a financial controversy, announced an administrative shake-up yesterday.

AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 1 -- President Johnson does not need to go constantly among the people to know how they feel because he has a "great natural gift for knowing, feeling and sensing the mood of the American people," according to a key White House aide.

SCHWEIZER RENEKE, South Africa, Oct. 30 -- The vivid blue skies of a South African summer vanished in a swirl of orange dust about 100 miles before the car reached this drought-ridden town in the Western Transvaal.

SINGAPORE, Nov. 1 -- The Indonesian Army threw more troops into the battle against Communist rebels in central Java today, and an army spokesman described the situation in the Communist strong-hold as "increasingly serious."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 1 -- The Soviet Union has asked the Security Council to agree that all United Nations military observers be withdrawn from India and Pakistan in three months as its price for a resolution speeding the withdrawal of forces in the subcontinent, Western diplomatic sources said tonight.
A bitter legal battle among members of the family of J. Meyer Schine, who recently disposed of his vast real estate, hotel, theater and broadcasting empire, was started yesterday in Federal Court.

After a shaky start Premier Forbes Burnham's coalition government in British Guiana has made substantial progress toward economic viability, political stability and racial harmony. It is dismaying that the coalition partners have fallen out over what seem to be fairly minor issues at the start of discussions in London aimed at charting the colony's path to independence.
The National Football League, which commands a higher price for television rights to its events than any other sports organization, is considering a plan to set up its own network to carry its games.

The Bank of America, the nation's largest bank, has started an aggressive program to break into the United States Government bond market as a full-fledged dealer, making primary markets, and doing business directly with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 1 -- South Vietnam Celebrated today the second anniversary of the overthrow of Ngo Dinh Diem with a parade of Government troops and a fly-past of fighters and helicopters.
TOKYO, Nov. 1 -- Japan laid claim to the world's fastest train service today.
An array of uncertainties forced the stock market to retreat a bit yesterday. Most of the popular averages were down at the close of the session as turnover declined from Friday's level.

Bob Windish, the coach of New York University's football club, resigned from the Violet athletic staff yesterday and accused the university administration of misleading him about the future of football at the school.

THE choreographer Anna Sokolow has a very proper respect for Hell -- a respect that even Dante might envy. Last night at the East 74th Street Theater, the Dance Theater Workshop's "Mondays at Nine" subscription series got under way with a production of her work "Dreams."

WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 1 -- Woodlawn Drummond, a filly who is the queen of pacers -- colts included -- in her native Canada, easily won the $50,639.25 Lady Maud Pace tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. Scoring a 1 3/4-length eased up victory over Adios Alice, the Canadian champion cast a vote for herself for division honors among 3-year-old female pacers.
LAST night's original play, "The Drapes Come," by Charles Dizenzo, was in keeping with the expressly experimental purpose of the New York Television Theater on Channel 13.
Governor Rockefeller stood at the edge of the sewage-laden Hudson River yesterday and appealed for a yes vote on Proposition 1, which would help finance water purification.

DETROIT, Nov. 1 (AP) -- United States auto makers will set another production record next Friday when, with eight weeks left, their output for the calendar year to date tops the entire 1964 production of 7,739,034 cars.
Supporters of Make New York Beautiful, Inc., will take their sea legs to the New York Hilton tomorrow evening instead of to the Italian liner Raffaello for a champagne dinner dance.

A leading local trucking association has filed a complaint with the Federal Maritime Commission against the New York Terminal Conference and 21 of its members in protest against higher pier cargo rates and tariffs.
Like weary soldiers during an unexpected drill, commuters accepted last night's delay on the New Haven Railroad with dismay, despair, amusement and, in the main, forbearance.
THESE two books expand our horizon beyond the passing, feverish literary scene. Quite incidentally, they remind us that other ages, near or far, were as alarmingly twitchy and heroic as our own.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Consumer installment credit rose by $683 million in September in the largest increase since the record rise in April, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 1 (UPI) -- The mother of a suspected drunken driver whose arrest helped touch off the Los Angeles riots was convicted late today of interfering with a police officer.
TRENTON, Nov. 1 -- One of the most bitter and emotional campaigns in New Jersey's history ends tomorrow when the people elect a Governor and a reapportioned Legislature.

Nelson E. Finch, vice president of Walter Oertly Associates, Inc., 271 Madison Avenue, has been appointed head of the company's new consultant service for chain-store leasing and shopping-center development, which is being operated on a national basis.

THE Giant-Cardinal game on Sunday displayed a rarity -- something new in pro football. The St. Louis defense introduced what might be called the total blitz -- seven, eight and nine men in varied combinations going after the Giant quarterback, Earl Morrall.

WHAT is the optimum level of football competition, and by what standards? Recent and forthcoming events in New York provide ample material for reflection on this question, which has relevance in every section of the country.
A French national, identified by the police as Raoul Matalon, 42 years old, of Paris, has been ordered held in $50,000 bail here as a fugitive in a $850,000 jewel robbery in Paris.
Edward I. Koch, who three times defeated Carmine G. De Sapio for the Democratic leadership of Greenwich Village, yesterday endorsed the Republican-Liberal candidate for Mayor, John V. Lindsay.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Yields on the new issues of Treasury bills bounded back up in this week's offering to reach their highest level in more than five years.
Aksel Schiotz, baritone, was Lucy Brown's guest at Carnegie Recital Hall last night in the second of the three concerts Miss Brown is giving there this season.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- A Special committee was appointed today to review the Public Health Service's activities and their relationship to similar functions of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare and other Government agencies.
There will be extensive radio and television coverage of today's elections in New York and New Jersey.
Nearly 1,500 passengers aboard the Italian Line's luxury ship Raffaello learned yesterday morning that the vessel was plodding back toward Italy instead of speeding toward a landing here tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The Pentagon is holding up its plan to liquidate six Army Reserve divisions, including New York's 77th Infantry.
Wheat prices staged some pyrotechnics yesterday as they skyrocketed to life-of-contract highs. The spark apparently was the possibility of larger exports that might cut into the abundant supply.

ONE of the great personalities in the world of bridge retired from active bridge administration recently. Baron Robert de Nexon, afflicted by ill health, resigned as president of the European Bridge League and was succeeded by Count Bonde of Sweden.
Controller Abraham D. Beame demanded in his annual report yesterday that the Mayor's annual budget proposals include a four-year projection of expenditures and revenues.

OXFORD, Md., Nov. 1 -- There is no more pleasant and melodious sound to a goose shooter than the querulous gabbling of Canada geese hidden away in the darkness of the night before the opening of the season.
The School of American Ballet, the most distinguished school of classic ballet in the country, will become associated with the Juilliard School of Music.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Although the evidence is tenuous and indirect, some American experts are speculating that the Soviet Union is urging North Vietnam to clarify the terms it laid down last spring as a basis for negotiations to end the Vietnamese war.

WHEN long-haired, blonde Mary Travers learned that she was to be presented to Queen Elizabeth II and the Duke of Edinburgh next Monday she asked herself the same question that must be answered by almost any woman going anywhere: What shall I wear?
ROCKAWAY TOWNSHIP, N.J., Nov. 1 -- Two young boys, lost overnight in rugged woodland near the Split Rock Reservoir, hiked out safely today.
LINCOLNTON, Ga., Nov. 1 (UPI) -- A racial crisis in northeast Georgia appeared to be waning tonight.
John V. Lindsay spent his last full campaign day yesterday -- as he had his first more than five months ago -- on the streets of New York, asking "whether or not now is the time for a change."
WITH the tinsel and holly season only weeks away it is not too soon to begin leafing through the many colorful catalogues of gifts that cheer.

BRISBANE, Australia, Tuesday, Nov. 2 (Reuters) -- Marty Riessen of Evanston, Ill., the third-seeded foreign player, was the first overseas player to reach the men's singles quarterfinals of the Queensland lawn tennis championships today when he beat an Australian left-hander, Owen Davidson, 6-2, 6-1, 6-4.
Here we recapitulate The Times' previous recommendations on the contests and issues facing the voters of New York City today:
William F. Buckley Jr. told the people of New York City last night that a vote for him today would be a vote "for a vision of a new order" and "the beginning of a new dawn."

Brown, Harris, Stevens, Inc., plans to increase its real estate brokerage and commercial leasing operations in the financial district under Charles L. Goldenberg and Ira M. Koerner, vice presidents of the company, who have been appointed co-directors of the downtown office at 1 Chase Manhattan Plaza.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 -- A Chicago physician testified at the Krebiozen conspiracy trial today that he had administered 10 ampules of the controversial drug to himself at one time and that a stomach cancer he was told he had was not found later.

PARIS, Nov. 1 -- Several French newspapers have accused the United States of conducting a "violent" anti-French campaign to embarrass President de Gaulle in the election campaign and to interfere with the French-Soviet talks in Moscow.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- A State Department spokesman described as "patent nonsense" today a French charge that the United States Government had undertaken a campaign against President de Gaulle.

The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., announced yesterday a yearend extra dividend of 40 cents a common share, along with the regular payout of 70 cents. Both are payable Dec. 20 to stockholders of record Nov. 22.

NEW DELHI, Nov. 1 (UPI) -- Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri said today the United States had become more sympathetic to India's position in the recent fighting with Pakistan. He indicated he might soon visit the United States.
For the first time since its completion 1,500 years ago the Talmud, the basic collection of Jewish law, will be accessible to rank-and-file students of Judaism.
CAIRO, Nov. 1 -- A trolley bus jammed to overflowing with shoppers and students veered out of control, plunged down a 20-foot river bank and sank in the Nile this afternoon, drowning 62 persons.
The death of Daniel Burros appeared yesterday to have put an end, at least temporarily, to the Ku Klux Klan's organizational campaign in New York before it had made headway.

ST. PAUL, Nov. 1 -- Cyrus E. Magnusson, Minnesota Insurance Commissioner, abruptly refused today Gov. Karl F. Rolvaag's demand that he resign, saying he had no reason to do so. He is under Federal indictment in an insurance fraud case.
The New York Knickerbockers made one of their most significant trades yesterday as they acquired Walt Bellamy from the Baltimore Bullets in exchange for three players and an undisclosed sum.
CHICAGO, Nov. 1 (UPI) -- About 4,350 fuel truck drivers went on strike today, threatening the Chicago metropolitan area with a gasoline and fuel oil shortage.
PARIS, Nov. 1 -- Mehdi Ben Barka, the prominent Moroccan Opposition leader who disappeared here three days ago, is believed by his friends to be the victim of a political kidnapping.

David S. Lifson's letter of Oct. 23 under the caption of "Incinerators to Blame" makes more than interesting reading. In my opinion, this concise, direct statement points a major cause and the action that is required to deal with it.
Three of the six stores operated by Lane's are expected to be converted to units of Klein's Department Stores, Inc., but no date has yet been specified by the move.

Congress has taken its first look at the administration of the multimillion-dollar campaign against poverty. The result has been criticism of Sargent Shriver, director of the Office of Economic Opportunity, and the imposition of restrictions on the program.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov. 1 -- President Ayub Khan said tonight that "peace can return to this subcontinent only if the basic cause of the India-Pakistan conflict is resolved."

Americans can take pride in two things -- our orderly election days, and our voluntary health and welfare institutions. On Election Day, we choose those who will administer the money we contribute in taxes toward the common good.

Aluminum companies would not comment yesterday on reports that President Johnson was considering use of the national aluminum stockpile as a tool to force rescission of the price rise announced last week.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday its governors had adopted a new set of rules that would permit them to raise initial margin requirements on "day trading" -- the quick in-and-out purchases and sales of the same stocks in the same day.
The Copper Range Company dropped the other shoe yesterday, a move some observers of the copper industry had been expecting for two weeks.
The British pound reached it highest level in 3 1/3 years on London's foreign exchange markets yesterday. The closing quotation was $2.8042, a gain of 0.55 cents on the day.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 1 -- The Trusteeship Committee voted today to send to the General Assembly a resolution calling upon Britain to suspend the Constitution of Rhodesia, which weights voting heavily against the black majority of four million.
LONDON, Nov. 1 -- The House of Commons hustled through its question period today with unusual alacrity. Within the hour allocated, 69 questions were answered orally, more than for many years.
Michigan State tightened its hold on first place in both the United Press International coaches' poll and the Associated Press writers' poll after its 49-7 victory over Northwestern last Saturday.
LAUREL, Md., Nov. 1 (AP) Washington D.C. International race Nov. 11 was restored to eight today wih the addition of three entries -- from Venezuela, Argentina and France.
ALGIERS, Tuesday, Nov. 2 -African and Asian foreign ministers formally postponed today the scheduled meeting of their heads of state until a "date to be fixed later."
LONDON, Nov. 1 (Reuters) -- Gales lashed Britain, Northern France and Scandinavia today, causing death, injury flooding and widespread damage.
Gem-studded gold cigarette cases that belonged to Cole Porter, who collected them as avidly as children collect bottle caps, have been given to the New York Public Library's theater collection.

THE color is Ming pink, the look is eclectic, and the decorating notes to watch are shirred curtains and pleated lampshades in the newly redecorated House of Years opening today on Sloane's fifth floor.
The United Aircraft Corporation sharply increased its sales and earnings in the three and nine months ended Sept. 30, according to the report issued yesterday.
Former Gov. Thomas E. Dewey yesterday attacked as "a dreadful misrepresentation" an assertion that Kenneth B. Keating, candidate for the New York Court of Appeals, had never actively practiced law.
Commandant Bill Ringrose of Ireland thinks that money has tampered a bit with the luck of the Irish in their horse show fortunes here the last week.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Autumn in Washington: Golden leaves and ice-blue sky. The President in Texas. Ted Kennedy in Vietnam. Congress in the sinks of Paris, the haberdasheries of Hong Kong, the baths of Tokyo.

ALGIERS, Nov. 1 -- Algeria displayed today Soviet-supplied weapons, including two antiaircraft ground-to-air missiles, before delegations from 45 countries here for the conference of Asian and African foreign ministers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. l -- A White House meeting of high officials discussed disposing of surplus aluminum today as the Johnson Administration and the aluminum industry appeared to be in a cat-and-mouse game over the price of the key metal.
LONDON, Nov. 1 -- Charles Chaplin is returning, to filmmaking after an eight-year absence.
POLITICS sneaked into the act at the spring showings on and off Seventh Avenue yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Housewives crusading for more peanuts in peanut butter won a preliminary round today, but the real test is yet to come.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said today that common carriers alone -- such as A.T. -- should be allowed to lease space-communications channels directly from the Communications Satellite Corporation (Comsat).

Broadway theater ticket prices will be reduced slightly, starting Jan. 1, when the 10 per cent Federal tax on tickets will be lifted. Some producers will pass along the entire savings; others plan a partial reduction. One show will make no change at least until July.

THE Museum of Modern Art and the Whitney Museum of American Art are opening new exhibitions today. One is an exhibition of super-high-class guaranteed gold ribbon showpieces; the other is sort of little and pawky.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Nov. 1 -- The Venezuelan Government notified the Latin American Free Trade Association today of its intention to join the nine-nation trade bloc. The step is expected to be ratified by the Venezuelan Congress.

The mayoral race of William F. Buckley Jr. was primarily a mission in sabotage. The Conservative party candidate sought to obscure the clear lesson of the Goldwater Presidential debacle by taking enough votes away from John V. Lindsay to prove that a liberal Republican could not win either.
SEVEN SPRINGS, Pa., Nov. 2 (UPI) -- Getting elected Mayor of this ski resort community was a snap for Philip Dupre today, relatives and the rest were friends.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2 (UPI) -- The Scott Paper Company announced today the development of a new paper making machine it described as substantially cheaper to buy, operate, and maintain than conventional units.
SIX fashion-conscious women who may never have worn glass slippers, but who probably could, will play the part of Cinderellas at a ball this evening at the New York State Theater.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Nov. 2 -- Fifteen persons have been slain in post-election rioting in the Ekiti Division of Nigeria's Western Region. In Abeokuta, the region's second biggest city, mobs of opposition party members burned two courthouses, drove a nail into the neck of a judge and severely beat a court clerk.
MOSCOW, Nov. 2 -- The United States accused the Soviet Union today of jeopardizing their cultural-exchange agreement.

Three surveys published in daily newspapers here predicted that the mayoral election would be close.
PHILADELPHIA. Nov. 2 -- Barry Goldwater called today for the resignation of Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara.

Frank Sinatra said yesterday that he had withdrawn permission for the Columbia Broadcasting System to televise material furnished by him for "Sinatra," a C.B.S. News special. The C.B.S. News division, which produced the program, said it still planned to present the hour-long profile of the singer as scheduled Nov. 16 at 10 P.M.
The Bryn Mawr Hotel -- once notorious as a center of narcotics addiction and crime and later the focus of a bitter Morningside Heights community battle -- is being closed.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Wednesday, Nov. 3 -- Israeli voters have given Premier Levi Eshkol a surprising vote of confidence in the national elections for a new Parliament.

LONDON, Oct. 2 (Reuters) -- Prince Philip today honored Paul Mellon, the American art collector, in a ceremony at Buckingham Palace.

The United States Mission to the United Nations is investigating a charge that the First Secretary of the Nigerian Mission was involved in a hit-and-run car accident in Tuckahoe, N.Y., on Sunday.

Surging crowds in a sweltering, smoke-filled ballroom of the Roosevelt Hotel roared exultantly for Representative John V. Lindsay this morning as the Republican-Liberal candidate overcame an early deficit to win the race for Mayor.
The New York chapter of the Arthritis Foundation will hold a cocktail party tomorrow from 5 to 8 P.M. in its new shop at 1407 Second Avenue, near 73d Street. The shop is scheduled to open on Tuesday.

The Rockwell-Standard Corporation is expanding its automotive equipment business through the $21 million cash purchase of Lyon, Inc., of Detroit, effective Nov. 12.

AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 2 -- Gov. John B. Connally Jr. was set back today on his plan to increase terms for Governors and other state officials from two to four years.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 2 -- A former cell mate of Harold Strachan, the political prisoner whose articles started The Rand Daily Mail's crusade against brutality in South African jails, testified today that the articles resulted from a conspiracy to discredit the Government.

BRISBANE, Australia, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Arthur Ashe of Richmond advanced to the quarter-finals of the Queensland lawn tennis championship today. He and Marty Riessen of Evanston, Ill., became the last American hopes in the tournament.

Jack Frank, a Freeport, L.I., man who allegedly helped his nephew purchase the 20-mm. cannon used in the $400,000 burglary of a Brink's office Syracuse last week, consented yesterday to face prosecution in Albany.

CLEVELAND, Wednesday, Nov. 3 -- Mayor Ralph S. Locher won a hard-fought contest for re-election early today against the challenge of State Representative Carl B. Stokes, a Negro, on the basis of complete unofficial returns.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2 -- A code of practices for undertakers, calling for complete clarity in handling the costs and other details of funerals, was adopted today by the National Funeral Directors Association.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Nov.2 (AP) -- Victory in Southeast Asia hinges on a decision needed soon on whether the United States and South Vietnam will go "all the way," according to the commanding general of 30,000 United States marines in Vietnam.

LONDON, Nov. 2 -- The Pennine Hills -- bleak, wet, spotted with peat bogs -- run down through the dark north of England. In that gloomy setting the police are pressing a grim search, a search unlike any within memory here.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 2 (UPI) -- Cassius Clay, heavyweight boxing champion, said today he intended to "punish" Floyd Patterson and give him "a good beating so he won't have any excuses" when the two meet at Las Vegas on Nov. 22.
BONNEVILLE SALT FLATS, Utah, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Craig Breedlove, who survived one crash last year and nearly had another this year, set a world land-speed record of 555.127 miles an hour today.

The Johnson Administration's attempt to hold the line on aluminum prices points up one of the many hazards facing business forecasters. Yet the forecasters are in a fearless and optimistic mood, willing to climb farther out on a limb much earlier than usual with their predictions for 1966.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (UPI) -- The Food and Drug Administration announced today plans to seize 66,000 pairs of surgical gloves it said were found not to be sterile.

Quiet trading prevailed yesterday on the London Stock Exchange. The day opened in rather dull trading but picked up somewhat after the favorable United Kingdom gold figures and a rise in dollar reserves had been reported.

DETROIT, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Mayor Jerome P. Cavanagh was elected to a second term in Detroit's nonpartisan municipal election today. He won a sweeping victory over Walter C. Shamie, a political newcomer, who is a businessman.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 2 -- Horse racing in Australia these days is not quite the national addiction it once was, but the 104th annual running of the Melbourne Cup today, won by Light Fingers, a New Zealand filly, showed the sport of kings still is a feverish fixation with a vast number of Australians.

RICHMOND, Nov. 2 -- Mills E. Godwin Jr., a Democrat, was elected Governor of Virginia tonight with strong support from Negroes, organized labor and Senator Harry F. Byrd's conservative political organization.
John V. Lindsay was elected Mayor of New York yesterday on the Republican-Liberal ticket, a victory that deeply affected the national political picture.
AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 2 -- President Johnson led a 22-car caravan today on a four-hour, 52-mile tour of three of his ranches.

John V. Lindsay is the next Mayor of New York. The politically incredible has come to pass. This city, weary of twenty long years of plodding one-party rule, has cast its vote for a better future. The people have made it plain that they want a change. They will get it in Lindsay.
The Ford Motor Company reported yesterday that its new-car sales in October were the highest in the company's 62-year history.

Mary Harrison Lindsay shared her husband's hour of victory last night. A slim brunette with deep gray-green eyes, she had spent the last six months alternately caring and campaigning for her husband of 16 years.

Three years ago in Dallas, Roosevelt Brown and several of his teammates among the New York Giants were standing on a corner downtown passing time before their game against the Cowboys. A college sophomore named Carl Lockhart from North Texas State approached them, but then backed off.

MONTICELLO, Ark., Nov. 2 -- A speech instructor at a state-supported college here was dismissed Friday after he circulated among his students petitions condemning the practice of whipping prisoners at the state penal farm.

LONDON, Nov. 2 -- The Treasury reported today -- just about a year after eruption of the latest sterling crisis -- that the nation's gold and convertible currency reserves rose for the second month running to the highest level since May 1963.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2 -- In an upset victory over the Democratic machine, Arlen Specter, the Republican nominee, tonight defeated the Democratic incumbent, James C. Crumlish Jr., for District Attorney.
The Irish Government Tourist Board has leased the six-story building at 590 Fifth Avenue, near 48th Street, for 21 years at an aggregate rental of $1,600,000.
A new Transit Authority express bus service between Staten Island and Brooklyn known as R-84 and an extension of the R-7 Verrazano Bridge route begin today.
CHICAGO, Nov. 2 -- Trading on the Midwest Stock Exchange was moderate today. Volume totaled 70,000 shares contrasted to 260,000 yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 2 -- Roger Seydoux of France accused the United Nations today of wasting funds on studies that produce no action and on unproductive international conferences.

The Rt. Rev. Silas has been named spiritual leader of the First Archdiocesan District, which covers 80 communities in New York, Connecticut and other Middle Atlantic states. Bishop Silas is now Auxiliary Bishop to Archbishop Iakovos, the Greek Orthodox Primate of North and South America.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Nov. 2 -- Clarence J. Brown Jr., a Republican who publishes a 38-year-old Republican who publishes a newspaper at Urbana, Ohio, was elected tonight to the House of Representatives from the Seventh Congressional District.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Total government employment increased by 18,420 jobs during the year ended in June. More than half of the increase -- 9,511 positions -- went to Negroes.

PALMIRY, Poland, Nov. 2 -- The hills outside Palmiry suddenly flatten out and it is here that the cemetery is situated. The leaves on clumps of surrounding trees were brilliant in autumn colors yesterday and at first all a visitor could think of was the beauty of the spot -- though the Nazis did not choose Palmiry for its beauty.

THE newest gallery in town is filled with puzzles, the kind one takes apart and puts together again on long winter evenings. But, once completed, the jigsaw puzzles in the new gallery at Henri Bendel are designed to be hung on the wall.
The Lighthouse, the New York Association for the Blind, will benefit from the Lighthouse Dinner Dance, to be held on Nov. 16 in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The United States is preparing to provide India with another monthly allotment of surplus wheat. But it is holding back on a long-term food commitment until India takes steps to improve her agricultural production.
The Conservative party yesterday amassed the highest vote it has obtained in this city since it was organized in 1962 to counterbalance the influence of the Liberal party on city and state politics.
OUR master choreographer, George Balanchine, has in the past compared himself to a chef and to a carpenter.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara is not interested in running for Governor of Michigan, a spokesman said today.

The Zenith Radio Corporation, one of the leading manufacturers of television sets, achieved record sales and earnings in the three and nine months ended Sept. 30, the Chicago producer reported yesterday.

SINGAPORE, Nov. 2 -- The Communist revolt appeared today to be spreading from central Java to the eastern and western reaches of Java, Indonesia's most important island, according to reports reaching here.

Larry Furnell, slowed by a stomach cramp, still broke the meet record by 47 seconds yesterday in winning the 39th annual Metropolitan Intercollegiate cross-county championship at Van Cortlandt Park. His 135-yard triumph led St. John's to a surprising team championship.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Nov. 2 -- Prime Minister Ian D. Smith cautioned the British Government tonight not to wait too long before allowing a royal commission to determine whether the people of Rhodesia want their independence.
TORONTO, Nov. 2 -- A major expansion of the Canadian automobile industry is getting under way following the auto trade agreement integrating the Canadian and the United States auto industries.

I generally agree with Arthur Krock's views about inflation. However, I believe his analysis in The Times of Oct. 19 of the breakout from price stability we are currently experiencing puts the wrong emphasis on the facts.
Advertising men, like most other people, took time off yesterday to vote. Some devoted a couple of hours to it, some a half day, and others shot the whole day in the interest of good government.

MOSCOW, Nov. 2 -- France and the Soviet Union concluded official discussions today without reaching agreement on new approaches to the problem of divided Germany or broader questions of European security.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- "The secret of our power lies in the secrecy of our membership," says an official instruction of the Ku Klux Klan. "By this means we see and hear everything. We know the evil forces but they do not know us."
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The Indonesian Communist party was accused today of having planned to lead a revolt against the Indonesian Army.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The Small Business Administration is refusing to accept applications for its ordinary small business loan program until further notice.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The time was late July. President Johnson had called in the leaders of Congress to tell them in advance of his impending announcement of a large troop build-up in Vietnam and an increase in the over-all size of the military forces.

A POUILLY-FUME wine called Ladoucette, an excellent dry white wine from the Loire Valley, was introduced to New Yorkers nearly 12 years ago. At the time, this newspaper called it a wine that "hardly needs a press agent; it recommends itself."

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 2 (AP) -- A jury of 10 men and two women was selected today in the Federal District Court trial of Duane E. Pope, the former college football player from Kansas, who is charged with bank robbery and murder.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 2 -- County Executive Edwin G. Michaelian of Westchester, a Republican, was re-elected for a third term of four years today and Republicans retained control of the county Board of Supervisors for the 57th consecutive year.
WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 2 (UPI) -- Interloper, enjoying his most successful season, set all the pace tonight to win the $7,500 invitation trot at Roosevelt Raceway.
The appointment of William H. Adams and Jean M. Lindberg as senior vice presidents was announced yesterday by the Chase Manhattan Bank.
The Fairchild Hiller Corporation announced yesterday that Ozark Airlines planned to buy 21 FH-227 turboprop airliners under terms of a $32 million contract.

Bill Steinkraus, the United States Equestrian Team captain, gained the individual championship of the international jumping at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night, which took a bit of doing.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Nov. 2 -- Banks reopened and newspapers resumed publication today after a civil-war shutdown of more than six months.

BONN, Nov. 2 -- Former members of Nazi Germany's SS who during a meeting last week in Schleswig-Holstein demanded higher benefits from the Government are already receiving the same war compensation as the average German veteran of World War II.
The present cultural exchange program expires on Dec. 31. In the past, agreements have been made before or after the start of the year and in the latter case have been made retroactive.
READING, Pa., Nov. 2 -- The body of Ku Klux Klansman Daniel Burros was cremated here today and buried in a nonsectarian cemetery. The service was private.
FOR some 75 years Lincoln, the savior of his country, has been much more loved by most Americans than Washington, the father of his country.

The Metropolitan Opera National Company, six week into its first tour has met with critical and box-office success. And the Omens are all bright, according to its managers, Rise Stevens and Michael Manuel.

HARTFORD, Nov. 2 -- Mayor Richard C. Lee, a Democrat, was elected to his seventh consecutive term as Mayor of New Haven today. In Norwalk, the Democrats scored an upset mayoral victory and they retained the Mayor's office in their strongholds of Hartford and Bridgeport.

The new 46,000-ton Italian luxury liner Raffaello was reported yesterday to be proceeding toward Gibraltar at reduced speed on the second day of an aborted Atlantic crossing that started at Genoa on Oct. 26.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 2 -- A hundred and one countries pledged $147,706,000 today for 1966 projects of the United Nations Special Fund and the Expanded Program of Technical Assistance.

MOSCOW, Nov. 2 -- A group of rank-and-file Old Bolsheviks met today in Moscow's Museum of the Revolution to reminisce about their experiences in the frenzied days of the Bolshevik Revolution 48 years ago.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The 100 Washingtonians, including Ambassadors and prominent Government officials, who were invited to Perle Mesta's latest wing-ding are about as well-acquainted with what goes on at night on the television screen as TV people are with early Babylonian culture.

BEGINNING to clutter up the mails these days are those elegant Christmas catalogues that can make most persons, normally pretty well adjusted to their state of affluence and their impulses for giving, suddenly realize how underprivileged, unimaginative and inadequate they really are.

Much has been written and commented on regarding the map, made about the year 1440, recently discovered and published by Yale University. This map proves again that Leif Ericson (Leifur Eiriksson) was the first white man to discover North America.

BOSTON, Nov. 2 (UPI) -- Mrs. Louise Day Hicks, chairman of the Boston School Committee, and three other incumbents were re-elected tonight in a repudiation of Negro demands for an end to racial imbalance in city schools.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The Communist party of the U.S.A. won a point and lost one today as its second trial for failure to register with the Government as an agent of the Soviet Union moved toward selection of a jury.

TAHOE CITY, Calif., Oct. 31 -- Lake Tahoe, high in the Sierra Nevada, has long been celebrated as a gem of rustic beauty. Paradoxically, it has also suddenly become a nightmarish composite of the woes of urbanization and problems of government afflicting communities across the nation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The American Telephone and Telegraph Company formally asked the Federal Communications Commission today to revoke its recent order for an investigation of the company's costs and profits.

Mario Angelo Procaccino, the Controller-elect, approaches a political speech with the enthusiasm of a tenor attacking a Puccini aria. The Robert L. Hague Post of the American Legion has chosen Adm. Edwin John Roland, Commandant of the United States Coast Guard, to receive its distinguished service medal.
Police Commissioner Vincent L. Broderick has lost no time in assigning bodyguards to Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay.

The Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, District 2, announced yesterday that 88 marine engineers employed on 14 Great Lakes vessels had voted 38 to 24 for representation by the union. The voting was conducted by the American Arbitration Association.

White, Weld Company, investment bankers, announced yesterday the election of Homer McK. Rees, Morgan Hovey Harris Jr., Robert B. Lee and Lauren Arnold as vice presidents.
The Ingersoll-Rand Company realized a 37 per cent increase in earnings on a sales gain of 25 per cent in the third quarter this year.

A long-projected plan to convert a historic estate at Independence Avenue and West 252d Street, Riverdale, into a public arboretum and a scientific and cultural center will move a step closer to realization today.

The Wheeling Steel Corporation may be having its troubles, but it demonstrated yesterday that it intended to be aggressive in its fight back to financial health.

Alex Rose, leader of the Liberal party, told Democrats yesterday "not to take for granted" his party's support in next year's gubernatorial election. The party's support of John V. Lindsay is widely regarded as the key to the Republican-Liberal's election as Mayor.

OLEAN, N.Y., Nov. 4 -- Bridling over the idea that anyone would think their rolling countryside "a poverty area," the leadership of four so-called southern tier counties of western New York nevertheless plunged enthusiastically today into the Federal Appalachian redevelopment program.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 4 -- Antara, the Indonesian press agency, reported today that scientists and intellectuals were demanding the dissolution of the Indonesian Communist party and organizations affiliated with if.
IN the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

COACH BOB BLACKMAN of the undefeated Dartmouth Indians normally is pessimistic and becomes more so with each passing Saturday. So Buff Donelli, the Columbia coach, was alarmed yesterday at the weekly Columbia luncheon over what he is sure is a Blackman plot.
A former television producer testified yesterday that he did not try to find out whether the Russian prince who assassinated Rasputin in 1916 was still alive before dramatizing the slaying in 1963.
Trading on the American Stock Exchange continued to be hectic yesterday for the second consecutive day as the market advanced on a broad front.

American industry and business will spend nearly $55 billion on new plant and equipment in 1966, a rise of 8 per cent over the 1965 total. This will be almost $4 billion more than the similar outlays of this year and close to $10 billion more than was actually spent in 1964.

Many persons entertained at dinner parties before the reception and dance held at the Museum of the City of New York last night. The benefit, attended by more than 900, opened the museum's new Dutch Galleries.

The two-day White House Conference on Health covered a wide range of topics, but its leading theme emerged clearly enough: the United States is now morally committed to trying to assure all its people -- regardless of income, color or place of residence -- access to the best possible medical care.

Amid the gold of autumn sun and leaves the city took possession yesterday of two historic stone mansions and 20 sweeping acres along the Hudson River at Independence Avenue and 252d Street in Riverdale.

The National Dairy Products Corporation had three news developments to report to its 70,000 shareholders yesterday. They were the elevation of Gordon Edwards to the presidency to succeed J. Huber Wetenhall, who was elected to the new office of chairman of the board; the addition of two new directors, and the highest quarterly and nine-month earnings in its 42-year history.

The 28-year-old leader of a plot to destroy national monuments had a 10-year prison term reduced to 5 years yesterday by Federal Judge William B. Herlands. He was also placed on probation for five years on completion of his sentence.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The United Arab Republic has purchased nearly $6 million worth of corn from the United States and paid for it in dollars the State Department disclosed today. Thus the stage was set for resumption of American surplus food shipments, to the U.A.R.

ALBANY, Nov. 4 -- A Democratic advisory committee consisting chiefly of college professors -- none with legislative experience -- organized today to develop a new apportionment plan, perhaps with an electronic computer.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The White House Conference on Health called on the Federal Government today to help provide birth control devices and instruction to all American families, particularly the poor.
The British pound improved slightly in very quiet trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. It closed at $2.8052, a gain of 4 points over the Wednesday level.

A contemporary twist on "keeping up with the Joneses" appeared to be one of the reasons America House is opening a "Collector's Room" today on the second floor of the crafts shop at 44 West 53d Street.

SOME potential bridge exports fail to reach their full maturity because they become more interested in organization than in technique. A number of leading tournament directors are able players who seldom get the opportunity to play.

AMERICA'S only year-round resident ballet company is plonked with an endearing lack of ceremony into the middle of what is surely one of the world's most distinguished theaters -- architecturally that is. We refer, of course, to the ballet company of the Radio City Music Hall.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The Government ran into trouble today as testimony began at the trial of the Communist party on charges of willfully failing to register as a Soviet-controlled group.
The Chemical Bank New York Trust Company has lost its fight to initiate a general increase in the cost of loans to top-quality finance company borrowers.

LISBON, Nov. 4 -- The Government permitted the publication today in Portuguese newspapers of a pre - election manifesto by a hundred outstanding Roman Catholic laymen strongly opposed to the Government of Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar.
The Soviet Union and its satellites once again had a double impact on futures prices of two major commodities yesterday.

PARIS, Nov. 4 -- The Club Mediterranee, a French organization that offers informal, inexpensive and often exotic vacations to its 250,000 members, has chartered a Soviet passenger liner and most of its crew for a series of 10 cruises.
DETROIT, Nov. 4 (UPI). -- The defending National Hockey League champion Detroit Red Wings routed the Boston Bruins tonight, 8-1.

WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 4 -- The daily double -- not the twin double -- paid $1,699.60 at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. It was the highest daily-double payoff in the 26-year history of parimutuel harness racing in New York.

PRINCETON. N.J., Nov. 4 -- The nation's universities must create huge systems of regional, national and even international cooperation or lose control to the Federal Government and the states, James A. Perkins, president of Cornell University, declared tonight.

John Kenneth Galbraith, a former Ambassador to India who is now a Harvard economics professor, suggested yesterday that the time might be at hand for an increase in stock margin requirements, presently at 70 per cent.

There will be many theories to explain why President de Gaulle has decided to seek another seven-year term as the uncrowned King of France. The simplest is that he enjoys the exercise of power. He fought for it too long, too hard and too bitterly -- and suffered too many frustrating years in the wilderness -- to yield it when still vigorous at 75.
The 11-day threat of a milk strike was lifted yesterday when representatives of most of the distributors serving the metropolitan area and their employes agreed on a new two-year contract.

WAKEFIELD, Mass., Nov. 4 (UPI) -- Ten leaflets calling for the assassination of President Johnson because of United States involvement in Vietnam were found today in this suburban city about 10 miles north of Boston.
Jerry J. Pike has been elected vice president of the Struthers Scientific and International Corporation, a subsidiary of the Struthers Wells Corporation. He was a divisional sales manager.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Retail sales rose 6 per cent over the levels of the preceding week in the week ended Oct. 30 and were 16 per cent higher than the totals in the comparable 1964 week, the Commerce Department said today.
HONOLULU, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Easy-going Al Geiberger got birdies on two of the last three holes today to take the first-round lead in the $60,300 Hawaiian open with a 68.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 4 -- While the military effort against the Vietcong guerrillas resounded throughout the countryside this week, an equally grim but a silent war was being waged on the economic front.

STRINDBERG wrote "Miss Julie" in 1888, and the play, a shocker in its day, was immediately hailed as a masterpiece. It remains a strong piece of theater, even if the years have dulled its message. Somehow, the idea of a love affair between an aristocrat and a menial does not seem as earth-shaking as it used to.

The Eastern Air Lines air shuttle out of La Guardia Airport to Boston and Washington, which began with piston-engine airliners in 1961 and moved into newer turboprop planes this year, will go jet starting May 1.
WITH INDIAN TROOPS, On the Cease-fire Line, Pakistan, Nov. 4 -- There is a story Indian soldiers tell as they sit around their fires at night here on the dusty plains of Pakistan.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 4 -- United States troops, adopting guerrilla tactics, ambushed a force of North Vietnamese regulars last night three miles from the Cambodian border.
Mayor Wagner made it clear yesterday that he would have a keen interest in the Democratic party's selection of a candidate for Governor next year.

KANSAS CITY, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Three billion years ago -- when this planet was about one-fourth as old as it is now -- there lived organisms so small that 50,000 of them end-to-end would have been one inch long. Their discovery this year may upset some theories of how the world began.

Although the Curtis Publishing Company has expressed the belief it will approach the break-even point this year, the company in the three months to Sept. 30 had an operating loss of $1,158,000. This raised its loss for the first nine months to $3,727,000.
A key prosecution witness in the murder trial of Richard Robles denied yesterday that she had conspired with her husband to implicate Robles in the slaying of Janice Wylie and Emily Hoffert.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Nov. 4 (UPI) -- A helicopter located today the wreckage of an Argentine military transport that had been missing since yesterday with 68 persons aboard. There was no sign of survivors.
The Sinclair Refining Company, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Sinclair Oil Corporation, announced yesterday the election of George T. Stocking as a vice president.
Mrs. Ogden White is chairman of the seventh annual dinner dance for the Visiting Nurse Service of New York. Mrs. Ellmore C. Patterson is co-chairman of the Nov. 16 event at the St. Regis Roof.

Princess Margaret of Britain arrived in New York yesterday to begin 20 days of public and private engagements in this country -- and to promote British products. She was accompanied by an 11-member royal entourage, including her husband, the Earl of Snowdon.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Lawrence F. O'Brien, on his first full day as Postmaster General today, promised steady improvement in the postal service, including ultimate overnight mail delivery "almost anywhere in the country."

AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 4 -- Presi-Johnson announced today the first allocation of Federal funds to the states for highway beautification. The allocations were made under the Highway Beautification Act signed by Mr. Johnson on Oct. 22.
YONKERS, Nov. 4 -- A 15year-old Gorton High School football player died of a gunshot wound here last night and a 16-year-old friend was charged with aiding and abetting his suicide.
MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 4 -- The State Department of Pubic Works has been sharply criticized in a report by the State Department of Audit and Control for allegedly wasting millions of dollars annually.

HAVANA, Nov. 4 -- Seated in his air-conditioned office on the sixth floor of the Cuban Communist party headquarters, Carlos Rafael Rodriguez, one of the Government's principal economic planners, clasped his hands tightly in front of him and said:
AN amazing new "whisper quiet" bilge pump with a capacity of 1,250 gallons an hour was introduced by a Massachusetts company the other day.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 4 -- The Ripon Society, a Republican research and policy group, asserted today that party breakthroughs in the elections in New York and Philadelphia demonstrated a leadership "that well may capture the future of American politics."
A local law designed to drive illegal coffeehouses out of business was signed yesterday by Mayor Wagner.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The American voter is an amusing fellow. He will not be roped or measured. What he does one year he may very well repudiate the next. How the Negro or the Catholic votes in one city is no sure guide to how he will vote in another, and this is the genius of the system.
BERLIN, Nov. 4 -- The Brandenburg Gate, the historic landmark on the border between East Berlin and West Berlin, may be reopened to traffic by the East German Communists, Allied officials said today.

That old red ink item -- the minus pool -- made its appearance at Aqueduct again yesterday as the odds-on Beaupy from the Hobeau Farm skipped to an easy success over Ethel D. Jacob's Isle of Greece in the $10,000 Golden Voyage purse.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4 -- Mayor Richard J. Daley, Democratic leader of Illinois, said today the election of John V. Lindsay, Republican-Liberal, as Mayor of New York City, "wasn't any great victory for the Republican party."
DETROIT, Nov. 4 (UPI) -- The Detroit Public Library said today that it would not attempt to rewrite history and that racial slurs in rhymes of the past would be kept on the shelves.
A hearing on a motion by William F. Buckley Jr. to transfer an upcoming libel trial against him out of the city was postponed yesterday until Nov. 10.
PARIS, Nov. 4 -- President de Gaulle, in an emotion-charged television address, told the French people tonight that he was in the running for the presidency and asked them to re-elect him.

The Louis H. Silver collection of rare books and manuscripts, which created an uproar in 1964 when it was sold to the Newberry Library of Chicago for $2.75 million is again the center of book dealers' speculation. Part of the collection is in London awaiting auction sale on Monday and Tuesday.
The stock market survived a late wave of profit taking to finish with slim gains yesterday. The volume of $.58 million shares made it the busiest trading day in two weeks.

Protection of any natural enclave within a city's limits is worth mention, but the projected development of the twenty-acre Perkins estate overlooking the Hudson River at Riverdale merits special note. Under aegis of the Parks Department, a community planning association and a nonprofit foundation working in conjunction with city schools and colleges, this magnificent property is to become a distinguished center for cultivation of the arts and sciences and the preservation of natural beauty.
PARIS, Nov. 4. -- The face was alive with animation, the voice was firm, the gestures were energetic -- France's President personified his vision of his country.
Plans for two new Manhattan office buildings, one-in midtown and the other in the downtown area near the site of the projected World Trade Center, were disclosed here yesterday.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 4 (UPI) -- A Supreme Court judge today made an infant girl a Reynolds tobacco heiress worth millions of dollars.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 4 The No. 1 football offense in the Ivy League will be matched with the No. 1 defense when Princeton's champions and Harvard play here Saturday in the opening game of the Big Three series.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 4 -- The American Jewish Congress called on the State Education Department today to forbid two school districts in Nassau County from holding public school classes in religious institutions.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Nov. 4 -- A kindly gray-haired grandmother, whose vigor belies her age of 66, was inaugurated today as the sixth president of Sarah Lawrence College, and she immediately produced a recipe for big universities to become good little colleges.
A CHROME-PLATED tractor seat almost stole the show yesterday from four panelists at a Fashion Group luncheon at the New York Hilton Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The nation's employment picture showed "comparatively little change" last month as the unemployment rate continued to hold at an eight-year low, the Labor Department reported today.
AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 4 -- President Johnson named a 30-member commission today to make a thorough study of agricultural problems in the United States and recommend solutions.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- A House investigator told today of a 1958 convention of the Ku Klux Klan at which a proposal to burn schools drove some members out of the hooded order.

The keel for the longest ocean-going barge, a 475-foot craft to be named the Caribbean, was laid yesterday at the Bethlehem Steel Corporation's yard in Sparrows Point, Baltimore. The barge will be launched next spring.

A member voluntary nonprofit hospital of the United Hospital Fund is conducting a comprehensive multi-discipline research program to seek out ways to make paralyzed or diseased muscles obey electronic commands.

George Szell, with the New York Philharmonic at Philharmonic Hall last night, strode on stage like a whirlwind. He dispatched Mozart's "The Marriage of Figaro" Overture in what seemed like record time, and then strode off again just as briskly.
Sears, Roebuck Co. and the J.C. Penney Company, two giant chain store organizations, each announced yesterday record sales for October and for the first nine months of their fiscal years.
The Public Housing Administration announced yesterday that housing agencies in 24 states and the Virgin Islands planned to sell $90.19 million of bonds at competitive bidding Dec. 8.
A rather unusual advertising presentation took place last Friday in Moscow. It was conducted in Russian, but by Americans for the purpose of selling space in American publications.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Parachute jumping for fun was variously pictured today as a safe sport and as a threat to all air passengers.
The city's winter project Head Start, a $2-million-to-4 million program that has been delayed for lack of funds, is scheduled to begin Jan. 15.

THE state of Wisconsin, as represented by the management of the Green Bay Packers, yesterday turned back another assault from Atlanta, the city that had previously captured the state's major league baseball team, the Milwaukee Braves.
PARIS, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Following, in unofficial translation, is the text of President de Gaulle speech tonight announcing his intention to seek re-election.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The Budget Bureau, fiscal arm of the White House, has told the Office of Economic Opportunity that it would prefer less emphasis on policy-making by the poor in planning community projects.
MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 4 -- David T. Gibbons, the unsuccessful Democratic candidate for District Attorney of Nassau County, has been subpoenaed to appear before a grand jury here tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Kathy Kusner of Arlington, Va. raced Fire One to victory in the first international jumping event of the six-day Washington-International Horse Show tonight.
Frank D. O'Connor, who was elected City Council President by a much larger vote than John V. Lindsay polled in his election as Mayor, will present his own Legislative program for the city.
Revived independence threats in Rhodesia dampened trading yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.

Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn was designated yesterday as a "center of excellence" by the National Science Foundation. As such, it will receive $3,332,000 over the next three years to carry out its programs.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Friday, Nov. 5 -- Four Turkish Cypriotes were wounded in new fighting around the walled harbor town of Famagusta last night. There were unconfirmed reports that two Greek Cypriotes had been wounded.

NATCHEZ, Miss., Nov. 4 (AP) -- A group of white businessmen said today that if Negro leaders do not call off an economic boycott here by Wednesday Negro employes will be discharged and housewives will be asked to lay off their domestic help.
Five Vietnamese university students who are touring this country to "sell" Saigon's view of the Vietnam war to American collegiate critics are discovering that they will not listen.

The New York Knickerbockers unveiled their new 6-foot 11-inch 245-pound center before a crowd of 16,881 at Madison Square Garden last night. Both Walt Bellamy, the man the Knicks hope will lead them to the National Basketball Association playoffs, and New York barely survived.
Michael J. Quill presented contract proposals to the Transit Authority yesterday that an authority spokesman estimated would cost more than $250 million over a two-year period.
Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay said last night that he had invited Milton Mollen, who was defeated for Controller, to join the new city administration and, in effect, to pick his spot.
OXFORD, Md., Nov. 4 -- One might win a small, outdoor-style wager if he were to bet that the largest and smallest American geese were one and the same bird, the Canada goose.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported the following spot primary market prices for the dates shown:
A public offering of 500,000 shares of C.I.T. Financial Corporation preference stock priced at $100 a share was sold out yesterday soon after it was placed in the market.

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz asked the Internal Revenue Service yesterday to lay down rules prohibiting theater owners or ticket sellers from retaining any excise tax monies paid on tickets for performances after Dec. 31.
The Rapid-American Corporation said yesterday it had signed a contract to buy Joseph H. Cohen Sons, Inc., a privately held maker of men's clothing.
TOKYO, N0V. 4 -- For the first time since the formation of Japan's postwar defense forces, the number of men seeking to enlist exceeds the recruiters' goals.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., Nov. 4 -- Five hundred orderly but noisy students marched from Perth Amboy High School to City Hall today to urge officials to end the three-day teachers' strike or close down all 10 public schools.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Nov. 4 -- For more than two hours yesterday afternoon, President Rene Schick Gutierrez stood in a room of the National Palace and handed out money, advice and moral support to several hundred poor Nicaraguans.

THE HAGUE, Nov. 4 -- Britain and five of the six member nations of the Common Market expressed hope today for an early start of "fruitful dialogue" between the Common Market and the seven-nation European Free Trade Association.

MONTREAL, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Henri Richard scored twice, sparking a three-goal Montreal rally that carried the Stanley Cup champion Canadiens to a 5-1 National Hockey League victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Nov. 4 -- Brazil all but rejected today a Chilean plan to hasten the transformation of the nine-nation Latin American Free Trade Association into a common market with autonomous power.

The first half of the battle to retain Section 14(b) of the Taft-Hartley Act is now history -- but we have a long way to go. Based on the results of this session of Congress there is every reason to believe 14(b) will not be repealed.

The Federal Reserve System was reported yesterday to have purchased some of the new 4 1.4 per cent notes offered Monday by the Treasury. The $9.73 billion offering drew an exceptionally light response from investors.
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Nov. 4 -- Republican leaders agreed today that prospects for the party in 1966 seem good here in the West.

" Richer Than Spices" is the title of a book by Gertrude Z. Thomas, which Knopf will publish on Nov. 15, but the story is in the subtitle. It reads: "How a royal bride's dowry introduced cane, lacquer, cottons, tea and porcelain to England and so revolutionized taste, manners, craftsmanship, and history in both England and America."

Many private dinner parties were held last night for guests attending the Yorkville Ball at the Sheraton-East, a benefit for the Yorkville Youth Council. Nearly 400 attended the ball, proceeds of which give major financial help to the agency.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 5 (AP) -- Tennessee nudists argued today that a state law requiring them to keep their clothes on was a violation of their civil rights and should be declared unconstitutional.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 5 -- The Indonesian Government is trying to divest the Communist party of its appeal among the peasants by emphasizing its own land-reform campaign.

String programs in which Debussy's Quartet in G minor emerges as the weightiest work played are not common, but that this was the case last night with the Loewenguth Quartet at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
Columbia's football team will face its most difficult test of the season when it meets undefeated Dartmouth this afternoon at Baker Field. Game time for the Ivy League contest is 1:30 o'clock.

The invincible Big Three of college football, Michigan State, Arkansas and Nebraska, are heavily favored, along with Notre Dame, to hold their places at the forefront today as the season approaches the homestretch.
Richard Robles confessed the slaying of Janice Wylie and Emily Hoffert to several detectives on the day he was arrested for the crime, one of them testified yesterday.
Nearly half the teen-agers in the Neighborhood Youth Corps here will have to be dropped from the program because their family incomes are too high.
AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 5 -- The nation's largest aluminum producer announced price increases today that President Johnson had hoped to forestall.

Three dissident directors of the Reading Company filed a petition with the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday seeking to have the Reading merged now into the Chesapeake Ohio-Baltimore Ohio Railroad System.
An airline plan for making a fourth jetport unnecessary in the New York area has been given strong support by a nationwide organization representing owners and pilots of business and private planes.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 5 -- By American standards, Britain's Princess Margaret was elegantly overdressed today for the English-Speaking Union's fashion show luncheon at the San Francisco Hilton Hotel. She wore white brocade shot with silver threads. The ensemble, a a fitted sheath and matching coat by Norman Hartnell, is the kind of thing British royalty often wears whether snipping a ribbon, christening a ship or watching the horses at Ascot.
Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay said yesterday he would name several financial experts before he takes office to advise him on ways to solve the city's fiscal problems.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 5 -- Senator Robert F. Kennedy expressed concern today that students' disagreement with policy in Vietnam was bringing about a sense of "disengagement" on all issues.
LISBON, Nov. 5 -- Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar told the Portuguese tonight that his 37-year-old regime was still "impervious to the political hysteria" of the outside world.
PARIS, Nov. 5 -- The newest way to choose clothes here is to go to the movies to do it.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Nov. 5 -- A nationwide state of emergency for three months was declared by the Rhodesian Government today.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 5 (UPI) -- Bob Charles of New Zealand, a former British Open champion, and Peter Thompson of Australia, the current British titleholder, shared the lead today in the $8,960 Wills Masters golf tournament with 36-hole totals of 139.
IF a time machine could make it possible for the stars of the thirties to oppose the experts of today, there would be no doubt that modern bidding methods would show greatly to advantage.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Masanori Murakami, the only Japanese ever to play major league baseball in the United States, plans to return home tomorrow, the San Francisco Giants said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The Johnson Administration has made as clear as it could, after a week of confusing developments related to aluminum, that it still puts top priority on good relations with the business community.
AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 5 -- President Johnson will sign the Higher Education Bill at the college from which he graduated 35 years ago.
The American Cyanamid Company announced the election yesterday of Edward J. Breck as chairman of John H. Breck, Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary.
PARIS, Nov. 5 -- Italy has added one more extraordinary device to the world's growing network of international monetary plans.
The nation's electric power production rose 8.0 per cent for the week ending Oct. 30, from the level in the corresponding 1964 week, it was reported by the Edison Electric Institute yesterday.
The Northern Natural Gas Company announced yesterday it had registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission a $40 million issue of debentures to be offered during the week of Nov. 22.
The big rise in British gold and dollar reserves in October, reported earlier this week, may be bigger than the figures indicated.

THE art dealers were complaining last week that business was off, but it could not have been because they were offering less than the usual variety of lures. One dealer suggested that the bull market on Wall Street accounted for the slump on Madison Avenue.

In the wake of the Lindsay victory the Democrats are, naturally, saying wait till next year; and the big guessing-game now will be on the question: Who will run for Governor of New York? The question is not confined to the Democrats. In spite of his repeated declarations of intent to run for a third term, Governor Rockefeller could face rebellion within his own party.

To Honorable Harvey S. Firestone Jr., National Chairman, U.S.O., Inc.: My sincere thanks to you and General O'Donnell for informing me of the recent action of the National U.S.O. Executive Committee to meet the needs for U.S.O. services which are resulting from our expanding commitment in Southeast Asia.
STOCKHOLM -- Air is a $100-million-a-year business for a former Swedish fan manufacturer that now dominates the market in Western Europe for air-conditioning systems.

In a letter published Oct. 18 the Ambassador of Somalia to the United States took exception to a report published in The New York Times that some 70,000 refugees with some 250,000 cattle had fled Somali persecution and settled in Ethiopia.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The index of wholesale primary market prices advanced two-tenths of 1 per cent to 103.0 of its 1957-59 base during the week ended Nov. 2, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
CLEVELAND Nov. 5 (UPI) -A Negro who was almost elected Mayor of Cleveland won the first round today in his battle to prevent Mayor Ralph S. Locher from being certified the winner.
The decline in Off Broadway production activity, which started several seasons ago, continues unabated.
GENEVA, Nov. 5 -- The International Red Cross Committee is greatly embarrassed by United States protest groups who are using it to channel aid to Communist North Vietnam and Vietcong guerrillas.
NATCHEZ, Miss., Nov. 5 (AP) -- A plan to break a civil rights boycott by forcing Negroes off their jobs failed today to win Chamber of Commerce endorsement.

BARCELONA, Spain, Nov. 5 (UPI) -- Straight-set victories by Manuel Santana of Spain and Ramanathan Krishnan of India today left the nations deadlocked, 1-1, at the end of the first two singles matches in the Davis Cup interzone tennis finals.
Two important industrial metals -- copper and platinum -- shone in futures trading yesterday as eager buyers once more pushed prices to new high levels during the day.
SAN SALVADOR -- Salvador has decided to do something more than hust complain about her inability to sell her coffee crop -- up to now the principal source of her income.
HOLLYWOOD, Nov. 5 -- American International, the movie company that has reaped enormous publicity and profits from its teen-age "beach pictures," is desperately shopping around for a new locale.
CHERRY HILL, N.J., Nov. 5 -- Four 2-year-old fillies whose names either begin or end with "lady" were among the 10 named here today for tomorrow's $184,190 Gardenia Stakes.
The aluminum price rises effective Monday will include the fourth increase for raw metal in two years.
Two of New York's leading Protestant churches will mark important milestones tomorrow.

ATLANTA, Nov. 5 -- Seven civil rights and church organizations today announced plans for a series of Alabama street marches to protest "segregated justice" and to urge "more vigorous" Federal action in combating it.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The Supreme Court agreed tonight to rule on the constitutionality of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 in a case brought directly to the Court by South Carolina.
The London Stock Exchange was shaken yesterday by events in Rhodesia.

ROME, Nov. 5 -- Less than two weeks after publication here, Luigi Barzini's "The Italians" -- a best-seller in the United States in the original English version -- has virtually exhausted its first printing of 35,000 copies.

PARIS, Nov. 5 -- Opposition candidates and newspapers lashed out today at what they called the "arrogance" and "impudence" of President de Gaulle's statement last night that he would seek re-election. They accused him of having confused his own destiny with that of France and of having given the voters a "false choice between himself and the abyss."

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Nov. 5 -- Representatives of the parliament of 13 Latin American countries have called on nine foreign ministers gathered here for trade unification talks to postpone the conference of the Organization of American States scheduled to begin in Rio de Janiero Nov. 17.

An official recount of the close vote for Bronx Borough President was unexpectedly delayed yesterday and neither of the two leading candidates -- Herman Badillo and Joseph F. Periconi -- was willing to claim victory or accept defeat.

I read with interest your Nov. 1 news report that the Vatican Sacred Congregation of Rites has absolved the Jews of Trent for a murder which they were alleged to have committed in 1475. One cannot help feeling that the absolution would have been more timely if it had come before the Jews of Trent were tortured to death. But better late than never.

LUIS ESTEVEZ, known for his sexy but ladylike afternoon and evening clothes, showed his first California-made collection yesterday; Abe Schrader, a bread-and-butter house, presented virtually every style in the book, including a version of the smock, and Modern Couture had one halter neckline after another, usually with a floppy bow at the throat. Modern Couture, like Estevez, specializes in cocktail and evening dresses.
Williams Brothers, which rarely appears in the limelight of the most active list, made most of the news yesterday on the American Stock Exchange as the market advanced on strong volume.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today that the United States military effort to prevent a Communist victory in South Vietnam was "progressing well" but cautioned that some "severe fighting" lay ahead.
Directors of the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railroad voted yesterday to ask stockholders at a special meeting on Jan. 14 to split the common stock two-for-one.

As an African student (Congo-Brazzaville), I would like to raise my voice and express my disappointment at the lack of political realism manifested by the African leaders at their recent Accra meeting in their handling of the Rhodesian crisis.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Philip Elman, a member of the Federal Trade Commission, vigorously attacked today the belief that any action on the part of a manufacturer to influence the retail price of his product is illegal.

The Citizens Union, one of the oldest nonpartisan civic organizations dedicated to better government, keeps a close eye on the administrative, legislative and judicial branches and periodically comments on them. Particularly it informs the voters, through its invaluable Voters Directory, before they go to the polls.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 5 (AP) -- The State Court of Appeals said today that all pending criminal indictments returned by Maryland grand juries whose members had been required to affirm a belief in God were defective.
Bond prices continued to decline yesterday, and all major segments of the market ended the week at their lows of the year.
NEWARK, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Three North Jersey savings and loan companies were robbed of at least $8,400 within a period of 90 minutes today.

BEREVERLY HILLS, Calif., Nov. 5 -- A small, plain-looking restaurant called the Bistro emerged this week as the focal point of some lively social machinations. PARIS, Nov. 5 -- The liner France sailed from Southampton tonight, a day late. For a while it looked as if she might not leave at all as the French Line prepared to call off the voyage and a Caribbean cruise scheduled to start next Wednesday.

The British pound fell sharply in moderately heavy dealings on foreign exchange markets here.

W.W. Norton Co. is changing its basic contract with authors to give them a potentially larger share of income from paperback reprints than the 5050 division that is traditonal in the publishing industry.

The principal of a junior high school in Harlem has sent a report to his superiors describing two weeks of widespread disorder and violence by youths he suspects of membership in a Negro racist organization.
