WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The battle between the Government and the aluminum industry grew in intensity today as the two sides issued sharply differing versions of what happened in last week's negotiations over disposal of excess aluminum from the national stockpile.

The higher education aid bill that President Johnson signed yesterday will be hailed largely for the scholarships it will provide for talented needy college students. But important as such financial assistance is, the new law will make its real impact in more subtle ways.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- A challenge by a group of white parents in Supreme Court failed today to overturn the New York City Board of Education's efforts to reduce racial imbalance in two elementary schools in Queens.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- A "hard start" similar to the backfiring of an automobile engine was tentatively blamed today for the failure of the Agena rocket that cut short the Gemini 6 flight last month.

The most confused element in the war against poverty remains the extent to which the people of the slums should have a controlling voice in developing community action programs to end their own poverty.
HOLLYWOOD, Nov. 8 -- Britain's Princess Margaret and a platoon of Hollywood stars swarmed into the newly redecorated Palladium here tonight for the World Adoption International Fund Ball.

Everyone connected with Want A Cracker at Aqueduct yesterday knew what she had to do to win. Her trainer, H. Allen Jerkens, sent her postward in the fifth race with specific instructions to her jockey, Mike Venezia. Venezia listened to Jerkens, but Want A Cracker listened to no one.
CHICAGO, Nov. 8 -- Andrew Goodman, president of Bergdorf Goodman, will open his first branch store in Chicago.
J. Peter Grace, president of the widely diversified W.R. Grace Co., was elected yesterday as a director of the Magnavox Company.

THERE is this to say about Frank Lasky. He did not hide yesterday. He went to a fan club luncheon, took some ribbing, submitted to questioning and said he was sorry. It could not have been easy for him.
WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 8 -- A group of builders accused commuter towns today of becoming too strict about esthetics.
WASHINGTON, Now 8 -- Robert C. Weaver, the highest ranking Negro in the Federal Government, said today he would like to head the new Department of Housing and Urban Development.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Nov. 8 -- Apparently defying his own Government, Rhodesia's Chief Justice, Sir Hugh Beadle, flew to London tonight for talks with Prime Minister Wilson.

NEWARK, Nov. 8 -- "It was about 7 in the evening. I . . . went and tried the door. The lights were on, by the way. I went in. There were two desks and several filing cabinets. I opened every drawer. In the left-hand section of the [filing cabinet] drawer, there were about five pads [of warehouse receipts.] Knowing where the pads were, I then left."

Three statues by Aristide Maillol have been acquired by the Metropolitan Opera for placement in the foyers of its new home in Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts. The opera house is scheduled to open next fall.
Reversing Friday's pattern, issues on the American Stock Exchange retreated yesterday on a broad front in active trading.

Hotel and motel guests are due for some pleasant surprises in the near future. The industry is undergoing dramatic changes that will have a startling effect on both its appearance as well as the services provided to guests.
A Canadian-American team is developing a satellite-launching system based on two 16-inch guns welded end to end that it believes can place a 50-pound vehicle in orbit.
Deputy Chief Inspector John Wynne, who is married to a policewoman and who has four children on the force, was promoted yesterday to the rank of assistant chief inspector.

" O.K. Crackerby!" the situation comedy starring Burl Ives, will be discontinued Jan. 6 by the American Broadcasting Company television network. Filming of the show was halted Friday in Hollywood after 17 half-hour episodes had been completed.
WASHINGTON. Nov. 8 -- The Supreme Court ventured farther into the troubled area of obscenity today by agreeing to decide whether the novel "Fanny Hill" is obscene.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UPI) -- A panel of heart specialists recommended today that airline and other commercial pilots be given tougher physical examinations.

Events today: Verdi's "Il Trovatore," 8 P.M. Metropolitan Opera; Puccini's "Madama Butterfly," Metropolitan Opera National Company. 8:15, New York State Theater, Lincoln Center; Hyman Bress, violinist, 8:30, Philharmonic Hall; National Orchestral Association, all-Sibelius program, 8:30, Carnegie Hall; Evening for New Music, directed by Lukas Foss, 8:30, Carnegie Recital Hall.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Yields on the new issue of 91-day Treasury bills declined from the recent record level of last week while those on the 182-day bills remained almost unchanged at a five-year high.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Pressure is building here for enactment next year of a personal security law for Negroes and civil rights workers and for Federally imposed court reforms in the South.
The bond market inched downward again yesterday as dealers waited anxiously to see how this week's big volume of new corporate bonds would sell.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Frank Chapot was presented the President of the United States Cup by Vice President Hubert Humphrey at the Washington International Horse Show tonight.

CORNELL appeared to be a 7-3 victor over Dartmouth on Nov. 16, 1940, when the Big Red scored with seconds remaining in the game. A day later, films proved that the "winning" pass was thrown on what was a fifth-down play.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 8 -- A. resolution calling for a treaty to stop the spread of nuclear weapons was approved without opposition today by the General Assembly's Political Committee.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 8 -- Portugal urged the Security Council today to investigate "the vast network of foreign interests" seeking the overthrow of Portuguese rule in her African territories of Angola and Mozambique.

SPORTS humor, like most humor, stems from someone's embarrassment. Most of the bright remarks and repeatable anecdotes involve some failure, accident or inadequacy. The jokes that receive widest circulation, therefore, can be put into two categories: self-deprecation and other directed ridicule.
Governor Rockefeller yesterday ordered the erection of temporary, pre-fabricated buildings to relieve overcrowding at the Willowbrook State School for Mental Defectives.
LONDON, Nov. 8 -- With Rhodesia creeping toward independence, the Bank of England faces a dilemma over possible sanctions that could compromise its position as banker to the sterling area.

THOSE who have been wistfully longing for a large Motherwell to hang on their whitewashed walls need not hock the family stainless steel to get it. That is, if they are willing to settle for a reproduction in startlingly vivid color, silk-screened on a special kind of textured paper that is said to permit great clarity and depth of hue.
The American Safety Razor Company, a subsidiary of Philip Morris, Inc., announced yesterday the appointment of Harold Thorkilsen as president.
The jam session, a seemingly dying institution that once flourished in the small, dark hours of the morning, is swinging vigorously back to life on Mondays at noon in an East Side restaurant.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Nov. 8 -- The Harkness Ballet completed its first United States tour tonight at Proctor's Theater.
SAN MARCOS, Tex., Nov. 8 -- President Johnson returned today to the college from which he graduated 35 years ago and signed the pioneering higher education bill.
I see no report in The Times of Nov. 2 of Ambassador Averell Harriman's reiteration of our sterile blockade of seating Communist China in the U.N.

MANILA, Nov. 8 -- President Diosdado Macapagal, winding up a closely fought election campaign, tonight criticized his chief opponent, Ferdinand E. Marcos, President of the Senate, and promised to perform as a "nonpolitical" chief executive if elected to his second and final four-year term.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 8 -- The great debate over Communist China's admission to the United Nations opened explosively today in the General Assembly with spokesmen for the East and West emphasizing that the future of the world organization hangs upon the outcome.
Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay intends to appoint at least five, and perhaps seven, panels of experts to try to devise solutions for the city's major problems.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
The five pacifists who burned their draft cards in Union Square last Saturday were questioned yesterday by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. No arrests were made, however.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Vice President Humphrey said today that the way to deal with communities that shun the antipoverty program was to "let the people know who are standing in their way."
A Federal antipoverty official said yesterday that the financial troubles of Haryou-Act had been caused by the agency's "headlong" dash into its summer programs to fight poverty and delinquency.

Clarence Campbell, the president of the National Hockey League, and William M. Jennings, the president of the New York Rangers, were named yesterday to head a six-man committee to select the first winner of the Lester Patrick Memorial Award.
MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 8 -- Of the 370 prospective jurors expected to report for duty today at the County and District Courts exactly one showed up.
LAST week this writer had the distinct pleasure of enjoying a meal of mallard ducks prepared by Kelsor Smith, the chef at Remington Farms, a game management demonstration project in Maryland.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., Nov. 8 -- The United Synagogue of America, which represents 800 Conservative Jewish congregations in this country and Canada, today unanimously elected Henry N. Rapaport of Temple Israel in White Plains, as its president for the next two years.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- U. Alexis Johnson, Deputy Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, today was named winner of the $10,000 Rockfeller Public Service Award of 1965 for foreign affairs.

The Rev. W.L. Damian Pitcaithly's clinic for narcotics addicts -- which was driven from the rectory of his church in Queens by threats to the congregation, barred from two proposed locations in Astoria by outraged neighbors, and harassed by screaming, stone-throwing pickets in Corona -- has apparently thrived on adversity.

I note with interest in a news article in your Nov. 4 issue assessing the sources of John Lindsay's votes that the Liberal party, in an official statement, claims as an indication of its strength the entire Liberal-Independent (Row C) vote, and even notes the increase in Liberal votes (80,000 plus) over the last Mayoral election.

A year after his decisive defeat as the 1964 Republican Presidential candidate, Barry Goldwater says that if he had it to do over again he would probably have deferred to someone else on the nomination.

LONDON, Nov. 8 (Reuters) A laughing Queen, resplendent in a diamond and sapphire tiara, necklace and earrings, stole the spotlight at the royal command variety showy in the Palladium Music Hall tonight.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 8 -- For the second time in 10 days, American planes bombed a friendly South Vietnamese village by mistake yesterday.

Looming problems in the midst of record economic prosperity are the focus of attention in the latest surveys of business conditions by two of the nation's leading Federal Reserve Banks. By coincidence, no doubt, both reports were issued yesterday.
Secretary of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler warned American businessmen last night to avoid "hasty and ill-considered" price increases because of the danger of inflation.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Kenya protested today to the State Department over the alleged beating of a native student by Nashville policemen Oct. 31.

The new 46,000-ton Italian liner Raffaello will be out of service for a month for repairs of engine room damage that forced the liner to abandon a westbound crossing in mid-Atlantic last week, it was announced here yesterday by the Italian Line.

The Western Union Telegraph Company reported yesterday total revenues of $228,274,962 for the nine months ended Sept. 30. The addition of $1.7 million in miscellaneous income raised total revenues and other income to $230,018,607.

Last night's crash was the second involving the Boeing 727 model, which has been in service since February, 1964. One hundred and ninety-one of the craft are now in use with 16 airlines, and 428 more are on order by 26 airlines.
MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 8 (UPI) -- Lee Assenheimer set a course record today in leading Northwestern to the Big Ten cross-country championship.

LISBON, Nov. 8 -- The Portuguese Government, despite its clear sympathies for the white Rhodesian cause, remains officially noncommital as to its future actions should Rhodesia declare its independence.

ALBANY, Nov. 8 -- Within the next 10 days more than 6 million New York motorists will receive applications for their 1966-1972 license plates, which will have new colors. The state Motor Vehicles Department announced that the mailings began last week.

PEC, Yugoslavia -- His calling card lists him as a school administrator and he wears a business suit most days, but Rame Nicki's title dates back more than 300 colorful and bloody years. He is the sword-bearing vojvod (chieftain) of the Pec Patriarchate.

The controversial flagstick rule in golf will be changed for 1966 and two other measures will be introduced for faster play on the greens. The United States Golf Association said yesterday the three regulations would go into effect on Jan. 1.

The commander of the Manhattan detective squad that investigated the murder of Janice Wylie and Emily Hoffert testified yesterday that he had "never believed" that George Whitmore Jr. had slain the girls.
John V. Lindsay is wrestling long hours every day with the problem of how a maverick Republican can conduct a nonpartisan administration with much of the city's machinery in Democratic hands.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- Leaders in Government and industry sought today to allay fears that automation would bring more problems than benefits in the long run to Britain.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 8 (UPI) -- The Rockwell-Standard Corporation announced today that it would sponsor a round-the-world polar flight, crossing the North and South Poles, later this month.
Three fundamentals take priority in the city transit "emergency" shaping up at the end of the year.

For copper, there is seldom a dull moment on the international front. The Rhodesian crisis, first hot, then cold; the off-and-on Chilean copper workers' strike; the price increases by some leading producers -- all have served to push prices to new high levels.
WHEN Bettina Gates took over a gypsy fortune teller's 8-by-15-foot room with a view of the future, she got the space but no forecast of what would happen to her own business -- pleated lamp shades.
ARLINGTON, Va., Nov. 8 -- Indiscriminate borrowing and lending of mascara pencils has led to at least one epidemic of a severe eye infection, an eye specialist said here today.

AT some future time the United States may find itself opposed to New Zealand in a world championship match. The representatives of these distant islands compete in the Far East Championships, whose winners are now eligible to play in the annual Bermuda Bowl contests.

LAUREL, Md., Nov. 8 (AP) -- A large number of early horse-racing fans marveled this morning at a small, insignificant-looking horse who is expected to win one of thoroughbred racing's great prizes on Thursday.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Nov. 8 -- Nine pounds of explosives, apparently laid by Arab terrorists, was discovered today by an Israeli border patrol under the main railroad line leading to Jerusalem.

" You better wait until you hear me before you use the word 'sing,'", Lillian Gish said yesterday. She confirmed a report that she will be heard in song on Broadway for the first time in her career. As the dowager empress of Russia in "Anya," the musical version of the play "Anastasia," opening here Nov. 29, Miss Gish will sing a special number, "Little Hands."
Businessmen and bankers across the nation gave their moral backing yesterday to aluminum producers who are jousting with the Johnson Administration over aluminum price increases.
The British pound dropped slightly in slow trading on foreign-exchange markets here yesterday. Its closing quotation was $2.08030, down 2 points from the level on Friday.
The curtain is about to go up again on Show magazine.

Talks have been held on the possibility of a merger of the Coca-Cola Company with the National Biscuit Company, officials of both companies confirmed yesterday. But the executives were quick to point out that the talks were preliminary, adding that no definite offers were made on either side.

VIEWERS, spare those sets! National Educational Television and its local affiliate, WNDT, once again combined last night to keep civilization on the home screen. There was a 90-minute representation on Channel 13 of the current triumph of Martha Graham's dance season at the 54th Street Theater.
GENEVA, Nov. 8 -- A United Nations agency opened a study here today into the best ways of using shipping to further the trade of newly developing countries.
Herman Badillo was declared elected Borough President of the Bronx by 2,086 votes last night -- 198,499 to 196,413 -- in what the Board of Elections said was the official post-election canvass.

Previous indications that the post-Khrushchev regime in Moscow has finally decided it cannot appease Peking have been powerfully strengthened by Dmitry S. Polyansky's speech marking the Bolshevik Revolution's 48th anniversary.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Nov. 9 -- Paratroops of the United States 173d Airborne Brigade and the First Australian Infantry Battalion inflicted major losses on Vietcong guerrillas in a day-long battle yesterday on the southern edge of the Vietcong stronghold in Zone D, 30 miles north of Saigon, a millitary spokesman said today.

Bernard Kessler, the lawyer for Mrs. Addabbo and the other Queens parents, said yesterday that he might appeal to Dr. James E. Allen Jr., the State Education Commissioner, or start a new action in Federal court in an effort to upset the city school system's pairing. program.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 8 -- An American Airlines jet flying here from New York crashed into a wooded hillside tonight. Fifty-eight of the 62 persons aboard were feared killed.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 8 -- The new moderate Iraqi Cabinet will re-establish free enterprise, reconsider the Socialist system applied last year, and follow a different approach to the Kurdish problem, according to a policy statement broadcast yesterday by the Baghdad radio.

For anyone wondering at the reputation the Marlboro Music Festival enjoys, a visit to Town Hall would have been in order last night. The festival, an annual summer-long event in Marlboro, Vt., has attracted the best of this country's young musicians for the past 15 years.

OUT of Bulgaria has come Nicolai Ghiaurov. He is a basso, 36 years old, has been receiving the kind of adulation all over the world normally reserved for sopranos and tenors, and last night he made his debut at the Metropolitan Opera.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Nov. 8 -- Stephen G. Doig Jr., Democrat and Liberal, won the Assembly contest in the new 104th district in Rockland County by 78 votes, defeating Joseph F.X. Nowicki, Republican, by 19,800 to 19,722.

T. Rieber, chairman of the Barber Oil Corporation, announced yesterday that suits which certain stockholders of Texas Gulf Sulphur Corporation filed against Texas Gulf, its directors and some large stockholders, including Barber, have been dismissed insofar as Barber Oil was concerned.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Nov. 8 -- President Hector Garcia-Godoy started talks with party leaders today for a political trace prior to the general elections scheduled for June.

NOTTINGHAM, England, Nov. 8 (UPI) -- Johnny Pritchett won the British middleweight title tonight when he scored a 12th-round technical knockout over Wally Swift. Swift's left eye was so badly cut that Referee Harry Gibbs had to stop the scheduled 15-round bout.

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 8 -- Because food surpluses are dwindling, Herschel D. Newsom told the annual convention of the National Grange today, the United States should set aside stocks of grain for an emergency reserve.

" Man in Metropolis," by Louis B. Schlivek, which Doubleday will publish on Nov. 19, is a photo-story about New York City. Mr. Schlivek is primarily a still photographer and documentary film maker. This book grows out of an attempt to translate into popular terms the New York Metropolitan Region Study, organized by Harvard University.

It wasn't enough that the Beatles became members of the Order of the British Empire. Now their songs have given birth to four elaborate serious compositions, all in baroque style, no less. They may all be heard on a record, "The Baroque Beatles Book," scheduled for release next week.
OTTAWA, Tuesday, Nov. 9 -- Canada was headed this morning for a continuation of minority government.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The Pentagon. in a swift precautionary move, checked major military installations throughout the country during the Northeast power blackout and found them operational.
The Wagner administration moved yesterday to protect by law the right of city employes to organize and bargain collectively on wages and working conditions.
Bridge systems, like languages continue to grow. New bidding devices, or words, are added or abandoned. Slight stylistic variations, or spellings, creep in as time goes on.

In an unusual business arrangement, the International Business Machines Corporation announced yesterday that it had obtained a license from Dun Bradstreet, Inc. International Business Machines will market D. B.'s business information.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Nov. 9 -- Premier Levi Eshkol's coalition government received a slim majority in the new Knesset (parliament) as a result of last Tuesday's general election. The final results were announced tonight.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 9 -- Over strenuous objections by defense counsel, Federal District Judge Robert Van Pelt admitted in evidence today two signed confessions by Duane Earl Pope that he killed three persons while robbing a bank in Big Springs, Neb., last June.

" Testaments of Time," by Leo Deuel, which Knopt will publish on Monday, deals with what the author calls the "archaeology of books." It tells about the search for lost books, authors and records of early civilizations.

Just over two and a half years ago -- in June, 1963 -- the Consolidated Edison Company announced that chances of a major power failure like the one that had blacked out much of Manhattan two years earlier were miniscule.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Robert Kennedy has passed his first test as a Senator from New York, and has gone off to Latin America, where he will stay in the headlines and celebrate his 40th birthday.
More than $200 million of corporate bonds were placed on the market yesterday, and most of them sold out quickly.
AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 9 -- President Johnson ordered today an immediate and complete investigation of the power failure that blacked out a large section of the East.
TOKYO, Nov. 9 (AP) -- A Foreign Ministry spokesman, Akira Sono, said today that the majority of the Japanese people opposed the war in Vietnam but that this did not mean they were anti-American.
A competitive sale of $50 million of Canadian debentures was postponed abruptly here yesterday for balance-of-payments reasons.
MAYOR-ELECT John V. Lindsay, the Democratic Controller-elect and the City Council President-elect got together for the first time yesterday to the accompaniment of smiles, quips and unity.
SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 9 (UPI) -- Arthur Ashe, the United States tennis ace, said today he would enter military service next June.
A Brooklyn grand jury has sharply criticized a Federal narcotics agent and a city policeman in connection with charges that they used a former convict in efforts to shake down a Mafia figure.

New Yorkers learned something about themselves yesterday that they probably never suspected: Under stress, and in the face of the unknown, they proved, generally, to be courteous, friendly and considerate.

The Commercial Credit Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday a consolidated net income from operations of $25,036,462 for the first nine months this year. This is equal to $2.38 a share on 10,680,333 common shares outstanding and compares with $24,796,046, or $2.20 a share, earned in the corresponding period last year.
BIENHOA, South Vietnam, Nov. 9 -- The toll of almost, 400 Vietcong killed in a battle 30 miles northeast of Saigon yesterday marked a decisive victory for troops of the US 173d Airborne Brigade.

LAUREL, Md., Nov. 9 -- Although the international aspect of the $150,000 Washington, D.C. International race on Thursday is not so broad as he would like to have it, John D. Schapiro, the president of Laurel Race Track, is confident that the event will continue to be one of the top thoroughbred attractions of the world.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 (UPI) -- If the use of agricultural chemicals in the United States were banned tomorrow, the nation's surplus food stocks would soon disappear, an entomologist told an international gathering of nutrition expert today.

Short of a nuclear bomb, the most crippling affliction that can befall a modern metropolis is a total power failure. The blackout that crippled New York and most of the Northeast last evening was a dismaying reminder of the vulnerability of any community to a severing of its electric lifeline.

The International Paper Company realized a 24 per cent increase in third-quarter earnings on a sales gain of 6 per cent, Richard C. Doane, chairman, and Lamar M. Fearing, president, reported yesterday.

Braulio Baeza, the Panamanian exponent of riding and guiding thoroughbreds to victory with much more than average consistency reached a milestone at Aqueduct yesterday before 21,577 chilled patrons.

London, Nov. 9 -- The Socialist Government laid out today a program for the next year containing almost no hint of socialism. Many saw it as a move to broaden the Labor party's political appeal in preparation for an early election.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The Government increased today from 200,000 tons to 300,000 tons the amount of aluminum it plans to release from Government surplus stocks.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 9 -- Leo Margolian, the general manager of the three-mile Stardust International Raceway, which will run its first sports car major event here on Sunday, is a newcomer to the sport who talks and acts like an old man.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Nov. 9 (REUTERS) -- Prince Sihanouk, a frequent critic of the United States and the West, attacked Cambodian Communists today, calling them the valets of North Vietnam.

" Sir Gawain and the Green Knight." a poem cloaked in magic and dread, was written by a brilliant but anonymous contemporary of Chaucer. A planned price increase in an aluminum product was rescinded yesterday in the face of industry reluctance to make the rise general.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 9 -- The volume of African-Asian support for Communist China's admission to the United Nations developed significantly today, the second day of the debate on the most divisive issue yet to face the 20th session of the General Assembly.

CAPE KENNEDY. Fla., Nov. 9 (UPI) -- Space agency officials announced today that Gemini 7 and Gemini 6 spacecraft would be launched on their rendezvous mission early next month.
Directors of Cunningham Drug Stores, Inc., proposed yesterday in Detroit a two-for-one split of the common stock. Plans for a possible dividend increase on the split shares also were announced.

The "common goals" for a better city on which New York's newly elected Mayor, Controller and City Council President agree not in themselves extraordinary. They are, in fact, so fundamental to success of a new administration that it would have been strange if agreement on them were lacking.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities ended today for the time being its investigation of the Ku Klux Klan.
ROME, Nov. 9 -- The Roman Catholic hierarchy was asked to consider a revamping of the system of indulgences.

WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 10 -Armbro Flight, the only filly in the one-mile race, had the speed and Joe O'Brien, her capable driver, had the savvy. They collaborated handsomely and the result was an easy victory in the Dexter Cup trot at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -The new Department of Housing and Urban Development, in being "in name only" because President Johnson has delayed its organization until January, was publicly without even a name today.

One crewman was killed and two others injured yesterday when an explosion ripped through the bow section of an empty Liberian tanker at a Bayonne pier.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- A member of the Federal Reserve Board said today the idea of widening the limits within which currency exchange rates may fluctuate should be "studied." The board member, Sherman J. Maisel, said that from the United States point of view this could be done only "by lowering the purchase price of gold, since we have a firm national commitment to maintain the selling price at $35 an ounce."
The chancellor of the City University said yesterday that he would present to the Board of Higher Education at its meeting on Nov. 22 a proposal to charge tuition in the city's colleges.

A high mass of requiem will be sung tomorrow for Roger A. LaPorte, the 22-year-old pacifist who set fire to himself in front of the United Nations on Tuesday. The funeral service will be in his home town, Tupper Lake, N.Y., and will be celebrated at 9 A.M. in St. Alphonsus Roman Catholic Church by the pastor, Msgr. Paul G. Brunet.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 11 (Reuters) -- Indonesia's Defense Minister, Gen. Abdul Haris Nasution, today called for united leadership between President Sukarno and the armed forces following the abortive coup of Oct. 1.
SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 11 -- Premier Nguyen Cao Ky of South Vietnam said here today that he would never sit down at a negotiating table with the Communist aggressors.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 11 -- Mexico has begun an intensive diplomatic effort to win support for the establishment of an inter-American emergency fund to help the reconstruction of any Latin-American country hit by natural disaster or civil strife.
WHEN William Alfred brings his new play, "Hogan's Goat," to fruition, he does so with shapeliness, clarity and glowing power.
City College treated itself and its coach to a sixth consecutive City University of New York cross-country championship yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx.

WILLIE MAYS, a right-handed outfielder who plays for the San Francisco Giants, has been named the National League's Most Valuable Player for 1965 by the Baseball Writers Association of America, which has been making such awards for 35 years.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Nov. 11 -- The Government of Rhodesia declared its independence from Britain today.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Nov. 11 -- Communist China's sudden reappearance as a buyer in the Singapore rubber market has brought a sharp rise in prices here in the expectation that Ceylonese rubber will also benefit from increased buying.

The first report on new car sales for early November indicates that the record sales boom, in effect for most of the year, is continuing. The Ford Motor Company reported yesterday that its Ford division had record passenger car and truck sales in the Nov. 1-10 period.

GENOA, Italy, Nov. 11 (AP) An engine-room thermometer the size of a thumb figured in the mid-Atlantic fire of Oct. 31 that forced the 46,000-ton liner Raffaello to return to Genoa, the head of an inquiry commission said last night.
BONN, Nov. 11 -- United States Army headquarters in Heidelberg confirmed today that Sgt. Glen R. Rohrer, a specialist in Slavic languages, had been missing since Aug. 16 and was listed as a deserter.

The Oct. 27 ukase of President Castelo Branco, who was confronted by the results of the Oct. 3 elections, grants him dictatorial powers and reduces Congress and the Supreme Court to puppet institutions under his sway. [Editorial Oct. 28.]
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 11 -- The General Assembly adopted a resolution tonight calling on Britain to take all necessary steps to end the rebellion by Rhodesia's white minority Government.

LONDON, Nov. 11 -- A burly, phlegmatic former truck driver insisted yesterday that only charitable thoughts for old-age pensioners had prompted him to take the celebrated Goya painting of the Duke of Wellington from the National Gallery four years ago.
CHICAGO -- Chicagoans are in a constant dither about housing. But while New Yorkers bitterly criticize the rising cost and declining pleasure of urban living, the accent here is on the positive.
Most New Yorkers were surprised to learn when the power failed across a wide area Tuesday night that the electricity they "burn" may come from Boston or Niagara Falls, or even as far away as Detroit.

LONDON, Nov. 11 -- The British Government, denouncing Rhodesia's unilateral declaration of independence as rebellion and treason, today took the first counter-measures. Rhodesia was expelled from the sterling area. Her preferential tariff treatment as a Commonwealth land was suspended.

ROME, Nov. 11 -- Roman Catholic prelates approved a draft today calling for "brotherly cooperation" among missionaries of different Christian denominations to end "the scandal of division" offered to non-Christian eyes.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- One of the Senate's most important committees will have a new chairman next year as a result of Senator Harry F. Byrd's retirement from Congress.

" An Evening With the Royal Ballet," a color feature film of performances by Rudolph Nureyev, Margot Fonteyn and the Royal Opera House ballet company, will have a two-day engagement Dec. 8 and 9 at over 50 theaters in New York and New Jersey.
Lawyers will debate today whether pages of advertising in Dr. Benjamin Spock's perennial best-seller, "Baby and Child Care," violate the public interest.
The Stuyvesant-Fish House at 21 Stuyvesant Street, which was officially designated as a city landmark a month ago, has been placed on the market for $140,000.

No news was viewed as good news in the potato futures market yesterday. Prices surged higher following a Department of Agriculture report that indicated little change in its previous estimate of a bumper supply of potatoes in the current crop year, largely November through May.

GAME wardens, or conservation officers as they are called in the new-image vernacular, may sometimes appear to be cold-eyed men who appear magically out of the bushes to chide a culprit for catching one trout too many.
AACHEN, West Germany, Nov. 10 -- A play about the assassination of President Kennedy, called "Dallas -- November 22d," Opened at the tiny Borderland Theater here last week.
The preview, now a Broadway commonplace, has created a new type of theatergoer: one who wants to be a critic on his own and save money at the same time.
MEXICO CITY, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Billy Maxwell of Dallas shot a two-under-par 70 today and shared the first-round lead in the Mexican open golf tournament with two young Americans and a pair of Mexicans.

HAVANA, Nov. 11 -- Premier Fidel Castro, in a gesture aimed at reaffirming the mystique of his revolution, is climbing Cuba's second highest mountain along with 400 medical students, several Cabinet Ministers and the wife of Ernesto Che Guevara.
Commissioner Ford Frick will undergo questioning today in connection with Milwaukee County's baseball antitrust suit against the Braves, the National League and nine other league teams.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- The United States prepared today to join with Britain in a campaign of economic warfare against the all-white Rhodesian Government.
CHICAGO, Nov 13 -- A gift of $10 million for construction of a new library at the University of Chicago has been made by the Joseph and Helen Regenstein Foundation of Chicago.
The nation's aluminum stockpile, which the Administration brandished as a weapon in the "aluminum war," is stored at 152 sites throughout the country.

Financial advisers to Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay expressed concern privately yesterday as early analysis confirmed that, with a half-billion-dollar deficit in prospect, less than a tenth of the city's spending could be curtailed to any material degree.

A STEP-UP in entertaining for the holiday season will bring the golden glow of many more candles to tables and interiors, Georg Jensen believes. In anticipation, the store will open a special shop Monday with 350 designs in American and imported candleholders and a large selection of tapers.

THE venerable New York Yacht Club finally got around to giving a prize for competition afloat to a woman last night. It happened in the West 44th Street clubhouse and the recipient was Mrs. Caryl H. Sayre, one of the club's few women members.
Bankers and business leaders across the nation criticized yesterday the methods used by the Johnson Administration in achieving the rollback of aluminum price increases.
MALVERNE, L.I., Nov. 11 -- The Malverne School District, which has been beset by controversy in the last few years over integration of the schools, now has a Negro as a member of the school board.

Ian Douglas Smith, the 46-year-old farmer-turned-politician who yesterday proclaimed Rhodesia's independence, is regarded by his supporters as a man of unshakable determination and by his critics as a zealot leading his country to disaster.
A brief word, if I may, about the recent election here in New York City, and about a trend that is now common in all our elections.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The United States won the team title after a double shootoff and a German marksman from Munich fired a perfect 100 today in the first day's competition of the world skeet shooting championships.
KEY WEST, Fla., Nov. 12 (UPI) -- The Coast Guard announced today that an 85-foot sightseeing vessel with a capacity of 150 passengers had been selected to ferry refugees out of Cuba.

PAGE, Ariz., Nov. 12 -Princess Margaret was introduced to motel life here today after a flying trip that took her sightseeing over the Grand Canyon. She and her husband, the Earl of Snowdon, arrived here late this afternoon.
Shoplifting was described yesterday as the No. 1 problem facing college bookstores throughout the country.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Nov. 12 (AP) -- A circuit court judge dismissed today an indictment charging Theodore J. Isaacs, former Illinois Revenue Director, with conflict of interest, collusion and conspiracy.

A white parent attempting to block the integration program of the Malverne, L.I., school board, filed a civil action yesterday in Federal Court. Brooklyn, asserting the plan violated both the Constitution and the Civil Rights Act of 1964.
HAVANA, Nov. 12 -- A young woman member of the British Embassy staff was fired on by members of Premier Fidel Castro's bodyguard while driving home from work at night early last week.

RIVERSIDE, Calif., Nov. 12 -- The liquid in the test tube was a brilliant green, a standard reagent. What caught the attention of an investigator in the Riverside County Health Department laboratory a few days ago was an almost imperceptible layer of bubbles on the liquid's surface.

Not long ago the head of the house sat daydreaming. Having declined an invitation to help with the dinner dishes, he found a comfortable chair for himself and a comfortable coffee table for his feet, and drifted into a set of adventures all having the same likable hero.

John Adams and Bayside, Queens' high schools football failures of last year, meet today at Woodrow Wilson Field in Jamaica, Queens, to determine the Public School Athletic League's Division I champion.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Nov. 12 (AP) -- One of three Chinese Communist airmen who defected to Nationalist China died today of brain injuries suffered when their twin-jet Il-28 bomber crashed on landing, the Air Force announced.
The Sanitation Department is pressing for the right to put $15 tickets on illegally parked vehicles that are in the way of its mechanical street sweepers, an authority now restricted to policemen.

Ford Frick said yesterday that Milwaukee should be given serious consideration in major league baseball's next expansion move, but defended a club owner's right to shift a franchise "where it appears a city will not support big league baseball."
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 12 -- Foreign Minister Subandrio disclosed today that there had been a brief break in Indonesia's trade relations with Communist China.
LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 12 -As a college senior, Duane Pope took a criminology course that explored insanity as a defense against criminal charges.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 12 -- United States troops fought a daylong battle today against Vietcong guerrillas 40 miles north of Saigon.

MOSCOW, Nov. 12 -- Soviet sportsmen were said today to have found difficulty in prolonged exertion under atmospheric conditions similar to those they will encounter at the Mexico City Olympics next year.

A Beatrice Lillie painting, "Urn With Flowers," priced at $3,000, and a Sid Caesar abstract oil, tagged at $350, are among 315 works of art from the collections of entertainment stars at Philharmonic Hall.
A 50-foot-long aluminum submarine has dived to a record depth of nearly one and a quarter miles, J. Louis Reynolds, chairman of Reynolds International, Inc., reported yesterday.

We find scant merit in the proposal by Dr. Albert H. Bowker, chancellor of the City University, that all students at its constituent colleges pay a fictitious tuition charge as a means of qualifying the municipal university for large additional sums of state money. The issue transcends the always emotional debate over any suggested abandonment, whether real or apparent, of free undergraduate tuition in the city's colleges.
A Chicago Bank, operating in the New York money market, has breached the Federal Reserve Board interest ceiling on time deposits through the use of promissory notes.

No one would have thought some years back that Premier Fidel Castro's revolution in Cuba would cause a ripple in Seventh Avenue. But the expropriation of industry in Cuba has had its effect in the textile distributing industry in an odd way.

THE fashions women will be wearing Easter Sunday on Fifth Avenue and Main Streets to the north, south and west have been pretty well charted as Seventh Avenue completed its second week of spring showings yesterday.
Stock prices moved forward yesterday and finished smartly higher in active trading.

BONN, Nov. 12 -- Although the Social Democratic party has not yet decided why it lost the September election, it has agreed on one basic new policy: it is the duty of the opposition party in the Bundestag to oppose.
THOMAS WATSON preferred to have the elevator shaft pure and glistening white, as might befit the elegant home of a business leader.

EASTON, Pa., Nov. 12 -- Bernie Bradley, a linebacker, intercepted a pass with 14 seconds remaining and ran 4 yards for a touchdown tonight to give Thomas Jefferson High School of Brooklyn a 13-7 triumph over Easton before 4,000 fans.
MANILA, Nov. 12 -- Senator Ferdinand Edralin Marcos, the apparent winner of the Philippines Presidency, was "No. 1" to his countrymen long before they voted him into the highest Government office.
Your Oct. 27 news article on alleged sick-leave abuse and moonlighting by postal employes requires a reply on behalf of the 580,000 dedicated workers.
Ludicrous as it may seem, an announcement that the Police Department has begun to enforce the parking laws -- or some of the parking laws -- was front page news the other day.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 12 -- Maryland, where thoroughbred horse racing and breeding has flourished for more than 200 years, will offer the richest race in its history with the running of the Pimlico Futurity tomorrow.

BONNEVILLE SALT FLATS, Utah, Nov. 12 (UPI) -- Bobby Summers drove the four-engined Goldenrod to a record for wheel-driven cars today by streaking across the salt flats at a two-way average speed of 409.227 miles an hour.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Retail sales dropped 5 per cent from the preceding week's level in the week ended Nov. 6 but were 12 per cent higher than totals in last year's period, the Commerce Department reported today.

Casey Stengel's disembodied voice sounded as cheerful and stubborn as ever in the manager's office alongside the Mets' dressing room in Shea Stadium yesterday. Stengel himself had not set foot in the room that used to be his since his farewell to the troops on Sept. 2, but the modern miracle of "conference call" telephone made his latest news conference seem familiar rather than ghostly.

MOSCOW, Nov. 12 -- The Soviet Union launched a 2,123-pound space craft early this morning on a three-and-a-half month journey toward Venus in an apparent bid to match or surpass the successful United States probe of the planet in 1962.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 12 -- Seventy-five Princeton students carried signs such as "Uhuru Now" and "Kill Yale and Ian Smith" in a one-hour demonstration today protesting Rhodesia's unilateral declaration of independence from Britain.
MEXICO CITY, Nov. 12 (UPI) -- A converted war-surplus B-26 bomber carrying seven persons crashed today after take-off from the Mexico City Airport, killing three persons.
LUSAKA, Zambia, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Zambian troops were moving to the Zambesi River border with Rhodesia today, a Government spokesman announced.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Nov. 12 -- The Governor of Rhodesia, Sir Humphrey Gibbs, was divested tonight of all executive powers by an order of Prime Minister Ian D. Smith.
Eighty years ago Trinity College and Wesleyan University played their first intercollegiate football game. This afternoon on Trinity Field in Hartford, Conn., the teams will meet for the 65th time.

As New York continued to grapple with its water problem and announced another drop of 917 million gallons in its reservoirs, the Mayor of Stamford, Conn., invoked a recently passed city ordinance and declared an emergency.

While controversy continued over a proposal to charge tuition at the City University, the Board of Higher Education made public yesterday a preliminary operating budget that calls for record expenditures next year.
The American Stock Exchange ended the week with an advance along a broad front yesterday in very active trading.
The spoilage at hospital blood banks during the blackout was kept to a minimum by the cool weather and the cooperation of hospitals and local communities.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Nov. 12 (AP) -- Mrs. Marlene Bauer Hagge, who said par golf would win the Alamo women's golf tournament, shot a 71 in the opening round today and gained the lead.
ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 12 -- The Soviet Union signed a protocol with Turkey today offering to undertake seven economic development projects under a prospective credit of $200 million.

One of the year's most profitable purchases, Paul Falkenstein's Bold Bidder, faces another chance to add to his owner's rapidly growing bankroll today when he faces five rival 3-year-olds in the $50,000 added Roamer Handicap at Aqueduct.
The Taft Broadcasting Company, closely identified with the more conventional means of mass communications, is seeking to give a colorful twist to its product mix.
BRECKINRIDGE, Ky., Nov. 12 (UPI) -- Deputy Director James R. Fornear was named today acting director of the troubled Breckinridge Job Corps Center, succeeding James W. Hughes.
TOMS RIVER, N.J., Nov. 12 (AP) -- Long dresses were in, in granny's day but they are definitely out today in Toms River -- at least for the moment.

RICHMOND, Nov. 12 -- Harry F. Bird Jr., 50-year-old son of former Senator Harry Flood Byrd of Virginia, was appointed today to succeed his ailing father in the United States Senate. The elder Byrd resigned yesterday.

FOR years it has been easy to characterize the National Antiques Show at Madison Square Garden as "junky" and its contents as "attic leavings." But those who indulge in such dismissal remain haunted by the really worthwhile exhibits the show offers, and -- no question about it -- the finds that can be made.
The British pound weakened slightly in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. The closing quotation was $2.8036, down 6 points from Thursday.
LAS VEGAS, Nov. 12 -- Jim Hall of Midland, Tex., won a hotly contested battle for qualifying honors today as 50 cars raced for positions in the 195-mile Grand Prix to be run here on Sunday.

It is a sad characteristic of our chaotic times that excessive shock has dulled the moral sensibilities of most of us. Thus the repeated news of blatant racially inspired injustice in Southern courts fails to stir anything like the degree of outrage and search for reform which it ought to in a civilized community.
SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Six United States men and the only American girl in the New South Wales tennis tournament advanced to the second round today without the loss of a set.

A minor population explosion of elephants, monkeys, and false vampire bats has given the Bronx Zoo what Joseph A. Davis, Jr., curator of mammals, calls "its most productive birth and acquisition month in a long time."
MIAMI, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Luis Medina Perez, a 20-year-old Cuban refugee, pleaded not guilty at his arraignment today on charges of trying to hijack an airliner and divert it to Cuba.

CANBERRA, Australia, Nov. 12 (Reuters) -- Australian Army headquarters said today that Newsweek magazine faced possible loss of accreditation in Vietnam unless it could substantiate statements in an article about liaison between United States and Australian forces.

The capital stock of the Hallicrafter Company yesterday became the first issue to be subject to the New York Stock Exchange's new rule of a 50 per cent margin on day trading -- the quick in and out purchase and sale of a stock on the same day.
British Government bonds scored widespread gains in quiet trading on the London Stock Exchange yesterday.

It is distressing to note that an obvious distaste for the regular Republican party organization has again so upset you that you must belittle what contribution the Republicans made to the victory of John V. Lindsay on Nov. 2.

MOSCOW, Nov. 12 -- The paintings of Aleksei Arkhipovich Leonov might not attract much international attention if it were not for one fact: As the first man to step into space, he saw the cosmos as no man had known it before.

THE finest exhibition to turn up this week, or for some time, is shared by the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Pierpont Morgan Library -- 151 Italian Renaissance drawings selected, in about equal parts, from the storehouses of those two institutions and from private collections in New York.
Five heavy-duty generators were shipped to Kennedy International and LaGuardia Airports yesterday to restore power quickly in arty future blackouts.
Mayor Wagner warned Consolidated Edison officials yesterday that the city could not tolerate another long paralysis of subways such as followed the massive power failure last Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UPI) -- The Defense Department said today it was investigating to determine if information had been leaked in advance about th eaward of a $2 billion airplane contract to Lockheed Aircraft Corporation.
The revival of the American merchant marine may come about through new technology and systems, the highest Federal transportation official said here last night.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -The Sun Chemical Corporation has developed what it regards as the world's fastest method of printing.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 12 -Physicians attending former President Dwight D. Eisenhower said today that he suffered "a definite heart attack" yesterday but that "the greatest period of danger has passed and his chances of recovery are good."
The Health Department warned yesterday against the use of a Japanese cult diet that is under investigation after the death of a woman who had been following it for nine months.
The so-called "actuarial school" of Elyseeology undoubtedly was President de Gaulle's chief target in letting it be known that he intends to serve another full seven-year term if elected in December.
BATON ROUGE, Nov. 12 -A chlorine-laden barge that had caused two months of nervousness here was raised without incident today from the muddy bottom of the Mississippi River.

PARIS, Nov. 12 -- The world's monetary reformers have begun their negotiations. The atmosphere is cordial. Some of the negotiators profess that they can reach a meaningful agreement by April. Others are not so sure.
PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., Nov. 12 -- Pockets of darkness remained in Westchester County after Tuesday's power failure because of damage to pole switches, the Consolidated Edison Company said today.
The $50 million sale of Quebec Hydro-Electric Commission debentures that was abruptly held up last Tuesday for balance-of-payments reasons has been rescheduled next Thursday.

THE crown lay heavy on the head of the heir apparent to the recently restored Molyneux fashion empire. As John Tullis passed through customs yesterday at John F. Kennedy International Airport, he snapped off a large pair of sunglasses and said, "I'm worn out -- I feel I've been in that airplane since I was born."
GENEVA, Nov. 12 (AP) -- A bigger voice in the control of international shipping was demanded by delegates from developing nations at a United Nations conference here today.
KEY WEST, Fla., Nov. 12 (UPI) -- Dick Bertram won the Miami-to-Key West powerboat race in record time today and clinched the 1965 ocean racing championship.

John Williams, the 24-year-old Australian guitarist, played for an audience made up largely of fellow guitarists in Town Hall last night. It was one of the most respectful as well as enthusiastic audiences observed in months, and there was good reason in everything Mr. Williams played.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Antonio Cerda of Mexico, who has won major golf championships in almost every part of the world, smashed the Bellavista course record today with a four-under-par 68 to take the halfway lead in the Mexican national open golf championship.

LAREDO, Tex., Nov. 12 (UPI) -- Lucien Rivard, 50 years old, a Canadian resort operator, was sentenced to 20 years in Federal prison and fined $20,000 today for directing a huge narcotics smuggling operation.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Nov. 12 -- The Republican-controlled Suffolk Board of Supervisors added $1,024,548 to County Executive H. Lee Dennison's record proposed operating budget for 1966 before adopting it today. The budget calls for a 42 cent tax rise in Western Suffolk.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The American Hospital Association has nominated the Blue Cross Association to serve as administrative intermediary between the Federal Government and the providers of service in the Medicare program.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Politics and economics may play a role in deciding how to prevent a repetition of the great Northeast power failure.

The door to membership in the city's construction unions was opened a little wider yesterday for Negroes and Puerto Ricans.
It is not often that Ivy League football commands the attention it does today, with the four teams in the first division pairing off in games of more than ordinary appeal.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 12 -- Senator Thomas H. Kuchel laid down conditions today under which he would support a Republican nominee for Governor of California next year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -Frank D. O'Connor, President-Elect of the City Council in New York, declaring that the job of running New York was "too big for any one man," came to Washington today to establish his own lines or contact with top-level Administration officials.
A telephoned report that three "pacifists" would set fire to themselves sent 40 patrolmen, two firetrucks, a police emergency car and an ambulance to Fifth Avenue and 42d Street yesterday.

MANILA, Nov. 12 -- The Philippines began recuperating today from the ordeal of electing a President. After a one-year election campaign, the Government is disrupted, the economy is limping, and many Filipinos are feuding with their neighbors.

DONIZETTI'S comic masterpiece, "L'Elisir d' Amore," entered the current Metropolitan Opera repertory last night, and along with it came Mirella Freni as Adina. It was the Italian soprano's second role at the Metropolitan; up to now she has been concerned with Mimi in "La Boheme."

In an effort to stimulate Roman Catholic involvement in problems affecting the metropolitan area, nine church-related organizations have scheduled an all-day forum on "New York City in Ferment" one week from today.
WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 12 -- Bret Hanover, apparently headed for second straight harness horse-of-the-year honors, turned in an impressive workout this morning at Roosevelt Raceway.

TWO sculpture shows, conveniently within a few steps of each other, belong in the top group of the week's gallery openings. At the Lefebre Gallery, 47 East 77th Street, the French sculptor Etienne Martin is holding his first American show.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 12 -The forced resignation of the director of the new $12.2 million Los Angeles County Museum of Art has triggered a bitter clash between museum trustees and members of the local artistic community.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Two apparent Vietcong agents who posed as his friends led a young American aid employe to his death today in a Vietcong ambush, United States officials said.

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- The Government introduced legislation today that would term the Rhodesian declaration of independence a legal nullity and authorize virtually limitless British intervention in Rhodesia.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -The "tragic and massive" refugee problem in South Vietnam is being handled with "reasonable effectiveness," a seven-man delegation from American voluntary relief agencies reported today to President Johnson.

COATS and suits that are all whirl and motion and mad ideas are what's coming out of Elite Juniors. The eight-year-old manufacturing concern, a mere child by Seventh Avenue standards, showed its precocity with one of the most exciting spring collections seen this season.
TOKYO, Nov. 12 -- Japan and South Korea will establish full diplomatic relations late in December, Government sources said today.

The phone at the American Place Theater, the non-profit, nonsectarian organization housed in St. Clement's Episcopal Church at 423 West 46th Street, began ringing insistently at 10 A.M. yesterday.
MADRID, Nov. 12 -- The Spanish Government unveiled today a six-year plan for the economic development of the region adjoining Gibraltar.
TEL AVIV, Nov. 12 -- Teddy Kollek, long a right-hand man to former Premier David Ben-Gurion, was designated Mayor of the Israeli sector of Jerusalem today.

Autumn colors prevailed in it the decor for the Chrysanthemum Ball, which was held in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza last night. The event is held annually for the benefit of the Philoptochos Society of the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of the Holy Trinity under the auspices of Archbishop Iakovos, leader of the Greek Orthodox Church of North and South America.

The old saw about everybody enjoying a wedding received additional support yesterday when the Nielsen ratings for the 30 major market cities showed "The Farmer's Daughter," heretofore not represented in the first 40 popular programs, nestled comfortably in first place.

Substantial improvements were announced yesterday in the pension benefit schedules for 27,000 members of District 65, Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Workers Union.
A University of Wisconsin scientist reported yesterday the growth of a whole tobacco plant from a single, isolated, normally nonreproductive cell.
MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 12 -Dr. Joseph Eisenstein, a 42-year-old Long Beach physician, was sentenced to six months in jail today for his part in a welfare fraud.
Charges against Carmine Lombardozzi, the Mafia leader accused of failing to answer 102 parking tickets, were dismissed yesterday by Judge Ludwig Glowa in Criminal Court.
PERTH AMBOY, N.J., Nov. 12 -- Striking Perth Amboy schoolteachers agreed tonight to return to their classes next Monday.
William F. Buckley Jr.'s attempt to have two libel suits pending against him transferred out of the city was rejected yesterday by State Supreme Court Justice Edward R. Dudley.

A tearful seaman who had hoped to ship out over the weekend for some badly needed wages ($302.56 monthly base pay as a steward; average earnings $500) telephoned The New York Times last night to appeal for help in getting back his seamen papers.

The Earl of Balfour, nephew of the author of the Balfour Declaration, the document that led to the establishment of Israel, will be honored at a reception at the Plaza on Thursday. The hosts will be Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Parker.
