ATLANTA, Nov. 13 (UPI) -- A sophomore quarterback, Kim King, broke four Georgia Tech records today to lead the Yellow Jackets to a 42-19 victory over Virginia. After the game the Tech players voted to accept a bid to the Gator Bowl at Jacksonville, Fla., on Dec. 31.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 13 (UPI) -- Playing in a steady rain over the final holes, 27-year-old Homero Blancas, a standout on the American tour this year, took the third-round lead in the Mexican open golf tournament today.

Relations between the business community and the Johnson Administration have turned slightly sour as a result of the rollback of aluminum prices. The entire episode increases the doubt that President Johnson can continue to count on the voluntary cooperation of businessmen -- and of labor -- in holding the line on wages and prices and in stemming the outflow of dollars.
" Fanny Hill' became required reading in the Supreme Court this week, as the justices agreed to decide whether the book, described as "an erotic novel" by its publishers, is obscene.

PARIS -- If General de Gaulle remains dissatisfied with NATO and denounces the treaty in 1969 there is still a way of facing the problem posed by the alliance's odd man out. This is simply to admit another odd man in to try and transpose existing United States relationships with France and Spain.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Two hundred rampaging university students broke into the office of the British Information Services today, smashed windows and wrecked furniture. They also tore down the Union Jack from the nearby British High Commission building and stoned the car of the High Commissioner Robert Fowler.

SAN SALVADOR, Nov. 13 -- The surprise appointment of Col. Oscar Osorio, former President of Salvador and later exiled, to an important Government position, appears to have come as a political bombshell. The Government of President Julio A. Rivera has now named Mr. Osorio to head the autonomous Institute of Rural Colonization, which has the task of carrying out a broad land reforms program.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The emphasis in the comment on the resignation of Harry Flood Byrd as United States Senator from Virginia has been on a point of incontrovertible fact. This point is that the public policies and philosophy of government to which he has consistently adhered have become obsolete in contemporary practice.

AMONG the concepts cherished by most Americans is that of romantic, companionable marriage: the free selection of a mate for himself or herself alone on the basis of love. The sociologists call this a "primary relation"; the personal interaction of human beings whose value to each other is intrinsic and independent of secondary considerations.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Nov. 13 -- Dr. and Mrs. Benjamin Fine have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jill Barbara Fine, to Michael Raymond Mainelli. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Mainelli of Providence, R.I.

The Federation of the Handicapped will benefit from dinner and a performance by Martyn Green and the Mr. Gilbert, Mr. Sullivan and Mr. Green Company, augmented by the Blue Hill Troupe on Nov. 30 in the Grand Ballroom of the New York Hilton.

The nineteen-thirties and forties are portrayed by Bruce Bliven through short biographies of eight "world changers": Roosevelt, Churchill, Gandhi, Hitler, Stalin, Mussolini, Chiang Kai-shek, and Hirohito, some of whom Mr. Bliven met in the course of his work as writer and editor.

Shouts of "L'Chaim" greeted Dov Markus, a broad-shouldered, bushy-haired, 19-year-old Long Island University sophomore, as he left the school's soccer field yesterday, and the Israeli youth deserved the cheers.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 13 -- Offenders "just old enough to be excluded from the juvenile delinquent category" are the subject of a world study just issued by the United Nations.
Debate in the House of Commons and in the United Nations Security Council emphasizes how precarious is the tightrope Britain must walk in trying to restore its control over Rhodesia.
Proposals to depress the Lower Manhattan Expressway were criticized yesterday by Robert Moses, coordinator of Federal-state-city road projects.

The Washington National Symphony gave the second of this year's series of Sunday Afternoon Family Concerts yes-day at Philharmonic Hall. Howard Mitchell, who conducted, made introductory remarks before each work, and considering the relative scarcity of children present, the whole thing took on the atmosphere of an adult young people's concert. Fortunately, the comments were brief.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Nov. 14 (AP) -- Gary Cuozzo, filling in for the injured Johnny Unitas, threw five touchdown passes, a Colts' record, as Baltimore trounced the Minnesota Vikings, 41-21, today. The victory kept the Colts in the Western Conference lead in the National Football League, a game ahead of the Green Bay Packers.

DURBAN, South Africa, Nov. 13 -- Through lengthy cross-examinations in the trial of Harold Strachan, the Government is pressing its contention that his account of brutality in South African jails resulted from a left-wing conspiracy to embarrass the Government.
The Alfred P. Sloan Foundation will give matching grants totaling $1 million to 23 predominantly Negro colleges in 10 Southern states over the next two years, it was announced yesterday.
THERE is an eternal triangle at the bottom of "The Fifth Commandment" -- as much a universal as a Jewish triangle.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Planning for the White House Conference on Civil Rights proposed by President Johnson in a speech at Howard University last June is expected to be a "free-swinging, open-ended" affair with a good deal of criticism directed at the Administration.

The last of the 122 local storefront headquarters that helped John V. Lindsay with his fight for the mayoralty were shut down over the weekend. The final tab for the operation was put at "upward of $750,000."
Praise be to Robert Lawrence and the Friends of French Opera!
MEXICO CITY, Nov. 14 -- Plans for construction of one of the largest fertilizer units in the world were announced here over the weekend.
FRESNO, Calif., Nov. 14 -Simon Casady has survived a bitterly fought move to depose him as president of the 50,000-member California Democratic Council.
MEXICO CITY, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Homero Blancas, tied for 12th place in the opening round, applied to take the Mexican open golf tournament by four strokes today.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 14 -- In his fourth day of recovery from a heart attack on Wednesday, the condition of former President Eisenhower was described by attending physicians as "most satisfactory."

United States Commissioner of Education Francis Keppel has confirmed reports that some urban school superintendents are concerned over the possibility of Federal control through increasing Federal aid. He admits that there may be administrative problems -- perhaps more aptly called red tape -- resulting from Federal grants; but he rejects the idea that there is any attempt by Washington to run the local schools.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 14 (UPI) -- The Los Angeles Lakers, in one of their better offorts of the season, defeated the Baltimore Bullets tonight, 129-114, and took over first place in the National Basketball Association's Western Division.

The third and final phase of the Elizabeth-Port Authority Marine Terminal, designed especially for containership operations, will soon get under way, S. Sloane Colt, chairman of the Port of New York Authority, announced yesterday.

CARSON CITY, Nev., Nov. 14 (AP) -- Residents of the gambling centers of Las Vegas and Reno stood ready today to take control of Nevada's lawmaking process under a state reapportionment bill that was passed last night.
DETROIT, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Clark Miller's 75-yard touchdown run with a recovered fumble enabled the San Francisco 49ers to defeat the Detroit Lions, 27-21, today in a National Football League game.

The Borough President-elect of the Bronx, Herman Badillo, said yesterday that "proceedings should be brought" to take away the Democratic-party membership of Charles A. Buckley, county Democratic leader.
BOSTON, Nov. 14 -- Three plays after the opening kickoff today, the New York Jets forced a fumble, recovered on the Boston Patriots' 2-foot line and scored in two plays.

PARIS, Nov. 14 (UPI) -- The police arrested the chief of the Paris narcotics squad and one of his detectives today and accused both of having illegally arrested and abducted the Moroccan leftist leader, Mehdi Ben Barka.
The Transit Authority warned the Consolidated Edison Company yesterday that it would not tolerate a repetition of last Tuesday's blackout that trapped upward of a million riders in its subways.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- In the nation's capital, it will be Margaret au go-go most of the week.
This week observers on Wall Street will be watching with unusual interest the performance on the New York Stock Exchange of American Telephone and Telegraph, the most widely-held stock in the nation.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 14 -- Most of the New York experts had mixed fortunes when play resumed here this afternoon in the International Team Trials.

IN the classical conception, politics is concerned with the question: Who gets what, when and how? "Politics," writes Richard Hofstadter in the introduction to his new, thoughtful book, "was taken as an arena in which people define their interests as rationally as possible and behave in a way calculated to realize them as fully as possible."

Larry Templeton's slight frame and extremely youthful appearance left one unprepared for the big, warm tone with which the young tenor sang at Carnegie Recital Hall yesterday afternoon. The same factors served to mitigate one's disappointment over the lack of style with which his formidable vocal equipment was used in songs and arias by Francesco Mancini, Handel and Mozart.

Mark K. Leeds of Laurelton has been elected president of the Jamaica-Queens County Real Estate Board, to serve for the year 1966. He succeeds John J. Kennedy of Richmond Hill, who will be board chairman this year. Other newly elected officers are Robert S. Dillworth, chairman of the advisory board, and John S. Linakis, director of board planning.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 14 -- New Negro voters are causing Senator Allen J. Ellender the most serious concern of his political career.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Nineteen injured survivors of the Yarmouth Castle sea tragedy remained in the hospital here today, five of them in critical condition. A spokesman at Princess Margaret Hospital declined to say which five were the most seriously injured.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Nov. 14 -- Former Premier Moise Tshombe, dismissed a month ago by President Joseph Kasavubu, today blocked confirmation of the government nominated by the President to replace him.
MADRID, Nov. 14 -- Spain appeared today to have achieved a partial victory in the latest round of the bitter and protracted European Common Market "orange war" with Italy.

DANBURY, Conn., Nov. 14 -- A number of floating islands have come to the surface of Candlewood Lake in the last month and are posing problems for shorefront dwellers and the Connecticut Light and Power Company, despite effort to blow them up and tow them away.

A NIGHT of television extremes took place Saturday evening over television station WNJU-TV in Newark. There was taped bullfighting from Mexico as the newest sports attraction for the family viewing group.
The statement published Nov. 11 of the chairman of Consolidated Edison about the blackout seems enlightening, indeed, but hardly in the way intended.
Putting the Japanese slogan, "Maximum efficiency with minimum effort, mutual benefit and welfare to all," to better use, a Northern judo team defeated a team from the South here yesterday.
OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 14 -- (UPI) -- Billy Joe smashed over from a yard out with seven seconds left to play today to give the Buffalo Bills a 17-14 victory over the Oakland Raiders.

LONDON -- The rebuilding of the bombed-out Paternoster area around St. Paul's Cathedral, one of the most historic and badly war-damaged sites in London, is finally reaching completion after 20 years as the city's most widely publicized and passionately debated hole in the ground.

This morning -- 40 calendar days or 34 shopping days before Christmas -- many of the nation's merchants will start their Christmas season. If it seems early, it is not unusual. For several years now, retailers have tried to cope with their stores' physical limitations and the irritating consumer habit of shopping at the last minute by advancing their use of Christmas themes in advertisements, store decor and windows.
Federal authorities and the shipping industry have set up a consultation system to meet the rising demand for merchant ships in the military sealift in Southeast Asia.

More than $100,000 was raised last night at Madison Square Garden to provide additional United Service Organization Clubs and entertainment for American troops in Vietnam and other Pacific areas. Hillard Elkins, theatrical producer and producer of this benefit, labelled "U.S.O. a Go Go," estimated that approximately 10,000 persons attended.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Lionel Aldridge recovered a fumble by Bill Munson on the Los Angeles 20-yard-line with less than three minutes to go today and set the stage for a seven-yard field goal by Don Chandler that gave the Green Bay Packers a 6-3 National Football League victory over the Los Angeles Rams.
Four survivors of the Yarmouth Castle arrived yesterday at Kennedy International Airport and were reunited, amid tears, with their families.

ST. PAUL, Nov. 14 -- The assumption that the power of absolution in connection with the Death of Christ lies with a particular church rather than with God was attacked here by the Rev. Dr. Eugene Carson Blake, Stated Clerk of the United Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A.

In the performance of "Carmen" given by the Metropolitan Opera National Company at the New York State Theater on Saturday night. John Gutman's English version of the text was heard in New York for the first time.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Nov. 14 -- As opposition to the breakaway Government of Rhodesia began gathering momentum, the Royal Governor, Sir Humphrey Gibbs, issued a defiant statement tonight that he would not accept Prime Minister Ian Dr. Smith's order that he step down.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 14 -- In the face of pressure from Indonesian army units, Communists in central Java have been broken into roving bands whose only potential at the moment is small-scale terrorism.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 14 -- Earl Morrall did not discourage easily. "He kept us alive," said Coach Allie Sherman of Morrall's efforts on behalf of the New York Giants in their losing game with the Cleveland Browns today.
MIAMI, Nov. 14 -- Premier Fidel Castro said two "pirate gunboats" attacked the Havana waterfront at dawn today and he charged that the United States Government was responsible.

Brandeis University has acquired 22 unpublished letters of Marcel Proust. The letters shed light on the novelist's stormy relationship with Bernard Grassett, the first publisher of his major work, "Remembrance of Things Past."
BERRYVILLE, Va., Nov. 14 (AP) -- Senator Harry F. Byrd Jr. cast himself today in the role of a forward-looking conservative attuned to changing conditions and times.
The New York City Opera Company last night gave its final performance in the house where it was born.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 14 -- Steel mills are heading toward several major market tests.

VINA DEL MAR, Chile, Nov. 14 -- Senator Robert F. Kennedy and President Eduardo Frei Montalva discussed Latin-American problems for two hours today at the presidential summer palace overlooking this Pacific resort city.
LONDON, Nov. 14 -- The logic of British policy against Rhodesia, in the opinion of experts here, points inevitably to United Nations economic sanctions.

IT takes all sorts to make a world, and, for that matter, all sorts to make a subscription series. On Saturday night the dance subscription series of the Brooklyn Academy of Music opened with a performance by the Alba/Reyes Spanish Dance Company.

BOSTON, Nov. 14 (UPI) -- Goals by Forbes Kennedy and Al Langlois in the third period gave the Boston Bruins a 2-0 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight. The shutout went to Bernie Parent, Boston's 20-year-old rookie goalie.
SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Clark Graebner of Beechwood, Ohio, and Cliff Richey of Dallas advanced to the third round in the New South Wales tennis championship today.
ALGIERS, Nov. 14 -- The Algerian Government has told Western oil companies that it plans to set up its own state-run distribution system by mid-1966.
" Complete insurance protection." That phrase might make the automobile renter feel quite secure, but, in some instances, it would be more accurate to say, "complete lack of insurance protection."
A decorated police lieutenant with 22 years on the force was suspended last night after the gun and shield he had reported stolen were turned in to the police by a prostitute.
TUCSON, Ariz., Nov. 14 -Princess Margaret's overnight visit to Page, Ariz., cost that small, back-country community's middle-income residents what by their standards is a lot of money.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 14 -- A flashy red fawn Afghan, Ch. Holly Hill Desert Wind, added to his show laurels tonight by winning the top award of the Onondaga Kennel Association event. The best-in-show title, awarded by Theodore L. Gundersen of Ottawa, was the 16th for the 4-year-old hound belonging to Mrs. Cheever Porter of New York.
Yugoslavia, for many years recipient of generous Western aid, is quietly repaying the favor by helping underdeveloped nations improve their economies.
AFTER the first-game draw in the 12-game match between the Soviet grand masters Boris Spassky and Mikhail Tal, a former world champion, the next two games were won by the player of the black pieces.

PLEIKU, South Vietnam, Monday, Nov. 15 -- United States troops fought a sharp four-hour battle yesterday and today with a battalion of North Vietnamese regulars dug into a series of jungle ridges between Pleime and the Cambodian border.

In a letter to The Times published Nov. 2 a group of "scholars and specialists" objected to "distortions of fact" by some of their colleagues about the war in Vietnam. But their own "facts" were incompatible with the reality which anybody can learn about from reputable books, such as "The Two Vietnams," by Bernard Fall, or "South Vietnam: Nation Under Stress," by Robert Scigliano.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- A special committee has begun work on sweeping proposals to reorganize the Federal Government's assistance to the nation's cities. The group is meeting in an atmosphere of urgency and unusual secrecy.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Nov. 14 (UPI) -- Mrs. Marlene Hagge shot a one-over-par 73 today to capture the $10,000 Alamo open golf tournament by three strokes over fast-closing Kathy Whitworth and Carol Mann.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The Soviet Embassy, through its press department, issued a statement tonight attacking the Penkovsky Papers.
The Small Business Administration has come to the aid of the coffeehouse business in Harlem.

CLARK FIELD the Philippines, Nov. 14 -- "We will need some help right away in the emergency rooms," the C-130 medical-evacuation transport from Vietnam radioed as it came in for a landing at this United States air base.

TY COBB never played on a team that won a World Series. Y.A. Tittle never succeeded in being on the winning side in a National Football League championship game. And Wilt Chamberlain, in his college and professional basketball career, has never been on a team that won a national title; nor for that matter, has Oscar Robertson.

At Philharmonic Hall Saturday night, Andre Kostelanetz conducted the New York Philharmonic in the first of their two Saturday nights together this season. It was a pop concert in everything but name (and price), complete with a couple of encores, and the rather less than capacity audience, a recognizably different group from the Philharmonic's regular subscribers, ate it up.
It became apparent to New York City residents last week that flicking a light switch is not a wholly isolated act.

Arthur M. Schlesinger, the historian, said today that Lyndon B. Johnson "seemed to have faded astonishingly into the background" during his final year as Vice President in President Kennedy's Administration.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- A policy based more on expediency than on morality or ideology lies behind the insistent but increasingly difficult United States effort to keep Communist China out of the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Two critical decisions affecting the Apollo lunar landing program lie ahead of space budget planners in the next month when the budget for the fiscal year 1967 will be determined.

MIAMI, Nov. 14 (UPI) -- Officials of Yarmouth Cruise Lines, Inc., released today the names of passengers and crew members still unaccounted for after the sinking of the Yarmouth Castle in Bahamas waters yesterday. It does not include the name of Nathan Lehr of 1621 S. Treasure Dr., Miami Beach, a passenger who died of burns yesterday after reaching a Nassau hospital.
NASSAU, Bahamas, Nov. 14 -- The skipper of the cruise ship Baham Star, which picked up most of the survivors from the doomed Yarmouth Castle, today told of his ship's rescue efforts.
The 54th Street Theater, 152 West 54th Street, between Seventh Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas, will be renamed the George Abbott Theater.
Holy Cross won the Catholic High School Football League championship yesterday by defeating Mount St. Michael, 35-22, before 5,500 fans at Memorial Field, Flushing, Queens.

Behind the closed doors of Room 4512 at the Federal Power Commission headquarters in Washington this morning, electric power engineers will unfold their charts and unroll miles of graph paper that may well contain the secret of what caused the great blackout.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Bruce Devlin of Australia shot birdies on three of the last four holes and won the Dunlop international golf tournament today after Doug Sanders of the United States had failed to hold a lead in the final round.
MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 14 -- New York City's Police Commissioner criticized the American Civil Liberties Union tonight for adopting what he considered a soft attitude on pornography.

From the Arctic icecaps to the boondocks of Vietnam, the U.S.O. is still providing entertainment for American armed forces. Last year 700 entertainers gave 4,000 performances before 2.5 million military personnel.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 14 -- Jim Brown, who represents so much of the Cleveland Browns, peeled the tape from his magnificent legs with the calm precision he exhibits in all his movements, "Milestones?" he asked. "They're somebody else's milestones, not mine."

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 14 -- Hap Sharp of Midland, Tex., set an American speed record today in winning the initial Sports Car Grand Prix on the new three-mile Stardust International Raceway. Driving a Chevrolet-powered Chaparral, Sharp completed the 195-mile contest with an average speed of 106.68 miles an hour.

Nebraska beat the clock by 38 seconds and completed a 75-yard scoring drive to snatch victory from Oklahoma State, 21-17, Saturday and Michigan State had to rally for two touchdowns and a field goal in the final quarter to defeat Indiana, 27-13 before 75,280 at East Lansing.
The city reported yesterday that it was succeeding in its effort to place qualified Negroes and Puerto Ricans in skilled administrative and professional positions.
NEW DELHI, Nov. 14 -- Richard Streiter, a New Yorker expelled from the Soviet Union last month, has denied charges that the Soviet Government has made against him.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Nov. 9 -- The Christmas and political seasons are in full swing and Costa Ricans have entered both with gusto.

GREENVILLE, Ala., Nov. 14 (AP) -- Nearly 70 Negroes attempted another street march today in their drive for new Federal legislation protecting civil rights workers. They were halted and turned back by the police.
The city's Police Department has taken precautionary steps to guard against further protest suicides by immolation.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14 (AP) -- A 78-yard pass from Norm Snead to Pete Retzlaff set up what proved to be the winning touchdown today as the Philadelphia Eagles snapped a four-game losing streak with a 21-14 victory over the Washington Redskins.
An electronic computer system introduced recently by the P O Orient Line reduces to minutes the days formerly required for booking passage on its 11-ship fleet.

Mazurkas and waltzes combined to make a festive program for the 17th annual Paderewski Foundation Ball last evening at the Plaza, with more than 500 people joining in the dances. The event's proceeds augmented the foundation's scholarship fund, through which students are enabled to advance their musical education at music schools and conservatories.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz is planning to develop a campaign against an "alarming increase" in spurious paintings.
New ideas for educating intellectually gifted children in the city's schools are expected to result from a fact-finding survey announced yesterday by! Dr. Bernard Donovan, Superintendent of Schools.

It is difficult to see any light at the end of the tortuous tunnel through which Britain must make its way to regain authority in Rhodesia. Whatever help the British get from the United States and others, the journey will be long and hazardous.
The Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism announced yesterday the establishment of a National Magazine Award to be given annually for outstanding editorial achievement.
The Crowell-Collier Publishing Company has acquired about 125,000 shares of Grosset Dunlap, Inc., the book publishing company, according to Manual Siwek, president of Grosset Dunlap.

Third-year students at Harvard Law School, resigned to the prospect of military duty but intent on serving as officers if serve they must, are thronging to hear about the Army's Judge Advocate General program.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 -- Zip it was, according to Coach Red Sullivan, what the New York Rangers needed. They had it tonight and scored their biggest victory of the National Hockey League season, defeating the Chicago Black Hawks, 4-2.

In the flickering light of hundreds of candles, Enrico Caruso, Emma Eames, Lucrezia Bori and other great singers of the past looked down from their portraits on the guests at the last Metropolitan Opera Club ball in the old house.
Underwriters of both taxable and municipal debt securities face unusually heavy schedules of sales this week.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Barry Goldwater said today that he did not consider Governor Rockefeller to be "as much of a liberal" as Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay and that he could support Mr. Rockefeller in a future campaign.
The Gillette Safety Razor Company has formally replied to the National Better Business Bureau for having condemned Gillette's use of competitors' products in its television commercials.

MADISON, Wis., Nov. 13 -- The course in the Sociology of Fashion is not listed in the official curriculum of the University of Wisconsin, but almost everyone takes it and even middle-aged visitors with rusty academic skills can grasp its fundamentals 24 hours after flying into town.
Governor Rockefeller has proposed that the state establish five four-year colleges in New York City -- one in each borough -- with a total of 50,000 students.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 -- The National Association of Real Estate Boards will continue to oppose legislation that prohibits racial discrimination in housing, the president of the realty group said here today.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., Nov. 14 -- Sunny Rhodes, a 6-year-old gray gelding, could do no better than reserve today in the green working hunter division at the Glen View Stables horse show. But it was the most important reserve of his life.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 14 -- The Government of Premier Nguyen Cao Ky is entering what a diplomat has called its time of trial.

KANSAS CITY, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Len Dawson threw three touchdown passes and the Kansas City defense came up with six interceptions today as the Chiefs scored a 31-7 victory over the San Diego Chargers, the American Football League's Western Division leaders.
AUGUSTA, Ga. Nov. 14 (AP) -- Richard Petty won the Georgia Cracker 300 late-model stock car race at a record speed today after Tiny Lund was forced out by mechanical trouble with 37 laps to go.

DETROIT, Nov. 15 (UPI) -- A pair of second-period goals by Norm Ullman gave the Detroit Red Wings a 2-2 tie tonight with the Montreal Canadiens in a National Hockey League game.
JOHNSON CITY, Tex., Nov. 14 -- President Johnson ended a 23-day convalescence today at his ranch here, but before flying back to Washington he entertained two soldiers who had served in Vietnam.
Gracie Mansion's new tenants think the place needs a paint job and apparently are willing to use their own money to pay for it.

CLIFTON, N.J., Nov. 14 -(AP) -- Charles Simon, whose 24-year-old wife died Tuesday of acute malnutrition after going on an oriental diet that shrank her to 70 pounds, has been placed on a diet that includes a protein and Vitamin C.
NASSAU, Bahamas, Nov. 14 -- The United States Coast Guard began investigating today the burning of the cruise liner Yarmouth Castle, which sank early yesterday off the Great Stirrup Cay.
LONDON, Nov. 14 -- The British Government warned to night that anyone who "lays hands on" the Governor of Rhodesia, Sir Humphrey Gibbs, would be committing "an act of treason."

The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. went to Harlem yesterday and was embraced by Representative Adam Clayton Powell. The 5,000 Negroes who jammed Mr. Powell's Abyssinian Baptist Church applauded as their pastor, smiling broadly, strode in during the 10 A.M. service, mounted the white marble platform and enveloped the civil rights leader in a warm bear hug.
The election of James R. Hand as executive vice president of the National Bank of Westchester, N.Y., was announced over the weekend.

DALLAS, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The Dallas pass defense and Don Meredith's 28-yard throw to Bob Hayes with two minutes left gave the Dallas Cowboys a 24-17 victory today over the Pittsburgh Steelers in a National Football League game.

HOUSTON, Nov. 14 (UPI) -- Gary Kroner kicked a 34-yard field goal and John Bramlett ran 25 yards for a touchdown on an interception today to give the Denver Broncos a 31-21 victory over the Houston Oilers in an American Football League game.

Probably no one is better qualified to give a series called Four Centuries of Music for the Violin than Joseph Fuchs. He opened a four-program engagement bearing this title at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Saturday night.
Yesterday was the day the lines crossed -- the city had more water in storage than on the same date last year. It was the first time since the city began its water-saving campaign last spring.

The city's water supply continued yesterday for the second day to improve over the supply last year. But a water official in Northern New Jersey warned that the supply there was far below last year's levels.

Brazil's 18.8 per cent devaluation of the cruzeiro over the weekend posed questions for commodity traders in staples such as cocoa and coffee yesterday. However, since there was a business holiday in Brazil yesterday, the full effects probably cannot be measured until today or tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The Air Force said today it had revised the honor code at the Air Force Academy and had adopted most recommendations of a committee that studied the academy's practices after widespread cheating had been disclosed there.

ROME, Nov. 15 -- Ecumenical Council drafts dealing with the issues of war and peace and with atheism drew fire today from, respectively, an American Archbishop and a large group of conservative prelates.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The official moralizings in London, Washington and Salisbury, in which comparisons between the first and the second Declarations of Independence of British colonials from the mother country have been asserted and denied, had best be abandoned by all concerned.

A Canadian power plant was being cited as the likely source of the historic Northeastern regional blackout within two hours after the trouble started, but utility and Government officials shied away from the indication.

TORONTO, Nov. 15 -- Everyone wishes it would be on the other man's system," the chairman of the Hydro-Electric Power Commission of Ontario remarked ruefully this afternoon. "But it's on ours, and we're going to face up to it."
LONDON, Nov. 15 -- The use in a television program of a four-letter word brought a demand tonight from Conservative members of Parliament for legal action against Kenneth Tynan, the drama critic.
Parks Commissioner Newbold Morris came, saw, but was still not conquered by Alexander Calder's stabile, "Le Guichet," (Ticket Window) at Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts yesterday.
The appointment of Philip N. Buckminster to the new post of vice president of the marketing staff was announced yesterday in Detroit by the Chrysler Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -Five major airlines that carry most of the nation's air traffic began joint negotiations today with the International Association of Machinists on labor contracts covering more than 32,000 machinists and service workers.
Governor Rockefeller announced yesterday that a 200-bed unit for mentally ill children would be erected on the grounds of Manhattan State Hospital on Wards Island.

FAMAGUSTA, Cyprus, Nov. 15 -- Dockworkers began today to unload tons of Red Crescent (Red Cross) supplies from a Turkish ship amid a dispute over customs charges levied by the Greek Cypriote Government against some of the food and clothing destined for Turkish Cypriote refugees.
Honeywell, Inc., opened a new attack yesterday on "Fortress I.B.M."
A pre-Christmas taxi strike threatens the city as an outgrowth of driver discontent over the slowness of National Labor Relations Board procedures for certifying their union.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 15 -- The arrival today in Belgrade of Wladyslaw Gomulka, the Polish Communist chief, and of the Polish Premier, Jozef Cyrankiewicz, marked another step in the improvement of Yugoslavia's relations with East Europe.
BRUSSELS, Nov. 15 -- Uncertainty about the future of the Common Market may be a depressing investment, the Executive Commission of the trade bloc observed today.

Judith Keller, mezzo-soprano, winner of the 1965 "The Joy in Singing" competition held annually by Town Hall, collected her award last night; a recital at the hall. She is no stranger to New York, having made her solo debut here in 1963 at Carnegie Recital Hall.

IADRANG RIVER VALLEY, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Nov. 16 -- Amid the stunted trees and scrub bush of this narrow river valley, men of the United States First Cavalry Division fought one of the toughest battles of the Vietnamese war in the last three days.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -The new Federal law permiting Puerto Ricans to vote on the basis of literacy in Spanish was struck down today by a three-judge United States court.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -The Supreme Court ruled today that individuals may invoke their constitutional privilege against self-incrimination and refuse to register with the Government as members of the Communist party.

Your Oct. 30 editorial calling for "Better Federal Judges" through the establishment of a nonpartisan nominating commission is well-intentioned but wide of the mark. The real question is whether the present procedure results in the appointment of Federal judges worthy of the office, not whether there are more or less judges who are Democrats or Republicans, or whether they were experienced politicians as well as lawyers.

STRICTLY speaking, the focus of interest at last night's Carnegie Hall concert of the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra should have been the performance of Edward Elgar's "Falstaff." This is a seldom-played, rather long (about 30 minutes) symphonic poem that has many moments of beauty and a good deal of individuality.
Firemen battled a blaze in the forward hold of the luxury liner Independence at her pier at 44th Street last night.

In a world where speed is becoming synonomous with the human essence, scientists will assure people like Craig Breedlove that they can go as fast as any man-built vehicle can carry them without much fear of upsetting their insides.

Shareholders of the new Republic National Bank of New York at their first meeting here yesterday elected eight directors. In turn, the new directors selected a slate of officers to run the new bank which is expected to open for business early next year.
CHICAGO, Nov. 15 -- Two young people with a theater and an idea are currently providing Chicago with a great six-week dance festival that any city anywhere would be proud to own.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange declined slightly yesterday in very active trading.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The Government and the aluminum industry "made progress" in resumed negotiations for disposal of excess aluminum from the national stockpile, a Government spokesman reported today. The negotiations reopened this morning after a nine-day hiatus during the peak of the clash between the two sides over aluminum prices.

NAHA, Okinawa, Nov. 15 -The pro-American conservative Democratic party retained its majority in the 32-seat Ryukyuan Legislature in yesterday's elections, taking 19 seats and assuring that this strategic United States island base will have relative political security for the next three years.
A bank robber wounded a guard and a woman pedestrian yesterday in a gunfight near Lincoln Center in escaping from the Bankers Trust Company branch at Broadway and 66th Street with $4,069.

HOLYOKE, Mass., Nov. 15 (UPI) -- Two Holyoke men were arrested today and charged with a series of burglaries, including a break-in at the home of a newspaper publisher, William Dwight Sr., in which swastikas were carved on the walls.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The Rev. Fred L. Shuttlesworth, a Negro leader with a flair for litigation, won his fifth Supreme Court reversal today of Deep South convictions for civil rights activity.

" I'D do anything to take the trauma out of luxury and make it fun," says Jacques Kaplan, the French-born furrier who has been known to cut holes in new fur coats to support his contention.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., Nov. 15 -- This city's public school system returned to "absolutely normal" today following settlement of a strike by Perth Amboy Teachers Union Local 857 of the New Jersey State Federation of Teachers.

There were no trades made yesterday in the stock of the Sun Chemical Company on the New York Stock Exchange. This resulted from the influx of a large volume of buy orders that could not be matched. At the close, the Big Board also announced a ban on stop orders in the stock.
DESIGNERS from Europe and California converged on New York yesterday to join Seventh Avenue manufacturers in proving you can't tell where a style comes from without a label.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -The United States denounced today an international treaty that limits an airline's liability for the death or injury of a passenger to $8,300 in most cases.
Chicago sold yesterday $14.45 million of bonds to an underwriting syndicate headed by the Northern Trust Company.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Nov. 15 -- A charge of cowardice against some crew members of the Yarmouth Castle was made in an interview today by the daughter of the acting chief medical officer of the Princess Margaret Hospital.

TORONTO, Nov. 15 (AP) -Frank Chapot of Wallpack, N.J., took his mount, San Lucas, over a 6-foot 9-inch wall tonight to win the international individual puissance event for the United States at the Royal Agricultural Winter Fair.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Princess Margaret of Britain arrived in Washington today and immediately began to play "Meet the Press" on a giant scale.

The New England states learned the importance of emergency illumination for public places in Boston's disastrous Cocoanut Grove fire in 1942. The sight of small, box-like structures mounted near the ceiling, with opposed floodlights on top, is now commonplace to the east of us.

AUGUSTA, Ga. Nov. 15 -- Physicians attending former President Dwight D. Eisenhower said today that they were "immensely impressed" with the progress of his recovery from his heart attack last Wednesday.

SELMA, Ala., Nov. 15 (AP) -- About 50 Negroes marched to the Dallas County Courthouse today in a protest against "segregated justice," but they were not allowed to take their grievances to the probate judge's office.
Dorothy Kilgallen, the newspaper columnist and television personality, died last week from the reaction of a combination of alcohol and barbiturates, the Medical Examiner's office said yesterday.

Twenty young couples will dance the opening waltz on Saturday at the fourth annual ball of the Grand Council of the Hungarian Boy Scouts Association. The event will be held in the Georgian Room of the Americana Hotel. Dinner will follow a cocktail reception.

Four changes in officer posts of Sears, Roebuck Co., were announced by Austin T. Cushman, chairman of the board, following a meeting of the board of directors yesterday. The appointments are all effective Feb. 1, 1966.

Burlington Industries, Inc., which plans to spend at least $125 million in its new fiscal year for capital outlays, does not believe that the current level of textile industry expenditures will generate any long-term excess capacity.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 15 -Senator Salvador Allende, who received 39 per cent of the vote last year as the presidential candidate of the Socialist-Communist Popular Action Front, today discussed the reasons for his defeat.
WASHINGTON Nov. 15 -The 80,000-square-mile Northeast power failure was traced today to a generating plant on the Ontario side of the Niagara River.

The controversy over what court shall handle adoptions was aired in public for the fourth time in three years yesterday in hope of a final settlement but no conclusion was reached. However the battle was joined.
LONDON, Tuesday, Nov. 16 -- Parliament approved legislation early today giving the British Government power to impose sanctions on the breakaway Rhodesian Government.

WILLIAM SNYDER's psychoanalytical drama on a girl consumed by her own anxieties was last night's taped attraction on the New York Television Theater over Channel 13. The work, entitled "The Days and Nights of Beebee Fenstermaker," is determinedly discursive and runs afoul of many of the rudimentary laws of stagecraft, but the performance of Rose Gregorio was a beautifully sensitive accomplishment.
JILL ISLES told her 136 friends that it was going to be a Parisian cellar party that they would be attending Sunday night at The Scene on West 46th Street.

The Van Arsdale twins will have a chance to exchange greetings and baskets when the Knickerbockers meet the Detroit Pistons tonight in the second half of a National Basketball Association doubleheader at the Garden.

ALBANY, Nov. 15 -- As many as one million automobile owners may get punch-card auto registration forms containing inaccurate information, the State Motor Vehicle Department said today. Automation again was blamed.

WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 15 -A "young, clean-cut" man who refused to disclose his name to reporters received the fourth highest twin-double payoff in history -- $129,631.80 -- tonight at Roosevelt Raceway, and he won it in spectacular fashion.

INCREASINGLY the Negro is using sardonic laughter to express his resentment at years of forced inferiority and to articulate his passion for change. In a double bill that opened last night at the St. Marks Playhouse, Douglas Turner Ward chuckles at the white employer-Negro servant relationship and bellows raucously at a Southern city's dependence on its Negro population.
LA JOLLA, Calif., Nov. 15 -Some day, highways crowded with cars at night may be brilliantly illuminated by headlights, yet there will be no glare from the oncoming cars.
TRENTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -Efforts by Marlboro Township to stop or slow down the construction of a 1,200-home development were blocked by the Appellate Division of Superior Court today.

AT 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon, Craig Norman Breedlove walked into the State Line Restaurant about 20 miles from the Bonneville Salt Flats in Utah and took a swig of Coor's beer. This was the only nourishment he had taken in nearly 20 hours.

NASHVILLE, Nov. 15 (AP) -- A three-judge Federal Court upheld today the 1965 Tennessee Legislative Reapportionment Act, which gives the state's five largest counties 12 additional seats and leaves them seven votes short of a majority.

PARIS, Nov. 15 -- Murray Schisgal's Broadway hit, "Luv," translated into French as "Love," opened at the Theatre Montparnasse-Gaston Baty Saturday, brightening the lackluster Paris season like a burst of fireworks.

The B.F. Goodrich Company has joined the lengthening list of corporations that have set up financing subsidiaries to raise long-term funds in Europe for expansion overseas -- yet still stay within the guidelines of President Johnson's balance-of-payments program.
The body of a man, a candle still in his grasp, was found yesterday at the bottom of an elevator shaft in a midtown hotel. He apparently fell to his death during last Tuesday's blackout.

The three Americans who set themselves afire to protest the war being waged in Vietnam by our President were not confused and misdirected. If they had been they could not have acted with the calm and purpose so clearly evident in all three immolations.

The popularity of chamber music might zoom to new highs if all examples and performances of it were as appealing and satisfying as those heard at Carnegie Recital Hall in a program presented by Young Concert Artists.
The Sun Oil Company's $100 million issue of debentures was offered publicly yesterday priced to yield 4.69 per cent by an underwriting syndicate headed by Smith, Barney Co., Inc.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Nancy Richey of Dallas, the top-ranking American women's player, led the way into the fourth round of the New South Wales tennis championships today by routing Norma Marsh of Australia, 6-3, 6-0.
ALEXANDER'S has expanded the selection in its fifth-floor Gift Shop at its 59th Street store with a collection of antiques and reproductions.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The use of nuclear power to generate electricity for civilian use has increased dramatically this year, surprising even the companies selling reactors.
Israel is wooing United States retailers for its young ready-to-wear industry by an old, yet potent, merchandising technique -- a fashion fair.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -The index of wholesale primary market prices advanced one-tenth of 1 per cent to 103.1 of its 1957-59 base during the week ended Nov. 9, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

Johnny Nerud, the amiable horse trainer who recently underwent an operation at the Leahy Clinic in Boston, must have received a helpful push on the way to recovery when he heard the news from Aqueduct yesterday.
BONNEVILLE SALT FLATS, Utah, Nov. 15 (UPI) -- Craig Breedlove surpassed 600 miles an hour today in regaining the world land speed record in two runs on the Utah salt flats.

RIO de JANEIRO, Nov. 15 -Brazil has assured delegations arriving for the Inter-American Conference, opening Wednesday, that an aggressive, narrow majority will not seek to impose controversial decisions on the assembly of the Western Hemisphere.
A leading corporate executive said here yesterday the time was ripe to devise new means of encouraging foreign investments.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -The State Department confirmed today a report that a year ago the United States rejected an offer by North Vietnam to have representatives of the two nations meet in Rangoon, Burma, to discuss terms for ending hostilities in Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The chairman of the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy suggested today that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization be given a greater voice in determining when nuclear weapons should be used in defense of Western Europe.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard, former Cleveland osteopath, was granted a hearing today on a new appeal to the Supreme Court from his conviction and life sentence for the slaying of his first wife.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The Navy has chosen a successor for one of two admiral retiring because of dissatisfaction with certain Pentagon management and procurement policies.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 15 (AP) -- Displays of poor sportsmanship by Notre Dame students and fans may result in the end of intercollegiate competition at the university, the Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, the president, warned today.
An assistant vice president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company was detached from corporate duties yesterday to become president of the Cincinnati and Suburban Bell Telephone Company.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 15 -- Leaders of American Reform Judaism started a $2 million campaign tonight for the establishment of a "religious art center" in New York City that will be used for the creation of various artistic projects dealing with Jewish religious and cultural themes.
Price changes were mixed on the London Stock Exchange yesterday. Most of the interest centered in speculative buying of Rhodesian stocks, some of which advanced as much as 4 points.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 15 (UPI) -- Charlie Boswell, a former star halfback at Alabama, who lost his sight in the Battle of the Bulge, was named today to receive the National Chapters Distinguished American award of the National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame.
The Baltimore Ohio Railroad estimates its net income for 1965 at about $16 million, up from $7,218,391 in 1964, stockholders were told yesterday at their annual meeting in Baltimore.
J. Sinclair Armstrong, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission from 1955 to 1957, was elected yesterday to the board of Barnes Noble, Inc.
DETROIT, Nov. 15 -- Suburban housewives frightened by reports of a so-called "giggling prowler" applied for scores of pistol permits last week, the police said today.

Riding with him was Harold Parrott of the Dodger executive staff, and Parrott was visibly shaken when they finally came to a screaming halt only a minute before the time of the appointment.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 (AP) - Demands that the nation's railroads negotiate with the Brotherhood of Railroad Firemen and Enginemen to restore 17,500 locomotive crew jobs were met coldly today by a spokesman for the railroads.
SECAUCUS, N.J., Nov. 15 -- A woman doctor delivered her own grandson today in the shadow of the toll plaza of the New Jersey Turnpike here.
Marion Sadler, president of American Airlines, Inc., strongly defended his industry's current fare structure yesterday.

A Marc Chagall painting looted by the Gestapo from an apartment in Brussels in March, 1941, belongs to the woman who left it behind in the wake of the German onslaught of Belgium, a jury ruled here yesterday.

SAIGON, Nov. 15 -- An investigation of the accidental bombing Saturday in the demilitarized zone between North and South Vietnam disclosed that the attack was carried out by three United States Navy jet planes as a "result of a navigational error," a military spokesman said today.
Two educators who have figured prominently in recent political controversies were attacked for their stands on academic freedom at a teach-in at New York University last night.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Nov. 15 (AP) -- William F. McKee, administrator of the Federal Aviation Agency, said tonight the first experimental version of the United States supersonic transport should make its initial flight in 1969 or 1970 and the production model may be certified in 1974 or sooner.
Dr. Allen Balcom Du Mont, a pioneer in the practical development of television, died yesterday at Doctors Hospital after a short illness. He was 64 years old.
The stock market ran hot and cold yesterday and finished lukewarm.
MIAMI, Nov. 15 -- The cruise ship Yarmouth Castle passed a safety check three weeks before she burned and sank, the Coast Guard said today.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Nov. 15 (AP) -- The Geos 1 map-making satellite was turned in space today, and officials said it was ready to start charting the globe.

NEARLY a billion and a half pounds of celery are grown in this country every year, which adds up to quite a bunch of stalks. When a recipe refers to a celery stalk, it means the whole plant. Each stalk is made up of 18 ribs, and the delicate white inner ribs are the celery heart.

Has Federal Reserve policy shifted toward easy money? This is what bankers were asking themselves yesterday in the wake of the disclosure late Friday afternoon that the banking system posted a net free-reserve position last week for the first time since last February.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 15 -- A 35-year-old cosmetics manufacturer who has never been in politics but who says he has $1.5 million to spend on a campaign, announced his candidacy today for the Republican nomination for Governor of California.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The Treasury bill rate rose sharply at today's auction to the highest level since early 1960, the Treasury disclosed tonight.

A new contract providing for wage increases and other benefits for 6,500 composing room employes in the city's commercial printing establishments went into effect yesterday -- 10 days before the expiration date of the old contract.

Mayor Wagner is attempting to defend the weakest part of his twelve-year record when replying, as he was yesterday, to what he calls "recent incautious statements suggesting that we are . . . on the verge of bankruptcy." By way of reassurance he says the city's fiscal condition is "sound and secure," the city government "wholly solvent," its budget legally "balanced."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- President Johnson, back in the White House after his recuperative stay of more than three weeks in Texas, did some catching up on paper work today. His press secretary, Bill D. Moyers, said Mr. Johnson spent the day on a variety of subjects mostly dealing with international and defense affairs.

All of the stock, or 250,000 shares, held by Marvin Kratter in Countrywide Realty, Inc., formerly the Kratter Corporation, has been purchased by the Realty Equities Corporation, it was announced yesterday.

The Canadian dollar registered a sharp advance yesterday in active trading on foreign-exchange markets here.

Like Captain Fitzbattleaxe in Gilbert and Sullivan's "Utopia, Ltd.," Bruno Prevedi, singing his first Manrico in "Il Trovatore" with the Metropolitan Opera, just couldn't do himself justice last night. He had delivered a virile, rich-voiced performance up to that tenor-tester, "Di quella pira," but when the two high C's came around, they just weren't there.
The Coca-Cola Company, the giant producer of soft drinks, reported yesterday sharply higher profits in the third-quarter and first nine months, compared with 1964 levels.
QUEENSTON, Ont., Nov. 15 -- The switch yard of the Sir Adam Beck-Niagara Generating Station was operating at normal capacity this chill, rainy evening.
THE NEW YORK debutante, often thought of as outdoing debutantes in other places, is actually inclined toward understatement when it comes to what she wears for making her bow.

The Latin Americans are moving slowly in the direction of a common market. The latest step taken by the foreign ministers of the nine-nation Latin-American Free Trade Association calls for establishment of a permanent ministerial council and creation of a high-level technical committee to speed development of economic integration. Undoubtedly additional proposals for economic integration will be examined at the forthcoming meeting of the extraordinary Inter-American conference opening this week in Rio de Janeiro.
A study of 12 employer-employe health and welfare plans indicated yesterday that surgeon' fees increased as the schedule of insurance allowances for various operations was increased.
Directors of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. declared yesterday a year-end common stock dividend of $2.25.
Governor Rockefeller's grandiose proposal to establish five new undergraduate liberal arts colleges in New York City is, under the circumstances in which it was made, highly questionable.

ORLANDO, Fla., Nov. 15 -Walt Disney announced here today the purchase of 27,000 acres in Orange and Seminole Counties for the construction of a Disneyland-East. The use of anonymous buyers to acquire the land parcels made for one of the biggest mystery real-estate transactions in Florida's history.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 15 -Duane Pope, taking the witness stand in his own defense as his murder trial entered its third week, told today of a dream that has remained etched in his memory since he was a third-grader.
Yehudi Menuhin was honored at separate occasions yesterday by each of two foreign governments.

RALEIGH, N.C., Nov. 15 -Moderates in the State Legislature opened a drive today to modify North Carolina's controversial "Communist speaker ban law." With the backing of Gov. Dan K. Moore, a conservative Democrat who formerly supported the law, they seemed likely to succeed.

TORONTO, Nov. 15 (AP) -The Ontario Supreme Court has opened a legal door for holders of about $20 million in unsecured notes of the Atlantic Acceptance Corporation to get a return on their investment in the defunct organization.

" Skyscraper," Broadway's newest hit, underwent one of the most extensive rewriting periods of any musical in recent years. A new ending to one of the scenes and new dialogue were added a few hours before the curtain went up Saturday night at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater.
The chancellor of the City University and the president of its senior colleges backed down yesterday from their proposal to impose a "theoretical" tuition charge of $400 a year.
Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay and Mrs Lindsay do not need to worry, city funds are available for painting Gracie Mansion and the job will be done soon, city aides said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, NOV. 15 (AP) -- Space scientists will use two rockets and balloons this week in hopes of sweeping up bits of falling stars as the annual Leonid meteor shower takes place.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Nov. 15 -- Prime Minister Ian D. Smith warned the armed forces, the police and all other servants of the Rhodesian Government tonight to beware of the efforts of the British to undermine their loyalty.

Judith Todd, 22-year-old daughter of R.S Garfield Todd, former Prime Minister of Rhodesia, said yesterday that Britain should send troops into her country to do a "swift, clean surgical job" of removing Prime Minister Ian D. Smith's rebellious Government.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission announced today the dates for a series of hearings on an application by the New Haven Railroad to discontinue its passenger service.
PRAGUE, Nov. 13 -- A play called "The Accident," currently being performed here, illuminates a struggle being waged in Czechoslovakia.
The new Chilean freighter Aconcagua II made her debut here yesterday and received the traditional maiden voyage welcome, complete with fireboat salute, tugboat escort and helicopter aerial cover.

Steel production picked up last week after a did the week before. Output of the nation's mills has fluctuated up and down by small variations in the last few weeks and the latest small rise could not be considered particularly significant, let alone a harbinger of a sustained rise.
WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 15 -The owner of a Westchester house assessed at $20,000 can expect to pay $15 more taxes next year to help finance an $8.5 million increase in departmental spending by the county.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 15 -- South Africa made it clear to the Security Council today that she would place her own interests before any recommendations by the United Nations regarding relations with independent Rhodesia.
