TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 15 -- The first Government funds, amounting to almost $3 million, have been allocated to a new national program for the arts.

The New York Yankees, who finished in sixth place last season, will try to improve their image next season by televising their games in color. The baseball club and station WPIX announced yesterday that all home games at Yankee Stadium will be presented in color, as will some games on the road. The television station will have six color cameras installed at Yankee Stadium next April when the baseball season opens.

With 200,000 troops expected in Vietnam by the end of the year, the White House and the Department of Defense have requested an immediate expansion of USO operations in Vietnam, includ ing more USO shows at remote and forward stations.

INDIO, Calif., Nov. 15 (AP) -- The wreckage of a plane with eight aboard, including four members of a family of wealthy land developers and the son of the president of Flying Tiger Line, was found today in the hills to the north of here. There were no survivors.
Norm Van Brocklin, a stubborn but able leader of men, resigned yesterday as coach of the Minnesota Vikings, a move that surprised the world of professional football and shocked the Viking owners.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The Food and Drug Administration is going to take another look at the problem of pesticide chemicals in the food supply.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (UPI) -- Commissioner George P. Larrick today announced he would retire on Dec. 27 as head of the Food and Drug Administration.
The Radcliffe Club of New York has arranged tours of private art collections for the afternoons of Dec. 4 and 11 to raise money for its scholarship fund. The club office is at the Berkshire Hotel.

ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 15 -One of the most striking results of Turkey's latest election is the emergence in Parliament for the first time of a Marxist party, which advocates Turkey's withdrawal from Western alliances, removal of all foreign forces, nationalization of the economy and a neutralist foreign policy.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 15 -- Ten nations submitted a resolution today that, if approved by the General Assembly, would lead to the defeat of the drive to seat Communist China in the United Nations this year.

To hear Eamon O'Reilly tell it, he has weak ankles, he runs atrociously up and down hills and he always manages to do something wrong when he runs a cross-country race at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -The West German Embassy in Washington today honored a German diplomat who opposed the Nazis and was executed by them 21 years ago.
PARIS, Nov. 15 -- A small but influential private group of Europeans and Americans is helping to keep the flame of intellectual cooperation alive within the Atlantic alliance.

ARMY and Navy, as almost everyone knows, will meet in their annual football game at Philadelphia a week from Saturday. These are not two of the best football teams the academies have produced. But this Saturday, as not too many persons may know, two of the best soccer teams ever produced at any college will meet when undefeated Navy plays undefeated Army at Annapolis, Md.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Nov. 15 -- The need for education in marketing, both from a public relations standpoint and with a view to future recruitment, emerged today as a major theme of the 56th annual meeting of the Association of National Advertisers, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The Supreme Court ordered a lower Federal Court today to determine whether assignment of teachers on an alleged racial basis invalidated school desegregation plans in Richmond and Hopewell, Va.

The R.A.C. Corporation, formerly the Republic Aviation Corporation, has sold part of its stock interest in the Royal Netherlands Aircraft Factories (Fokker) to the Northrop Corporation for $2.32 million.

The big-game season, which in this part of the world means deer, is in full swing in many areas. New York State alone will probably sell nearly a million licenses. This is a lot of people out looking for a deer.

The ninth annual Yankee Fair will be held tomorrow from 11 A.M. to 9 P.M. in the Plymouth Church gymnasium, 75 Hicks Street, Brooklyn. The sponsor is the Women's Guild of the church, which will use proceeds for local, state and worldwide enterprises.

Mayor Wagner hotly denied yesterday that there was "any basis in fact whatever" in Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay's statement that he would be "acting as a receiver in bankruptcy" when he takes over at City Hall.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 15 -- The nonaligned states have agreed on a resolution for a world disarmament conference that could overcome Communist China's opposition to a parley under United Nations auspices.

The leadership of the Communist party of the United States hailed yesterday a ruling by the Supreme Court that the Fifth Amendment protects party members from a requirement that they register as agents of a foreign power.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Nov. 15 -- President Joseph Kasavubu renominated Evariste Kimba as Premier today and asked him to form a new Government.

KEN SCOTT is the American designer who went to Italy and beat the Italians at their own game -- making prints. Starting with fabric designs, he went on to clothes utilizing his bold, dramatic flower prints on silk jersey, chiffon, voile and cotton.
DETROIT, Nov. 15 (AP) -The United States automobile industry wrote a new page in its record book today when the 8-millionth car of the calendar year rolled off an assembly line.
Ballerinas pranced past the windows of a ballet school across Sixth Avenue and from the Women's House of Detention came a cry of "Hey, mister, look over here."

BIRMINGHAM, England, Nov. 15 -- Differences between parents of white pupils and the headmistress of the Grove School in a Birmingham industrial suburb reveal the tensions that have built up in Britain over what is euphemistically called the immigrant question.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 15 -- Abram Fischer, the object of the most intensive manhunt in the annals of the South African police, appeared before a magistrate today minus the dyed brown beard that had hidden him in the middle of Johannesburg for 10 months.
Businessmen in the Hanover Square area were united yesterday in opposing a public garage proposed for their neighborhood.
ON a July morning in 1846, Henry David Thoreau was given a pint of chocolate and some bread for breakfast, and then asked to leave the Concord jail.
RIO de JANEIRO, Nov. 16 -- Leaders of the Inter-American Conference moved today to head off any divisive airing of frontire disputes during the two-week meeting that opens tomorrow.

MOSCOW, Nov. 16 -- The Soviet Union launched today its second instrumented space craft in four days toward Venus in what appeared to be a determined effort to advance man's knowledge about the mysterious, cloud-covered planet.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- A creeping defeatism on merchant marine policy threatens the nation's future security, maritime men and shipbuilders said here today.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., Nov. 16 -- The president of the CBS television network came here today to do a little "dreaming" out loud about the future of his medium.
DONALD BROOKS, whose fall collection was described as little girlish, has decided women can grow up next spring.

PARIS -- The plain fact is that France cannot leave the Western alliance system even if de Gaulle chooses to denounce the North Atlantic treaty in 1969. France can indeed withdraw from NATO's organization; but it will nevertheless remain militarily allied to Britain, West Germany, Italy and the Benelux countries for twenty-nine more years.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Nov. 16 -- Not many friends of Sir Humphrey Gibbs are surprised by the family coat of arms. It bears three battle-axes and the motto "Tenax Porpositi" -- "tenacious of purpose."
Mayor Wagner named the Legal Aid Society yesterday to defend indigent persons in criminal cases.
Construction contracts totaling more than $20 million have been awarded by The Madison Square Garden Center, the 8.5-acre complex rising atop Pennsylvania Station.
MUNICH, Germany -- "Munich is no longer the beer city of Germany. It is now the fashion city of Germany."
Directors of the Continental Steel Corporation voted yesterday in Chicago to reduce the year-end extra dividend to 45 cents a common share from a payment of 70 cents in 1964.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 16 -- Hofstra University and Long Island University both insisted today that they would set up the first law school on Long Island.
A major bankers' syndicate said yesterday that it might have to drop its option to buy the first big batch of bonds under the city's "borrow now, pay later" budget program.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 16 -- President Arturo U. Illia proposed today that the United States and Latin America intensify their collaboration to close the gap between the developed nations and the underdeveloped world by embarking on a program to expand agricultural production.

WHAT actually happened, and what precisely the United States role was in the civil war that broke out in the Dominican Republic last April 24, is still shrouded in secrecy. Every so often, a little more of the story leaks out (the latest leakage from the still-secret Senate hearings came early this week).
MOSCOW, Nov. 16 -- The Soviet leadership unleashed a harsh broadside attack on Communist China today.

The first of four programs concerned with careers in the theater was held last night at the Broadhurst Theater under the sponsorship of the Sam S. Shubert Foundation, of which Lawrence Shubert Lawrence is president.
The City College of New York paid a memorial tribute yesterday to one of its most distinguished alumni, Bernard M. Baruch.
Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay said last night that a subway strike "cannot be permitted" and called for a broad reform of "the whole bargaining process" between the city and labor unions.
Lawrence F. O'Brien, the new Postmaster General, has promised improvement of the United States postal system. This it badly needs.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 16 -- Captured North Vietnamese soldiers said today that their units had received assistance from Cambodian "militiamen" during their infiltration into South Vietnam and that each infiltrated regiment had one Chinese Communist adviser.
Plans for speeding recovery and increasing protection in power failures were being widely developed yesterday as a sequel to last week's Northeast regional blackout in eight states and Canada.
A syndicate headed by Francis I. duPont Co. and Bear, Stears Co. won yesterday $9 million of debentures sold at competitive bidding by the Jersey Central Power and Light Company.

The Motor Vehicles Department added one of its own mistakes yesterday to the many errors found by automobile owners in the new punch-card forms essential to secure 1966 license plates. It apologetically noted it had pushed back by 60 days the mailing of amended forms.

As a former resident of Eastport. Me., I would like to see some inquiry into the famous Quoddy project. This plan is to build dams that would take advantage of ocean tides. Salt water tides are more dependable than fresh water power projects.

RALEIGH, N.C., Nov. 16 -- The North Carolina Legislature completed today all but one step in the drive by the administration of Gov. Dan K. Moore to lift a controversial ban on Communist speakers at state colleges and universities.
Futures traders focused their attention yesterday on two sets of statistics covering two widely different commodities -- cocoa beans and pork bellies.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 16 -- The Annapolis City Council, in the face of heavy opposition, adopted last night an ordinance amending the city's zoning regulations to allow construction of motels of 100 or more rooms along the waterfront.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Charles Cogen, president of the American Federation of Teachers, urged the Government today to set nationwide educational standards as the price for Federal aid to the schools.

A 35-year-old truck driver began a legal suit yesterday against Consolidated Edison and two other utilities for damages allegedly sustained when a candle set fire to his apartment during the blackout last week.

Business leaders cautioned the Government yesterday against assuming that the program of voluntary restraint in overseas investments could provide more than a shortterm solution to the nation's payments problems.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The decline in steel output was overwhelmed by the continuing boom elsewhere in the economy, and industrial production rose in October, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

HOUSTON, Nov. 16 -- Back in the late twenties, when jet engines were still unheard of, Ray Keech, an American in an American-built car, streaked down the hard-packed sands of Daytona Beach, Fla., at a fraction better than 220 miles an hour.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 16 -- The United States and Nationalist China ascribed lack of frankness and wishful thinking today to the sponsors of Communist China's admission to the United Nations.
PARIS, Nov. 16 -- Two plays by LeRoi Jones are receiving a bilingual production in Paris.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 16 -- A group of experts of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development proposed today a possible method of achieving additional international liquidity for the industrial and less-developed countries.

The battle over aluminum prices may be over but economists continue to be at odds in assessing the impact of the rollback on the business outlook. Their disagreement reveals a deep division of opinion about the present state of the economy and where it is headed.

CONCEPCION, Chile, Nov. 16 -- Angry leftist students spat on Senator Robert F. Kennedy and threw eggs, rocks and money at him when he visited Concepcion University tonight. He had been warned by student leaders to stay away.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that "there will be plenty more statements" from City Hall in what he made clear would be a course in municipal affairs for Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay.
DUSSELDORF, German, Nov. 16 (Reuters) -- The first step toward enabling private investors to share in the Krupp coal and steel group was taken here today.
The $375 million of certificates of the Federal National Mortgage Association were offered publicly yesterday, and by late afternoon were estimated to be slightly more than 70 per cent sold.

QUEENSTON, Ont., Nov. 16 Specialists at the Sir Adam Beck-Niagara Generating Station here were going over a relay designated Q29 today to find out why it had triggered the great northeastern power failure.
George V. McLaughlin, a member of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, said yesterday that Robert Moses had ignored his protest about an authority statement on the Lower Manhattan Expressway.
Yale and Princeton Universities will increase their tuition next September to $1,950 a year.
Robert E. Williams, 52 years old, was elected yesterday as president and chief operating officer of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company, one of the nation's major steel companies.

Formation of Aero Systems Associates, a new company that offers services in aeronautical systems analysis and development, has been announced by Albert W. Blackburn, former test pilot and head of the company.
GREENVILLE, Miss., Nov. 16. -- Winter weather is taking the place of the plantation owner as the major opponent of the first Negro farm strikers since the 1930's.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The debate over how to give the Atlantic alliance a greater voice in its nuclear defense took a new turn today. A member of the United States Atomic Energy Commission suggested that West Germany be equipped with longer-range weapons armed with American atomic warheads.

If Lady Marguerite had known her husband was the Scarlet Pimpernel during the French Revolution (and if she'd had a sense of humor) she might have written the sort of mystery Mary Stewart has given us. It would have been a ladylike version of the head-rolling, of course, and Mrs. Stewart, too, never descends to the sordid -- although an enjoyable tension underlies her beautifully plain prose.
Macy's suffered a defeat yesterday in its battle with one of the nation's largest distributors over the sale of liquor at cut-rate prices.
Julius A. Stratton, president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology since 1957, will be the next chairman of the board of the Ford Foundation, it was announced yesterday.
The United States Lines Company, one of the nation's largest steamship companies, has applied to the Maritime Administration for permission to diversify its activities.

THE advertised storm over the profile of Frank Sinatra dwindled into a harmless draft on the home screen last night. Theatrically, the program was something of a welcome innovation in entertainment specials, but journalistically it was a placebo of rewrite.
Alexander's Department Stores has named Benjamin Bartel to the new post of director of real estate and development, it was announced yesterday.

Events today: Donizetti's "L'Elisir d'Amore," 8 P.M. Metropolitan Opera; Arthur Gold and Robert Fizdale, duo pianists, 8:30, Philharmonic Hall; Czech Philharmonic Orchestra, Karel Ancerl, conductor, 8:30, Carnegie Hall.

Frank Wille, the New York State Superintendent of Banks, called yesterday for a "joint effort . . . on the part of the State Legislature, the State Banking Department, the Federal bank agencies and the Congress" to preserve the so-called dual banking system of parallel Federal and state bank regulation.
CARNEGIE HALL held a good deal of suspenseful tension last night. Eugene Ormandy conducted the Philadelphia Orchestra in Mahler's Tenth Symphony, an event not nearly so ordinary as it might sound.
The American Stock Exchange continued to decline yesterday in active trading.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 16 (AP) -- A scientific flight circling the world over both poles took off at 3:51 P.M. (1:51 P.M. Eastern Standard Time) today from Ezeiza International Airport for Christchurch, New Zealand, by way of the South Pole, it was more than 50 minutes behind schedule.

WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 16 -- Until today only one horse, Speedy Scot, the great trotting stallion now in stud service, had been listed at 1-9 on the morning line at Roosevelt Raceway. In 1963 and again last year, Speedy Scot was held in such high esteem by Jack E. Lee, the exacting line-maker here.

LONDON, Nov. 16 -- Charles Clore, the financier fighting to acquire one of Britain's biggest department store chains, said today that he would extend his offer to stockholders for another week. The date of expiration was today.

Opera lovers who treasure the sound of the natural voice have taken exception to the use of electronic amplification by the Metropolitan Opera National Company in two productions at the New York State Theater, "Cinderella" and "Susannah."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The N.A.A.C.P. Legal Defense and Educational Fund, Inc., released today a 59-page memorandum containing a scathing criticism of the Administration's efforts to desegregate schools under the Civil Rights Act of 1964.
A secondary issue of 150,000 shares of E.J. Korvette, Inc.'s common stock, at $28.75 a share, was quickly sold out yesterday. Shearson, Hammill Co., Inc., handled the sale.
LONDON, Nov. 16 -- Homes and factories were darkened in many parts of Britain today as authorities fought to conserve gas and electricity during a surprise November cold snap.

Max Loew, who closed his Viennese Lantern last March after dispensing schnitzel and schmaltz for 17 years, has moved his traditional red table cloths, his candles enclosed in minature lampposts, his musicians, his singers and his own elfin presence to the Penthouse Club at 30 Central Park South.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 16 -- A determination seems to be developing among the five active Common Market members not to let the French boycott delay internal tariff reduction or cause an increase in external tariffs.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Nov. 16 -- Four thousand black postal workers balked today at signing pledges of loyalty to the rebellious Government of Prime Minister Ian D. Smith.
The New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects will present its 1965 Award of Merit to David Rockefeller, president of the Chase Manhattan Bank.

BONN, Nov. 16 -- Mrs. Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit said today that Communist China had formulated a "grand design" for the leadership of Asia and Africa. She expressed doubt that admission to the United Nations now would "civilize" Peking.

MONTREAL, Nov. 16 -- Dense fog and sudden snow squalls that played havoc with radar equipment were blamed for a collision today that resulted in the sinking of the $8 million Canadian laker Lawrencecliffe Hall.
PARIS, Nov. 16 -- It costs $80 to make an official debut in France, and last night 111 hand-picked 18-year-olds got their money's worth in the first part of a package deal.
Uncertainty about the Rhodesian situation again restricted trading on the London Stock Exchange yesterday. Prices wound up with minor losses predominating.
The nation's leading chain and mail-order houses posted another sharp sales gain in October, a survey by The New York Times showed yesterday.
Constellation, the 12-Meter sloop hailed by yachtsmen as a "super" Constellation after her 1964 defense of the America's Cup, has been sold to a Dutch businessman-sportsman.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The Government and the aluminum industry announced agreement today on a plan for the disposal of the entire 1.4 million-ton aluminum surplus in the national stockpile over a period of years.
Theodore W. Kheel announced last night that he would not act as mediator in any future newspaper contract disputes.
The American Civil Liberties Union did an about-face yesterday and urged the mass communications media to accept controversial non-commercial advertising on a nondiscriminatory basis.

While protests continue across the nation against the United States involvement in the Vietnamese war, individuals and groups around the nation are sending food, blood and cheering messages for American troops in Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- In the midst of the most savage battle of the Vietnamese war, the State Department has confirmed that it rejected a year ago an offer to enter into peace talks with the North Vietnamese in Rangoon, Burma.
A $40,500 filly had just made the first start of her career, had won it by 2 1/2 lengths -- and had been claimed for $7,500.

LONDON, Nov. 16 -- After an absence of seven months during which it toured the United States, Canada and Italy, the larger of the two Royal Ballet companies returned to Covent Garden tonight to open its new season with Kenneth Macmillan's "Romeo and Juliet."
IN THE IADRANG RIVER VALLEY, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Nov. 17 -- Two United States battalions pulled out of this valley today after five days of heavy fighting near the Cambodian border.

FAYETTVILLE, Ark., Nov. 16 (AP) -- Sen. J.W. Fulbright said today that the Senate Foreign Relations Committee "very rarely" made public the testimony delivered by Administration witnesses in executive session.
NEW DELHI, Nov. 16 -- In Parliament today, a legislator said India did not want American wheat because it "stinks."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The United States has joined with Britain in an offer to sell to Saudi Arabia up to $200 million in supersonic airplanes, antiaircraft missiles and radar equipment to improve Saudi air defenses.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Comdr. M. Scott Carpenter, a space and undersea adventurer, said today the nation and world stood to get much more immediate practical gains from underwater research than from space projects, "such as the assault on the moon, for example."

DANCE and literature are interesting although often restless bedfellows. On the new Dance Theater Workshop's "Mondays at 9" program at the East 74th Street Theater on Monday, Mary Anthony and her company presented two works based on Irish literature, and in both one was uncomfortably aware that little, if anything, had been added to the original.
District Attorney Frank S. Hegan's office has opened an investigation into advertisements purchased by corporations in a journal prepared for an Oct. 26 fund-raising dinner for the Democratic ticket.
The New York Mets will open their home season against the Braves, either Atlanta or Milwaukee, depending on the law courts, when the Shea Stadium baseball schedule starts on Friday, April 15, 1966.

A member of the city's Board of Higher Education criticized the Chancellor of the City University last night for issuing a controversial tuition plan "with out prior notice or consideration by our board."
ATHENS, Nov. 16 -- Rivalries among Greek bishops over vacancies in wealthy dioceses touched off a major clash between church and state in Athens today.
Eight aircraft jet engines are scheduled to be fired up this morning to drive a 121,000-kilowatt generating plant in Woodbridge, N.J.
CHICAGO, Nov. 16 (UPI) -- Michigan State's unbeaten football team, ranked No. 1 nationally, was named unanimously today to represent the Big Ten in the Rose Bowl game Jan. 1 and accepted the bid.
The Texaco Company announced yesterday that James V.C. Malcolmson, vice president in charge of the marine department, will retire on Dec. 31 after 22 years of service.

TORONTO, Nov. 15 (Canadian Press) -- Jim Elder, riding Pieces of Eight, gave Canada its first victory in six events at the international horse jumping show tonight at the Royal Agricultural Winter Fair.
Charles T. Ireland Jr., president of the Alleghany Corporation, was elected yesterday to the board of the International Telephone Telegraph Corporation.
Miss Janet M. Bond, a 21-year-old senior at Mount Holyoke College, has been elected Mercer County coroner by 54 write-in votes, most of them from friends and relatives.
" TASTE is nothing but the lively eye, the eye that can see deeply into things," Sandra Hochman said.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Nov. 16 -- A 25-year-old man, shouting "This in the name of my people!" spat at the face of Secretary of State Dean Rusk today.
LONDON, Nov. 16 -- The public debate about Kenneth Tynan's use of a four-letter word on television intruded into the House of Commons today for a brief, uproarious moment.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 16 (UPI) -- Clark Graebner became the second American in two weeks to beat Roy Emerson when he defeated the Australian, 6-3, 7-5, 3-6, 7-5, today in a third-round match of the New South Wales tennis tournament.
Dick Barnett of the New York Knickerbockers turned in the finest game of his National Basketball Association career last night in Madison Square Garden.

MIAMI, Nov. 16 -- Capt. Byron Voutsinas of the Yarmouth Castle said today that he was the last man to abandon the old cruise liner when she burned and sank early Saturday off Great Stirrup Cay in the Bahamas.
The Marine Engineers Beneficial Association said yesterday that it would renew its drive to represent licensed officers aboard the city's Staten Island ferryboats.

Last night's "Don Carlo" at the Metropolitan Opera had been scheduled with two major cast changes. But Jon Vickers came up ill, and was replaced by Richard Tucker. That left the new Bulgarian bass, Nicolai Ghiaurov, as the only real newcomer to the evening.
The appointment of H. Roberts Hansen as vice president of Lyras-Adams, Ltd., has been announced by Stephen C. Lyras, president of the real estate and construction company.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 16 -- Plans for a new home for the United Nations International School on a landscaped platform jutting into the East River will be offered for General Assembly approval within the next few days.
IN THE LADRANG RIVER VALLEY, Nov. 16 -- A company of the First Cavalry Division beat back five determined assaults by a North Vietnamese force estimated at battalion strength before dawn today.
With six of their next eight National Hockey League contests scheduled at home, the New York Rangers face the Chicago Black Hawks tonight at Madison Square Garden. The game time is 7:30 P.M.
The adoption division of the World Adoption International (WAIF) Fund will benefit from the Cinderella Ball, to be held on Dec. 9 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, John W. Gardner, has accepted recommendations by Federal and state conferees on what should be done to control pollution in Lake Erie and on the Mahoning River, which borders Ohio and Pennsylvania.
Baltimore sold yesterday $26.65 million of bonds to a syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and the First National Bank of Chicago.

From a safe, sentimental cause of little old ladies, landmark preservation has suddenly become a dangerously controversial subject, thanks to a law to back it up and thanks to the official designations currently in process by the city.
Commissioner Joe Foss moved back the American Football League's draft yesterday from Saturday to Nov 27.

The Landau-Unger film company announced yesterday nine features to be produced or co-produced next year at a general cost of more than $15 million. The company said more emphasis would be given to filmmaking and less to company-supervised distribution.
Is it a bird? Is it a plane? No, it's Bob Holiday as Superman.
The Toronto Stock Exchange is stiffening its attitude on full disclosure for its 1,100 listed companies.

Unanimous consent to government views is a phenomenon of the totalitarian, not of the free, society. It can only be obtained by the various forms of coercion that make up the substance of tyranny.

Alex Rose's "declaration of independence" and your editorial congratulation [Nov. 11] of the Liberal party on its decisive role in the mayoralty election strike a very sour note in Nassau County, where Liberal party endorsement played an equally decisive role in the reelection of William Cahn as District Attorney.

The current dispute over free tuition in the city colleges is apparently over but issues raised in the dispute remain. Their outcome could well determine the course of the City University. The basic issue involves the rift that has developed between the Board of Higher Education and some of its administrators, including the chancellor of the university.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 16 -- The New York experts closed up on the leaders during this afternoon's play in the International Team Trials here.

ROME, Nov. 16 -- Efforts to force a condemnation of Communism by the Ecumenical Council and to soften implied criticism of the stockpiling of atomic weapons for defense drew only lukewarm support today.
The May Department Stores Company, the St. Louis-based department-store chain, announced yesterday it had achieved record sales and earnings in the three and nine months ended Oct. 31.

ENERGETIC statisticians have been warming up for Saturday's Princeton-Dartmouth clash, The Game, at New Haven and the Columbia-Brown meeting at Baker Field. The two other league members have a day off, since the Cornell-Penn season finale is scheduled for Thanksgiving Day at Franklin Field.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 16 -- Dr. John A. Hannah, chairman of the United States Civil Rights Commission, said today that publicly supported universities must be in the forefront of the civil rights struggle to the end.
HOBOKEN, N.J., Nov. 16 -- A burst of firecrackers set off by his supporters celebrated the election tonight of Louis DePascale as Mayor of Hoboken.

A STUNNING play, one of the finest of our age, has come to town. "The Devils," which opened last night at the Broadway Theater, has an Elizabethan sweep and richness of texture. It is also as personal and poignant as the quest of man yesterday, today and tomorrow for an answer to the perplexities of the conflicts of his senses and his conscience.

James D. Landauer, chairman of James D. Landauer Associates, Inc., and immediate past president of the Real Estate Board of New York, will speak at the monthly dinner meeting of the Mortgage Bankers Association of New York at 6 P.M. this evening in the Biltmore Hotel.

IF Branch Rickey was not the most remarkable man to become a vital part of baseball for more than half a century, deep thought fails to produce even one valid challenger to his position of pre-eminence. He reshaped the game in so many ways because he was smarter and more imaginative than his contemporaries.

Irving J. Gitlin, an independent producer who formerly did documentary and public affairs programs for the National Broadcasting Company and Columbia Broadcasting System, has sold his first television entertainment show to C.B.S.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 16 (AP) -- An aide of Secretary Rusk said here today that the man who spat at Mr. Rusk in Montevideo did not hit him. Earlier a newsman had said that the man had spat in the Secretary's face.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (UPI) -- The judge called time out in the Communist party trial today to examine documents concerning the undercover career of the star prosecution witness.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Nov. 16 -- New, insistent rumors that rightest military coup d'etat was imminent led to an order today confining the armed forces to their barracks.

It is beguiling to think that the solution to the world food shortage lies, as Pope Paul VI suggested, in multiplying "bread so that it suffices for the tables of mankind." But experts at the Western Hemisphere Nutrition Conference made clear that more than bread is needed to alleviate the hunger that afflicts so many people around the world.

LONDON, Nov. 16 -- British strategy in Rhodesia, according to qualified sources, is to undermine the Rhodesian public's confidence in Prime Minister Ian D. Smith's rebel Government to the point where the loyal Governor, Sir Humphrey Gibbs, would have wide support for the calling of new elections under the 1961 Constitution.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Representative Adam Clayton Powell, Democrat of Manhattan, charged the Civil Service Commission today with denying promotion opportunities to Negro Federal employes.

E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., expects to earn about $8.60 a share or "possibly a bit more" in 1965 on sales of some $3 billion, Dr. Rollin F. Conway, assistant treasurer, forecast yesterday following a talk to the St. Louis Financial Analysts.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The Republican National Committee is $5 richer today, thanks to a Democrat.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 16 (UPI) -- Doctors disclosed today that former President Dwight D. Eisenhower had not been in an oxygen tent for almost three days, and had resumed some work he had started before suffering two mild heart attacks last week.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 16 -- Premier Drabdel Rahman Bazzaz of Iraq said today that "the have Socialism we adopted is not stagnant ideology nor blind adherence to theories imported from abroad."
CHERRY HILL, N.J. Nov. 16 (AP) -- Jorge Velasquez of Panama tied an American record today when he won with six straight mounts and finished third in the last race on the card.
Businessmen wondered yesterday whether copper would be next.

A COUPLE of years ago a heavily hunted Western state reported what seemed to be an unusually large number of fatal hunting accidents, a figure that went against the general trend of a decline in such accidents.
The World's Fair, after weeks of "protracted negotiations," yielded yesterday to the Chase Manhattan Bank and agreed to pay all additional $4 million to note holders.

SOUTH HAMILTON, Mass., Nov. 16 -- Mr. and Mrs. F. Burnham Chapman have announced the engagement of Mr. Chapman's daughter, Miss Helen Chapman, to Roland Gustav Droitsch. He is the son of Mrs. Gustav Droitsch of Jackson Heights, Queens New York, and the late Mr. Droitsch of Berlin.

An alleged swindle in the sale of airline tickets that was said to have cost the leading domestic carriers at least $1.75 million in the last year was disclosed yesterday in United States District Court in Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Princess Margaret's press aide assumed a hounded expression today as someone asked him at the British Embassy: "Why Katzenbach?"

CONCEPCION, Nov. 16 -- Senator Kennedy received a wildly enthusiastic reception in this industrial and port city before the near-violent confrontation with pro-Communist students at Concepcion University tonight.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 16 -- Lo, and it was written, that a crusader would emerge from the desert to smite the haughty Saracen, repay a debt of honor to the kingdom, and scoop up a cool million or two for himself.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Camp Kilmer, the Job Corps's Eastern showcase, has "flagrant deficiencies," in the opinion of a group of university consultants on the project.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 16 -- The president of the Central Conference of American Rabbis deplored tonight the "consensus curtain" that he said was descending in this country over the right of people to speak out on the Government's Vietnam policy.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- President Johnson promised tonight to ask the next session of Congress for legislation aimed at preventing "injustice to Negroes at the hands of all-white juries."

PARIS, Nov. 16 -- Senator Mike Mansfield's two-day stay here over the weekend has been welcomed by French Government officials as a positive step toward the resumption of a much-needed dialogue between Washington and Paris.

The 21,329-ton Greek passenger liner Queen Frederica, operated on the Mediterranean route by National Hellenic American Line, has been sold by Home Lines, Inc., to another Greek shipping company.

TUCSON, Ariz., Nov. 16 (UPI) -- Three young suspects were arraigned today in one of three slayings that allegedly were the outgrowth of a teenage "sex and drinking club."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The Justice Department's Internal Security Division, created to enforce the antisubversive legislation of the McCarthy era, found itself with only one Internal Security Act case and a bleak future today.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 16 (AP) -- The whipping of Arkansas convicts is cruel and unusual punishment unless it is "surrounded by appropriate safeguards," United States District Judge J. Smith Henley has ruled.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Organized labor will take the ticklish step this week of bidding formal farewell to James B. Carey, the turbulent union leader who resigned earlier this year as president of the International Union of Electrical Workers after disclosures of election abuses.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 16 -- Fouad Ammoun, a Lebanese jurist who also served as his country's delegate to the United Nations and as Foreign Minister, was elected today to the International Court of Justice.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 (UPI) -- United Air Lines was under court order today to produce data on its 727 jet aircraft in connection with a $1 million damage suit filed against United and Boeing, the maker of the aircraft.

LONDON, Nov. 16 -- Kempton Bunton was found guilty today of having stolen the frame around the celebrated Goya painting of the Duke of Wellington. But he was acquitted of having stolen the portrait itself.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (UPI) -- The Federal Trade Commission accused the Sperry Hutchinson Company today of having illegally pressured store owners to keep them from giving away free S. H. Green Stamps.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 17 -- Dr. Barnaby C. Keeney, president of Brown University, interrupted a talk to a freshman convocation today to charge that students had attempted "to undermine the administration" by circulating a petition in support of the dean of student affairs, who had resigned.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Anonymous anti-Communist phone calls with targets ranging from President Johnson to the Parent-Teachers Association will come under the scrutiny of a Senate subcommittee tomorrow and Friday.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Nov. 17 -- Two State Representatives, who have been investigating charges of vote-buying in the General Assembly, were found in contempt of court today in a dispute over the contents of tape recordings.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 17 -- The Special Political Committee of the General Assembly voted today to call for greater efforts to enable Arab refugees to return to their former homes in Israel or be paid compensation.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The Government reported today a sharp deterioration in the United States balance of international payments in the third quarter of this year.
LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 17 -- Duane Pope told today of a desperate hope, held until the fatal moment, that someone would prevent him from committing a crime he felt powerless to avoid.
MOUNT TURQUINO, Cuba, Nov. 15 -- All Saturday afternoon clouds had covered this mountain, making the 1,000 persons camped there damp and chilly.

Two weeks before he took the oath of office as Mayor on Dec. 31, 1953, Robert F. Wagner stepped into the stalled contract negotiations between the Transit Authority and the Transport Workers Union. Although he was not yet Mayor, Mr. Wagner's proposals headed off a threatened transit strike.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) The State Department expressed today full confidence in the reliability and integrity of Abba P. Schwartz, administrator of the department's Bureau of Security and Consular Affairs.

Some 600 residents of Portage, Ind., were given electronic telephone switching service yesterday in a field test of such equipment by the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation. The transfer from the conventional electro-mechanical equipment was accomplished by Herbert F. Lello, executive vice president-manufacturing, at ceremonies in the Indiana community.

AUGUSTA, Nov. 17 -- A week after his heart attack, former President Dwight Eisenhower was allowed to sit up in a hospital chair today. His physicians considered the possibility of his transfer Saturday by train to Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington.

None of the major protagonists emerges with credit from the General Assembly's 1965 debate on the question of admitting Communist China to the United Nations. No one who hopes for the steady development of universal U.N. machinery for keeping the peace in an explosive world can take comfort from the course of the debate or its outcome.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Senator Eugene J. McCarthy advanced some proposals here today for helping the Dominican Republic overcome economic stagnation and achieve political stability.

Senator Robert F. Kennedy has urged Orin Lehman, who unsuccessfully sought the Democratic nomination for Controller, to seek the Congressional seat that will be vacated by Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay.

MOSCOW, Nov. 17 -- The Soviet Union has informed India that President Mohammad Ayub Khan of Pakistan is now "ready and willing" to meet Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri on Soviet territory to discuss the Kashmir dispute.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Told that "the dimensions of the problems demand vaulting imaginations," a White House conference on civil rights opened today with a proposal for a $100 billion "freedom budget" for eradicating slums.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The Food and Drug Administration acknowledged today that it had requested the manufacturers of oral contraceptives about a month ago to circulate to doctors and pharmacists "a warning about visual hazards" of the drugs.

Events today: Puccini's "Manon Lescaut," 8 P.M., Metropolitan Opera; Rossini's "Cinderella," Metropolitan Opera, National Company, 8:15, New York State Theater, Lincoln Center; New York Philharmonic, 8:30, Philharmonic Hall.

Having proved to his own satisfaction and despite convincing evidence to the contrary that New York City is in pretty good shape financially, Mayor Wagner has now passed on to Lesson No. 2 in the municipal primer he is offering to Mayor-elect Lindsay.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Nov. 17 -- Foreign Minister Elias Tsirimokos of Greece arrived today to confer with President Makarios on a joint policy for Cyprus.

Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested a 24-year-old pacifist affiliated with the Catholic Worker Movement yesterday morning on a charge of failing for two years to let his draft board know his whereabouts.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- A New York lawyer testified today that he had voluntered to register the Communist party with the Government upon the request of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- President Johnson ordered the Civil Rights Commission today to study the problem of racial discrimination in education and make the facts available to the public "as rapidly as possible."
MOSCOW, Nov. 17 (Reuters) -- The Soviet Union has new small intercontinental rockets that can be launched from mobile ramps that reconnaissance satellites cannot find, it was reported here today.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Nov. 17 -- A youth died on a washroom floor of Mount Vernon Hospital last night after receiving an illicit injection of heroin from a friend, the police reported today.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 17 In the hours before dawn, when Muhammed Ali runs, Las Vegas still has her night face on: Worlds spin in garish neon, mystical animals pulsate in yellow and red and green, great washes of color flow and blink and jerk against the black desert sky.

WURTSBORO, N.Y., Nov. 17 -- It was a good Southern Zone deer season opening at the week's beginning. The first day was clear, crisp and cold, and uncounted thousands of red-clad hunters crunched through the Catskill Mountain woods looking for bucks or does -- if they had doe permits.
Secrets of ancient Roman glassmakers and the earliest origins of long-distance commerce are being unraveled through sophisticated chemical and phycisal techniques recently put to use in archeology.
" Mikado" Saturday and "Pinafore" Sunday at Jan Hus Playhouse. LE 5-6310.

A radical reorganization of baseball's top administrative structure accompanies the installation of its new commissioner, but the intent behind the innovations is to restore the commissionership itself to its original concept.

Union representation elections among taxicab drivers and maintenance personnel employed by 42 companies in the city were ordered yesterday by Samuel M. Kaynard, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Nov. 17 -- To the dismay of local antipoverty officials, a private group of volunteers working among the migrant and seasonal farm workers here, has filed a request for $344,000 in Federal antipoverty aid.

" IT makes no sense," wailed Jim Finks, the general manager of the Minnesota Vikings, when he first heard the stunning news that Norm Van Brocklin, the coach of the hotshots from the frozen north, had impetuously quit his post.

The McCrory Corporation has withdrawn its two-month-old offer of a "combination" or merger with S. Klein Department Stores, Inc., and will now make a tender offer to acquire a majority or more of Klein's common stock.

Indian Sunlite flashed through the gloom at Aqueduct yesterday and won the $30,000 Demoiselle Stakes by a neck. The winner is owned by a former Secretary of the Treasury, George Humphrey. The favored Lady Pitt was second by a margin of 2 3/4 lengths over Prides Profile.

Mack Haut, a 70-year-old dress manufacturer who lives in Greenwich, Conn., was found guilty yesterday in Federal District Court, Brooklyn, of having rigged invoices for apparel imported from Hong Kong.
Four Reform Democratic district leaders in Manhattan charged yesterday that the city's election procedures were "a disgrace'" and should be revised extensively.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The United States Clerics Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit has granted a new trial to a group of Episcopal clergymen, including the Rev. Robert Pierson, son-in-law of Governor Rockefeller of New York, in their suit for damages on grounds of false arrest.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay was reported tonight to have decided on the two top appointments for his New York City administration.
The Continental Oil Company announced the election yesterday of William A. Hewitt to the board. Mr. Hewitt is chairman of Deere Co.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Joseph C. Swidler, the chairman of the Federal Power Commission, believes that special steps will have to be taken to assure New York City of unfailing electric service because the consequences of a power cutoff there are so much more serious than in smaller cities.

ROME, Nov. 17 -- The Roman Catholic world hierarchy completed semifinal action today on definitions of the church positions on most of the major issues of the times -- war and peace, marriage and the family, atheism, poverty, and economic, social, political and cultural life.

American Telephone and Telegraph, the nation's most widely held company, gave its shareholders and the whole stock market a big lift yesterday by raising its quarterly dividend to 55 cents a share from 50 cents.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 17 -- Communist China was barred again today from admission to the United Nations. Diplomats suggested that the rejection amounted to a hollow victory for the United States, which had led the opposition to Peking's entry.
A 54-year Queens man who contends he watched his wife burn to death on the cruise liner Yarmouth Castle last Saturday sued the steamship owners yesterday for $2,250,000.

With the possible exception of Michael J. Quill, New Yorkers generally will endorse Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay's declaration that a subway strike "cannot be permitted." But it becomes increasingly clear that a fair and orderly settlement, free of strike jitters, will be impossible to achieve unless Mr. Lindsay shares some of the responsibility for a new agreement with Mayor Wagner and the Transit Authority.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 17 (AP) -- The retirement of Speedy Scot, Dartmouth and Race Time was announced today by Frederick Van Lennep, the owner of the Castleton Farm.
A SILENT theater. A bare, empty stage. A man alone, dressed in white, with the chalky face of a clown. Marcel Marceau is back in New York. Last night he opened a four-week season at the City Center.
The National Institute of Social Sciences will mark the centennial of its parent organization, the American Social Science Associations at a dinner to be held Dec. 2 in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom.
The Magazine Publishers Association invited a couple of Trojan horses behind its walls yesterday to discuss a subject of great interest to all media men -- color in advertising.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Despite the strains caused by the war in Vietnam, the United States and the Soviet Union are moving toward negotiations for a new cultural exchange agreement.

Robert Price was named by Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay yesterday to serve as a Deputy Mayor. In a typical display of individualism, Mr. Price said he thought the $37,500 salary that goes with the post was too high for him.

JERSEY CITY, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The last two of five indictments were dismissed today against former members of the Jersey City Board of Education and contractors who had been accused of conspiracy involving school repairs.

Defense lawyers for Richard Robles succeeded yesterday in placing into evidence the alleged confession of George Whitmore Jr., the man first indicted and later absolved of the slaying of Janice Wylie and Emily Hoffert.
IN the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

SOUTH SALEM, N.Y., Nov. 18 -- "We're not officially open until 8 o'clock." Ernest Warga, the postmaster, was saying, "but every morning he'd be here at 7:30 in his Renault Dauphine to pick up the mail.

Jose Torres received a medical suspension from the State Athletic Commission yesterday. This means, in effect, that Torres will not be forced to defend his world light-heavyweight boxing championship until he is well enough to do so.

New York University announced last night a gift of $1.5 million to its College of Dentistry from a man who was born in the back of his father's candy store on the Lower East Side, not far from a new building that will bear his name.
ROME, Nov. 18 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of Pope Paul's speech today at the public session of the Ecumenical Council, as translated by the Council press office:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- President Johnson announced today the appointment of Dr. Barnaby C. Keeney, president of Brown University, as chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities and of S. Dillon Ripley, secretary of the Smithsonian Institution, as chairman of the Federal Council on the Arts and Humanities.
Cocoa traders went through a hectic session yesterday with prices on the upside. The volume -- 2,911 contracts -- was called the busiest day in history by traders.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Nov. 18 -- Prime Minister Ian D. Smith announced today that he had set up an organization to counter economic sanctions against Rhodesia.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Intercity truck tonnage in the latest week ended Nov. 13 was considerably above the volume in the corresponding week of 1964. Rail freight carloadings during the same period were slightly below the comparable 1964 week.
NO one, at least so far, eats popcorn at the ballet. Or if some people do they are pretty quiet about it. But for the rest, anything goes, especially if it rustles.
A total of $1,685,011 was realized in the sale of 74 parcels at yesterday's auction of city-owned property by the Department of Real Estate at the Statler-Hilton Hotel.

Two men have shaped the baseball thinking of Wesley Noreen Westrum Leo Durocher and Casey Stengel. But Westrum is as quietly dissimilar as any man can be from tile flamboyant, tough Durocher or the theatrical Stengel, whom he succeeded yesterday as manager of the New York Mets.
CHICAGO, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The second triple dead heat in Illinois thoroughbred racing history resulted today in the sixth race at Sportsman's Park.
The recent slowdown in the aerospace industry, now reversed with the intensification of the war in Vietnam, is indicated in the latest earnings results of two leaders in the field.

A visit by Lynda Bird Johnson, the President's elder daughter, added to the excitement last night at the opening of the Harkness House for Ballet Arts. Her visit had been a closely guarded secret until late afternoon.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 18 -- A United States Army battalion was ambushed and mauled yesterday by several hundred North Vietnamese regulars in the ladrang River valley, about 200 miles north of Saigon.
The premature winds of winter whipped into the city yesterday, breaking branches, power lines and plate-glass windows and messing elegant hairdos.

LAST night at Philharmonic Hall started out as Dvorak night, with George Szell conducting the New York Philharmonic. But by the time the Soviet cellist, Mstislav Rostropovich, got through playing the B minor Cello Concerto, there was no question but that it was Rostropovich night.
NEW HAVEN, Nov. 18 -- The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Hartford announced today that it would use its multimillion-dollar purchasing power to help end discrimination in employment.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 18 -- Dr. Percy Yutar Deputy Attorney General of the Transvaal, charged here today that reports of brutality in South African prisons given to newspapers by a head warder were lies.
PARIS, France, Nov. 18 -- Hanoi officials declared today that North Vietnam offer transmitted to the United States by France last May could "not be resolved as a valid offer of negotiation."
WARSAW, Nov. 15 -- A new opera house will be inaugurated here Saturday. All Poland has been waiting for the day for 15 years.

Howard Nemerov's "Journal" may be the first non book put out by a respected novelist, poet, and critic. It is a cautious diary written with an eye to publication; it is sketches of novels unwritten (the easiest way to write without writing), and it is dull dreams described and then analyzed, with a few poems included at the end of the book.
Alfred Deller, the English countertenor, was the soloist with the Esterhazy Orchestra led by David Blum last night at Town Hall, and this should have been an occasion of rare, musical pleasure.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 18 -- Government cross-examination failed today to crack Duene Pope's insistence that there had been no motive or plan for the triple slaying and bank robbery in Big Springs, Neb., last June.
Mayor Wagner made public yesterday the text of the following letter he had sent to Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The United States will attempt to mediate the century-old dispute between Britain and Guatemala ever their rival claims to sovereignity over British Honduras, the State Department announced today.

Negotiations for the proposed merger of the Puritan Fashions Corporation and the Colonial Corporation of America, which would have created a $200-million-a-year apparel business, were abruptly terminated yesterday by both parties.

The annual meeting of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association was held at the Hotel Delmonico yesterday. Mrs. M. Stuart Roesler of Stanwich, president, presided and told the delegates of the gains and troubles of the association during the past year.

TORONTO, Nov. 18 (Canadian Press) Jim Elder, Canada's team captain, rode Pieces of Eight to victory tonight in the Maple Leaf Stakes in the international horse show at the Royal Agricultural Winter Fair.

DENVER, Nov. 18 -- Government actions such as "telling aluminum producers what prices are justified" are stifling constructive criticism of Government policies to a "dangerous" extent, George Champion, chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, asserted here tonight.

A RESTAURANT of more than passing interest has opened in New York this fall: the Clos Normand at 42 East 52d Street. It is another of those splendiferous dining palaces with grace and elegance that come from lofty ceilings, bright new murals and subdued lighting. This time the murals are principally in shades of green and red with harbor views of Trouville, Normandy towns and the like.
Public speculation over the recent death of Dorothy Kilgallen, newspaper columnist and television personality, caused the preparation of a new bill for the City Council yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission recommended to day a review of physical standards for truck and bus drivers as a result of an accident in which Representative T. Ashton Thompson, Democrat of Louisiana, was killed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The Commerce Department estimated today that retail sales totaled $5.6 billion in the week ended Nov. 13. Sales were virtually unchanged from the preceding week but were 11 per cent higher than the corresponding 1964 week.
C.L. Sulzberger's Nov. 12 column, relating to President de Gaulle's attitude toward NATO, points to a basic question.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Nov 18 -- The school board of this racially disturbed city proffered an olive branch to integrationists today, but Negro leaders said it looked like camouflaged barbed wire to them.
LAKEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 18 -- Joseph DeCausey walked to the end of the living room of his new house and pointed down the hallway with the handle of a claw hammer.
A portrait of John F. Kennedy as a parent is about to be added to the gallery of writings by former associates of the late President.
The Board of Education announced plans yesterday for a series of citywide experimental centers to improve instruction in areas ranging from anthropology to music.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 18 -- In the 1966 world championships in St. Vincent's, Italy, North America will be represented by Ira Rubin and Philip Feldesman of New York, Lew Mathe and Robert Hamman of Los Angeles and Eric Murray and Sam Kehela of Toronto.

SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 18 -- The death toll in the fiery crash a week ago of a United Air Lines 727 jet rose to 42 today. T.W. Fulmor, 61 years old, of Anaconda, Mont., died in Salt Lake Hospital of burns and other injuries.
The General Education Board, founded in 1902 by the late John D. Rockefeller, has spent itself out of existance.
CHERRY HILL, N.J., Nov. 18 -- With most of the top 2-year-olds now in training listed to compete, the Garden State Stakes will have its 13th running on Saturday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- An almost cloudless picture of current business activity was presented today with the release of six major statistical reports on the economy by two Government agencies.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- A conversation between a representative of North Vietnam and French officials last May about arranging peace talks with the United States occurred several hours after the end of a five-day pause in American air attacks on North Vietnam, a State Department spokesman said today.

WHILE on a posh African safari a few years ago, I mentioned to Terry Mathews, one of the white hunters, that having a portable deep freezer and two refrigerators with us was was perhaps a bit too much.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 -- David L. Lawrence, former Governor of Pennsylvania and now a special assistant to President Johnson, appealed to the real estate industry today to help eliminate racial discrimination in housing.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange managed to advance slightly yesterday in listless trading.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- National economic welfare and national security in time of crisis demand a strong and prosperous merchant marine, Vice President Humphrey said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Corporations can withhold significant news from the public "during brief periods when dictated by good business reasons" without running afoul of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Commissioner Hamer H. Budge said today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- A powerful segment of the labor movement authorized a major organizational campaign among the nation's 15 million "working poor" today.

LONDON, Nov. 18 -- The National Coal Board announced today that it would close 150 uneconomical mines over the next three years. The closing will affect 120,000 workers in Scotland, South Wales and Northeast England, almost a third of Britain's miners.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 18 -- Former President Eisenhower's recovery from his heart attack continued without complications today and attending physicians plan his removal by train to Walter Reed Army Hospital in Washington over the weekend for further convalescence.

Toby Saks, the 23-year-old cellist who recently won the Tchaikovsky competition in Moscow, will make her first orchestral appearance in New York on Dec. 12, as soloist with the Youth Symphony Orchestra of New York.
ROME, Nov. 18 -- Pope Paul VI announced today initiation of the long process to bring beatification, and probably sainthood, to his two immediate predecessors, John XXIII and Pius XII.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The Johnson Administration is beginning to worry about the political consequences of Vietnam. The polls support the President's conduct of the war, but as the casualties mount the reports from the Democratic Congressmen in their home districts are beginning to reflect a rising opposition.
A realignment of top executives of Dan River Mills, Inc., the textiles concern, was announced yesterday. Also announced was an increase in the quarterly dividend and a 5 per cent stock payout.

MONTREAL, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Larry Jeffrey scored his first goal for Toronto midway in the third period, snapping a tie and leading the Maple Leafs to a 3-1 victory over the Montreal Canadiens tonight in a National Hockey League game.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 18 -- Oakland officials today requested the help of National Guardsmen and Federal marshals for protection of marchers and onlookers during an anti-Vietnam war parade to be held Saturday.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and trendy is given every Friday in this page. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost of dining in any particular establishment.
Wes Westrum was named manager of the New York Mets yesterday with the unanimous approval of the team's board of directors and the blessing of the only other manager the Mets have had, Casey Stengel.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The largest United States casualty total for a single week of fighting in Vietnam was reported today by the Defense Department -- 108 killed in the week that ended last Monday night.

TOKYO, Nov. 18 -- A lifelong acquaintance with Japanese psychology appears to have paid off for Edwin O. Reischauer, the scholarly United States Ambassador in Tokyo, in his efforts to gain a better hearing in Japan for the American position in the Vietnamese war.

The controversy in West Germany over the Oder-Neisse border with Poland indicates a faint beginning toward realism on a critical issue involving the future of Europe as a whole.
The proposed Lower Manhattan Expressway, which has been on the drawing boards as years, survived its first major legal test yesterday.
Uncertainty concerning the site of the 1966 $100,000 Thunderbird golf tournament may result in the scheduling of two major tournaments for the metropolitan district next summer instead of one.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 18 -- The most serious contender for boxing's top title is a slightly overweight, partly blind 30-year-old who earned $18,500 for his only professional fight, which he lost in a one-round knockout.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Nov. 18 (AP) -- Zoilo Versalles, who led the Minnesota Twins to the pennant, was named the American League's most valuable player today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- A panel of delegates to the White House Conference on Civil Rights made an "urgent" recommendation to President Johnson tonight that he take immediate steps to protect "the lives and safety of Negroes and civil rights workers in the Deep South."

Since the city is so heavily in debt I assume that the new incoming administration will welcome every suggestion on how to cut expenses and increase tax returns.
Stocks continued to ease on the American Stock Exchange yesterday for the fourth consecutive session with mostly fractional losses.
The first book to be published jointly by official organizations of the Protestant, Eastern Orthodox and Roman Catholic churches came off the presses yesterday.

ROME, Nov. 18 -- Among the 21 Council experts and superiors of religious orders selected by Pope Paul VI to concelebrate mass with him today in St. Peter's Basilica were two Jesuits who had suffered sanctions at the instigation of the Holy Office.
HOLLYWOOD, Nov. 18 -- Auto racing has become a hot subject for Hollywood filmmakers. At least four major movies on the sport are scheduled for release during the coming year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Representative Edward A. Garmatz, acting chairman of the House Committee on Merchant Marine, has written a letter to Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara criticizing the department's lack of foresight in meeting its Vietnam logistics problems.

ROME, Nov. 18 -- There are theologians here for the Ecumenical Council who believe that the decree on divine revelation proclaimed today by Pope Paul VI is the most important document to come out of the synod.

With a bright green butterfly coming to rest on a stark white page, a manufacturer of interlinings for the fashion trade hopes to increase its share of the home sawing market.

Joe H. Wray has been named manager of the Reynolds Aluminum Supply Company's "Everwear" buildings division, with headquarters in Louisville, Ky. Mr. Wray, who has been West Coast building products sales manager for the Reynolds Metals Company, will be succeeded in that post by Clark H. Turner.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 -- Leaders of the Students for a Democratic Society have abandoned a proposed antidraft program in the face of opposition to it in their local chapters, Paul Booth, the national secretary, said in the headquarters here today.

Licia Albanese sang the title role in Puccini's "Manon Lescaut" at the Metropolitan Opera last night, for the first time this season. She made a fine appearance, but much of her singing was more to be inferred than actually heard.

Net debit balances carried by New York Stock Exchange member firms for their customers climbed $80 million last month to reach $5,096,000,000. These figures show the borrowings of individual investors on margin.

PARIS, Nov. 18 -- Jean Chauvel, former French Ambassador in London, will join a French technical delegation traveling to Peking next month to open an industrial exhibit, it was announced today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Johnson Administration officials are learning that a soft answer compoundeth wrath -- if the answer is given by the wrong person.
Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay plans Michael J. Quill willing -- to have celebrations in each of the five boroughs Jan. 1, so the public can meet him on his inauguration day.
The British pound gained moderately in light trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday.

The elevator leaving the first floor for the fifth-floor banquet room at the Harmonie Club yesterday started slowly. It was loaded with persons to be seated on the dais. Somewhere between the fourth and fifth floor, it came to a jerking halt.
The 23-year-old wife of Huntington Hartford, heir to the A. fortune and patron of the arts, has filed a suit for separation in State Supreme Court, Mr. Hartford's lawyer said last night.

William F. Butler, vice president and chief economist of the Chase Manhattan Bank, added a conservative, cautionary voice yesterday to the developing economic dialogue on the broad question of the course of the United States economy.

PARRIS ISLAND, S.C., Nov. 18 ( UPI) -- A 20-year-old Marine recruit told a court-martial today that his boot-camp drill instructor had punched him in the stomach four or five times for dropping out of a long run.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Senator Russell B. Long of Louisiana said toady that he would resist any effort to force him to yield his position as assistant Democratic leader when he becomes chairman of the Senate Finance Committee next January.
John W. Gardner, the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, opposed yesterday any attempt to break up the department into separate agencies.
LONDON, Nov. 18 -- Britain seen a United Nations oil embargo against Rhodesia as a way of meeting African nations' demand for stronger action against the rebellious colony without the use of force.
The stock market, which had been hesitating all week, finally picked a direction in which to move yesterday -- down.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Nov. 18 -- The possibility of a sharp clash between the New York State Banking Department and the state's $33 billion mutual savings bank industry loomed today at the opening session here of the 72d annual convention of the Savings Banks Association of New York State.

PAULINE TRIGERE left her showrooms on Seventh Avenue yesterday and dashed over to the east side of town, headquarters for the lingerie industry. With a black and white striped skunk capelet over a black wool dress, she introduced her first lingerie collection for Formfit.
JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 18 -- One afternoon this week, a Mississippi highway patrolman stopped a car in which a white civil rights lawyer and a Negro were riding.
